DOC.HEAD: Music Tapes Being Sent to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: The spoken and sung messages of some of Nashville's top recording artists will be sent to American troops in Saudi Arabia within the next month, record company officials announced Wednesday. Ten national record companies will ship up to 150,000 cassettes of country and gospel music to the Middle East through the newly launched ``Operation Desert Song'' project, said Ken Harding of New Haven Records. The effort appears to be the largest of its kind in the country, said Harding, who helped spearhead the project. Two similar but smaller projects were recently launched in Los Angeles, he added. Already, record companies have donated 120,000 tapes to the project and another 30,000 are expected by the end of November. he tapes will be sent to the Defense Department for distribution. Organizers did not specifically name performers to be featured on the music tapes. Instead, they said the cassettes would represent every recording artist signed to a major record label in Nashville. That would include performers such as Kenny Rogers, Dolly Parton, Willie Nelson, George Strait, Hank Williams Jr., Clint Black, Randy Travis, Reba McEntire, the Judds, Garth Brooks, Kathy Mattea, the Kentucky HeadHunters, Ricky Van Shelton, Alabama, Waylon Jennings, Amy Grant, Take 6 and Sandi Patti. Also to be sent are 500 copies of a videotape with messages from country and gospel music singers. Some of the messages: From McEntire, ``Hurry up and come home 'cause we miss you. Thanks for keeping us safe.'' From Tammy Wynette, ``Hang in there until November. I promise I'm coming over to sing to all of you.'' From Lee Greenwood, ``I believe in what you are doing and all Americans support you.'' Gov. Ned McWherter also appeared on the tape, saying he hoped troops were back home ``in time to go squirrel hunting, duck hunting and for Christmas.'' Maj. Gen. Carl Wallace, head of the Tennessee National Guard, told a news conference announcing the project that the tapes would boost U.S. morale in the Persian Gulf. ``Next to being there, it's one of the best things that can be done,'' Wallace said.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan's Mapping of Venus to Resume by Nov. 8
DOC.TEXT: Magellan's mapping of Venus will resume next week after engineers repair a computer programming glitch that makes the spacecraft's solar power panels wobble, NASA says. Magellan on Friday suspended its $744 million effort to make pictures and maps because of the solar panel problem and because its communications with Earth are being hindered by the sun, which is lined up between Venus and Earth. NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory expects to fix the computer software so Magellan can resume taking radar pictures by Nov. 7 or 8, Magellan experiment representative Steve Wall said Wednesday. The twin solar panels are essential for recharging Magellan's batteries, but the wobbling hasn't hurt their ability to gather solar energy. The craft was launched from a space shuttle in May 1989 and arrived at Venus on Aug. 10. It has made pictures of volcanoes, huge solidified lava flows, faults, craters and 600-mile-wide, mile-high bulges on Venus.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 Protest Prayer Meeting Called To Fight Hell on 'Frisco Bay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs, `Outside, the...,' to UPDATE with demonstration breaking up. SUBS 13th graf pvs, `DeLight - who...,' to DELETE reference to Brooks Hall, which is the same as the auditorium where prayer warriors met. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `Lea, who...
DOC.TEXT: A screaming crowd of nearly 1,000 pro-homosexual activists mobbed the entrance of an auditorium to protest a Halloween night Christian crusade aiming exorcise the city of evil spirits. They blocked buses bringing the faithful to the meeting, which they contend is a thinly veiled attack on homosexuality. ``We're queer, we're here; get used to it,'' they chanted. ``Born again bigots, go away; racist, sexist, anti-gay.'' The focus of their wrath was a ``Prayer Breakthrough'' for at least 5,000, organized by Texas evangelist Larry Lea and San Jose minister Dick Bernal. They say the City by the Bay is plagued by immoral homosexuals, crime, witchcraft and general sin. ``We're praying to God for people, all people, and against the powers of darkness,'' Bernal said earlier. ``The ultimate goal is to save the fallen angels of the city from Satan, from evil immorality.'' Despite the protest, the meeting started on time with the faithful jumping up and down and singing. Evangelicals from some 250 northern California churches needed police to pull them bodily through the crowd to the Civic Center Auditorium. Once inside the doors, they were roughly grabbed by badge-wearing monitors and sentries. They bags were searched. Some stood for a pat-down search. ``You come in here for a Christian activity and they search you like a thief,'' said one of the revivalists. ``Jesus is Lord,' reminded a woman next to him, shaking a fist at the crowd through the glass doors. Outside, the screaming was at a ear-splitting level. The protesters lifted a 12-foot-high paper penis in the form of a cross in front of barricades guarded by dozens of visored police. Police eventually separated the two groups, keeping the demonstrators across the street. The demonstration started an hour before the ``prayer warriors'' began their program and broke up about an hour after it started. Many of the protesters headed for the predominantly gay Castro district, where thousands usually gather on Halloween. A war of words raged all day in this city that takes advantage of Halloween to flaunt it non-conformity. ``They'll end up in the hell they deserve with their narrow-minded views,'' said Sister Missionary DeLight, founder of the 11-year-old Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence, said of the evangelists. ``I think it's scary that they think we're a real threat to society.'' DeLight - who is a man - was dressed in a nun's habit and curled fairy shoes and held a wand during a pagan ceremony Tuesday across from the hall where the prayer warriors were to meet. Lea, who distributes ``prayer army dog tags'' and has donned military fatigues in previous crusades, said Halloween was selected to launch his three-day assault on evil and sin because, according to legend, demons are strongest at that time. ``This is not just kids having fun,'' Lea said. ``There is actual worship of the devil.'' As the evening wore on, an estimated 300,000 revelers were expected to camp it up in the Castro district. Police barricaded 15 square blocks instead of the usual four and a stage was set up on Market Street to lure partiers away from the most crowded areas. ``This is just good clean fun for us, a celebration of our lifestyle,'' said Joe Van Es-Ballesteros, organizer of the drag extravaganza. A group called Grand Homosexual Outrage at Sickening Televangelists - GHOST - was formed to engage in the spiritual warfare with Lea and Bernal. ``Lea's characterization of the city as being ruled by spirits of perversity and witchcraft is nothing but thinly veiled homophobia and fear-mongering,'' said GHOST member Mark Pritchard. ``We intend to show that San Francisco is a diverse community of people who love peace and freedom.'' Tim Lavender, vice president of the Larry Lea Ministries, denied the Christians hate homosexuals and others with different lifestyles. ``We're not here to pray against the gays or any group of people,'' Lavender said. ``We are here to pray for a return to traditional values. ... This is an opportunity for all Christians to come together.'' Lavender said the ``so-called peace-loving'' people in San Francisco who oppose the religious right have been calling Lea and Bernal with death threats since the prayer event was announced in September. ``We're not trying to provoke any type of violence,'' he said. On Tuesday, city workers washed sidewalks in front of the auditorium to erase at least one dozen red, spray-painted threats that said: ``Kill The Christian.'' Last summer, Lea turned out 6,000 exorcists in Anaheim for a three-day ``Prayer Breakthrough'' to ``inflict serious damage'' on forces of darkness in southern California. Nearly 7,000 believers showed up to help him ``clobber the devil'' in Chicago where they brandished imaginary swords and spoke in tongues.

DOC.HEAD: 132-Year-Old Sailing Ship Looking for Work
DOC.TEXT: The world's oldest active sailing ship, built of Spanish pine 132 years ago, may creak and groan but it's looking for work. ``Sailing ships are no longer commercial so there is no reason for her existence except her existence and I will do anything to keep this ship going,'' said Mark Litchfield, skipper of the 127-ton brig, Maria Asumpta. Bunting fluttered between the two masts as Litchfield welcomed potential hirers and sponsors at a shipboard reception Wednesday in St. Katharine's Dock near the Tower of London. ``As she costs nearly 200,000 pouns ($388,000) a year to maintain and run in a full 10-month season, there's a lot of work to be done in raising money,'' Litchfield said. For the crew, it's more of a romance than a job. ``It is a living spirit and if you were aboard for a week you would know that too,'' deckhand Michael ``Spike'' Jenkins said Wednesday. ``She's all wood and natural rope, not clinical like a steel ship,'' he said. Lucy Taylor, 29, the only woman among a crew of 10, said she got tired of teaching in an eastern England primary school and answered an advertisement for ship's cook. ``I always had a subconscious dream to sail on a tall ship,'' she said. ``It's a very free way of life and we are together as a community.'' ``I feel attached to the ship - it's like a person. I was away on land for a week and when I came back and saw it I cried. This is the first job I have done that I haven't wanted to leave.'' The Maria Asumpta is in the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's oldest active square-rigged sailing ship. The brig was built in Badalona, near Barcelona, in 1858, for trans-Atlantic trade, carrying rum, molasses, tobacco and spices from the Caribbean and returning with up to 500 tons of cargo. The Maria Asumpta was discovered in 1980 lying as a hulk in Malaga, southern Spain, by Litchfield and a friend, Robin Cecil-Wright. It was about to be towed to sea and burned, the usual fate of many old wooden ships. The two Englishmen bought the ship and spent 18 months restoring it, then sailed it to England. It crossed the Atlantic in 1984, spent three years in the Great Lakes and came back in 1988. ``I believe that feat, under sail, was never achieved before by a vessel 130 years old,'' said Litchfield, a 49-year-old former Royal Navy officer. The ship is hired for parties and promotions, film work and sail training and turns up at seaport festivals and regattas. It is 11 years older than the famous clipper Cutty Sark, now preserved in a London dry dock at Greenwich in southeast London. Deckhand Charles Smith, 43, from the Shetland Islands north of Scotland, said it's noisy in the old ship at sea and he likes to hear the creaking of the timbers. ``It's talking to you,'' he said. ``Of course it if didn't creak, it would break apart.''

DOC.HEAD: Netherlands Becoming Less of a Haven for Refugees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Netherlands is tightening the rules on asylum because it hasn't enough money, housing and jobs for all the poor refugees flooding in. Holland is a historic haven for the oppressed. It sheltered the Pilgrims, who fled religious persecution in England, before they sailed for the New World. A decade ago, in 1980, only 1,330 people claimed refugee status in the Netherlands. This year, the number is expected to reach 20,000 and the government threatens to jail aliens who make unjustified requests for asylum. Dutch officials contend most asylum seekers are economic refugees looking for easier lives in this high-tech welfare state. Hundreds of people have come from economically depressed Eastern Europe in recent months, and the government fears a new rush of arrivals if the Persian Gulf crisis turns into war. The Netherlands subscribes to the U.N. definition of political refugees as those fleeing persecution on ideological grounds, and is reluctant to stretch its welfare resources in a time of economic uncertainty. Jobs, housing and tolerance are getting scarce, and only about 13 percent of asylum requests are approved. ``This is one of the most densely populated countries in the world,'' said Maurice van Hezik, spokesman for the Justice Ministry. ``There's pretty high unemployment among the non-Dutch population. If you were to admit people who only come to work, that would make the problem worse.'' One asylum seeker, Sara Amini of Iran, claims she was persecuted at home for being a member of a small opposition party in Iran. When she arrived last summer with her husband and two children, she expected the free housing and allowances that used to be given nearly all asylum seekers. Instead, they were jammed into a 15-foot-square room at a former convent school in Rijsbergen, one of 23 refugee camps in Holland. ``I heard people in the Netherlands were very friendly, very helpful compared to other European people,'' She said in an interview. ``I didn't expect it to be like this.'' People seeking asylum in the Netherlands used to be taken to government-subsidized housing projects and given social welfare payments equivalent to about $800 a month. In 1987, however, an influx of ethnic Tamils fleeing the civil war in Sri Lanka gave rise to what critics call the ``bed, bath and bread'' program. The government opened 15 refugee camps, including Rijsbergen, to house asylum seekers during processing. Aad Kosto, deputy justice minister, said this summer he would jail those who sought asylum without good reason and might flee the camps and try to lose themselves in the population. Only a few people have been jailed, but the practice is expected to become more common in the effort to stop rejected asylum seekers from joining the estimated 50,000 to 60,000 illegal aliens in this nation of 14.6 million. Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers summoned the mayors of eight towns and villages in September and told them each would be host to a new refugee camp. He said the first busloads of people were on their way. Seven more camps are planned by the Welfare Ministry, which is buying 500 mobile homes. Van Hezik said some people admit they've only come for jobs, and others offer ``the strangest stories.'' He cited the case of a Third World refugee who claimed to have arrived on a ship bound for Switzerland, which is landlocked. Van Hezik said the man apparently hoped to be expelled to that country. In early August, Romanians began pouring into Eindhoven in southern Holland. Radio Free Europe, the U.S.-sponsored station, had described the city as hospitable to strangers, van Hezik said. Hundreds of East Europeans have made their way to the Netherlands and the Persian Gulf may provide the next source of refugees, said Jan Tielemans, director of the Rijsbergen camp. ``We'll probably be noticing the side effects . . . the Indians, the Sri Lankans who are huddling in Jordan, Eygptians too,'' he said. ``We won't know for another few months. ``Some of these people are simply looking for a living, and they think one of the ways they'll get it is by asking for asylum.'' A 26-year-old Iraqi at Rijsbergen said he deserted Saddam Hussein's army days before it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``I was sick and tired of it all,'' said the man, who identified himself as an artillery sergeant born in Yemen but would not give his name. ``I just wondered what would happen if I deserted.'' He said he hid in a helicopter belonging to the Red Crescent, the Moslem version of the Red Cross, which took him from his position near Basra in the south to the Kurdistan region of northwestern Iraq, then crossed into Turkey. The Iraqi said he reached Amsterdam by ship, and acknowledged he stood ``very little chance'' of being accepted as a refugee. ``If they're willing to listen, I'll tell my story,'' he said. ``If not, the world is big enough.''

DOC.HEAD: CenTrust Chairman Falls Hard From Ranks of Miami Elite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: David Paul, entrepreneur and real estate developer, was by all accounts a stranger when he arrived in the early 1980s and bought a dying Miami thrift. By the late '80s, the chairman of CenTrust Bank had been embraced by Miami's establishment and accepted into the inner sanctums of civic leadership. And Paul enjoyed an extravagant lifestyle and had deep pockets matched by few in this city of risk-takers and jet-setters. Trouble was, financial regulators say, he was using CenTrust depositors' money to support his philanthropy and lavish expenditures. They contend Paul's spending habits contributed to CenTrust's collapse, at $1.8 billion one of the nation's biggest savings and loan failures. And now the federal government wants Paul to reach into his pockets and return $30.8 million. Paul, 51, is accused of using CenTrust as his own personal piggy bank. Regulators say depositors' money paid for gold-plated bathroom plumbing and a $29-million art collection that included a $13-million painting by Flemish master Peter Paul Rubens. The artwork was later sold for a loss. ``We can't find ... anyone who has been so involved in conspicuous consumption,'' said Thomas P. Mason, public affairs officer for the Office of Thrift Supervision in Washington. Once a prominent Democratic fund-raiser, Paul also has become something of a political pariah. Gov. Bob Martinez and Democratic challenger Lawton Chiles have criticized each other for their routine political dealings with Paul. And Paul's contact with Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., has become an issue in his race against Republican challenger Jim Rappaport. Maurice Ferre, a former Miami mayor, reflected several months ago about Paul's acceptance in business and civic circles: ``In hindsight, it was a misjudgment, but David Paul is a spectacular guy. He's a super salesman, a gambler. And Miami is a place where people are awed by money as a status symbol of achievement.'' Paul, who has until Nov. 1 to pay the $30.8 million restitution or post bond for that amount, has been in Israel and could not be reached for comment. His Miami attorney, Sanford Bohrer, says the government action has no merit and will be vigorously contested. ``His problems aren't over by a long shot,'' acknowledged Terence McElroy, spokesman for the state Office of the Comptroller. But Bill Cullom, president of the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce argues that Paul shouldn't take all the blame for the federal takeover of CenTrust, once the biggest S&L in the Southeast. ``Every single savings and loan in the United States had board members and they were allowing these things to happen. ... It's unacceptable to me for the bank examiners to come in and play Monday morning quarterback,'' he said. That sentiment was echoed by a former CenTrust board member, one of the few willing to comment on Paul. ``There was a time that CenTrust was riding the crest and making lots and lots ofprofit,'' said Jessie McCrary, an attorney and civic leader. ``While they blame Paul for the demise of CenTrust, what do they say when he resurrected Dade Federal from oblivion?'' Paul acquired the failing thrift in 1983 and the following year renamed it CenTrust. He made earnings soar through liberal accounting practices and an extensive junk-bond portfolio, much of it purchased from the investment firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert, Inc. The 47-story CenTrust Tower, a downtown Miami landmark, was lit nightly; Paul changed the colors on the building during the holidays or when it was requested for a community event. The flamboyant bank chairman, who collected a salary of $4.8 million plus other compensation from January 1988 to September 1989, donated to local universities and causes such as the campaign against casino gambling. In all, he gave some $1.7 million over a three-year period. Then the roof started caving in, in 1989. The bank's losses mounted, and a published report showed Paul had lied on his official CenTrust biography, including that he had a Ph.D. from Harvard and an MBA from Columbia University. He didn't. Regulators seized control of CenTrust this year and in June, the bank was sold to Great Western Bank of California. His La Gorce Island residence is for sale at $9.5 million, and his $7 million customized yacht, Grand Cru, was sold for a cut-rate $3 million. ``He was, for all appearance, a very good corporate citizen,'' said Cullom, the chamber of commerce president. ``All of these things are just coming to light. How could we know as a civic community what was going on?''

DOC.HEAD: Fort Lauderdale Paper Wins Top APME Freedom of Information Award
DOC.TEXT: The Sun-Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is the winner of the top award in the Freedom of Information competition of the Associated Press Managing Editors association. The Sun-Sentinel was selected for a series of articles on Florida's failure to impose adequate controls on care centers, leading to client deaths and injuries among such diverse groups as infants, retarded adults and teen-age criminals. The 20th annual award was presented Wednesday at the APME convention by David Hawpe, editor of The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., and chairman of the APME FOI committee. Three citations also were awarded for extraordinary effort toward a better-informed citizenry. They were signed by Hawpe and APME President Gene Foreman of The Philadelphia Inquirer, and presented to: -The Detroit News for an investigation tracing payments from a secret Detroit police fund, through which more than $1 million in taxpayer money was laundered. -The Daily Reflector of Greenville, N.C., for revelations concerning the background of a candidate for Superior Court judge, resulting in legislation opening the records of the North Carolina Judicial Standards Commission. -The Hartford (Conn.) Courant for an examination of the government's military recruiting system, which suggested that it promotes corruption, undermines quality of the armed forces, and costs taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars annually. The APME comprises managing editors and other news executives of the 1,500 member newspapers of the AP, the world's largest newsgathering organization.

DOC.HEAD: APME Honors KC Star's Burg With Meritorious Service Award
DOC.TEXT: George R. Burg, assistant to the publisher and associate editor of The Kansas City Star, has been honored as the second recipient of the Meritorious Service Award of The Associated Press Managing Editors association. Burg, 74, has been an APME member for 23 years, serving two terms as a director and also as treasurer. He has chaired a variety of committees that study industry issues. In recent years, he assembled The Red Book, an annual account of the organization's conventions and studies. Mike Waller, editor of the Hartford Courant, on Wednesday presented a plaque to Burg at the APME annual meeting in Dallas, describing him as ``the nicest, kindest human being in the world.'' Burg said he values his long association with the APME, which comprises managing editors and other news executives of AP member newspapers. ``It's the best group. It gets into every facet of the news business, and there's a good cross-section of people, from small and large papers,'' he said. ``I've never met anyone in this organization I didn't like.'' The Meritorious Service Award was first presented last year. It went to Hu Blonk, editor of the Wenatchee, Wash., World in 1954-74 and a longtime crusader for open government. The APME meeting continues through Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan breezed down memory lane in a visit to his hometown, leading 225 flag-waving children in the Pledge of Allegiance and bashing Democrats and Saddam Hussein when he got the chance. Greeted by adoring crowds Tuesday on a visit that coincided with the release of his memoirs, Reagan ate lunch at the first house in Dixon where the Reagan family lived. It is now a museum. He talked with old friends and skipped stones at the swimming hole where, local legend has it, he saved 76 people as a lifeguard over seven summers. He stopped at the now-vacant grade school he attended. ``I love and remember Dixon as the place I always know I can come home to,'' Reagan said of this town of 15,700 about 100 miles west of Chicago. Reagan said the Democratic-controlled Congress forced the new budget on the Bush administration, and he denounced Saddam for Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We have to keep up the pressure until that madman gives up,'' he said. --- ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) - Theodore Bikel admits his one-man show of folk songs and show tunes isn't the usual casino fare. But Bikel said Tuesday the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino was enterprising enough to search out entertainers such as himself. ``I sing in 21 languages,'' he said. ``I have a wealth of material and I mix it up with more modern tunes. I do some stuff that Sting writes.'' Bikel sings from musicals he has appeared in, such as ``Fiddler on the Roof,' and also does songs from ``My Fair Lady'' and ``Three Penny Opera.'' Bikel, who has been nominated for an Academy Award, said the number of film offers he has received in recent years has declined because he lives in Connecticut. ``Hollywood is a strange place,'' he said. ``If you're not there they think you are sick or dead. Every now and then I have to go back and show my face to show that I'm neither.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Barbara Eden is joining the cast of ``Dallas'' as a business executive who takes Ewing Oil away from J.R. Ewing. It's a bit of a role reversal for Eden and Larry Hagman, who plays J.R. Twenty years ago, Hagman was ``Master'' and Eden took the orders as ``Jeannie'' in the sitcom ``I Dream of Jeannie.'' This time Eden becomes J.R.'s boss. ``My character does end up buying Ewing Oil and J.R. hates it. Of course, he wants to still be in there, so I hire him back,'' Eden said in the Nov. 13 issue of Soap Opera Digest. --- ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. (AP) - Vanna White is marketing a look-alike doll on cable TV and women's clothes that will allow viewers to coordinate their outfits with those of the dolls. The Home Shopping Network said Tuesday that the Wheel of Fortune letter-turner's line of fashions also includes designer sheets. The merchandise is only available through cable TV. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Ferlin Husky was greeted by fellow country performers after his second heart bypass operation in 13 years. Brenda Lee, Chet Atkins, Johnny Russell, Jean Shepard, Skeeter Davis, Jack Greene, Bill Anderson, Connie Smith and others were on hand Tuesday when the 63-year-old singer left Baptist Hospital. ``I'm almost speechless,'' Husky said. ``I feel better all over.'' Husky, known for such hits as ``Wings of a Dove,'' had triple bypass surgery Oct. 19. He also had similar surgery in 1977. At the height of his career in the 1960s, he made 18 movies with such stars as Jayne Mansfield and Zsa Zsa Gabor. --- TAHLEQUAH, Okla. (AP) - Political humorist James Boren, who ran for president in 1984 on the slogan ``I've got what it takes to take what you've got,'' will teach a political science course at Northeastern State University. Boren, cousin of Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., will begin teaching ``Interest Groups in American Politics'' in January. Lyle Haskins, head of the school's political science department, said if Boren stays at Northeastern beyond the year, he will be asked to develop a course on the role of humor in international relations and politics. ``That's right up his alley,'' Haskins said. Boren, 64, has a doctorate from the University of Texas, a master's from the University of Southern California and two bachelor's degrees, all in government and economics.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Seeks Safer Garage Doors, Cigarette Lighters
DOC.TEXT: Congress wants electric garage doors to reverse automatically and cigarette lighters to be childproof, mining in Antarctica to be prohibited and food-hauling trucks to be barred from shipping hazardous trash. These mandates and more are among scores of bills approved and sent to President Bush in the final days of the 101st Congress while headlines concentrated on the budget legislation. Garage doors and cigarette lighters are governed by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which Congress strengthened in its first reauthorization of the agency in nine years. ``This important consumer protection agency was an abandoned stepchild during the Reagan years,'' said Rep. Doug Walgren, D-Pa., chairman of the House subcommittee on consumer protection. ``Ideological conflict among the members of the commission paralyzed the agency.'' Besides taking steps to make the commission work better, Congress ordered it to establish mandatory safety standards for automatic garage doors and to complete its work on cigarette lighters. Although many of the newer garage doors automatically reverse when they hit an obstruction, the safety provision is not required. More than 50 children have been killed in accidents involving automatic doors, Walgren's office said. It also said that in 1987, fires started by children playing with cigarette lighters killed 180 people, including 140 children under age 5. ``This is a horrible toll that can and should be prevented with an effective safety standard,'' said Walgren. ``I believe it is imperative that the commission move quickly to complete this important task.'' Lawmakers also saw the possibility of a toll being taken in Antarctica. The continent at the South Pole was established as a scientific area in 1959 with a treaty signed by 35 countries. In 1988, the nations agreed to regulate mining by requiring environmental impacts to be considered first. But that pact didn't guarantee preservation of the Antarctic. A bill passed last week bans any U.S. mineral development on the frozen continent and asks the president to negotiate new international treaties to ban all mining. ``Antarctica is the last, relatively untouched continent on the planet, providing unparalleled research opportunities, and the United States is in a position to exert international leadership to permanently protect and conserve this last frontier,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., sponsor of the bill. Oceanographer Jacques-Yves Cousteau, in testimony to Congress, forecast possible global tragedy if Antarctica were open to widespread mining. ``The Antarctic, with 90 percent of the ice of the world, represents a formidable cold storage that stabilizes the climate of the world,'' Cousteau said. A slight warming of the atmosphere could trigger melting that would raise the level of the oceans to intolerable proportions, he said. ``Coal mines would bring about coal dust on the surface of the ice. Even a small quantity would change the reflective power of the ic, would absorb more heat from the sun, would start some melting of the ice,'' said Cousteau. Congress passed about 200 bills in its final week. Some involved internal government operations, while others addressed regional issues. Some took hours of debate and were voted by roll call; others were passed in minutes on voice vote with little discussion. Two bills designed to protect the public from hazardous materials are on the way to the president. Rep. Thomas Luken, D-Ohio, led the effort to prohibit the ``backhauling'' of waste by trucks that also are used to carry food. He gave a graphic example of the danger of this practice. He said that after feed grain was transported in a rail car that earlier had hauled an arsenic compound, $1 million worth of cattle died from eating the contaminated grain. ``Milk from other cattle was poisoned and had to be dumped for over four weeks until it tested clean,'' Luken said. The legislation instructs the departments of Transportation, Agriculture and Health and Human Services and the Environmental Protection Agency to consult on regulations for transporters. No food cargo would be allowed in truck or rail cars that carry health-threatening materials. Extremely hazardous materials, such as asbestos or infectious waste, would have to be shipped only in carriers specifically designed for that purpose. After eight years of trying, Luken also won approval of his bill to strengthen the law governing the transportation of hazardous material. It makes civil and criminal penalties harsher, requires greater safety precautions, unifies federal, state and local laws and sets up training on responding to emergencies. Luken said that last year there were more than 6,000 accidents involving hazardous materials, and that more than 165 people were injured and 17 were killed. The accidents caused damages of more than $21 million, he said.

DOC.HEAD: APME Presents Top AP Staff Awards
DOC.TEXT: News and photo coverage of the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe earned recognition for two of the seven Associated Press staff members honored with Top Performance awards by the Associated Press Managing Editors association. Special Correspondent Mort Rosenblum was honored for his coverage of the Romanian revolution of December 1989. Photographer Diether Endlicher of Munich, Germany, was cited for two photographs of East Germans who fled to the West German Embassy in Prague. The Top Performance awards, given Tuesday, recognize outstanding work over the past year in three reporting categories - writing on deadline, feature writing and enterprise writing - and in spot news photography and feature photography. Other winners were: -Special Correspondent Tad Bartimus of Denver, chosen for ``Goodbye Daddy'' a recounting of the final days of her terminally ill father's life. Bartimus is the AP's Mountain States regional reporter. -National Writer Fred Bayles of Boston, Sharon Cohen of Chicago and Scott McCartney of Dallas, for their four-part series, ``Cashing in on the Drought,'' that tracked the allcation of $3.9 billion, the largest disaster relief measure in U.S. history. Cohen is the news service's regional reporter for the Midwest, and McCartney is the regional reporter for the Southwest. -Jim Mone of Minneapolis, for a post-surgery photo of former President Reagan doffing a cap to expose a half-shaved head, while Nancy Reagan tried to cover him up. The winners were awarded $1,500 and a plaque at the APME convention here. The organization also named Connie Cass, the AP's Evansville, Ind., correspondent, as winner of the 10th annual John L. Dougherty award for excellence by a young AP writer. The award is named for a former APME leader and managing editor of the Rochester, N.Y., newspapers who had an abiding interest in good writing and helped young writers improve their skills. He died in 1980. Cass received a $1,000 cash award and a plaque. Additional awards for excellence in the Top Performance reporting competition went to: -Linda Deutsch of Los Angeles for her coverage of the trial of former Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood and its aftermath; -Stefan Fatsis, AP business writer, for breaking the story of junk bond financier Michael Milken's plea bargain; -National Writer Robert Dvorchak, Mitchell Landsberg and Gary Langer, all of New York, for ``The Persuaders,'' a 50-state look at lobbying in state capitals. Awards for excellence in photography were given to: -J. Scott Applewhite of Washington for photos of survivors of the earthquake in Iran; -John Hopper of Mexico City for a photograph of a Salvadoran soldier holding his rifle to the head of a suspected guerrilla; -Munich's Endlicher for a photo of Romanian peasants standing in line for voting forms; -Susan Ragan of New York for a picture package of Soviet immigrants in New York City's Brighton Beach neighborhood. -Bob Galbraith of Los Angeles for a photo of President Bush gesturing in front of an anti-drug mural. The APME comprises managing editors and other news executives of the 1,500 member newspapers of the AP, the world's largest newsgathering organization.

DOC.HEAD: Political Ads Take a Walk on the Nice Side
DOC.TEXT: With voters in an anti-government snit, many candidates are trying hard to show their warm, fuzzy sides in the final week of the election season. Children, music, personal drama and high-minded sentiments generally make a comeback at the end of any political campaign. But strategists say the soft landing is especially important this year. ``The level of disgust is much higher,'' said Democratic pollster Celinda Lake. ``You need to offer an alternative, be seen as someone who doesn't seem political and will cut through all of this mess.'' That's not to say hard-hitting advertising and attacks have vanished. Many strategists believe long-shot challengers and candidates in tight races must keep up the barrage if they want to win. Republican pollster David B. Hill agreed that candidates need to clinch the sale with niceness at the end of the season. But, he said, ``that doesn't mean you need to pull off your other spots that keep your foot on the throat of your opponent that you've got down on the ground.'' Nevertheless, consultants acknowledge that negative advertising carries greater risks this year as a result of widespread voter frustration with politicians-as-usual. ``We've always known that when you do negative campaigning you raise your own negative ratings and make yourself look more political,'' Lake said. ``That's a more dangerous trend this year than normal.'' Thus, the special emphasis on touchy-feely ads and rhetoric such as this: -It's a warm, sunny day in a new ad from Lowell Weicker, the independent candidate for Connecticut governor. A choir sings and Weicker tells viewers that ``the governor's office is about leadership, vision, integrity.'' He explained his strategy last week: ``I want to become the governor of the state of Connecticut feeling good about how I got to be the governor of the state of Connecticut.'' -In neighboring Massachusetts, Democrat John Silber alienated many voters with his abrasive personality. Now he's running an ad in which he strolls amiably through a flea market. In another spot, he's surrounded by young children, joking with a little girl as she combs his hair. -In Rhode Island, an ad for Rep. Claudine Schneider praises both her and the man whose job she wants, Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell, as ``proven, caring, committed and honest.'' It's hard to tell who paid for the spot until the end, when the 71-year-old Pell's picture recedes behind a photo of the relatively youthful Schneider. ``Two of a kind,'' the announcer says. ``One with a past, and the other ready to meet the future.'' -California Democrat Dianne Feinstein reintroduced a dramatic ad that helped her win the party's gubernatorial nomination. Feinstein is shown announcing the traumatic 1978 murder of San Francisco Mayor George Moscone - an event that put her, then president of the city's board of supervisors, into the mayor's chair. The ad highlights her support for the death penalty and abortion rights, and describes her as ``tough and caring.'' -Ben Nelson, the Democrat challenging Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr, last week pulled all ads that criticized Mrs. Orr or mentioned her name. ``The people in Nebraska think all of that stuff is negative,'' he said. -Oregon Republican Dave Frohnmayer, running for governor, and Colorado Democrat Josie Heath, running for the Senate, each have switched advertising consultants and strategies. They're both striving for more positive images. Republican analyst Doug Bailey warns that too much rosiness can backfire. ``Television is so slam-bang. It's all confrontation and slugfest and battle royal,'' he said. ``If you come across as soft or dull, you can be missed altogether.'' But Dave Petts, a Democratic pollster, said strategists were rediscovering the power of positive advertising - particularly when it's used as a finale after weeks of aggressive crossfire. ``There's nothing more effective than a candidate looking at the voters and saying this is what he or she stands for,'' Petts said. ``Positive information can move voters if it's conveyed at a time in the campaign when voters are really paying attention.''

DOC.HEAD: Marion Cunningham Brings Fannie Farmer into '90s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY311 Oct. 27.
DOC.TEXT: Turn to page 225 of the 13th edition of ``The Fannie Farmer Cookbook'' to learn how to truss a chicken, page 628 to bake a batch of brownies. Or just soak in the spirit of the book, which is only partly about food. It also is about ``an act of giving and receiving, because the experience at table is a communal sharing; talk begins to flow, feelings are expressed, and a sense of well-being takes over,'' Marion Cunningham writes in the 13th edition of Fannie Merritt Farmer's guide to the American kitchen. A valuable cookbook also reflects its time, and the previous edition - Cunningham's first, published 11 years ago - already was losing its relevancy when she set out three years ago on the new edition. ``I tell you, things are different, really different. It was only looking recipe by recipe that I could see how dramatic our changes have been,'' she said in an interview in New York. Testing every recipe in the 12th edition, Cunningham dropped 200 and added 325, for an appropriate total of 1,990. Fat was reduced when it worked, and recipes sometimes dropped when it didn't. There's no kippered herring in cream or crabmeat terrapin, for example. There are new chapters on microwave cooking (which surely won't prompt any manufacturers to ask her to be a spokeswoman), outdoor cooking and vegetarian foods, such as zucchini pancakes and a winter vegetable cobbler that ``will win any contest.'' All sorts of ethnic ingredients are used. Raw fish is out, as is steak tartare. Salt generally is left up to the cook. And there are warnings about raw eggs and fish and other safety problems. ``Those were the issues that were very hard to reconcile,'' Cunningham said. ``To act responsibly and not destroy the feeling that cooking and eating are ... well, certainly one of the better human endeavors.'' While Farmer aimed ``The Boston Cooking-School Cook Book,'' published in 1896, at families who had help in the kitchen, the newest edition of ``The Fannie Farmer Cookbook'' (Alfred A. Knopf, $24.95) is intended to capture the way ordinary people actually eat. So along with the instructions for making past from scratch are recipes for a ham and cheese sandwich, for making popcorn, hotdogs and macaroni and cheese. Cunningham tells how to improve the flavor of canned broths, and offers suggestions for leftovers. ``Everyone clamors'' for the simple cheese spread in the appetizer chapter, she writes. There is plenty of practical advice, too. Of olive oils, for example, she says, ``Money does not always buy the best, and I have found the terms `virgin' and `extra virgin' not very meaningful.'' Both inside covers have all sorts of nifty facts - things you've been told dozens of times but can't seem to keep straight, such as how to tell if an egg is stale and whether cream whips better cold or at room temperature. Farmer would, Cunningham concluded, wholeheartedly embrace today's health movement. Cunningham, too, thinks we ought to know what we eat. ``But in concentrating so much on the negative aspects of eating, we are making ourselves overly fearful and we are missing the pleasure that a good meal provides,'' she writes. ``Instead of stringent diets, eliminating almost all fats, all salt, all sugar from our diets, and bloating ourselves with high-fiber products, I believe that the best possible approach for the average person is to eat a wide variety of foods and to eat sensibly, in moderation.'' While there is plenty of low-fat food, this is no diet book. Along with the turkey patties and vegetable soups and green salads, there is a ``carpetbag steak,'' a beef and oyster dish from the ``improvident days'' of the 19th century, and chicken fried steak served with milk gravy. Cunningham delivers a storehouse of basic information - and a pep talk. Come on, now, just get up and go in the kitchen. Taste the food, experiment. It's fun, it's homey and it tastes good. Don't let your failures stop you. ``Cooking is a dandy way to solve a lot of problems,'' said Cunningham. Besides, she said, ``It's harder to learn to drive a car.'' Cunningham, 68, began the 12th edition of Fannie Farmer in 1974, with no writing experience and no famous name. She had been a full-time homemaker, and two years earlier had met the late American cooking icon James Beard. ``Jim Beard recommended me. I didn't think I had any qualifications,'' said Cunningham, sitting on a hotel bed with her legs drawn up under her, gray hair pulled straight back into a short, neat ponytail. The choice made sense to Judith Jones, Cunningham's editor at Knopf. ``For one thing, she had worked with Beard and his classes on the West Coast. He thought she really typified the good home cook in America and had natural good taste, and that's just what Fannie Farmer needed,'' Jones said. Cunningham was charged with ``restoring the old-fashioned principles.'' ``It made me so happy to have something to focus on. I've really loved it,'' she said. ``I loved it from the beginning.'' Her pale blue eyes still express a little awe at her success more than a decade later, during which she also has written ``The Fannie Farmer Baking Book'' and ``The Breakfast Book'' and worked as a restaurant consultant. Her husband, a man she'd known since kindergarten and who she says gave her the support and encouragement to become a professional, died three years ago. Their son and daughter are grown. So except for a yellow labrador named Rover and a cat, she lives alone and cooks for herself in Walnut Creek, Calif. Besides Beard, she uses ``Joy of Cooking'' and the early American cookbooks she collects: ``I turn to a lot of them, wonderful recipes, simple to make.'' Like three-quarters of American families, she has a microwave. The ``speedy, clean and silent'' oven did not fare well under Cunningham's scrutiny, although she includes more than 50 recipes specifically for it. ``The microwave has promised a lot more than it can deliver,'' she said. It was, she wrote, no faster than the stove for many of the vegetables she tested. Meat becomes ``pallid and the texture is not appealing.'' While Cunningham experimented with the new in equipment and ingredients, sometimes she found the old to be far superior. Lobster thermidor and newburg, for example, did not work with milk instead of cream, and with cream they stayed. ``People can read about them if they don't want to make them,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Halloween a Nightmare for Real Freddy Kruegers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Freddy Krueger hates Halloween. In fact, Oct. 31 is a nightmare for five Fred Kruegers who live in Pennsylvania, Virginia, North Carolina and Illinois. It's particularly tough for the Fred Krueger who lives in Tobyhanna, Pa. His house is two blocks from Elm Street. No kidding. Fred Kruegers, men with the same name as the star of screen, scream and gore, are alive and well but unenthusiastic about the holiday that is descended from the medieval All Hallows Eve. The prank calls and weird stares, they say, will be relentless. None of the Freds is maimed by scars, has pop-out claws or even dons a fedora. None has been accused of even one grisly murder, unlike the prolific maniac featured in the never-ending movie saga, ``A Nightmare on Elm Street.'' But these disparities do not ward off pranksters. ``I got some regular customers on the phone,'' said Fred Krueger who lives in Olivers Mills, Pa., and works for Liberty Mutual Life Insurance Co. ``It's best to go along with them,'' he said, noting that kids will just harass him if he sounds mad or hangs up. Fred Krueger, a retired banker from Charlotte, N.C., also plays the demonic role but said he tries to keep it simple because he once scared a little girl. ``She wanted to know iicopters to make sure no herds wander into their ranges. They also patrol the ranges in trucks before the shells start flying over the tortured landscape. ``It may look like crap to us, but it's Kentucky blue grass to them,'' said Lt. Col. Bruce Judge, a Marine operations and training officer. ``Safety is a paramount concern,'' said Marine Capt. William Taylor, a public affairs officer. ``It's like going into a farmer's field and telling him we'd like to bust some big caps in your backyard.'' The clash of cultures is stark. A Bedouin tending his bleating livestock can see helicopters flitting through the skies, armored columns rumbling across the terrain and endless convoys of military trucks on the roads. On one night recently, a patrol of three Marine amphibious assault vehicles passed within 25 yards of a Bedouin camp deep in the desert. Goats were visible through night vision goggles, but the soldiers said they never saw the camp. Another night patrol picked up movement on its sensors but couldn't hear anything. It turned out to be a herd of 20 camels passing by. Bedouin require lots of space to roam. Yet they say they welcome the troops in the desert. ``I thank God the government is having people come to defend the kingdom,'' Al-Azmi said, giving a visitor Arabic coffee, sweet tea and fresh dates while sitting on a rug in the shade of a tent flap. ``Saddam Hussein should be punished. He attacked people who did him no harm. God will punish him,'' he said. Although the Bedouin life is rustic, some have the luxuries of modern life such as Mercedes Benz cars and cellular telephones. A camel can fetch $2,500 at auction, and that's a lot to lose to an errant artillery shell or a tank. On the advice of Saudi authorities, another Bedouin named Abdullah Rajab prepared his herd of 70 camels for a journey south and out of harm's way. ``Some of the troops came and drank tea with me. They were very nice,'' Rajab said. As he spoke, dozens of tanks and armored personnel carriers from the British 7th ``Desert Rats'' Armored Brigade shook the ground as they rumbled past his livestock. Their tracks scarred a desert once trodden only by animals and herders. But the military also does good deeds in the desert. When Hassan Rashed Alkhater of Jubail, the eastern Saudi industrial city, got his pickup truck stuck in the sand, an army vehicle stopped to help. ``I was waiting for 30 minutes for someone to help, and a passing army vehicle pulled me out,'' said Alkhater, who owns 150 head of sheep and goats.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapping: A Lucrative Trade in Karachi
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers dragged Hasson Saleem, 11, from his schoolbus Oct. 10, forced him into a car and sped away. Hours later, abductors seized three more boys from affluent families of Sindh province and a former chairman of the Pakistan National Shipping Corp. Kidnappings for ransom are increasing in Karachi, and the belief grows that authorities are helpless against the lawlessness gripping Pakistan's largest and most turbulent city. In the rambunctious southern port where parties once ran until dawn, people are afraid to go out at night. More than 100 people have been snatched in two years. No one has been killed, but more than 1 billion rupees ($500 million) in ransom has been paid. The list of victims reads like a Who's Who of industrial and financial families. ``We want a military government,'' an executive of a multinational corporation said, echoing the sentiments of many residents. ``We may not have law, but at least we'll have order. In this democracy, we have neither law nor order.'' Benazir Bhutto's political opponents blamed her for the violence in her home province until President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed her 20-month-old government Aug. 6. It was one of the factors he cited in taking the action. Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, army chief of staff, then declared the crime wave over and said peace had been restored. Kidnapping gangs soon proved him wrong, abducting people at the rate of one a day. Businessmen held protest strikes that paralyzed Karachi, the country's financial and industrial center, but nothing changed. The gangs ``have lists of top businessmen and their family members,'' a security agent said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Once they have selected their target, a reconnaissance team is deployed to gather the necessary information about their daily movement, and then they strike.'' Gamg members then get in touch with the victim's family, a deal is struck and the ransom paid. Families seldom request official help because they lack faith in the police and fear for the victims' safety. ``We can't trust police because most of the crimes are committed with their connivance,'' said a businessman whose younger brother was kidnapped. Police say lack of cooperation by victims' families and the public is a major reason for their failure to stop the kidnappers. They also claim the gangs enjoy the patronage of some political parties. Authorities accuse such extremist ethnic parties of involvement in many of the abductions. Students hostels in Karachi are said to be hideouts for the gangs. ``Apart from political patronage, feudal patronage is also a factor,'' the security expert said. ``Most gangs enjoy the support of the big landlords who wield political influence. Because of these factors, the governments in Sindh have almost become hostage to the criminals.'' Karachi's economy has suffered. Businesses and investors are moving their operations from the financial and trading center of 9 million people to safer Punjab province in eastern Pakistan. ``I don't know what will happen to me when I leave my home,'' industrialist Tariq Shafi said. ``I keep an automatic gun in my car. In this situation, how do you expect us to invest in the city?.'' The flight of capital has boosted unemployment, already about 25 percent, and fed the ``Kalashnikov and heroin culture,'' a reference to the Soviet automatic rifles and heroin trade brought to Pakistan by the war in neighboring Afghanistan. Companies that specialize in protection are thriving. Two years ago, the Adamjee Insurance Co. started offering kidnap policies. ``Initially, we approached the leading businessmen . . . but now they are coming to us,'' an Adamjee executive said, on condition his name not be used. Adamjee works with Lloyd's of London. When a client is kidnapped, experts from Britain are flown to help negotiate the ransom. Businessmen are abandoning expensive luxury cars for less conspicuous compacts, hiring bodyguards and building huge steel gates to close off the streets around their fortified estates. Each week, the heads of the 22 most powerful industrial empires gather in downtown Karachi. ``When these meetings started 15 years ago, the discussions were about business, politics, culture,'' an executive said. ``Now the only topic is our and our families' safety.''

DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian Pays Nostalgic Visit to Postwar Child's World
LaserPhoto WX10
DOC.TEXT: For a kid growing up in the post-World War II suburbs, it was a comforting world of Captain Kangaroo on the tube, a new washing machine in the basement, a shiny gas guzzler in the carport and a bomb shelter in the backyard. ``This is our childhood,'' said Roger G. Kennedy, director of the National Museum of American History, where he introduced a new exhibition that takes a nostalgic look at the lives of children born during the Cold War years. Kennedy meant not only the childhood of the current baby boom generation of parents but, in a deeper sense, the innocence of a nation that yearned only for peace and the emblems of middle-class prosperity. The show, titled ``This is Your Childhood Charlie Brown: Children and American Culture, 1945-1968,'' opens today at the Smithsonian Institution museum for a six-month engagement through next April. It contains more than 500 artifacts and graphics from an America that would soon lose its innocence in Vietnam and the social upheavals of the late 1960s. Among them is Charles M. Schulz's first ``Peanuts'' comic strip, which appeared Oct. 2, 1950. Perhaps more than any other cartoon characters of that era, Charlie Brown and his friends mirrored the hopes and fears of postwar America with a gentle, captivating humor. In an age when children were taught to live by society's rules and obey their parents, their TV heroes frequently wore uniforms. Even Bob Keeshan's Captain Kangaroo wore a uniform jacket with badge as a ``figure of benevolent authority.'' It was the world according to Dr. Spock, whose lab coat and spectacles are on display along with the drafting table where he wrote his best-selling paperback, ``Baby and Child Care,'' for a generation of worried mothers. Parents worried, too, about communism and nuclear attack. Their children's toys included a Gilbert U-238 atomic lab and Civil Defense medical kit among the hula hoops, Barbie dolls, GI Joes, Lassie lunch boxes and Davy Crockett coonskin caps. Also on display are such postwar images as a model of the Sputnik satellite, a space helmet, Dale Evans and Nurse Nancy books, a pink chenille bedspread, a Captain Video game, an Annie Oakley cowgirl outfit, a ``Ding Dong School'' record player and ``Romper Room'' diploma and an Easy-Bake toy oven. Curator Charles McGovern, a historian of popular culture, said the exhibition seeks to highlight some of the myths and realities of what is remembered today as ``a very calm and tranquil era.'' Actually, he said, ``happy suburbanites and the threat of nuclear war lived side by side'' along with growing urban poverty and racial divisions that erupted into social conflicts in the 1960s. Kennedy said ``the whole fabric of American society began a long unraveling.'' Parents tried to shield their children from society's problems with barriers of ``security and conformity,'' McGovern said, but the children rebelled against parental values when they discovered that ``affluence was not translating fully into happiness'' and social justice. The show ends by raising questions about whether parents can protect their children from new threats of drug abuse, violence, AIDS and homelessness. ``Childhood today is at risk,'' suggests McGovern. The exhibition was underwritten by a $125,000 grant from United Media, which syndicates the ``Peanuts'' comic strip.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Inquirer Executive Editor Had No Evidence of Justice Corruption
DOC.TEXT: Eugene Roberts, former executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Tuesday said he had no evidence that Pennsylvania Supreme Court Justice James McDermott was corrupt, either before or after the newspaper published a 1983 series critical of the state's highest court. McDermott has sued the Inquirer claiming he was maliciously defamed and his reputation damaged because of the articles, which were published May 17, 1983 and titled ``Above the Law.'' Roberts is listed as a defendant in the case. The series, subtitled ``the questionable conduct of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court,'' alleged that the justices ``routinely participate in cases in which their friends have an interest ... ignore judicial canons of ethics meant to regulate their conduct (and) engage in politicking, influence-peddling and favoritism.'' McDermott's lawyer, James Beasley, asked Roberts if any evidence has appeared since series was published that would indicate McDermott was corrupt. Roberts answered, ``No.'' Beasley asked how the series title came about, and Roberts told him ``Above the Law'' was probably composed by a copy editor handling the series written by Daniel Biddle, also a defendant in the lawsuit. ``Is it a reasonable synopsis of what the story was about?'' Beasley asked. Roberts responded, ``Yes.'' Beasley pressed on: ``Do you believe the title could connote criminal conduct?'' ``No,'' said Roberts. Most of the day's proceedings involved legal conferences out of the jury's hearing by the opposing lawyers with Common Pleas Judge John Lavelle of Carbon County, specially appointed by the Supreme Court to try the case. Roberts, who was scheduled to return to the witness stand Wednesday, acknowledged that one of the objectives of journalism is to write a story that is fair, balanced and accurate. ``That's because you want the people to believe what you print is true?'' Beasley asked. ``That's one of the reasons,'' Roberts replied, adding that readers have a right to a balanced story that gives different points of view and is accurate. Roberts three years ago was named president of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. which publishes the morning Inquirer and the afternoon Daily News. He retired last month and plans to teach next year at the University of Maryland. He testified that as the Inquirer's executive editor, a post he held for 18 years, he could kill any story he didn't want in the newspaper, and never needed anyone's permission to do it. ``That's enormous power,'' Beasley said, and Roberts agreed. About the court series, Roberts testified he didn't select the language that went into the story or how paragraphs were positioned, nor does he remember doing any editing of it. Beasley asked, ``Do you have any evidence that prior to May 1983 that Justice McDermott ruled on any case in favor of a friend or campaign contributor while he served for 15 years on the Common Pleas bench?'' ``I don't recall the Common Pleas bench (but) I know he ruled in a case for a friend and campaign contributor (when he was on the Supreme Court),'' Roberts responded.

DOC.HEAD: Alliance Against Saddam: Divided Over Strategy, Goals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The solid United Nations front forged to squeeze Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait has evolved during the three-month occupation into an alliance divided over strategy and goals. The wild card is Saddam himself, who is selectively freeing some Western hostages - like the French - in hopes of eroding support for military action. He has tried to fashion a regional perception that the struggle is not over Kuwait, but whether Arabs or the West will hold sway in the Middle East. Saddam's neighbor, Saudi Arabia, exemplifies the conflicts within the alliance assembled against Iraq. The Saudis demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and want Saddam to promise never to attack another Arab state. At the same time, there have been indications the Saudis might consider concessions of Kuwaiti territory. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev suggested Monday the time was ripe for another Arab diplomatic initiative, perhaps led by Saudi Arabia. With the Saudi oil installations vulnerable to attack, the country's defense minister, Prince Sultan, has said his country - now playing host to the multinational force - would never allow an attack to be launched from its territory. However, King Fahd's son, Prince Mohammed, was quoted as saying ``the waiting period for ending Iraq's occupation of Kuwait through the embargo will be soon defined because patience has limits.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected to visit Saudi Arabia and possibly other Arab capitals next month in an apparent effort to shore up the alliance against Saddam. Some analysts say the differing approaches of the nations opposed to Saddam actually complement each other, preparing the military punch while pursuing the diplomatic option. ``That range of difference in the multinational group is a positive thing,'' said Middle East analyst Shahram Chubin of the Geneva-based Center for Strategic Studies. ``If you want the regional coalition behind you, you have to show that you've given the U.N. option a chance,'' he said by telephone. ``There's a great and deep ambivalence on the part of the United States' regional (Arab) allies about the whole enterprise,'' he said. ``There's a lot of anti-Western feelings and there's a feeling of solidarity with their cousins in Iraq.'' The linchpin position is held by the United States, which has deployed 220,000 troops in the Persian Gulf. President Bush has demanded Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from the oil-rich emirate it invaded Aug. 2, as well as restoration of the ruling al-Sabah family. Bush has repeatedly stressed the military option, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said as many as 100,000 more GIs could be deployed if needed. CIA Director William Webster said the Bush administration believes the Middle East will not be secure while Saddam's weaponry is intact. The Persian Gulf crisis is filled with political traps for Bush. Large-scale casualties would be a liability, while a diplomatic solution that left Saddam's war machine in place would sow the seeds for a reprise of the present conflict. ``We're into a perilous phase in the standoff if the goal of the allied forces is more than what the U.N. resolution calls for - to destroy Saddam and his ability to make war,'' said a Middle East expert with the U.S. State Department. ``Then, no matter what amount of diplomacy is engaged, there's no way to avoid shooting. Most of the European allies would not necessarily support that, with the exception of Britain,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``I don't think you can get the French to agree that the goal is now to destroy Saddam,'' the State Department expert said. ``I don't think the Arab states can send their troops into battle for that purpose.'' The United States has the most troops in the multinational force, followed by Britain and France. Britain stands squarely behind Bush on the use of force against Saddam, but France and the Soviet Union have rejected any military action without express United Nations approval. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been most outspoken about military action. ``You get him out, make him pay and see that he's never in a position to do these things again,'' she has said. France, which favors waiting for economic sanctions to force Iraq out of Kuwait, was Iraq's closest Western economic partner before the invasion. Although Iraq apparently tried to woo France by freeing French hostages, President Francois Mitterrand has rejected any concessions in exchange for hostages. This week, Yevgeny Primakov, Gorbachev's gulf envoy, completed a second round of talks with Saddam - discussions that reportedly were largely unsuccessful. Analyst Chubin said: ``The Soviets are doing a fine job, demonstrating that a diplomatic solution is not possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Arab Lawmaker May Be Prosecuted For Backing PLO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Mohammed Miari, an Israeli Arab, and Michael Eitan, a Jew, are two members of Parliament whose quarrel goes to the heart of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Miari, from an Arab village in northern Israel, was involved with the Palestine Liberation Organization in a futile attempt to sail a shipload of Palestinians back to their homeland in February 1988. Eitan, a Jew, saw it as an act of treason designed to turn Israel into Palestine and undermine the Jews' right to the land. He went on a 36-day sit-down strike in the attorney general's office to get him to prosecute Miari. The attorney general, Yosef Harish, finally agreed to ask the Knesset, or parliament, to lift Miari's parliamentary immunity so that he could be prosecuted. On Monday, a parliamentary committee agreed to the unprecedented step by a vote of 13-6 with two abstentions. The move stands a good chance of winning final approval by the 120-member Knesset next month, and an equally good chance of being declared unlawful by the Supreme Court, because the whole point of immunity is to enable a lawmaker to fulfill his election promises. ``My immunity is not given me by legislators but by the masses who elected me for my message of seeking peace and a just solution by establishing a Palestinian state alongside Israel,'' Miari said after the vote. Miari is not accused of abetting terrorism, and a 1986 law forbidding contact between Israelis and PLO officials has been openly violated by several Israeli lawmakers, including Miari. But to Israelis like Eitan, the case of the PLO ship is very different. The ship was to carry 180 Palestinian deportees and some 120 sympathizers. Moreover, it was named ``Al Awda'' - the Return - an evocative word meaning the Palestinians' right to reclaim the land that became Israel in 1948. ``Al Awda is one of the basics of PLO doctrine,'' Eitan said in an interview Tuesday. ``The PLO knows that talk of throwing the Jews into the sea no longer goes down well, so they say `right of return,' whereby all the Palestinians will come back to Israel and then the Jews will have nowhere to go but into the sea.'' The project failed because the ship owner canceled the charter agreement, and the vessel was then sabotaged in an explosion. The perpetrators are unknown, but Miari suspects Israeli secret agents. Miari says Eitan's fears are groundless. ``Yes, there are those who think in an abstract way that the whole land belongs to the Palestinians, just as there are Jews who think the whole of Palestine belongs to the Jews,'' he said in an interview. He believes, based on a dozen meetings with Arafat and other top PLO officials, that the PLO is set on a course of negotiations to achieve ``two states for two nations.'' Miari, 51, was born in the village of Birweh, near Acre in northern Israel. In 1948 the Arab-Israeli war reached Birweh, and the Miaris fled to a neighboring town. When they came home, the village was in rubble. Miari studied law at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, and was always politically active. In 1984 he ran for the Knesset on the ticket of the Progressive List for Peace - a left-wing Arab-Jewish coalition advocating negotiations with the PLO - and was elected along with Matti Peled, a retired Jewish army general. In 1988 he was re-elected, this time alone but still the third strongest force among Israel's 800,000 Arab voters. At each election, authorities banned the party as a threat to state security. Each time, the Supreme Court quashed the ban. Eitan, 46, sees the PLO as a movement bent on Israel's destruction and Miari as one of its representatives in the Knesset. Until his party, the governing Likud bloc, ordered him to desist, he would open each speech with the words, ``Mr. Speaker, honored members of the Knesset, excluding PLO representatives seated in this chamber....'' He says he understands Miari's motives and respects his integrity. ``But understanding and sympathy are only good as far as my front yard. When understanding and sympathy means having to give up the state of Israel, the only country I have, then it stops.'' Every Independence Day, while Israeli Jews dance in celebration of their statehood, Miari takes his wife and children to Birweh and joins the rest of the villagers in paying respects to the place they still call home. ``For 2,000 years the Jews remembered Jerusalem and the land,'' he says. ``So why should the Arabs forget after 40 years?''

DOC.HEAD: Is the Big Town Still a Union Town?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: There are still more labor union members in New York City than anywhere else, but whether it is still a ``union town'' in the traditional sense is critical to the unions striking the Daily News. Despite a steady decline in the power of non-municipal labor unions over the past 30 years, the battle over the newspaper has provided evidence of labor's continuing clout: - Many newsstand dealers said they were not selling the Daily News because of threats from men who followed delivery trucks around the city. - Two municipal unions barred a Daily News editor from covering a news conference Monday at which the unions announced they were breaking off contract talks with the city. - Union leaders announced plans for a boycott against Daily News advertisers. - In an ad in the Daily News, a Manhattan car dealer said: ``Attention Union Members. Extra Deep Discount Savings. Just Show Us Your Union Card.'' But what, really, is a union town? Union leader Don Owen summed it up by telling of a day in his childhood when his mother stopped him from crossing a picket line in front of a store. ``She said, `We can't go in there.' She explained the whole thing to me, and that was it - we didn't go until the strike was over,'' he said. But today, ``people are not familiar with that scenario any more. Everybody's just out for themselves,'' says Owen, now a vice president of the Amalgamated Transit union. Union drivers struck Greyhound eight months ago, but riders are still buying tickets and the buses roll with permanent nonunion replacements. Eastern Airlines continues to operate in the second year of a machinists strike. ``You give people half fare and they'll get on the damn plane if they see a wing hanging off,'' Owen said. Esther Fuchs, a political science professor at Barnard College, says that although unions remain part of the city's political fabric, ``there are no union towns any more.'' ``I would guess that the public is not going to be particularly distressed that the Daily News is considered to be anti-union in this particular dispute,'' she said. Theodore Kheel, adviser to the newspaper unions, conceded that, unlike 40 years ago, crossing a picket line is no longer anathema. ``There is less support today for unions,'' Kheel said. The News said in Tuesday's editions that 45 of the 350 Newspaper Guild members in its editorial department returned to work Monday. Only nine of the paper's 10 unions are on strike; members of the Typographical Union have continued working because they have guaranteed lifetime jobs. But Kheel said the wounds inflicted by the Daily News on its workers are so raw that old-fashioned union solidarity will make the boycott work. ``One and a half million union people in the city, with an average of three people per family - four and a half million people with union connections - and there will be an impact,'' Kheel asserted. He said the Reagan administration's crushing of the air traffic controllers' strike in 1981 emboldened employers to take on unions. Today's unionists come less and less from the ranks of blue-collar factory workers, labor militants who also happened to be the core of the Daily News' 2.4 million daily circulation of four decades ago. Since World War II, New York City has lost two-thirds of a million factory jobs - more than Detroit had when it was the world capital of car manufacturing. There still are a third of a million manufacturing jobs in the city but they continued to bleed away. ``The areas of decline were heavily union and, except for the public sector, the growth industries have been largely nonunion in the 1980s,'' said Samuel Ehrenhalt, regional director of the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. ``The environment in which unions operate has changed,'' Ehrenhalt said. ``Both the economic environment and the political and social environment. We've seen people ready to disregard strikes, as in the case of the airlines. Unions have been on the defensive.'' In the United States, union membership is about 60 percent in private employ and 40 percent public, opposite to the balance in New York City, said Leo Troy, an economics professor at Rutgers University. ``New York City is clearly still a union town, but now predominantly public sector rather than private,'' Troy said. ``It's a union town because the politicians are in bed with the unions.''

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Muscular Dystrophy Treatment Strengthens Muscle, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: An experimental treatment strengthened a foot muscle in three muscular dystrophy patients, raising hopes of countering the disabling weakness produced by the disease, a study says. Scientists had injected about 8 million immature muscle cells called myoblasts into the muscle that raises the big toe. The result in the first three patients treated is ``very exciting news,'' said Peter Law of the University of Tennessee-Memphis. Results are not yet available for eight later patients, he said. Scientists hope the technique will let them overcome progressive muscle weakness and wasting caused by Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the most common and devastating childhood form of dystrophy. Duchenne, which strikes boys almost exclusively, usually appears between ages 3 and 5. Progressive weakness forces most patients to use wheelchairs by age 12, and few survive beyond their early 20s. The disease, caused by a defective gene, strikes once in every 3,500 male births. Law discussed his results in a telephone interview before participating in a news conference Tuesday at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in St. Louis. He cautioned that the experimental treatment needs more study before it could be considered for general use. Dr. Leon Charash, chairman of the Muscular Dystrophy Association's medical advisory committee, called the result ``a very important preliminary finding.'' It is the first report of increased strength from the technique, and ``that's of course what we've all been waiting for,'' he said. But Charash stressed that the result must be duplicated in larger muscles and that scientists must find out whether the improvement will endure. His association helped pay for the research. Researchers in part chose the foot muscle in case anything went wrong and the muscle had to be removed, Law said. Animal studies suggest that some injected myoblasts merge to form new, healthy muscle fibers, while others fuse to the patient's ailing muscle cells and introduce a full complement of genes. That stops muscle degeneration by replacing the defective gene that causes Duchenne dystrophy, Law said. Myoblasts for the first boy injected were taken from his adoptive father, while the two other boys received myoblasts from their brothers. The three boys took the drug cyclosporine to keep their bodies from rejecting the myoblasts. Three months after injection, the treated muscles in the three boys had strengthened by 18 percent, just over 30 percent and about 80 percent, Law said. The 80 percent gain probably reflects the fact that this boy was weakest to begin with, Law said. Cyclosporine was stopped three months after injection. At six months after injection, the muscles showed some additional gain in strength, Law said. ``The muscle function continues to improve, indicating that the cells are not dying, are not being rejected. So this is very important,'' he said. The eight other patients in the study are continuing on cyclosporine as researchers look for strength improvements six and nine months after injection, he said. No patient has shown side effects from the treatment, Law said. In perhaps three months, Law said, he hopes to start another study in which about 1 billion myoblasts would be injected into major leg muscles. If that is effective, it might help patients walk, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Agency Checking Whether It Was Involved
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration says it is investigating whether one of its undercover couriers may have unknowingly carried the bomb that blew up Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland. The December 1988 bombing, which killed 270 people aboard the plane and in the village of Lockerbie, has been attributed by law enforcement authorities to a pro-Iranian terrorist group. Investigators said the terrorist group put plastic explosive in a tape recorder in baggage that was shipped from Frankfurt, Germany.
