NBC News, which first reported the new DEA investigation Tuesday night, said it had learned that Pan Am's flights from Frankfurt had been used in a Cyprus-based undercover operation to fly informants and suitcases of heroin from the Middle East to Detroit. Nazir Khalid Jafaar, 20, of Detroit, was killed in the bombing. The network said part of the drug agency review was to determine whether he had been enlisted in the drug operation and whether he had been tricked into carrying the bomb. The drug agency and German authorities had arranged for Pan American World Airways' baggage operation in Frankfurt to be used to put suitcases of heroin on planes, apparently without the usual security checks, NBC News said. It cited an unidentified ``airline source.'' In a statement late Tuesday, the DEA said it was aware of ``allegations made to the media'' that an agency operation was involved in the bombing. ``Although no evidence has surfaced to substantiate such a claim, we are conducting an inquiry into these allegations, including a review of case files and DEA operations and activities in the relevant time period,'' the statement said. Spokesman Frank Shults said the agency hoped to know where it stands at about the end of this week. A presidential commission on air terrorism reported in May it found no evidence of any involvement by the DEA with the bombing. Rep. James Traficant, D-Ohio, said last November he had received an insurance investigator's report that convinced him the Central Intelligence Agency had been tipped an attack might be made on the plane. The report, he asserted, contended that the CIA was ``covering up a drug run'' between Frankfurt and New York - something the CIA immediately characterized as ``ridiculous.'' Pan Am subpoenaed documents from the DEA and five other agencies in an effort to prove that security agencies had received warnings about the bombings. The judge in the victims' lawsuit against the airline reviewed documents produced by those agencies, but found no basis for turning them over to Pan Am, said Steven Pounian, a lawyer representing victim families in the case in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn, N.Y. Pounian declined to comment on Tuesday's announcement by the drug agency. Pamela Hanlon, spokeswoman for the airline in New York, also declined to comment. The terrorist group, according to law enforcement agencies, was retaliating for the accidental shooting down of an Iranian airliner over the Persian Gulf the previous summer by a U.S. warship.

DOC.HEAD: Breathing Easier Will Prove Costly
With PM-Garage Doors and More, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Air may be free, but it will cost almost everyone to make sure it's clean. The newly passed clean air bill, aimed at ridding the nation of much of its atmospheric pollution over the next decade, is expected to carry an eventual price tag of more than $22 billion a year to the economy. And if you drive a car, use electricity or buy hair spray, you will help pay the bill. Businesses from mortuaries to bakeries will be affected and may pass on their costs to customers or reduce their profits. President Bush is expected to sign the measure, which will usher in new pollution control requirements on factories, refineries, electric utilities and automakers. The estimates on how much the anti-pollution law will cost have ranged widely. The White House puts the bill at $10 billion a year by 1995 and anywhere from $22 billion to $25 billion a year by 2005. Some industry estimates have ranged at more than $60 billion a year. ``Americans will see continued progress to improve the nation's air quality. But they also will pay the price,'' said William Fay, who headed industry's lobbying efforts against the bill. The measure cleared Congress easily last weekend. The economy already spends an estimated $32 billion a year on air pollution controls, the Environmental Protection Agency estimates. Many in industry and government say that amount easily could double. But environmentalists argue the industry figures are highly inflated and even the more conservative government estimates may not take into account future cost savings by the adoption of new technologies and business ingenuity. ``History demonstrates that once a law is passed, people find a less expensive way to comply with it,'' says Richard Ayres, executive director of the Clean Air Coalition, the environmental umbrella group that campaigned for a strong bill for more than a year. When all of the new requirements are in place, the typical household likely will pay less for the improved air quality than it does for going to the movies, said Ayres. He cited a study that estimated the cost at about $20 per household a month by the year 2005, less than what the typical family pays on movies, tobacco products or alcoholic beverages. While the extent of the new costs may be hard to pin down, the fact that cleaner air will be more expensive is certain. Automakers say new equipment to comply with tougher tailpipe emission standards will add $500 or more to the price of a car and make some vehicles difficult to engineer so they meet the new requirements. Others put the added cost of a car at closer to $130 per vehicle, and note that is less than the cost of many popular options such as a stereo radio. Gasoline prices also are expected to increase because refineries will have to produce cleaner-burning fuel. The new gasoline blends, which will be required in cities with the worst smog and account for one-fourth of all the gasoline sold, may cost motorists several pennies to a dime more a gallon. The cost of cutting acid rain pollutants from coal-burning power plants will total $5 billion to $7 billion a year, with consumers in Midwestern states absorbing most of that burden, the utility industry says. ``We estimated it will cost us approximately $700 million a year from 1995 to 2004'' to comply with the new acid rain control measures, said Luke Feck, a spokesman for American Electric Power. The utility holding company provides customers with electricity in Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Kentucky, Tennessee and West Virginia. Feck said rates for AEP customers will go up an average 13 to 15 percent, but for some - such as those provided electricity from Ohio Power, whose plants are among the dirtiest - the increase could be as much as 30 percent. Most of the utilities with dirty plants will be forced to either switch from high-sulfur coal to a more expensive fuel or install ``scrubbers'' that can cost $100 million apiece. New curbs on industrial emissions - both toxic chemicals and smog-causing pollutants - will be costly to small businesses as well as huge petrochemical plants, forcing higher prices on everything from plastic toys to car repainting and dry-cleaning a dress. Some consumer items - such as hair spray or deodorant - may become more expensive because of new requirements phasing out not only environmentally damaging chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, but also some of their less damaging substitutes. Motorists will find that automobile air conditioner coolants such as Freon, a CFC, will no longer be available over the counter.

DOC.HEAD: A First: `Chunnel' Links England to Continent
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Workmen tunneling under the English Channel have created the first land link between Britain and the Continent, connecting 31 miles of tunnel in a prodigious feat of engineering and finance. TransManche Link, the construction consortium building the ``Chunnel'' said the historic linkup occurred at 8:25 p.m. Tuesday when British workers sent a probe 2 inches in diameter through to their French colleagues. Linking England and France, the tunnel symbolizes the growing unification of Europe. It also fulfills a dream of Napoleon, who wanted to send his armies through the tunnel to conquer Britain. Eurotunnel PLC, the Anglo-French consortium overseeing the world's largest engineering project, plans for high-speed trains to pass through the Channel Tunnel in June 1993. Eventually a train trip from Paris to London should take three hours. Despite her countrymen's fears of losing their ancient moat against Europe, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher described the breakthrough as ``a very exciting moment.'' ``It is an example of what Europe is about,'' she said in London. ``This is Europe in practice.'' In London, the conservative Daily Express newspaper noted today that Britons will be able to walk to France for the first time since the Ice Age. ``This is a hugely historic moment because it means, in effect, that Britain is no longer an island,'' a construction union official in Calais said. Threading a spinning probe the width of a garden hose through 100 yards of chalk under the Channel bears the first tangible fruit in three years of drilling. Champagne corks popped and workers danced jigs after French drillers phoned news of the probe's arrival to their British counterparts. Initial tests indicated the two halves were 20 inches out of alignment. Technicians will be more certain Wednesday, but they called the rough line-up ``exceptional.'' The workers will now bore out a one-yard hole. Tunnelers are expected to walk through and greet each other with handshakes in a few weeks. The tunneling machine on the French side will then guide itself by laser toward the British machine, ensuring perfect alignment. Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand will meet mid-tunnel on Jan. 26. The linkup came on the maintenance tunnel, the smallest of three tunnels being dug. The other two will handle rail traffic - freight and special piggy-back trains that will carry passengers and cars. About 80 percent of all the drilling is now complete. Eight workers suffered injures, two seriously, about 90 minutes after Tuesday's linkup when a tractor rolled over on them in a service gallery, authorities in nearby Sangatte reported. Since the tunnel construction began in 1987 there have been seven accidental deaths on the British side and two on the French side. The tunnel's cost has soared from an initial estimate of $9.4 billion to $16.7 billion, including an extra $1.97 billion in case of unforeseen cost overruns. The digging is accomplished by gargantuan boring machines that bring to mind images from Japanese monster movies. Each resembles a gnawing worm, some three-stories high, with a spinning drill of hundreds of blades. Mechanical legs slap together the concrete tunnel lining in the wake of the advancing drill head. Whhen its work is done, the drilling machine on the French side will be hauled out in pieces. The one on the British side will dig a side passage, and be buried in cement. Officials say it is too costly to extricate the machine. The tunnels were joined 13{ miles southeast of Folkestone, England, the British terminus near Dover, and 10 miles northwest of Sangatte, near Calais. The tunnel starts a few miles inland on each side, accounting for its total length of 31 miles. Militant workers on the French side are striking for more pay and began a work slowdown Thursday, threatening to stall the link-up. But it came off on schedule. Eurotunnel PLC announced Oct. 8 that it had reached an agreement with its banks on $3.5 billion in new credit. More than 200 banks are involved in financing the world's costliest tunnel. The three-hour Paris-to-London trip would be comparable to flying, if transport to and from airports is included, and is half the time of the present car-ferry journey. Officials estimate the tunnel trains may carry 28 million passengers in the first year of operation. Eurotunnel doesn't expect a profit until the end of the century. France hopes the project will revitalize depressed northern regions. But many Britons fear an influx of continental ills ranging from terrorists to rabid animals. Britain warned Napoleon not to try to build the tunnel; digging was started subsequently in 1882 and 1974, but both efforts failed.

DOC.HEAD: `Citizens for a Free Kuwait' Spreads Word of Its Country's Plight
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: It's autumn in the nation's capital, but Fatima, a 32-year-old Kuwaiti educator, is still wearing the thin cotton outfits she had when she wound up stranded in the United States three months ago. She had left her husband and 16-year-old daughter at home so she could attend a conference at the University of Connecticut in July, shortly before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. She hasn't seen her family since. Depressed and alone, Fatima spends her days trying to spread the word about what is happening inside her country. At night, she sleeps in a rented one-room apartment. She asked that her last name not be used for fear that her family in Kuwait could be harmed. Fatima - and several dozen other Kuwaitis - work as volunteers at the headquarters of Citizens for a Free Kuwait, a non-profit group established to draw attention to Kuwait. The volunteers cling to each other as if they were family, anxiously awaiting news from inside their country. The group is financed in part by the Kuwait government-in-exile. It has hired the public relations firm of Hill & Knowlton to help publicize the country's plight. Kuwait's leaders are living in Saudi Arabia and its embassies around the world are still functioning. Kuwait is financing its projects and giving stipends to stranded citizens with money from its overseas investments. ``We are undertaking a public education campaign trying to explain what is happening to Kuwait, emphasizing the human tragedy,'' said Dr. Hassan Al-Ebraheem, the group's president. Al-Ebraheem, a professor at Kuwait University, was on vacation at the time of the invasion. Al-Ebraheem said the group has received ``tremendous support'' from Americans. People in the Midwest seem to be particularly eager to learn about Kuwait, he said. He was pleased that Secretary of State James A. Baker III highlighted Kuwait's situation in a speech in Los Angeles this week. ``It is a story of barbarism in its most crude and evil form, the rape of Kuwait,'' Baker said. He gave details of Iraqi soldiers shooting two Kuwaiti children. Citizens for a Free Kuwait has opened its main U.S. office in a building several miles from the White House. The furnishings are austere; few pictures are on the walls, and paper Kuwaiti flags serve as decorations. For most of the volunteers, the office has become their home away from home. All told, about 3,000 Kuwaitis are stranded in the United States, roughly half of them students. While most of the volunteers are Kuwaiti citizens, some are Americans, such as Stephanie McGehee, 37, of San Diego. McGehee worked in Kuwait for several years as a photographer and was there when Iraq invaded. She wrote about her dramatic Aug. 17 escape from the country for The Associated Press. McGehee said her work for the Kuwaiti group ``takes up about 24 hours a day.'' She and others arrange visits to college campuses, set up seminars nd plan publicity events. The group has reached supporters in many states in an effort to persuade local governments to pass resolutions supporting Kuwait. The group has scheduled prayer vigils in the nation's capital, Los Angeles and San Francisco on Friday. Al-Ebraheem said he and others hope for a peaceful solution to the situation in Kuwait, but he added that military action might be the only course. ``Nobody actually favors violence or bloodshed,'' he said. ``But all diplomatic efforts have been shut out. The news is very negative.''

DOC.HEAD: Chiles and Daughter Hold Different Views on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Lawton Chiles' daughter wept when he took a pro-choice stand on abortion during a televised debate in the Florida governor's race. ``I was watching my dad, being so proud of him,'' said Rhea Chiles-MacKinnon. ``When he said he would veto any legislation that would restrict abortion my heart fell. I was so overwhelmed I began to cry.'' That's because she's steadfast in her conviction that abortion is murder. So is her husband, Alex. ``We can't rationalize it. We can't turn our cheek and look the other way,'' said Chiles' adopted 24-year-old daughter. ``It's not a spiritual issue. It's not a Catholic issue. It's not a matter of personal choice. It's a human rights issue. Abortion is inhumane.'' The Democratic candidate first broached the issue during a primary debate in September when challenged for a stand by party rival Bill Nelson. He beat Nelson handily and is in a neck-and-neck race with Gov. Bob Martinez. During his 18 years in the U.S. Senate, Chiles supported abortion only in the case of rape, incest or danger to the life of the mother. He voted for a constitutional amendment to overturn the U.S. Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. Like pro-life candidate Martinez, he is personally opposed to abotion. But Chiles says he would veto any attempt to change Florida's abortion law because it would violate the state's guaranteed right to privacy. A decision whether to obtain an abortion is ``uniquely personal to each woman,'' Chiles says, and ``government should not interfere with this personal right.'' Martinez called a special session in 1989 in an unsuccessful bid to restrict access to abortion and regulate abortion clinics. Mrs. Chiles-MacKinnon wrote to Martinez at the time, calling abortion cruel and violent. ``I thanked him for standing up for what's right, for standing on his convictions.'' Her personal stand was known long before abortion became an issue in the governor's race. An article she wrote explaining her opposition was published in The Tampa Tribune in May, and three pro-life feminist guest columns have appeared in the Oracle, the University of South Florida student newspaper. Now that her views have been thrust into the campaign, it has created an emotional tug-of-war for her. ``I love my dad,'' she said, noting their similarities on a key point - education and counseling to end abortion. Chiles has said he respects his daughter's right to her own opinion and agrees there is a common ground for them. During her pregnancy Mrs. Chiles-MacKinnon began to wonder about her natural mother. She began a search for the woman who at 16 gave birth to her and gave her up under pressure from her family. She found her mother and they have since become friends. ``I was so grateful to the one who gave me life I wanted to find her so she would know it and know what a wonderful life I have,'' said Mrs. Chiles-MacKinnon. Abortion at that time was illegal but available. ``If it weren't for her choosing life for me, I wouldn't be here today standing up for the lives of unborn children who don't have a choice.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Increasing Stake in U.S. Agribusiness, Farmland
DOC.TEXT: Japan has increased its investment in the U.S. food system but still is a long way from taking over the nation's farms and agribusiness network, an Agriculture Department analyst says. For example, Japanese investors last year bought about $456 million worth of U.S. farmland, compared with $289 million spent in 1988. Before that, the biggest single-year Japanese investment in U.S. farmland was $22 million in 1982, said Christine Bolling of the department's Economic Research Service. Overall, about $1 billion worth of farmland - that agency researchers are aware of - has been bought with Japanese money, sometimes in joint ventures with U.S. companies. Also Japanese investors have spend an additional $5 billion to buy or invest in agriculturally related businesses. Bolling, whose study was reported in the November issue of Farmline magazine, said the joint ventures with partial ownership mask the overall presence of Japanese ownership. According to Commerce Department figures, total foreign investment in the U.S. agribusiness sector is about $30 billion, with an additional $10 billion in agricultural land. Thus, the $6 billion Japan has in farmland and related industries represents about a 15 percent share of the $40 billion foreign total. ``The U.S. agribusiness complex is so huge that foreign properties are a small part of the whole complex,'' Bolling said. Japan is not the largest foreign investor in American agriculture and agribusiness, she said. But it does appear to be grow faster than some of the traditional leading investors, including the United Kingdom. ``While some are concerned about increasing Japanese investment in U.S., agribusiness, there should be no more concern than that over British, Canadian or other foreign investment in the agribusiness sector,'' Bolling said. Among the largest Japanese holdings are a 77,000-acre cattle ranch in Montana, a 25,000-acre citrus grove in Florida, and a 1,000-acre prune orchard in northern California. In food processing, Bolling said, Japanese investors own the second-largest vinegar company in the United States, several food processing plants and a company that controls 60 percent of the bread-baking industry in Hawaii. Japanese are also involved in California wines, bottled water and soft drinks, Alaskan fish processing, textile mills and feed additives and grain storage. Bolling said they also hold a major interest in the 7-Eleven chain of convenience stores. ``In some cases, Japanese investments in U.S. agribusiness are part of a vertically integrated industry, where the products are shipped to Japan,'' she said. ``Such situations have developed in the citrus, prune and beef industries.'' For example, Bolling said, Japan not only has bought a Montana cattle ranch but also feedlots, and beef-processing plants in Washington and California. She said joint ventures in feedlots have been established in California, Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Nebraska, Nevada, Pennsylvania, Texas and Wyoming. Altogether, Bolling said, beef shipments originating from these cattle operations represent 15 percent to 20 percent of the U.S. beef exports to Japan. The Japanese investment in U.S. agribusiness is ``part of a global phenomenon of market integration,'' she said. ``It also fits in with Japan's situation in that it is an affluent but food-deficit country that sets high standards for the food it imports and consumes.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - About 330,000 farmers participating in the long-term Conservation Reserve Program soon will be getting $1.6 billion in rental payments for taking cropland from production, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says. The payments are for the 1991 fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Yeutter said Tuesday the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service will notify county offices to begin payments immediately ``without any further delay.'' During the recent budget-cutting maneuvers, it appeared the payments would be delayed or even reduced. But Yeutter said full cash payments will be made to cover contracts signed to place cropland in the program during crop years 1986 through 1990. Under the program, farmers agree to idle highly erodible cropland for 10 years. In return, the government helps pay the cost of establishing protective grass or trees, and provides annual rental payments for the land taken from production. The payments average nearly $50 per acre annually. Approximately 33.9 million acres have been signed up in the program. Yeutter's announcement was hailed by Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, as ``good news for farmers who need to pay bills for this year's operations and to make plans for next year.'' De la Garza said the conservation program ``continues to play a very important role'' in helping protect the environment. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Preliminary results show a new triple-whammy beetle bait shows promise against corn rootworm beetles, according to the Agriculture Department. Besides a small amount of lethal insecticide, the bait contains a compound that attracts the beetles, and a feeding stimulant that makes them eat more - a fatal last meal. Officials said the bait was spread on more than 1,000 acres of corn in South Dakota, Nebraska, Illinois, Iowa and Indiana in August. Gerald R. Sutter of the department's Agricultural Research Service in Brookings, S.D., said Tuesday in a report issued here that if the new bait works, corn farmers ``could dramatically cut insecticide use.'' The bait contains only about 2 percent of the insecticide normally used in sprays against the adult beetles, he said. Sutter said the preliminary results show the bait reduced beetle populations in the corn. Next spring will show whether the reduction was enough to significantly lower the beetles' egg laying for a new hatch.

DOC.HEAD: Two Incumbents Have More Campaign Cash Than 331 Challengers
With PM-Last-Minute Money
DOC.TEXT: The two House members with the biggest campaign bank accounts entered the final five weeks of the 1990 election season with more money than all 331 House challengers combined, according to a new survey. The review of the latest Federal Election Commission filings in House races underscores the huge fund-raising advantages enjoyed by incumbents. For example, the 406 House incumbents seeking re-election entered the final stretch of the campaign with $97 million to spend, 29 times more than the $3.3 million held by challengers. Seven of the 406 incumbents had at least $1 million in their campaign accounts as of Sept. 30, according to the survey by Common Cause, a citizens group that advocates public financing of election campaigns. The two incumbents with the biggest war chests - Democratic Reps. Mel Levine of California and Stephen Solarz of New York - had more cash on hand than all 331 challengers combined. Levine reported a balance of $1.7 million, while Solarz had $1.65 million. Not far behind were Reps. David Dreier, R-Calif., and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., who reported campaign balances of $1.6 million and $1.4 million, respectively. Reps. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., Robert Matsui, D-Calif., and James Quillen, R-Tenn., each had $1 million on hand as of Sept. 30. In all, House incumbents have had $204 million to spend on 1990 elections, including $146 million raised since 1988 elections and $58 million left over in campaign accounts, Common Cause said. That total is nine times more than the $24 million raised by challengers, the survey found. Common Cause, which is seeking new restrictions on political action committee donations, said House incumbents had reaped nearly $70 million in PAC money in 1989 and the first nine months of 1990. Challengers received just $3.7 million from PACs in that period. The hefty fund-raising edge allows incumbents to easily outspend their opponents. House incumbents spent $96.9 million from Jan. 1, 1989, through Sept. 30, nearly five times the $20 million spent by challengers. ``The extraordinary campaign finance advantage that House incumbents have over their challengers is corrupting our political process to the point where we won't have real elections for the House of Representatives in 1990,'' Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer said in a statement released with the organization's latest campaign finance survey. Common Cause said there were only 29 House races in which the challenger had raised at least half as much as the incumbent; in eight of those races the challengers had raised more.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion, Realty, Gun Control Forces Lead Independent Spending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note words in 21st graf, `I won't ... Japs,' may be offensive
DOC.TEXT: When the cost of the Senate race in North Carolina between Jesse Helms and Harvey Gantt is tallied it will be easy to forget the $220.72 spent on paper and envelopes in faraway Iowa. Neither candidate is shopping out of state. The supplies were for a conservative group's mailing criticizing Democrat Gantt. The spending is just a tiny slice of the millions special interest groups are pouring into targeted races as the 1990 campaign draws to a close. The money, not subject to contribution limits because it never enters campaign treasuries, is coming from such diverse groups as the Realtors political action committee, abortion rights groups, anti-abortion forces, environmentalists and a PAC representing dealers of Japanese-made cars. Entering the final week of the campaign, special interests had reported spending roughly $4 million on independent expenditures to influence congressional campaigns. In 1988, about $7.2 million in independent expenditures on congressional races was reported. This year, the matchup between Helms, a three-term GOP incumbent, and Gantt is a favorite target, drawing money from labor, conservative and gay-rights groups as well as both sides of the abortion debate. The National Abortion Rights Action League, for example, has spent $200,000 on radio, television and other ads attacking Helms' anti-abortion stance, according to Federal Election Commission records. Other major races targeted by NARAL for large independent spending include the Iowa Senate race between Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin and Republican Rep. Tom Tauke, the Florida governor's race and House contests in Oregon and Florida. NARAL and its Iowa affiliate reported spending more than $93,000 in September and October to support Harkin, and $3,000 to oppose Tauke. Its federal filings show nearly $80,000 has been spent to oppose the re-election of Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, a staunch abortion foe. Most of NARAL's spending on that state race does not have to be reported to the FEC. NARAL's spending in the past two weeks also has included $25,000 and $1,800 to oppose the re-election of Republican Reps. Denny Smith of Oregon and Craig James of Florida, respectively. Not surprisingly, anti-abortion groups also are involved in many of the same contests. The National Right to Life PAC has paid for mailings to support eight candidates, including Helms, Smith and James. Several Right to Life state PACs also mounted modest independent spending campaigns in recent weeks. A handful of conservative groups have spent a combined $100,000 on independent expenditures in the past four months. They were led by the Conservative Republican Committee, which reported $77,500 in independent spending - $28,000 of that supporting Helms. Much of the spending by the conservative groups has been for telephone banks, mailings and radio ads opposing liberal Democratic senators. The National Education Association's PAC reported spending $100,000 to support Gantt. A gay-rights group and a PAC representing social workers reported far more modest efforts on Gantt's behalf, and a North Carolina PAC formed to oppose Helms reported spending $15,000 on radio ads attacking the conservative Republican. The biggest spender so far is the Realtors PAC, which as of last week reported making $802,500 in independent expenditures on a dozen races. The Realtors spent $168,000 and $108,000 to support the Senate bids of Republican Reps. Hank Brown of Colorado and Larry Craig of Idaho, respectively. The Realtors also spent heavily to support freshmen House members Peter Hoagland, D-Neb., $70,000; Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, R-Fla., $70,000; and Ben Jones, D-Ga., $93,500. And it spent nearly $73,000 to support Republican Rep. Jack Buechner of Missouri, who is seeking a third term. The most controversial spending has been the more than $340,000 spent by the Auto Dealers & Drivers for Free Trade PAC to support the Senate candidacy of New Hampshire Republican Rep. Bob Smith. The PAC is running television ads supporting Smith, leading Democratic challenger John Durkin to protest that the organization is trying to buy his opponent. ``I won't sell out to the Japs,'' Durkin said last week in criticizing the PAC, whose members sell Japanese-made cars. Durkin has made an issue of the spending. Smith's camp has criticized Durkin's use of the word ``Japs.'' The Realtors also reported spending $54,600 to support Smith.

DOC.HEAD: British Police Guilty of Bias Against Indian-Born Constable
DOC.TEXT: In the first ruling of its kind in Britain, an industrial tribunal has found that a British policeman of Indian origin suffered racial discrimination from fellow police officers. Constable Surinder Chima Singh, 33, had complained he was barred from joining the Criminal Investigation Department of the Nottinghamshire county police force in 1987 because of his race. The tribunal is empowered to order the force to compensate Singh and will hear more evidence before ruling on his claim for damages. The tribunal's chairman, Christopher Tickle, said during Tuesday's hearing in the central British city of Nottingham that Singh had as he claimed been the butt of racist language. Tickle said that Singh's race had caused him to be treated less favorably than other officers who applied to join the investigation department. Singh, from Nottingham, was born in India but grew up in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire. He received a chemistry degree from Lancaster University before joining the Nottinghamshire force in 1981. Earlier this year, police launched a nationwide drive to recruit from racial minority groups, mostly blacks from the West Indies and people from the Indian subcontinent. Ethnic minority groups comprise 3.9 percent of the economically active working-age population in Britain and 10 percent in London. Police figures published at the beginning of this year showed 1 percent of police officers in England and Wales and about 1.5 percent of police in London's metropolitan force are from racial minorities. Industrial tribunals operate Britain's main judicial system, hearing disputes between employees and employers, mainly cases where unfair dismissal is alleged. They cannot force an employer to take back a fired worer or five the worker the job to which he claims he's entitled.

DOC.HEAD: Butterfly Town USA to Decide Preservation of Namesake Insect
DOC.TEXT: Voters in this city dubbed ``Butterfly Town USA'' decide next Tuesday whether to float a $1.2 million bond issue to protect a grove of pines and eucalyptus trees where monarchs - and tourists - gather. Developers and property rights groups oppose the measure, which calls for $1.2 million in borrowing to buy and set aside a 2.7-acre butterfly habitat. Butterfly fanciers insist that protecting the privately owned Diveley Grove is vital to saving the species in this part of the country. ``If we don't preserve this grove, 10 to 20 years from now the butterflies will be in trouble,'' said Ro Vaccaro, member of the Friends of the Monarch. ``They're running out of wintering sites. And they need a very specific climate with the perfect humidity, temperatures and trees. ``I just can't image Butterfly Town USA without butterflies.'' If the bond issue wins the required two-thirds vote, property taxes would rise 1.5 cents per $100 of assessed valuation - about $15 a year on a $100,000 home. Butterflies have long held a special place in the lives of the 16,000 residents of this seaside town 105 miles south of San Francisco. On the second Saturday of each October, children dress up as butterflies and march through town, spreading colorful wings to usher in the fall butterfly season. The grove of Monterey pine and eucalyptus trees is one of the few remaining wintering grounds in the Western United States for the orange and black butterflies. In the 1940s, as many as 2 million monarchs flew south from Canada to winter in Pacific Grove, compared to tens of thousands now. Monarchs east of the Rockies winter near the Gulf of Mexico, where their habitat is also dwindling as trees are cut. Some residents, including Steven Magyar, say the bond issue tramples on property rights. The City Council put the measure on the ballot after wavering on whether to allow development of the land. ``If somebody wants to develop their property, they should be able to. The butterflies will still hang around,'' Magyar said. ``Everybody's in favor of remaining the butterfly capital, but butterflies aren't the end-all, be-all.'' ``I hope the bond passes because I want to see the butterflies stay here,'' said 81-year-old Edna Milar Diveley, who owns the grove. ``But they're going to have to rehabilitate the grove. There aren't enough lower and middle branches on the trees to keep the butterflies happy.'' Mrs. Diveley retired and sold a motel adjacent to the property, the Butterfly Grove Inn, some 25 years ago, but in 1988 she decided to sell or develop the Diveley Grove. The City Council approved her plan to build housing units with a one-acre buffer zone for the tree grove. But public outcry prompted city leaders to put on the ballot the issue of whether to buy and set aside the entire property.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Deal Hits Northeast Hard
DOC.TEXT: Taxpayers in the Northeast would be hit harder than any other region in the country under the deficit-reduction package awaiting President Bush's signature, a non-profit group says. Of the 10 states facing the highest tax increases, five are in the Northeast, the Tax Foundation said Tuesday. These same five states - Connecticut, New Jersey, New York, Massachusetts and New Hampshire - already pay among the highest federal taxes in the nation on a per capita basis. And the increases come at a time when these states are limping through a recession. ``They're getting hit harder because the new budget package is more heavily weighed to high-income earners,'' said Paul Merski, the non-profit Tax Foundation's director of fiscal affairs. ``About 45 percent of the tax increases for the new package are for high-income earners.'' Many lawmakers from the Northeast supported the deficit-reduction package even though it hit their districts harder. Democrats, in particular, were anxious to position themselves in favor of higher taxes on the wealthy, even if those wealthy were their own constituents. Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., said Tuesday there was no irony in the voting pattern. ``If the state is wealthier than another state and you get hurt that's what you have to expect if you favor progressive taxation,'' Frank said. ``If the state pays more as a result of being a higher-income state, I don't regret that at all.'' The high tax burdens of the five northeastern states reflect their populations, which include the New York commuter-executives of suburban New Jersey and Connecticut; the Park Avenue elite; the insurance industry executives of Hartford, Conn.; highly skilled and highly paid defense workers in Connecticut; and high-tech industry executives and workers in Massachusetts and New Hampshire. Connecticut residents, on average, will bear the largest burden in the nation and the largest dollar increase. The tax increases will cost the average Connecticut resident $174 for one year. That compares to a national average of $133. The Massachusetts delegation voted 9-2 against the original budget summit agreement that was rejected by the House Oct. 5. That plan would have raised all federal taxes on Massachusetts residents by an average $100, according to the Tax Foundation. Less than a month later, the Massachusetts delegation voted 10-1 in favor of the deficit reduction plan approved by Congress. It raises taxes for Massachusetts resident by an average $158, the fourth highest in the nation. Frank noted the original budget summit agreement included many items that would have hit poor and middle-class northeasterners in the wallet, including a higher gasoline tax and a tax on home heating oil. The New York state delegation voted 18-16 against that budget agreement, which would have cost each New Yorker an extra $91. Last weekend the delegation voted 21-12, with one absent, for the new budget package that will cost their constituents an average $145 in higher taxes. New Jersey would have the second-highest per capita increase in the country under the new budget plan, at $173. New Hampshire, which ranks sixth, would absorb $149 in higher taxes per person. A number of provisions in the budget and tax package passed by Congress are intended to shift the burden to the rich. The proposal increases taxes on luxury items such as furs, jewelry and yachts, hikes the tax on airline tickets, and raises the wealthiest taxpayers from a 28 percent tax rate to a 31 percent rate. The measure also limits the deductions that wealthy taxpayers can claim and increases their share of a special hospitalization tax.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Unfamiliar with Ballot Proposition
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams stumbled when asked his position on a proposed constitutional amendment on next week's ballot that deals with appointments by the state's chief executive. In a session Tuesday with reporters at KERA-TV studios in Dallas, Williams said he was unfamiliar with the amendment, the only one on the ballot, and was unclear how he had voted on it when he cast his absentee ballot. Williams' opponent, Democrat Ann Richards, has criticized Williams, a Midland businessman, as a political amateur who doesn't understand government. Asked if his confusion did not lend credence to Richards' charges, Williams said, ``I'm not a politician.'' ``But you are running for governor,'' Slater said. ``Yeah, I can read and if you put that in front of me it would take me about 30 seconds to give you my opinion,'' Williams said. ``I had the highest grade point in the school of agriculture at (Texas) A&M my last semester.''
DOC.HEAD: Citing Earthquake Projection, Clerks Ask Delay of Dec. 4 Election
DOC.TEXT: The governor's office has turned down a request from Missouri officials to reschedule a Dec. 4 special election because of earthquake concerns. ``It's not like we're in a panic, but we thought it might ease everyone's mind if we did it another day,'' Stoddard County Clerk Don White said Tuesday from his office in Bloomfield. The election is to fill the Missouri Senate seat held by Democrat Steve Sharp of Kennett, who resigned to accept a circuit judge appointment. The Senate district is composed of Butler, Carter, Dunklin, Pemiscot, Ripley and Stoddard counties. Election Day coincides with New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning's projection for an earthquake along the New Madrid Fault, which runs from Cairo, Ill., to Marked Tree, Ark. Earthquake drills have been scheduled and schools have planned to close because of the projection, although many scientists have criticized Browning's methods and conclusions. White noted that schools double as polls across the district. ``I am, frankly, a little concerned about putting election judges in school buildings that school boards deemed it necessary to close because of safety questions. But we'll have to go ahead and have them open the buildings up,'' White said. ``If we have an earthquake - well, we'll just have problems,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say GOP Trying to Intimidate Voters
DOC.TEXT: The Republican Party in North Carolina is intimidating Democratic voters with a mail campaign, says state Democratic Chairman Lawrence Davis. State Republican officials said they were trying to ensure legal election returns. Davis said the GOP is mailing postcards to registered Democrats across the state, saying if they haven't lived in their precinct for at least the last 30 days they can't vote. ``This is an outright lie,'' Davis said. Voters who have moved from the precinct in which they are registered may go to the Board of Elections before they vote or to the precinct in which they are registered on Election Day and get transferred to the precinct in which they currently reside.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Get Chance to Shop for Christmas, Little Luxuries
With PM-Bush-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It's not exactly Neiman-Marcus, but a mail-order catalog from Dallas will allow soldiers in Saudi Arabia to play Santa Claus. With the Army and Air Force Exchange Service catalog, the 200,000 soldiers in the Persian Gulf can shop for loved ones back home without leaving their desert tents. Tens of thousands of copies of the Christmas catalog are on their way to the Middle East. ``One of the things I think most of our American troops over there are accustomed to is the ability to go in and browse in nice stores. And we want to give them that capability, every day if their duties will allow that,'' said Maj. Gen. Jeffery B. Kahla, who heads AAFES. ``Our goal is customer satisfaction, whether people are in the sands of Saudi Arabia or living in a beautiful house in Dallas, Texas.'' In addition to a mail-order service, the 95-year-old, self-supporting organization with headquarters in Dallas runs cut-rate stores on bases in the United States and around the world for members of the military and their dependents. The stores are known in Air Force slang as ``BX,'' for base exchange; in the Army, it's ``PX,'' for post exchange. Altogether, AAFES generates about $7 billion in annual sales and employs 82,000 mostly civilian employees. The AAFES set up field exchange stores within 15 days of the beginning of Operation Desert Shield, Kahla said. The 50 shops in Saudi Arabia offer soldiers candy, sodas, cigarettes, lotion and batteries - lots of batteries, mostly for cameras and personal stereos, also for sale. Shoppers also can buy socks, underwear and plastic thongs, popular for walking across the burning sand to the showers, Kahla said. The only things missing are alcohol and adult magazines, barred by the Saudis, Kahla said. Exchange sales in Saudi Arabia have reached about $3 million a month, he said. Some of the shops operated originally from the backs of trucks. Most are now in cramped tents, with shelves of wooden slats and sand or wood floors. Few as yet have air conditioning or refrigerators. And the inventory is limited to 350 items, which means, for example, that the only cassette tapes for sale are those in the Top 10. But it's still a link to home. ``It probably looks just like Neiman-Marcus to them,'' Kahla said, referring to the luxurious Dallas-based department store. About 98,000 copies of the Christmas catalog have been sent to Saudi Arabia, and an equal number are ready to be shipped. The troops' orders will be processed at AAFES in Dallas and filled from a warehouse or vendor. The Christmas catalog is available at military exchanges around the world. But orders from those stationed in the Persian Gulf will get top priority. ``We just don't want them to order something for their girlfriend or their mother and have it come back not in stock. Because they don't have another choice,'' Kahla said. The catalog includes items found in most any stateside store: model planes and tanks, puzzles, roller skates, walkie-talkies and wagons. There is the Bear Forces of America - 20-inch teddy bears wearing the uniforms of the four service branches, available in desert camouflage. There are housewares, jewelry, clothing and a grandfather clock. Soldiers can even order a personal tanner, although the idea may not have much appeal in the desert. Despite the Saudi ban on non-Moslem religious symbols, angel ornaments and creche figures are available in the catalog. ``I know that the BX is important because I've been to war. It's very important to the morale of the troops,'' Kahla said. ``It made me feel like I was a little bit back home.'' In the Gulf, AAFES also circulates hit movies, operates vending machines, manages pay phones and plans to open barber shops within about two weeks. One walk-up ``generic fast-food outlet'' has opened, with plans for four or five more. Next may be a mobile Popeye's fried chicken franchise.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Issue Pleas in Letters Smuggled Out of Kuwait and Iraq
With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: On Sept. 28, he wrote: ``Things get worse by the day.'' The Midwestern dentist is still stranded in Kuwait a month later, but his plea made it out. It is among a trickle of letters that newly released hostages have smuggled past Iraqi troops. Some are hastily scrawled on notepaper; others are typed. All offer stark, urgent views of the Persian Gulf through the eyes of those trapped when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The letters talk of daily trivia and tell tales of atrocities. They also carry the hostages' provisional attempts at proper goodbyes, postmarked in Bangladesh or Maryland or England - wherever newly freed foreigners pass their first mail slot. ``The situation here is entirely out of control,'' wrote the dentist, whose letters from Kuwait were provided on the condition he not be identified. ``I am in a `safe' house with a good friend. We are surrounded by Iraqi troops ... and there is a great deal of shooting in the area at night,'' the letter continued. ``(The Iraqis) have destroyed all forms of normalcy here. Looting, rape and sodomy and wanton destruction. ... Food stocks are almost gone and the garbage and rodent problems are increasing. ... Things here get worse by the day.'' The estimated 1,000 Americans stuck in Kuwait and Iraq are from varied backgrounds. They were in the Middle East as teachers, diplomats, oil workers, engineers and consultants. But in their letters are common themes: calls for quick and decisive American intervention, complaints about boredom and fatigue. For many hostages, time is measured by what they may be missing at home. ``Darling, the days and nights are long and boring,'' Fred F. Harrington, a Redmond, Wash., businessman held as one of Saddam Hussein's ``human shields,'' wrote to his wife. ``I do lots of reading, American and British novels. There is TV and VCR in the lounge. Breakfast is at 9 a.m., lunch at 1 p.m. and dinner at 7 p.m. Food is lousy. ... My back hurts,'' Harrington wrote in a letter dated Sept. 4. ``People here are terrified,'' a 26-year-old Kuwaiti wrote to H. Norman Angell, a friend in Bainbridge Island, Wash. ``One of my relatives was shot in front of his family after he was tortured for two months. He was 23 years old. ``Two of my cousins were taken away ... and nobody knows where they are now,'' wrote Angell's friend, whose cousin escaped and mailed the letter after reaching Germany. ``Tensions run high,'' wrote Mike Nickman, whose work on an irrigation project in Iraq was interrupted by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``They have security police sitting outside our door, waiting for one of us to leave,'' he wrote in a Sept. 4 letter smuggled out of the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad by a British woman who forwarded it to Nickman's parents in Pleaston, Neb. ``My patience is in short supply. It is easy for my temper to rise up and of course in this situation that's not very wise,'' wrote Guy Seago, a 49-year-old oil worker captured by Iraqi troops while trying to escape Kuwait. In their letters, many of the hostages mention their tempers. They are tired of listening to the Voice of America and waiting for the United States, which has deployed 220,000 soldiers, to strike. ``It has become a pretty tedious existence, but preferable to being in Baghdad or at some military installation,'' wrote the dentist, whose attorney provided copies of several letters. ``Those poor people will be killed when the shooting starts, as the Iraqis have nothing to lose.'' For American hostages and their families, the loss could be enormous. ``You have given me great joy,'' Joseph Murphy, a 63-year-old teacher wrote to his daughter in Fremont, Calif., from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``Be smart and strong and brave, my darling. You have a great life ahead of you,'' he wrote. ``I love you.''

DOC.HEAD: PLO Urges Arab Countries To Drop Effort To Expel Israel From General Assembly
DOC.TEXT: In a major policy change, the Palestine Liberation Organization is urging Arab countries to halt their 8-year-old effort to expel Israel from the U.N. General Assembly. The move is a gesture of moderation by an increasingly isolated PLO, which has lost some Arab support for siding with Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis and saw its dialogue with Washington cut off earlier this year over a PLO faction's attack on an Israeli beach. In a private meeting of Arab ambassadors on Tuesday, Palestinian and other Arab diplomats said PLO head envoy Nasser al-Kidwa proposed that the Arabs vote to accept Israel's credentials. Credentials of all nations must be approved each year, allowing representation in the U.N. General Assembly. However, the Arabs would propose an amendment to the official membership list that reminds Israel of its obligation to obey Security Council and General Assembly resolutions on the Middle East. Security Council resolutions have attacked Israel's declaration of a unified Jerusalem as its capital and, this month, ``deplored'' the Oct. 8 Temple Mount killings in which police killed 20 Palestinians during a stone-throwing protest in Jerusalem. General Assembly resolutions call for separate homelands for Palestinians and Jews, and guarantee the right of Palestinian exiles to go home to the new Palestine. Israel's U.N. mission was informed of the proposal but had no immediate formal response. The Arab ambassadors were unable to agree immediately on the PLO proposal. One problem for them seemed to be whether voting for Israel's U.N. membership, even with those amendments, would constitute recognition of Israel. ``I think they are very concerned about the implications themselves,'' said one Western ambassador who is an expert on the Middle East. The chairman of the Arab group, Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan, said he would likely ask the General Assembly president to delay consideration of the membership issue rather than take it up Thursday, as scheduled. Israel has been U.N. member since the Jewish state was founded in 1948. Since 1982, the Arabs have challenged Israel's right to sit in the General Assembly, claiming it is not a peace-loving state as required by the U.N. Charter. The Arabs have lost every year, and last year the Soviet Union abstained on the issue rather than voting with them. This year, the Soviets are expected to vote in favor of Israel. Al-Kidwa characterized the PLO's move as ``a more positive approach'' the Israel-Palestinian issue. This is the first major new diplomatic move by al-Kidwa, a nephew of PLO chairman Yasser Arafat. Veteran PLO Ambassador Zuhdi Labib Terzi retired from his 16-year posting as head of the delegation last month to become an adviser to Arafat. The PLO has observer status at the United Nations. Observers believe that hard-line Arab states such as Syria, Libya and Iraq will not support al-Kidwa's proposal if it is viewed as amounting to some form of recognition of Israel. In 1948, the newly founded Israeli government was willing to accept the General Assembly resolutions setting up two states, but the Arab nations rejected the two-state idea and attacked Israel the day after it declared itself a nation. Israel captured about half the land that was supposed to become an Arab Palestinian state, and the other half was divided between Jordan and Egypt. The Israeli government has claimed since then that it needs to retain some of the occupied territory as a buffer against Arab attacks. In 1988, Arafat became the first Arab leader to endorse the two-state concept originally devised by the United Nations. The PLO lost significant financial and political support from some Arab countries after Arafat sided with Saddam Hussein on the Iraqi leader's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. Arafat has since been trying to play a mediating role. Saddam has said he wants to link any solution to the crisis with an Israeli pullout from occupied territories and has won the support of many of the Palestinians living in those lands. Washington broke off dialogue with the PLO in June after Arafat refused to condemn a May 30 raid on a Tel Aviv beach by guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Front led by Abu Abbas. There were no Israeli casualties in the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Outcasts Stifle Debate About Own Problem
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Japan's outcast community has attacked an author who committed a faux pas in this nation where prejudice goes deep but largely undiscussed - he wrote about their plight. Trouble started for Dutch author Karel Van Wolferen when he wrote that Japan's burakumin community has used confrontational tactics to scare editors, publishers and TV producers into silence about its problems. As a result, the problems can't be addressed, the author says. Van Wolferen saw his book, ``The Enigma of Japanese Power,'' fall victim to the same treatment when the Burakumin Liberation League pressured his Tokyo publisher into temporarily halting sales. ``Burakumin'' - meaning hamlet people - is a euphemism for a former social class considered unclean in feudal Japan because they dealt with death. For centuries they were Japan's butchers, gravediggers and tanners. Though physically indistinguishable from other Japanese, their more than 1 million descendants today live in separate communities and the government keeps meticulous records on family histories. They have trouble marrying into the mainstream and getting decent jobs. Even mentioning their existence is taboo for most Japanese. Indeed, it was only in August 1989 that a Japanese television producer dared for the first time to broadcast a program on burakumin prejudice. On Tuesday, Van Wolferen challenged a burakumin leader in a debate to drop rough tactics that, ironically he says, have helped perpetuate their lowly status and ``self-censor'' the problem of prejudice in Japan. Van Wolferen and his publisher won't say what pressuring tactics were used to halt Japanese sales of his book, which has been sold in the United States since last year. But the burakumin group is known for cornering offending writers, teachers or scholars whose opinions they object to and verbally harassing them. ``Many Japanese scholars won't touch the subject of burakumin, in part because they're afraid of the liberation league coming and trashing their office,'' said Columbia University anthropologist Theodore Bestor, who is doing research in Japan. Van Wolferen suggested that such enforced silence about social discrimination has led many Japanese to remain ignorant of its impact. That in turn gives rise to the kind of racial slur uttered recently by Japan's justice minister, Seiroku Kajiyama, who compared U.S. blacks to prostitutes. ``The average Japanese has heard more about discrimination against blacks and other minorities in the United States than about Japan's minorities,'' Van Wolferen said. Tatsukuni Komori, the league's secretary general, responded during the debate that his group ``welcomes all criticism.'' ``We have never asked someone to rewrite or correct a passage that seems to be critical of the Burakumin Liberation League,'' said Komori, who also represents his community in Parliament. ``But if factual inaccuracies are spread then we will probably have to resort to other measures.'' Komori said the league pressured Van Wolferen's publisher, Hayakawa Shobo, into halting sales in early October and a planned advertising campaign for the book's Japanese version because it used ``discriminatory language'' to describe the community and made factual errors. During the debate, Van Wolferen said he had agreed to change ``special villages'' - long used to refer to the burakumin - to ``special communities.'' But he said he stood by the book's findings. The book went back on store shelves in mid-October after Van Wolferen urged his publisher to overcome its fear and resume sales. Tuesday's debate was part of his effort to try to reach agreement with the burakumin on altering the next printing. The controversy has underscored one of the major themes of Van Wolferen's book, which argues that political and social change in Japan is stifled in part by the inability to discuss it. ``The (league) has been trying to get United Nations recognition as an oppressed minority,'' he said after the debate, held at the Foreign Correspondents Club. ``But U.N. officials say they can't find enough written about the burakumin in Japan'' to make a decision. Val Wolferen said he thought the liberation league ``is at juncture where it may well begin to study its methods.'' Other analysts say that unwillingness to discuss prejudice extends to Japan's other huge minority, those of Korean descent, and other groups. Japanese, accustomed to hearing their society described as homogenous, ``are fundamentally not even aware of prejudice because they don't see these minorities as being internal to Japanese society,'' said Bestor. When protests arose several years ago over a government law that requires fingerprinting of Japan's Korean minority, Bestor said, he remembers being shocked at the reaction of a Japanese friend he considered ``fairly well informed.'' ``He didn't know until I told him that the people being fingerprinted were born in Japan and in some cases were third and fourth generation. He couldn't understand why they were disobeying the rules of their host country.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Stocks Fall Off Earlier Gains
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slipped from its opening but ended higher against the Japanese yen in Tokyo on Wednesday, while share prices lost early gains. The dollar closed at 129.35 yen, up 0.35 yen from Tuesday's 129.00-yen finish. It opened higher at 129.37 yen and ranged between 128.88 yen and 129.70 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 48.30 points, or 0.19 percent, ending the day at 25,194.10. The index rose about 200 points before sinking following a fall in government bond prices, traders said. In currency dealings, the dollar's slip came on selling from institutional investors attempting to take profits, said a dealer with Mitsubishi Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Otherwise, he said, ``the dollar-yen was moving quietly as investors slowed down major moves before their end-of-the-month book balancing.'' Dealers said the market has already adjusted for the higher-than-expected 1.8 percent U.S. third-quarter gross national product figure. On the stock market, brokers said the index's early gain was in reaction to a 17.82-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York and the yen's relative stability against the dollar despite the better-than-expected U.S. gross national product report for the third quarter. ``Index-linked large-scale buying also supported the Nikkei until about mid-morning, but the index started to slip because of the falling bond prices,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. He said the yen's stability was the key to the recent stock market performances amid volatile foreign exchange trading.

DOC.HEAD: Jury to Recommend if Salcido Should to Die in Gas Chamber
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `The sentencing ...' to CORRECT to fourth sted third day of deliberations.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX1 of Oct. 30
DOC.TEXT: The jury that convicted Ramon Salcido of murdering his wife, two daughters, boss and three others returns next week to decide whether the former winery worker should die in the gas chamber. Salcido, 29, was found guilty Tuesday in an April 14, 1989 rampage in which he criss-crossed the Sonoma Valley in California wine country, stabbing and shooting his victims. He slit his daughrers' throats and left them to die at a dump. The sentencing stage begins Tuesday. The jury, which reached its verdict on its fourth day of deliberations, can recommend death or life in prison without parole. ``What this means for the families is perhaps one chapter of this horrible nightmare will be laid to rest,'' Prosecutor Peter Bumerts said after the verdict. ``We knew he was going to die in prison, one way or another,'' said defense attorney Marteen Miller. Although Salcido confessed in a taped statement that was the prosecution's key evidence, his lawyers tried to save his life by portraying him as suicidal and mentally ill. They argued he suffered from a psychotic depression that was aggravated by an alcohol and cocaine binge in the hours before the rampage. The prosecution scoffed at the notion Salcido was suicidal, saying the killer demonstrated his methodical ways when he stepped over dead bodies to bandage his finger, which he cut while stabbing a victim to death. He was convicted of six counts of first-degree murder, one of second-degree murder and other offenses. A first-degree murder conviction requires proof of premeditation; defense attorneys had urged jurors to opt for second-degree murder or manslaughter. According to testimony, Salcido began his murderous frenzy after a night of bar-hopping and cocaine-snorting. When he arrived home around 5 a.m., he was furious that his wife was gone. He grabbed the couple's three young girls and drove to the county dump, where he slashed each child's throat and left them to die. One of them, Carmina, then 2, survived, telling investigators, ``Daddy cut me.'' Salcido's next stopped at his mother-in-law's home, fatally stabbing Marian Richards and two of her daughters. When he returned home, Salcido fatally shot his wife, Angela, and headed for the Grand Cru Winery, where he killed his boss, Tracey Toovey. Salcido also went to the home of his co-worker, Ken Butti, and shot Butti and tried to shoot his wife, Terri, before fleeing. Butti recovered from the wound. Salcido was arrested four days later in his native Mexico. He told investigators he was mad that his wife had hidden that their first child was fathered by another man. The trial was moved to San Mateo County because of publicity in Sonoma County.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas A.G. Takes Stand in His Defense
DOC.TEXT: Arkansas' attorney general says he billed personal expenses to a state credit card because it's hard for him to separate his personal life from his business affairs. ``I live, eat sleep and breathe politics,'' Steve Clark testified Tuesday at his theft trial. ``That is the truth. It's not necessarily good, but it's the truth.'' Holding back tears at times during 2{ hours on the stand, Clark, 43, said he made mistakes on his expense records but didn't intend to steal from the state. Clark is accused of entertaining friends, girlfriends, family and political supporters on a state-issued credit card, running up a tab of at least $8,448.27 for the meals of personal guests on 56 occasions from 1986 to 1989. He could get up to 20 years in prison and a $15,000 fine if convicted. The charges forced Clark to drop out of the race for the Democratic nomination for governor. The prosecution contends Clark used the card to support a standard of living he couldn't afford on his $26,500 annual salary, among the lowest in the nation for a state attorney general. Clark maintained he had complete discretion to use the card as he wished, without keeping records. But Circuit Judge Perry Whitmore disagreed, denying a defense motion Tuesday to dismiss the case. The attorney general said he filled out expense forms up to three months late, accidentally recording as guests people who didn't eat with him. More than 100 of 141 witnesses who testified last week said they didn't dine with Clark or discuss state business when he said they had. ``I never in my entire life meant to mislead or deceive or misrepresent,'' Clark said. ``I only meant to recall.''

DOC.HEAD: `60 Minutes' Wins Ratings Rate with Salman Rushdie Interview
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie surfaced on CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' coming out of hiding long enough to make the program the most-watched show on television last week. NBC won, just barely, in the overall ratings, placing four shows in the top 10, the A.C. Nielsen Co. said Tuesday. ``Cheers'' was No. 2, and ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Empty Nest'' tied for eighth, followed by ``A Different World.'' Fox and ``The Simpsons'' suffered their worst ratings since original fall episodes began competing with ``Cosby'' three weeks ago. The animated Simpson family plummeted to No. 24. The show's Oct. 11 premiere ranked eighth. An interview by ``60 Minutes'' correspondent Mike Wallace with Rushdie, who has lived in hiding since his novel ``The Satanic Verses'' led some Islamic leaders to issue a death sentence against him last year, helped the Sunday newsmagazine capture the No. 1 spot for the first time in the 6-week-old season. ``Cheers'' had been No. 1 for most of the new season. Separated by only one-tenth of a ratings point, the three networks were led by NBC with a 12.5, followed by ABC with 12.4 and CBS with 12.3. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. The top 10 was again dominated by longstanding hits, even though the season has had the most new shows in TV history. The highest-rated original fall program, at No. 20, was ``America's Funniest People'' - a spinoff of ABC's hugely successful ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' The newest Nielsen numbers also show that the battle between the networks continues to produce no big winners. With competition from alternative programmers like cable and Fox Broadcasting Co., the three major broadcasters are barely able to distinguish themselves from one another in the ratings. The network news ratings were won again by ABC and Peter Jennings, with a 10.6. CBS and Dan Rather had a 9.5, and NBC and Tom Brokaw a 9.1. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 21.1; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 20.4; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 20.1; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 19.9; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 18.6; ``Murder, She Wrote,'' CBS, 18.5; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 18.1; ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Empty Nest, NBC (tie), 18; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 17.9.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Begin Amphibious Assault Exercise With Arab Forces
DOC.TEXT:
An amphibious assault training exercise is under way in the Persian Gulf that a Pentagon source says will involve landing more than 10,000 Marines on a beach in Oman. The exercise, which started Tuesday and is to last 10 days, is the second major Marine practice of amphibious assault techniques that could be used in the event President Bush ordered an offensive against Iraqi forces in Kuwait. The first was conducted on an Omani beach in September. Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman, said the exercise involves elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade and Amphibious Task Group 2, which have been in the gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield to defend Saudi Arabia against possible Iraqi attack. Hall called the maneuver a ``routine amphibious training exercise'' designed to ``refamiliarize these forces with a desert environment.'' He declined to specify the number of marines and ships involved. A Pentagon source, speaking on condition he not be identified, said 18 ships, including Marine Corps amphibious vessels and Navy warships, will participate in the exercise, which he said also will involve forces from allied gulf nations. Hall said 20 airplanes and 75 helicopters will be used in staging the beach assault. The amphibious assault ship USS Iwo Jima was en route to the exercise area Tuesday when a boiler pipe ruptured, killing eight sailors and critically injuring two others. Hall said it had not been decided whether the 1,100 Marines aboard the Iwo Jima would participate in the beach assault exercise as planned after the ship is repaired.
---
DOC.HEAD: Vander Jagt Has Challenger For House GOP Campaign Group Chair
DOC.TEXT:
Rep. Don Sundquist of Tennessee is trying to oust Rep. Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan as head of the House Repulican campaign organization, sources say. Sundquist began making telephone calls and contacting colleagues in the final hours before Congress adjourned this weekend to recruit support for his bid. One Republican staff source, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday that the challenge is opposed by Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 GOP leader in the House. Gingrich views Sundquist's bid just a week before the Nov. 6 elections as a damaging distraction to the campaign arm, the National Republican Congressional Committee. Sundquist spokesman Ralph Perrey acknowledged that his boss had discussed running against Vander Jagt with colleagues, but added he would make no formal announcement until after the elections. ``Mr. Sundquist has a background as a manager of campaigns, a grassroots organizer and one who can recruit and develop candidates,'' Perrey said. ``Many believe those are precisely the skills needed'' at the NRCC now.
---
DOC.HEAD: Lawyers' Group Asks Ban on Over-the-Counter Sales of Asthma Drug
DOC.TEXT: A lawyers' group and medical experts are urging the government to strengthen safeguards for people with asthma who use an effective but potentially dangerous drug. They said Tuesday that over-the-counter asthma medications containing the drug theophylline should be banned. And they want physicians and patients to be made more aware of potential hazards also associated with prescription versions of the drug. ``Our message about theophylline is that this medication can be a lifesaver or a life-taker,'' said Michael Maher, president of the Trial Lawyers of America. Schering-Plough, the leading manufacturer of prescription theophylline products, called the lawyers' action a ``self-serving publicity campaign'' that will unduly alarm asthma patients and interfere with doctor-patient relationships ``by overstating ad overdramatizing the known risks of theophylline.'' Company officials said their theophylline products have had a good safety record. With more than 60 million prescriptions written in the past five years, adverse reactions amounted to 1.3 per 100,000 prescriptions, said David Pernock, a company marketing executive. He noted that Schering-Plough does not make any nonprescription theophylline products because it agrees that ``it is a drug that should be monitored.'' The Food and Drug Administration banned over-the-counter sales of theophylline as a single-ingredient product in 1986. Two years ago, the agency proposed a ban on other nonprescription uses of the drug. The lawyers' group last week sent a letter to the Food and Drug Administration saying it knew of 26 preventable theophylline-related incidents of death or serious injury since 1975. About 10 million Americans, most of them children, suffer from asthma, which causes about 5,000 deaths a year. Though not a cure, theophylline, a chemical cousin of caffeine, is the most widely prescribed remedy to ease breathing and has been on the market for more than 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Stocks Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen today on news of the United States' third-quarter economic performance, while profit-taking pushed share prices lower. The dollar closed at 129.35 yen, up 0.35 yen from Tuesday's 129.00-yen finish. It opened at 129.37 yen and ranged between 128.88 yen and 129.70 yen. The U.S. currency was strong in early trading after news of the third quarter's 1.8 percent growth in U.S. gross national product, higher than anticipated, dealers said. It weakened later on profit-taking, but rose again on reports of a senior U.S. Treasury official expressing wariness over the dollar's decline, said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It is no longer that easy to push the dollar lower,'' the dealer said. The dollar had fallen 13.55 yen in 13 trading days, closing at 124.40 yen on Oct. 18. It has mainly advanced since then, however. On the stock market, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 48.30 points, or 0.19 percent, closing at 25,194.10. In thin trading, volume totaled 400 million shares on the first section, unchanged from Tuesday. The index rose about 200 points, but then sank following a fall in government bond prices, traders said. The index slipped mainly because of large-scale profit-taking following early gains, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. ``Nomura Securities was trying to push up the Nikkei by index-linked buying, because today was the last trading day in October, but that invited more profit-taking,'' Nomura said. The index's early gains were in reaction to an overnight gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average in New York and the yen's relative stability against the dollar despite the better-than-expected U.S. GNP, brokers said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 84.60 points from Tuesday's close of 84.84. Their yield rose to 7.790 percent from 7.735 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sentencing Judge Says Some Jurors Determined to Acquit Mayor Barry
DOC.TEXT: The federal judge who sentenced Mayor Marion Barry to six months in jail on a misdemeanor cocaine possession conviction says he believes four jurors were determined to acquit Barry and misled the court during jury selection. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson also told a Harvard Law School forum on Tuesday that he had ``never seen a stronger government'' case against a defendant. He remarks in Cambridge, Mass., were reported by The Washington Post Meanwhile, Former District of Columbia Police Chief Maurice Turner said Tuesday that Barry was the target of undercover drug operations other than the one that led to his trial and conviction. ``There were several aggressive grand juries that were seated, and there were stings that didn't materialize,'' Turner, now a Republican mayoral candidate, said during a campaign forum on WJLA-TV. Turner declined to provide details on the sting operations against Barry, which he first mentioned in response to a question about whether he would have approved such a tactic against his then-boss. ``The stings were field operations, and I don't want to go into it,'' Turner said. ``I do approve of sting operations, though.'' Turner, who served 32 years on the police force with the last eight as chief, added that he would not have ``sacrificed my career for someone using drugs.'' The former chief declined to say whether the operations were coordinated with federal officials or whether his department was acting alone. Jackson told the law students at Harvard that he thought the evidence against Barry was ``overwhelming'' on 10 of 14 counts, even though the mayor was convicted on only one count. He said four jurors ``obviously did not tell the truth'' when they said during jury selection that they would approach the case without bias. It is unusual, but not necessarily improper, for judges to comment about cases that are no longer pending before them, legal experts said Tuesday. If Barry's conviction is overturned on appeal, Jackson would have to withdraw from any retrial because of his opinion about Barry's guilt, the experts said. But his comments apparently do not supply Barry with ammunition in his expected appeal of his conviction, they said. ``I am not happy with the way the jury addressed the case,'' Jackson said at the forum. ``Some people on the jury .... had their own agendas. They would not convict under any circumstances.''

DOC.HEAD: Census Shows Unexpected 20 Million People
DOC.TEXT: China's one-child policy hasn't worked as well as hoped, officials said today as they released census figures showing China has 1.133 billion people - 20 million more than anticipated. The discovery, the result of a door-to-door headcount in July that was the biggest ever conducted in the world, is the equivalent of finding that the entire population of Australia had been overlooked among China's masses. ``Our planners overestimated their capacity to control the population,'' Zhang Sai, director general of the State Statistics Bureau, told a news conference. ``If we look at the absolute figure of 20 million, it is equal to the total population of a province,'' he said, trying to explain why these people had been missed before. ``But if we take into account the large size of the population, it amounts to only 1.8 percent, so it is not that big.'' The figure of 1.133 billion also could be under by several million, however, because a random recount in sample areas showed those areas were undercounted by 0.6 percent, according to preliminary data released today.
