Fitzwater and other Bush aides deny any political motivation in the new round of coordinated saber-rattling by Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. But there's no denying that emphasizing the gulf crisis in the closing days of the campaign may help steer the electorate's attention away from the budget fiasco and the president's reversal of his ``no new taxes'' pledge. On Monday, Bush said in San Francisco that he would not hesitate to use force if provoked. And he discussed possible military action against Iraq in a meeting with congressional leaders Tuesday on the gulf crisis. Baker, who told a Los Angeles gathering ``we will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait,'' embarks Saturday on a week-long visit to Arab and European countries, beginning with Saudi Arabia. There is considerable speculation that Baker will discuss military options with Saudi leaders. And the United States was clearly savoring the United Nations Security Council's vote Monday declaring Iraq responsible for all damage and personal injuries resulting from its occupation of Iraq. The council said the UN would take ``further measures'' under its charter, although the use of force was not explicitly mentioned. It was the latest in a series of resolutions designed to increase pressure on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. At the White House, Bush discussed military options with congressional leaders - and was cautioned by some of them not to give up too soon on the economic sanctions against Baghdad, or let impatience draw him into war. ``There's concern on Capitol Hill ... that this is somehow a prelude to immediate military action,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. After stepping up its threats against Iraq on Monday, the White House was drying to dampen fears Tuesday that fighting was imminent. ``I would say that it's pretty much steady as she goes,'' Fitzwater said, trying to downplay suggestions that Bush's heightened talk about military options was new. ``If that's true, I'm a dismal failure, because I'm trying to play it down, be calm,'' he said. Asked pointblank whether the get-tough rhetoric was designed to help focus the final week of the election on the Persian Gulf instead of new taxes, Fitzwater said: ``I don't think there has been a shift ... I think the big factor is simply that the Congress is leaving and they finished up all the legislation, and now this has become a major focus again, which is probably good.'' Ed Rogers, White House political director, said there has been no effort to gin up Bush's speeches for the last few weeks to stress his toughness on the Persian Gulf. ``That's pretty much a constant,'' he said. At the same time, Rogers said that Bush has clearly stepped up his partisan attacks on Democrats, reflecting GOP strategy for the final week of the campaign. Bush leaves Thursday on a cross-country political barnstorming tour for GOP candidates - many of whom have kept him at arm's length on tax issues. The trip will last through Election Day. On Tuesday, addressing a group of about 500 party workers at a hotel rally, Bush moved easily from denouncing the Democratic-led Congress as a ``hot dog factory'' to seeking to put a GOP seal on his Persian Gulf policy. ``In times of crisis and challenge, the American spirit has been a constant source of strength. It's true now, obviously, in the Persian Gulf, and it's just as true at home today ... the spirit to which Republicans are responding.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Group Petitions Against Coronation, Plans Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: Japan's largest Christian organization has gathered nearly 80,000 signatures on a petition opposing state funding of a religious enthronement rite for Emperor Akihito, officials said today. The National Christian Council of Japan, which began gathering the signatures in December 1989, is one of a growing number of groups opposing the rite, called the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual. The council, an umbrella group encompassing nearly all mainstream Protestant denominations, also is planning a hunger strike to protest the funding of the ceremony. In the Daijosai, to be held 10 days after Akihito is formally crowned Nov. 12, the emperor is to have his first communion with the gods of Shinto, which until 1945 was Japan's state religion. Although the rite has roots going back more than a millennium, opponents say it conflicts with the postwar constitution's guarantee of freedom of religion and its ban on government involvement in church activities. ``Government involvement in a religious ceremony like this is a violation of the separation of church and state,'' said the petition. ``We oppose government involvement in the Daijosai, and we oppose government funding.'' Council official Natsuko Yoshida said the petition is to be presented to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other government officials in mid-November, after the final count has been made. She said officials had hoped to present the petition earlier, but the prime minister's office will not set a firm date, saying they are too busy at present because parliament is in session. ``We had originally only hoped to get about 50,000 signatures,'' Yoshida said. ``And though we were able to get more than that we are not really satisfied with just the numbers.'' She said, however, that the signature drive was ``revolutionary'' because it had the support of nearly all Christian groups in the country. ``The Catholics and some other groups had been slow to protest in the past,'' Yoshida said. ``But we all came together for this, and I think it will create a foundation for conducting future protests.'' Council officials also said that unless the government reverses its funding policy, they are planning to begin the hunger strike on Nov. 19 and stop it after the Daijosai ends on Nov. 23. Roughly 1,000 people are expected to join in the strike, they said. Over the past month, many groups from a wide section of society have voiced concern about the government's handling of the rite. More than 1,500 people have filed suit in a district court in western Japan claiming the state funding is unconstitutional. That case opened Tuesday in Osaka, Japan's second-largest city, with each plaintiff demanding a token amount of money in damages and a withdrawal of government funding if providing such is found in violation of the constitution. Many of the people who brought the suit to court are Christians, but the group also includes Buddhists, historians and teachers. Last week, the head of the Japan Federation of Bar Associations said government funding could ``only be seen as a violation of the principle of church-state separation.'' Government officials say the funding is justified because it is intended only to preserve an ancient imperial tradition, not to promote religion.

DOC.HEAD: Guests Evacuated In Fire At Huntington Hotel
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in an unoccupied hotel room this morning, forcing the evacuation of about 300 guests for about an hour. No one was injured, but the Radisson Hotel's sprinkler system caused water damage to the lobby of the 11-story hotel. Fire Chief C. Rickman said sprinkers contained the fire to one room. Hotel employees telephoned rooms and knocked on doors asking guests to evacuate. Among the guests was actor Peter Marshall, former host of the television game show ``The Hollywood Squares,'' who returned to the hotel from a radio interview after the fire broke out. A Huntington native, Marshall was in town for a performance of the Neil Simon play ``Rumors.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Feuding Factions Agree to Truce
DOC.TEXT: Moslem fundamentalists in Iran and moderates led by President Hashemi Rafsanjani agreed to halt a propoganda war waged since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death last year, an Iranian newspaper said today. The English-language Tehran Times said officials from both camps in the Parliament met Monday and ``decided to stop their war of words.'' The meeting grouped Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi, who leads the hard-liners in the 270-seat Majlis, or parliament, and Nateq Noori, leader of the so-called pragmatic faction that backs Rafsanjani. Karrubi's brother was arrested last month on charges of corruption, and Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered an audit of the multimillion dollar Martyr's Foundation, which Karrubi heads. But Karrubi declared his allegiance to Khamenei earlier this week, and warned other radicals in parliament to watch what they say. Arguments and fist-fights broke out in the Majlis earlier this month after Khamenei excluded most radical candidates from elections for a key constitutional body. Khamenei is a political ally of Rafsanjani, who has been trying to purge the government of fundamentalists since Khomeini's death. The hard-liners accuse Rafsanjani of violating Khomeini's teachings by seeking to improve relations with the West and Iran's Arab neighbors. They have also declared Khamenei unfit to be Khomeini's successor.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communist Official in Vietnam Sentenced for Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A former Vietnamese Communist Party official linked to an $8 million bank fraud has been sentenced to life in prison as part of a government crackdown on corruption, state radio reported. The Voice of Vietnam also reported a government forestry ministry was dismissed for allowing illegal timber exports. Former Communist Party official Hoang Thi Xuan was sentenced by the Supreme Court in Vinh Phu province near Hanoi for the 1988 bank fraud scam, the Monday radio broadcast said. A transcript of the broadcast was seen today in Bangkok. Twenty-three other defendants, including bank officers and local government officials, received punishments ranging from 15 years in jail to suspended sentences, it said. The court ruled the defendents plotted with bank officials to alter the amounts of 22 checks and loaned the extra $425,000 to earn interest. The Voice of Vietnam said Premier Do Muoi fired Vice Minister Than Trung Hieu on Monday for causing ``great losses'' to the forestry industry in Vietnam. An earlier state radio report said Hieu improperly allowed the export of timber worth $9.6 million. Hieu diverted other logs, claiming they were destroyed by fire, and committed other irregularities. The radio report did not give further details on the timber exports. On Saturday, the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court sentenced Nguyen Van Moi Hai to life in prison for defrauding hundreds of thousands of people of $30 million in a so-called pyramid scheme. The official Vietnam News Agency report of the trial said Hai had used his perfume company as a front for a high-interest investment scheme in which he paid back investors with money deposited later by other people. It said Hai also bribed government officials with gold and money. The agency on Monday said the court also sentenced Hai's wife, Nguyen Thi Nhu, to 12 years in jail. The tribunal issued punishments ranging from 14 years in jail to suspended sentences to the trial's 20 other defendant, including eight government members. The official media called it Vietnam's ``biggest case of fraud known to date.'' Vietnam's reform-minded government has been working in recent months to root out corruption and mismanagement. Radio Hanoi noted in an Oct. 23 editorial that corruption was particularly severe in the banking industry and among those managing the nation's meager natural reserves. The report, seen today in Bangkok, also said the problem was getting worse. ``We can say that corruption is no longer regarded as a practice that involves only those degenerate or deviant people with positions and power,'' the radio said. ``It has become a social vice.''

DOC.HEAD: Reuters to Cut 300 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Reuters, the international news and financial services agency, said today it will cut 300 jobs, 200 of them in Britain, because of ``difficult and unsettled'' market conditions. The company said it also will delay the launch of Dealing 2000, an improved system for electronically providing foreign exchange information to traders. ``Conditions in most financial markets remain difficult and unsettled, making forecasting beyond the current year more than usually hazardous,'' said managing director Glen Renfrew. ``We cannot rule out further setbacks, but the recent new order rate has been large enough, in combination with cost cutting, to support steady growth.'' Reuters said the jobs to be cut will be in the central corporate departments covering finance, marketing and administration. A small number of editorial jobs also could be affected. The layoffs represent 6 percent of the British payroll and 3 percent of the worldwide work force. Reuters shares dropped 42 pence (81 cents) to 566 pence ($10.98) by mid-afternoon on the London Stock Exchange, a new 1990 low. A total of 2 million shares changed hands. Renfrew said severence pay for those let go will cost the company around 10 million pounds ($19.4 million) in 1990. After absorbing this, the company expects pre-tax profits for 1990 to be around 320 million pounds ($620 million), he said. Reuters said it will make a statement on business conditions in early December, when analysts meet in New York.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Oct. 29 The Meridian (Miss.) Star on Bush and taxes: ``The Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no. And they'll push again. And I'll say to them: Read my lips. No new taxes.'' - George Bush, August 1988 Apparently, Congress pushed harder than then-presidential candidate Bush anticipated. Times and circumstances do change. The federal deficit is considerably higher than it was when Bush made that emphatic promise in his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention in New Orleans. The president made the decision to compromise in the national interest. But now he has taken to the campaign trail in an attempt to wash his hands of responsibility for the biggest tax increase in history. The Democrats in Congress made him do it, he told auidences over the weekend. Well, the president obviously knew two years ago that he would be pressured to go along with a tax increase. He didn't just say, I'm against new taxes, he went further in declaring his intent to resist the inevitable push to raise them. It is understandable that the president's public standing and credibility have eroded somewhat as a result of his reversal. The president would be better served politically if he would simply admit that his hard line was unrealistic rather than blaming the opposition for a tax package that he, his staff and Republican congressional leaders helped craft and approved. --- Oct. 25 The Evening Telegram, Superior, Wis., on the budget: C.B. Scott Jones, an aide to Sen. Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, recently wrote Defense Secretary Richard Cheney with a startling revelation: When tapes of speeches by Cheney, Secretary of State James Baker and President Bush are played backwards, the word ``simone'' can be heard. ... Jones alerted Secretary Cheney to his discovery because he feared ``simone'' might be a ``code word that would not be in the national interest to be known.'' ... Pell himself says, ``There may be some merit to it.'' ... Jones modestly admits that the whole thing may be a ``non-event, just another mystery in a new technology we are developing.'' Let's hear more about this new technology. If, for example, we played Bush's famous ``No new taxes'' campaign speech backwards, might we not hear the spectral words, ``I'm lying, I'm lying''? And those pious speeches by congressmen calling for fiscal restraint - wouldn't the reverse speech technique reveal a voice whimpering, ``Let me keep my pay raise''? No wonder we've had such trouble reading their lips! --- Oct. 24 The Bulletin, Bend, Ore., on the budget: There may be some comfort in all this budget mess. We are learning that the definition of ``rich'' is not an exact one. Both Republicans and Democrats want to use new taxes on the ``rich'' to help balance the budget. That's an easy target. Since few of us consider ourselves ``rich'' the proposed taxes meet the first obligation of a tax proposal; they tax someone else. House Speaker Tom Foley thinks ``rich'' starts with an income of $100,000 per year. George Bush holds to the same figure in part: He would raise taxes on those with incomes that high by limiting their deductions. Dan Rostenkowski, the chief House tax writer, thinks it takes $200,000 a year in income to make one rich. Some other members of the conference committee think the floor of wealth is at $300,000. But everyone is in agreement on one thing. An income of $1 million makes one truly rich. All are agreed on a new, higher tax for entertainers, for professional athletes and for those few leaders of big business who make that kind of money. That seems reasonable; few could argue that earnings of $1 million leave anyone disadvantaged. --- Oct. 30 St. Louis Post-Dispatch on Congress' record: The 101st Congress has adjourned to the boos and catcalls of a disgusted public. Yet on balance it had a productive session, a fact of which today's anti-incumbent voters should take note. Despite the shortcomings of the process, Congress did finally approve a major deficit-cutting measure, which for the first time in nearly a decade faces the need for new revenue to restore fiscal sanity. It also endorsed the first major revision of the Clean Air Act in 13 years, promising major improvements in the nation's air and water. Both the budget and clean air measures represent the resolution of tough political conflicts that completely stymied several earlier Congresses. The legislative session was a messy one; divisions between a Democratic Congress and a Republican president didn't help. Nevertheless, the results were impressive. Democracy still works. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: still works.
DOC.TEXT: Oct. 27 The Phoenix Gazette on obscenity: Despite all the rhetoric and posing of law enforcement officials who just happened to be up for re-election, juries in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Cincinnati, Ohio, came to the appropriate conclusion ...: Law enforcement officers and district attorneys should stick to enforcing laws in the streets and stay out of art galleries and nightclubs. The Fort Lauderdale jury that acquitted members of 2 Live Crew on obscenity charges and the Cincinnati jury that acquitted art gallery officials for exhibiting photos by the late Robert Mapplethorpe offered a working example of how freedom of speech works. Even unpopular things can be said; even some mighty rough words can be uttered in the course of an artistic performance. So once again the juries show themselves as more sophisticated in the meaning of America's freedoms than the politicians and county attorneys who have attempted to gain politically by attacking as pornographic that which is unpopular. One juror was so unimpressed with the prosecution's effort against 2 Live Crew that she toyed with the idea of writing the jury's verdict as a rap number. It's probably a good thing she dispensed with the notion. Rap isn't all that safe in Broward County, Fla., these days. --- Oct. 26 The Record, Hackensack, N.J., on Israel: Once again, the United Nations Security Council has voted to condemn Israel for its refusal to cooperate with an investigation into the killing of Palestinians ... at the Temple Mount. The Security Council is right. Israel's stonewalling of the investigation must stop. Otherwise, it looks as though the Israeli government has something to hide. Many questions remain regarding the Temple Mount incident. In an unprovoked attack, several thousand Palestinians at the Al Aksa Mosque threw rocks at Israeli worshipers at the Western Wall below, and Israeli soldiers opened fire on the Palestinians. In the days since the incident, tension and hatred between Arabs and Jews have soared, with calls for revenge from both sides. Some Israeli officials have exacerbated the tension by making inflammatory and irresponsible statements. The minister of agriculture, for example, said on Israeli radio that one possible solution to finding an armed Arab would be ``to shoot him in the head.'' For its own good - and for the good of the world - Israel must work to end tensions and restore calm. --- Oct. 28 The Providence (R.I.) Sunday Journal on Israel: Israeli bravery is becoming Israeli defiance, and it harms no one more than Israel itself. President Yitzhak Shamir, by refusing to receive a United Nations team seeking to investigate the killing of 21 Arabs by Israeli troops, is showing contempt for the very international law that can guarantee Israel's survival. ... The United States may be Israel's best friend, but ... American patience is not infinitely elastic. ... An Arab death and an Israeli death are equally lamentable. ... The Bush administration was right to register its displeasure. --- Oct. 27 Philadelphia Daily News on Lois Lane: Lois Lane and Clark Kent are getting married - each looking not one day older than they did when they first met in the comic strips a half-century ago. They'll make a lovely couple, we're sure - but frankly, we've always had some doubts about Lois. For 50 years, she's been working alongside Clark and being frequently rescued from death (or worse) by Superman. In all that time, she's never guessed that the Man of Steel and her mild-mannered fellow reporter are the same guy. Doesn't sound like the kind of reporter we'd like to send out on important assignments. Maybe the Daily Planet should reassign her to something a little less demanding. Like writing editorials, for example. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: for example.
DOC.TEXT: Oct. 27 Spartanburg (S.C.) Herald-Journal on a new hope in Lebanon: As an indirect result of the Persian Gulf crisis, a new light is showing at the end of a long tunnel of tragedy and misery in Lebanon. Fifteen years of insanity have almost destroyed what once was a Mediterranean coast of exquisite beauty. Ruins replaced what then was Riviera-lie resorts and casinos, high-fashion shops and bustling business centers. Gen. Michael Aoun, leader of a lonely fragment of Christian opposition, has been defeated. The reason: Iraq can no longer ship weapons to him or support him in his bloody struggle. Actually, Aoun chose to surrender rather than fight to the death, as he had promised to do. Now, the general has been given asylum in the French embassy in Beirut. The collapse of his forces means that an agreement reached last year will go into effect, ending domination of Lebanese politics by the Christian minority. A stronger central government may arise from the ashes. France's protection of Gen. Aoun is symbolic, for that country was there in the beginning and is there at the end. Lebanon was formed in 1920 from five districts of the dismembered Turkish empire. France took over its political affairs in 1922 with a mandate to prepare the new country for independence. The French united the Christians in Mount Lebanon and the Muslims along the coast under one government and helped to write its constitution. Lebanon became completely independent in 1943, with Christians and Muslims sharing power, but French troops remained until 1946. The national Covenant, establishing Christian power, was adopted before they left. About 90 percent of Lebanon's people are Arabs and they have become increasingly intolerant toward a system of government in which particular offices were reserved for certain religious groups. Syria, which has historical claims to the rule of Lebanon, was invited by the Arab League to send in troops as peacemakers during a civil war in 1976. They have been there ever since, controlling a large portion of the country. Factional militias and Palestinian guerilla groups continued to hold territory, fighting for advantage. Israel aided the Christian faction and periodically sent retaliatory forces into South Lebanon. The result of all these bitter contentions was anarchy and bloodletting. The American embassy in Beirut was dynamited, and more than 200 U.S. Marines were killed in a suicide bombing of their barracks. Americans and other hostages are still held in the satanic tenements of the Moslem section of West Beirut. Palestinians and other militias are still armed and dangerous. Israeli forces still occupy a zone of South Lebanon. Perhaps peace is now in sight for this beleaguered territory. It would be to the benefit of all the contending factions to end the slaughter and establish a new government chosen by free elections. --- Oct. 29 NRC Handelsblad, Rotterdam, Netherlands, on the U.S. budget agreement: After the lingering negotiations between Republicans and Democrats, between the House of Representatives, the Senate and the White House, at which budget proposals were tumbling all over one another, the (U.S.) federal government was briefly closed down and President George Bush incurred political damage. ... It is a start of the purge of the American federal overspending. From a political point of view the new budget means a change. Congress' rebellion against an earlier budget compromise has in the end created a result at which more taxes are being raised and less is being cut down. Especially wealthy Americans are left holding the baby. The favoritism of the rich elite, which profited from the anti-tax sentiment in the United States in the '80s, has met with more and more powerful resistance from the American middle class. The Democrats in Congress have broken through the budget limbo in the end and shoved a larger part of the burden through to the Americans with the highest incomes. This new tax populism could very well set a trend. Internationally the United States often sets the political tone for economic policy. In the '80s this was the case with lowering taxes and a supply-economy. The '90s can become the era of rebellion of the middle class. In Europe this will then go at the cost of the ``solidarity.'' --- Oct. 29 The Times of India, New Delhi, on the Soviet Union: It might be a blessing in disguise that more people can place Chernobyl than Chernenko. The Soviet Communist Party's entirely forgettable general secretary, who preceded its most memorable one, has been gravely dishonored even by Russian standards. The passion associated with de-Stalinization is lacking, replaced by a crueler indifference. Konstantin Chernenko's bronze bust has reportedly proved most awkward since no one knows what to do with it. It can't even be exiled to Siberia because that's where it already is, and the citizens of Krasnoyarsk are being rather crass about playing host to it, having already knocked it off its pedestal. --- Oct. 29 The Times, London, on the European Community summit in Rome: This summit was a disgrace. Challenged to resolve the chaos of farm prices in advance of the GATT round, members decided instead to bring forward a debate on economic union scheduled for December. In doing so, they almost casually accepted a 1994 date for a new central bank, to be followed by a single currency and the surrender of national control of economic policy. While few members expect actually to go along with such a union come the day, anything was clearly better than talking about farm prices. Such procedural anarchy is a measure of the shambles of the current Italian presidency of the EC - and of the EC's way of doing, or not doing, urgent business. This is not the executive decisiveness of Europe PLC, more the last days of the Austro-Hungarian empire, seizing ever more power to the center but careless of what to do with it. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
Soviets Defend Nuclear Test and Say No More This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today defended its recent detonation of a nuclear device and said it would have been dangerous to dalay the underground test until winter. The Soviets exploded the device Oct. 24 on the arctic island of Novaya Zemlya, less than 500 miles from Finland and Norway. Following complaints from the Nordic nations, the Soviet Parliament adopted a resolution today ordering the government to notify northern European countries in advance of any nuclear test. Deputy Foreign Minister Vitaly P. Karpov, a nuclear arms specialist, told a news conference that the test had voluntarily been put off for nearly a year, but that because of weather conditions the test had to be carried out. ``The nuclear device was in there for nearly a year. Every warranty for the time period was ending because winter was coming, and in winter, it is impossible to test,'' Karpov said. ``If we waited until April or May, many unexpected things could happen to the nuclear charge, and we could face a much more dangerous situation.'' The yield of the device, set off 200 yards underground, was 15 to 20 kilotons. There were no adverse affects to the region's ecology, he said. Karpov said he met with the ambassadors from Finland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Iceland, who protested underground testing. ``They said testing could hinder cooperation between the Nordic countries and the Soviet Union in the field of ecology,'' Karpov said. ``I explained why we had to hold the explosion at this moment.'' He said the ambassadors were aware that only one Soviet device was exploded this year and that ``it was a forced test and the Soviet Union took all measures to avoid negative influence on the environment.'' Karpov, citing seven U.S. tests and two Chinese tests, said although there would be no more tests this year, if it was necessary for the defense and security of the Soviet Union, more could be carried out in the future. The Parliament, ending three days of hearings on nuclear underground testing, passed a resolution today ordering that neighboring countries be notified of underground tests. The resolution also asked the Council of Ministers to speed up work, on a report on the impact of the Novaya Zemlya test and its impact on areas of the Far North.

DOC.HEAD: Parks Department Nixes Devil Display After Nun's Protest
DOC.TEXT: A city-run haunted house was exorcised after a nun gave them the devil. The haunted house featured a room where the devil asked children to sign over their souls while a lost soul implored them to resist. A Roman Catholic nun, Sister Jeanne McGue of the Gary Diocese, was outraged when she heard about it. She mobilized some priests to call officials of this Chicago suburb to protest. ``I read about this in the newspaper and I couldn't believe my eyes that they were trying to get children to sign their souls over to the devil,'' McGue said. ``Granted, Halloween is supposed to be fun, but we have to draw the line. This is not child's play.'' Parks Superintendent Richard Gomez said he closed the devil's room to avoid controversy. ``They felt that kids at this young age are impressionable and they didn't need to be exposed to this activity, and I agreed with them,'' Gomez said. ``The main purpose is to provide recreation for the kids ... We will still continue to have the scariest haunted house in the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Crowds Attack Hindu Temples
With AM-India, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Authorities imposed a curfew in parts of the capital Wednesday after Moslem mobs attacked Hindu temples and set fire to homes and shops in response to a Hindu-Moslem dispute in neighboring India. Curfew orders restricting people to their homes were also imposed in Chittagong, the country's second-largest city, after similar attacks began there on Tuesday night. The mobs took to the streets after hearing news of an attempt in India by fundamentalist Hindus to take over a mosque in the town of Ayodhya and replace it with a Hindu temple. Witnesses said about 2,000 people rampaged through a residential district where Chittagong's largest temple is located and torched at least 300 Hindu homes. Police fired in the air and said they arrested 10 people. Witnesses said they saw at least 35 other people being taken away by police. At least 11 temples in the port city were broken into and vandalized, officials and witnesses said. One group destroyed about 50 mud-and-straw huts owned by Hindus. Another mob attacked a garage owned by a Hindu and damaged five vehicles. In Dhaka, about 1,000 Moslems staged a protest march toward the Indian High Commission or embassy. The crowd was stopped by riot police but then attacked a temple and Hindu homes in nearby areas, reporters at the scene said. State-run television announced an indefinite curfew in three districts of the city beginning at 6 p.m. Police said they fired tear gas to disperse the crowd. Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, is an Islamic state whose 110 million people are 88 percent Moslem. About 10 percent are Hindus. India, which borders Bangladesh on three sides, is a predominantly Hindu but officially secular nation. Hindus comprise 82 percent of the country's 880 million people and Moslems make up 12 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Leads in Anchorage Mayor Runoff
DOC.TEXT: Incumbent Mayor Tom Fink held a lead of more than 1,000 votes today, but the challenger said he wouldn't concede defeat until 3,400 challenged ballots were tallied. ``We're gonna stick it out,'' said Rich Mystrom, who trailed after all 91 precincts were counted in Tuesday's runoff election. The municipal clerk's office said the unofficial count, including absentee votes, gave Fink the edge - 30,338 votes to 29,245. More than 48 percent of registered voters turned out Tuesday. The election came down to a runoff after neither Fink nor Mystrom gained 40 percent of the vote in a three-way race that included former state legislator H.A. ``Red'' Boucher. Authorities said challenged ballots - those cast by voters at polling places outside their own precincts - would be examined today. Fink, who appeared headed for his second three-year term, told supporters gathered at his headquarters he was pleased about leading all night, and got a good-natured round of booing when he said the runoff was still too close to call. It was a remarkable turnaround for a politician who, according to polls six months ago, was rated negatively by 50 percent or more of Anchorage residents. For Mystrom, that dissatisfaction translated into an early, comfortable lead, but it steadily eroded over the last three months. Mystrom, 46, is a former Anchorage assemblyman and former advertising executive who led the city's unsuccessful winter Olympics bid. Fink, 62, is an Anchorage insurance executive whose first mayoral term found him variously at odds with the municipal assembly, local reporters and unions representing city workers.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to FIX category code to `p.'
Judge on Ballot Fights Name Confusion With Unpopular Judge
DOC.TEXT: A judge facing an election next week shares his last name with an unpopular federal judge and has launched a campaign to make sure voters don't ``vote against the wrong guy.'' Jackson County Circuit Judge Thomas C. Clark says he is often confused with U.S. District Judge Russell G. Clark, who angered many residents by raising taxes to desegregate Kansas City's schools. Thomas Clark's answering machine at home begins: ``This is not the residence of Russell G. Clark.'' His 15-second radio campaign spot tells voters, ``Don't vote against the wrong guy.'' The name confusion was once merely annoying, but now Thomas Clark worries voters kicking the wrong Clark could make him the second judge ever to lose a retention election held under Missouri's 50-year-old merit appointment system. To avoid that, Thomas Clark has broken with tradition and launched a campaign to keep his bench. Missouri judges usually avoid politics and run on their records. But the records of the two Judge Clarks are often confused. When Thomas Clark received a 50-signature petition this year demanding he rehire a fired school principal, he sent it to Russell Clark, who oversees school desegregation. Russell Clark replied with a letter advising him to change his name to something like ``Zweerink or Zurweste.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion a Major Issue in Unpopular Race
DOC.TEXT: Voters don't seem to like either Kansas gubernatorial candidate very much, and their respective stands on abortion don't appear to be enticing constituents. Republican Gov. Mike Hayden and Democrat Joan Finney have negative overall ratings so large that political consultants say neither would stand a chance of election against an opponent that voters felt good about. Hayden's unfavorable rating consistently has exceeded 40 percent; Mrs. Finney's has climbed past 30 percent during the campaign. Mrs. Finney, the state treasurer, had an 18-point lead early in the campaign, but political observers think the neck-and-neck contest may be headed for the closest finish ever in a Kansas governor's race. In a state that has one of the nation's most liberal abortion laws, Hayden is the clear pick of pro-choice groups. In a political reversal, Hayden has declared himself pro-choice. Mrs. Finney is staunchly anti-abortion. It is Hayden who has captured the endorsement of Molly Yard of the National Organization for Women. That's a rarity for a Republican, especially one who was endorsed by right to life groups in 1986. Mrs. Finney, a Roman Catholic, wants the issue to go away. Women Democratic legislators have said publicly they're having a hard time supporting Mrs. Finney because of her anti-abortion stand. In cases of rape and incest, ``we have to look far deeper than a reactionary act like abortion,'' she said in September, touching off a furor. That widely publicized statement was offensive to large numbers of women and turned a lot of voters to Hayden, says Frank Ybarra, the governor's campaign press secretary. Mrs. Finney, meanwhile, is waging a damage control effort. She's said she won't propose legislation restricting abortions, although she says she would sign restrictions into law if they came to her as governor. And she's stopped talking about abortion as the campaign nears its conclusion, while aides try to downplay her earlier comments. ``I don't know how significant an issue it will be,'' said Finney spokesman Mark Schmeller. ``Polls show it's a major concern for only 10 percent or so of the voters. I think it'll probably be a wash.'' There are other issues in the campaign. One is the state sales tax. Hayden proposes raising that tax a penny, to 5.25 percent, and using the estimated $215 million in new revenue to reduce school property taxes. Mrs. Finney has proposed putting a 1 percent sales tax on goods and services now exempt, raising $460 million to lower school and local government property taxes. Mrs. Finney says Hayden's plan is inadequate; he says her plan would devastate Kansas business and agriculture by adding to the cost of state products sold elsewhere. It has been a negative campaign, by Kansas standards. Hayden has questioned Mrs. Finney's competence, saying she's unable to manage the treasurer's office, much less the entire state government. Mrs. Finney has accused Hayden of twisting her positions to make her look bad, and of airing ``mudslinging'' advertising. The latest figures show Hayden outspending Mrs. Finney $1.3 million to $274,000 during the fall campaign. Much of his money has gone for television commercials. In one, Kansas first lady Patti Hayden asks voters if they know which candidate for governor opposes capital punishment, ``even for people who murder children.'' A Finney TV commercial shows blobs of mud being slapped on a picture of Mrs. Finney's face, with the announcer explaining which charge by Hayden each spat represents. At the conclusion, the announcer says: ``All of this makes Joan Finney look pretty good. And the governor? Just another mudslinging politician.''

DOC.HEAD: Safety Commission Warns of Trick-or-Treat Erasers
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is warning consumers of hazardous trick-or-treat erasers that look like candy. The multi-colored Halloween Erasers have been imported from Taiwan, come in packages of 15 and resemble items such as pumpkins, skulls, bats and ghosts. The packages have a label that reads in part ``Lisa Frank Cool Collectibles ... Great Handouts for Trick of Trea.'' They sell for about $2 a package. The safety commission says about 200,000 have been distributed nationwide. ``The firm was asked to recall the product voluntarily, but was unable to agree to the recall in time to issue this notice,'' said the commission in a statement released Tuesday. The commission said the erasers do not meet the small parts regulations of the Federal Hazardous Substances Act.

DOC.HEAD: Queen Elizabeth Accepts Invitation to Visit United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds last graf background.
DOC.TEXT: Queen Elizabeth II has accepted an invitation by President Bush to visit the United States in May 1991, the White House announced today. The British monarch will be accompanied by her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, the White House said in a statement. The statement said exact dates of the queen's visit to Washington are yet to be determined. The queen last visited the United States in May 1989, when she traveled to Kentucky to look at horses.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Requests Part of Agenda for Coronation Dignitaries
DOC.TEXT: High-level representatives from more than 150 countries who converge on Tokyo in two weeks for the coronation of Emperor Akihito likely will have another agenda: getting money. Japanese officials expect the Nov. 12 ceremony and parade to be a replay of the February 1989 funeral of Emperor Hirohito, when dozens of visiting foreign officials sought greater economic assistance. Japan recently surpassed the United States as the largest donor of government aid to the Third World. ``It wasn't because they all loved Hirohito,'' said Robert Orr, director of the Stanford Japan Center and an expert on Japanese foreign assistance. ``I expect the same thing (this time). They're coming because they have other interests, they want some of that Japanese money.'' During the funeral diplomacy, then Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita had talks with 40 foreign dignitaries, and then Foreign Minister Sousuke Uno met with 69, the Foreign Ministry said. Japan's foreign aid in 1989 was $9 billion, compared with $7.7 billion from the United States, the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development announced earlier this year. But Japan ranked 12th of 18 major donor countries in terms of aid as a percentage of gross national product. It was 10th in aid on a per capita basis. Japan is in the middle of a five-year plan which should distribute about $50 billion, roughly twice the aid of the previous five-year period. With the U.S. economy apparently tumbling into recession, the importance of Tokyo to fund-seeking statesmen has become even larger. U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady stopped in Tokyo early last month as part of a global fund-raising mission for the multinational military buildup against Iraq. Days later, Japan pledged an additional $3 billion to the effort, including $2 billion in aid to Middle Eastern nations facing hardships because of the crisis. The past week has shown just how crowded the corridors of power in Japan can become with aid seekers. Nguyen Co Thach made the first official visit to Japan in 12 years by a Vietnamese foreign minister and headed home with a promise of a $180,000 grant for his country's national television station. The Japanese Foreign Ministry described the grant as the first major economic assistance to Hanoi since 1978, when Vietnam invaded Cambodia. Moscow Mayor Gavril Popov also came to Tokyo seeking loans to help convert state businesses into private enterprises, such as the retail distribution system. Another visitor, South African black leader Nelson Mandela, discovered the limits of Japanese largesse Monday when Tokyo rejected his request for $25 million for the African National Congress, which has been at the forefront of the fight against apartheid. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu responded that Japan does not give assistance to political parties, and instead offered funds to grass-roots groups working to improve living and educational conditions in South Africa. Mandela labeled Japan's contribution as ``absolutely insignificant'' compared with packages from other, much poorer, Asia nations. Generally, the political objectives of Japanese foreign aid have not been clearly defined. As a sign of changing times, however, Japanese officials point to their decision to temporarily freeze a $5.4 billion loan package to China to protest the crushing of the 1989 pro-democracy movement in Beijing. ``We'd like to support those countries working harder for the democratic process,'' said Takanori Kitamura, director of the ministry's research and programming division. Orr describes such statements as ``a major change in the rhetoric. Whether it's a major change in policy remains to be seen.''

DOC.HEAD: Foundation Rewards Two Who Provide Clean Needles To Drug Addicts
DOC.TEXT: Two people who lead programs providing clean hypodermic needles to drug addicts to prevent the spread of AIDS received awards of $50,000 each on Wednesday from the Drug Policy Foundation. The foundation, which advocates decriminalization of illegal drugs and treating drug abuse as a health problem, not a law enforcement problem, gave the awards to Jon C. Parker, founder of the National AIDS Brigade, and David Purchase, founder of the Tacoma (Wash.) Needle Exchange. National drug control policy director William J. Bennett has criticized such needle exchange programs, saying they muddy the anti-drug message by enabling people to continue using illegal drugs. Parker was acquitted in a widely publicized trial in Boston for providing free needles to addicts, and he sought arrest on similar charges during a recent tour of numerous cities. ``We will try to do it openly in several states and try to push the system,'' Parker said in an interview before the tour began. ``I don't think they should waste money arresting people trying to save lives.'' He faces charges in New York City; Jersey City, N.J.; Lowell, Mass.; and Redwood City, Calif. However, police in Baltimore and Washington, among other places, declined to arrest him. Parker, a former addict who is a Yale University graduate student in public health, said 35 percent of addicts not in needle-exchange programs in Boston and New Haven, Conn. tested positive for the AIDS virus, compared to 13 percent in Boston and 28 percent in New Haven for those in such programs. Parker said there was more AIDS already in New Haven than in Boston when his programs started five years ago. Purchase got approval from Tacoma's police chief before he started offering a one-for-one exchange of used syringes for clean ones at a table on a downtown sidewalk in August 1988. The program, which serves up to 350 users each week, was ruled legal last January. The Drug Policy Foundation also gave a $10,000 award to Arnold and Mae Nutt of Beaverton, Mich. who became active in making it easier to get marijuana for medical use after their son contracted cancer. He was debilitated by chemotherapy until he got relief from the drug, which his parents had to obtain illegally. Another $10,000 award was given to three people from Liverpool, England - psychiatrist John Marks, Allan Parry, who runs a needle exchange program, and Pat O'Hare, the executive editor of ``The International Journal on Drug Policy.'' The money for the foundation's awards came from Richard J. Dennis, who earned millions when he was a Chicago Mercantile Exchange broker and who now supports the foundation and other groups that advocate some form of decriminalization of illegal drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead, One Missing in Well Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout with fourth body found, search continuing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard today recovered the body of a fourth worker killed when a southern Louisiana gas well exploded in flames, and the search continued for a fifth man who is presumed dead. A sixth man was seriously injured in the blast Tuesday evening, which occurred as workers tried to cap the well and shut it down, the Coast Guard said. The rig is in marshes surrounding Barataria Bay south of New Orleans. The fire burned for about three hours, the Coast Guard said, but there apparently was no blowout or pollution. The bodies of three workers were recovered within hours of the accident. Coast Guard and civilian boats searched overnight for the two missing workers, and Coast Guard helicopters rejoined the search today. The cause of the blast was not immediately known. The dead and missing were employed by Pacer Atlas of Houston, Maestas said. ODY Corp. of Lafayette owned the well. The rig is about 15 miles north of Grand Isle, a barrier island between the bay and te Gulf of Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Write-in Candidate Passes Out Ammo
DOC.TEXT: Calling himself a straight shooter, Steve ``Bo'' Sawyer has been handing out bullets while campaigning as a write-in candidate for the congressional seat held by Democrat J.J. ``Jake'' Pickle. But he said the gimmick may be backfiring. ``If I don't shoot straight, shoot me,'' Sawyer, 39, told voters as he handed thm bullets. ``I think it scared a few people when I gave it to them,'' the candidate said in an interview. ``I handed one to a girl on the University of Texas campus, and she just looked scared of me. It made me feel bad.'' So bad that Sawyer says he's decided to give up the practice. Besides, he said, at 11 cents each the bullets were too expensive for a campaign of meager means.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Helping Push For More Black House Districts
DOC.TEXT: With encouragement from Republicans and the Supreme Court, blacks are pressing for the creation of new minority congressional districts next year, a demand that threatens once-secure Democrats. Creating a black congressional district in Virginia, for example, could require stripping three Democratic congressmen of their most reliable supporters. Comparable situations exist in Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida and Texas, according to an official of the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. The conflicting agendas of blacks and long-term white Democratic incumbents present an unusual opportunity for Republican gains when new legislative district lines are drawn next year to conform to the 1990 Census. The final Census figures won't be available until next spring. But preliminary data indicate that 19 House seats will shift, most of them going from northern industrial states to the Sun Belt. Democrats are far stronger than Republicans in state legislatures where the new lines will be drawn. Through alliances with blacks as well as through court action, Republicans hope to neutralize, at least partially, that Democratic advantage. The GOP tactic is driving a wedge between Democratic Party leaders and their most reliable constituency. ``There's going to be a real serious problem between blacks and the Democratic Party establishment,'' said Hank Sanders, a black Alabama state senator. Even in Virginia, where Gov. L. Douglas Wilder is black, tensions are high between civil rights organizations and party officials. Paul Goldman, the white chairman of the Virginia Democratic Party, complains that civil rights groups ``have threatened Virginia. They say if you don't do this or you don't do that, we're going to sue you.'' ``We will oppose any friend or fight any foe to ensure that there is a black congressional district in Virginia in 1991,'' said Jack Gravely, president of the state NAACP. Wilder has approached such proposals with extreme caution. The closest the nation's first elected black governor came to endorsing the concept was when he told the state NAACP that he saw no legal prohibition to such a district. At the same time, Wilder warned blacks against redistricting alliances with Republicans, saying it would be ``wrong to write off one party and get in bed with the other, not knowing what's in that bed. You might get bit.'' To emphasize his point, the governor cited President Bush's veto of civil rights legislation. Democratic concern about creation of a black district in Virginia is based on the fact that its likeliest location would strip blacks from the districts of Reps. Norman Sisisky, Lewis Payne and Owen Pickett, all Democrats. Goldman referred to all three as ``good Democrats who have worked hard for the party,'' and added that as party chairman he would take a hard look at ``any lines that are drawn that would affect them or make it harder for them to get elected.'' Civil rights leaders contend that legally the Democrats have no choice. Basing his view on a Supreme Court decision, Frank R. Parker, director of the voting rights project of the Lawyers Committee, said, ``If there is racially polarized voting and minority-preferred candidates regularly are defeated, the failure to create a majority blac where one can be created is a violation of Section Two of the Voting Rights Act.'' Parker acknowledged there is considerable disagreement over what constitutes a ``majority black'' district. For example, in Alabama, Sanders said it would be possible to create two districts in which 55 percent of the population would be black. But in neither case would a majority of the voters be black and ``neither of them would be truly winnable in terms of a black person,'' he said. ``I think we have to have one district, at least 65 percent black,'' he said. Assemblyman David Gantt, chairman of the New York Assembly reapportionment committee, said he was not prepared at this early stage to speculate on the percentage needed for black majority district . ``There is a varying attitude as to what constitutes a minority district, whether you try to put 100 percent or 65 percent,'' he said. ``I'm not sure where we will come down on that particular issue.'' Like other black Democratic elected officials, Gantt is wary of forming alliances with Republicans. ``While we may win the battle we may end up losing the war,'' he said. ``My understanding is they would like to take every minority and put them into one district and ... they may also end up picking up more conservative people in those areas contiguous to that.''

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Inch Up, Would Have Dropped but for Oil Cost
DOC.TEXT: Factory orders for manufactured goods inched up 0.1 percent in September but would have fallen except for the added cost of oil products, the government said Wednesday. The Commerce Department report points ``to a rather fragile state of affairs in the manufacturing sector,'' Stephen S. Roach, senior economist with Morgan Stanley & Co., said. The department said orders of durable and non-d the report said. ``Excluding petroleum, orders were down 1.1 percent.'' Orders for durable goods - ``big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - fell 1.4 percent to $125.2 billion after a 0.9 percent decline in August. It was their third drop in four months. Non-durable goods orders, which include petroleum products, advanced 1.6 percent to $119.3 billion in September. But excluding oil, non-durable orders were down 0.7 percent. Non-durable orders had jumped 4.7 percent after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The department also blamed most of that increase on petroleum price increases after the invasion disrupted the world's oil supplies. ``Orders continue to show sluggish behavior in the manufacturing sector,'' said Evalina Tainer, senior domestic economist with First National Bank of Chicago. ``On the whole, I think we're moving sideways.'' Factory orders are a key economic barometer of manufacturing industry plans, and a decrease may forecaefense capital goods orders, a barometer of business investment plans, turned up 7.0 percent to $38.4 billion ``but didn't even offset last month's drop'' of 10.0 percent. Defense orders, which jumped 12.0 percent in August after the Iraqi invasion, fell back 6.7 percent in September to $7.8 billion. Excluding the defense category, orders rose 0.3 percent. All major durable categories posted declines except for non-electrical machinery - up 6.2 percent to $22.7 billion. These orders thus regained their 5.2 percent loss a month earlier. But transportation orders dropped 6.8 percent to $32.8 billion after a 1.0 percent gain the previous month. A large decline for motor vehicles helped offset a 20 percent increase in aircraft orders. Excluding transportation, orders rose 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Price Hikes Portend Uncertain Future for Romania
DOC.TEXT: Romanians waited in long lines at stores Wednesday, hoping to stock up the day before a tough economic reform package frees prices on basic goods. But the wait was in vain. Bucharest stores were nearly empty, and shoppers who joined snaking lines for the few available items were angry and confused by the planned changes. Most grumbled about lack of information on the reforms, and few believed they would yield quick results. Car owners waited up to 10 hours at gas stations, despite guarantees that gasoline and other energy prices would not increase. Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu promised that the price liberalization Thursday would not affect the cost of housing or basic foodstuffs. But he did not specify which prices would be raised or by how much, adding to the confusion. Such information was available, but apparently only on request. Commerce Ministry official Gheorghe Oana told a reporter that prices of milk, bread, sugar, meats and other staples would not rise before Jan. 1. But some food prices were to rise Thursday, with a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of carrots going from four lei (about 11 cents) to 10 lei, for example, he said. On request, the Commerce Ministry provided figures reflecting a doubling of prices Thursday for clothes, public transport and furniture, among other items. Footwear and leather goods were to triple, and postal and phone rates to rise by about 70 percent. But most Romanians had no access to such information. ``I'm upset we are being kept in the dark for so long,'' one Bucharest man said. ``This is not at all what we were led to expect in the election campaign.'' The National Salvation Front, which took power in the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, promised slow reforms and social protection. But after the Front won overwhelmingly in May elections, Premier Petre Roman sped up reform. In July, legislation was passed on selling failing state-owned industries. Last month the government slashed their credits and energy subsidies. In addition to the price reforms, the national currency was to be devalued Thursday by more than 50 percent to encourage exports. The rate will be 35 lei to the dollar. With the reforms already in place nibbling away on earnings and wage increases still only a promise, some Romanians feared the worst. ``All I know is that life is no longer affordable,'' Ioana Ionescu, a cook, told a reporter. Another woman, working in Bucharest's only laundromat, said she makes 2,300 lei a month, and the average wash now costs a fifth of that. She charged that government arguments that prices must go up to reflect market realities is merely a coverup, a view at least partially shared by some experts. ``In the short term, companies are continuing the old habit of raising prices to cover inefficient production and losses,'' said Stefan Boboc, of Bucharest's Economic Studies Academy. But potential public rage over price hikes is likely to be muted because many goods available on paper at low official prices have in fact been lacking for years, except for a much higher price on the black market. In an interview, Finance Ministry Price Director Constantin Prigoreanu blamed ``both corruption and low production'' for the scarcities. Production has dropped by more than 20 percent this year for a variety of reasons that probably include less fear at the workplace than under Ceausescu. Also, many store managers have been selling under the counter for bribes. They are widely suspected of withholding goods until the new prices come into effect. The government believes real market prices will kill the black market and turn the economy around. But the country's emerging unions charge the reforms will only harm consumers and not improve the economy, unless corrupt managers who survived the Communist downfall are ousted. Viorel Marcu, president of the Bucharest chapter of the Drivers' Union, said there was a thin layer of committed reformers at the top. ``But under it rests a very thick layer of red, and these are the people who we have to deal with,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota GOP Reluctantly Backs Carlson for Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE with petition filed with Minnesota Supreme Court on lieutenant governor issue. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota's conservative Republican Party shelved its reservations about Arne Carlson and backed him for governor in place of Jon Grunseth, who quit the race because of sexual misconduct allegations. But the party's 14-member executive committee Tuesday left the question of Carlson's running mate to the Minnesota Supreme Court. Carlson wants Joanell Dyrstad, his running mate in the September primary. But Sharon Clark, who was Grunseth's running mate, has refused to step aside. Clark today filed a petition with the Minnesota Supreme Court seeking a hearing to determine whether she has the right to the second spot on the ticket or whether Carlson can make his own choice. ``What if a governor and lieutenant governor were running together, and the lieutenant governor decided to step down? Does that mean the governor candidate has to step down also?'' Clark said Tuesday. With only a week to go before Tuesday's election, the GOP executive committee voted unanimously to unite behind Carlson, even though many consider the state auditor too liberal, said party Bob Weinholzer. Carlson supports abortion rights. ``We encourage all Republicans to support Arne Carlson,'' Weinholzer said. Under the law, Carlson, as runner-up in the primary, would have become the GOP candidate anyway after Grunseth withdrew amid allegations he had an affair and swam nude with teen-age girls. Grunseth has disputed the allegations. Carlson, who had jumped into the race last week as a write-in candidate as pressure mounted on Grunseth to drop out, faces three-term Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich. Weinholzer said the party had no choice but to let the Supreme Court decide on Carlson's running mate. ``We have said that Arne Carlson is our candidate for governor. We are supporting him,'' Weinholzer said. ``He has picked his lieutenant governor. The court may decide to overturn it. That is out of our hands.''

DOC.HEAD: Violence Flares in Moldavian Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note material between dashes embargoed for release at 4 p.m. EST.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CHI1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of ethnic Moldavians attacked checkpoints on the frontier with Romania on Wednesday, vowing to ``wipe border posts off the face of the Earth,'' the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. The militants, who seek closer ties to Romania, threatened to kill border guards and their families unless the Kremlin withdraws troops sent to Moldavia last week to enforce a state of emergency, Tass said. Tass did not mention any casualties. It said the militants threw stones and set fire to a fence but relinquished control of the two checkpoints after speaking with Moldavian leaders. Part of Moldavia was Romanian territory until it was annexed by the Soviets during World War II. Some ethnic Moldavians, many of them Romanians by birth or descent, want to secede from the Soviet Union and rejoin Romania. However, the Gagauz, an ethnic minority numbering about 150,000, want to secede from Moldavia. Wednesday's border unrest was the first reported violence since the Gagauz minority began its secession drive last month. ---=
DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for Release at 4 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Romania's president, meanwhile, told Austrian television his country has no designs on Soviet Moldavia. Ion Iliescu, in comments recorded before the attacks on the border checkpoints, said Romanians are concerned about ethnic Romanians in the Soviet Union but do not seek to revise the borders.
DOC.HEAD: End Embargoed Material
DOC.TEXT: ---= Tass said 3,000 militants stormed the border checkpoints. However, the independent news agency Interfax put the number of militants at 7,000. The discrepancy could not be resolved immediately. ``The militants pelted the Stoyanovka checkpoint with stones and then set the fence around it on fire,'' Tass said. Stoyanovka is a town on the border with Romania. Moldavian leaders flew to the scene and persuaded the militants to surrender the two checkpoints they were blocking, Tass said without providing details. It did not say if both checkpoints were in Stoyanovka. The Gagauz, descendants of Christians who fled religious persecution in Turkey 160 years ago, claimed control over part of Moldavia in October. They feared rising Moldavian nationalism and were angry over a law making Moldavian the republic's official language. Last week, the Gagauz began elections for an autonomous government. Ethnic Moldavians opposed the move, and the elections were called off Saturday after talks between Gagauz representatives and a Soviet-Moldavian committee. The legislature of the Gagauz republic, which Moldavia's parliament declared unconstitutional, elected a president on Tuesday. He is Stepan Topal, a 52-year-old civil engineer. The militants who attacked the frontier checkpoints Wednesday also threatened to go to the Moldavian capital of Kishinev ``to restore order,'' according to Tass. The Moldavian Interior Ministry, reached by telephone in Kishinev, declined to comment on the unrest. Moldavia's Communist Party Central Committee issued a statement condemning use of ``power methods to solve national, political and other conflicts by stirring up passions and mass psychosis.'' It condemned seizures of party buildings in several towns in the republic. In June, tens of thousands of Romanians and Moldavians forced open several border crossings on the anniversary of Moscow's annexation of the region. In May, tens of thousands of Romanians streamed across eight bridges on a border river for the first time in more than a half-century.

DOC.HEAD: Mechanical Bugs Slow Tests of Pacific Chemical Weapons Incinerator
LaserPhoto HU1
DOC.TEXT: Mechanical glitches are plaguing a trial run of the Army's chemical weapons incinerator on this Pacific island, but officials expect to finish destroying deadly stockpiles on schedule. It's been a rough first few months for the Johnston Atoll Chemical Agent Disposal System, the first of nine incinerators planned to rid the United States of its aging chemical weapons. The high-tech incinerator, criticized by Pacific island leaders and environmental groups, has operated just 22 percent of the time since testing began in June, officials said. The Army conducted the first media tour of the island and the incinerator plant Tuesday. About 70 reporters and photographers were given a tour. The $240 million plant was built to destroy 300,000 aging chemical weapons moved here from Okinawa in 1971 and 100,000 rounds en route from Germany - 6.6 percent of the U.S. stockpile - at this flat, windswept island 800 miles southwest of Honolulu. About 1,300 people - civilian contract workers at the plant and military members - live on the island, which has no indigenous population. The Environmental Protection Agency will decide whether to allow the Army to destroy more weapons after the test period is completed late next year. The operation is expected to wind up by 1995. Charles Baronian, deputy program manager for the plant, said officials had hoped to have the plant working 70 percent of the time during a 16-month test. Although the glitches won't doom the program, Baronian called them ``very depressing for an engineer.'' ``It's not unusual for a brand new plant to have these kinds of problems,'' Baronian said. ``However, we're seeing more of these types of problems than frankly we anticipated.'' The main problem, Baronian said, is debris jamming a conveyor that carries away nerve gas rocket parts after incineration. Any breakdown in the system shuts down the entire plant. The glitches do not release any nerve gas and do not endanger plant employees. Still, Baronian said plant managers would rather err on the side of caution and shut down for any problem, no matter how minor. The Army will use what it learns from this plant at eight planned mainland incinerators that are to destroy all aging weapons by 1997, as required by Congress. Those plant sites are Umatilla, Ore.; Tooele, Utah; Pueblo, Colo.; Newport, Ind.; Aberdeen, Md.; Anniston, Ala.; Lexington, Ky.; and Pine Bluff, Ark. The Army decided the safest plan was to build incinerators where the weapons are stored. Besides the breakdowns, the project has suffered from a public relations problem. Some Pacific leaders openly worry the plant may be used to incinerate hazardous waste and chemical munitions from mainland storage sites. The South Pacific Forum, an organization of regional governments, claims the use of Johnston Atoll could make the region ``the toxic waste disposal center of the world.'' President Bush addressed those concerns Saturday when he met in Honolulu with leaders of 11 Pacific nations. Bush told them the United States is following strict environmental guidelines and will use the plant only on weapons already on Johnston Island and those from Europe. A small cache of World War II-era weapons also will be brought from the Solomon Islands. Brig. Gen. Walter L. Busbee, program manager for chemical demilitarization, said Johnston would be out of the chemical weapons business when incineration winds up in 1994. He said the plant would be unable to operate safely beyond 1994 without extensive renovation, and would not have the capacity to handle weapons from other sites. He also cited the prohibitive costs of operating such a large complex at such a remote location. The plant was running during Tuesday's two-hour tour, and destroyed 79 M-55 nerve gas rockets before reporters left the island. The plant has destroyed about 3,500 rockets since June.

DOC.HEAD: Craig Russell, Mae West Impersonator, Dead at 42
DOC.TEXT: Female impersonator Craig Russell has died of a stroke resulting from AIDS, a hospital official said today. He was 42. The actor died Tuesday night at Toronto Western Hospital, according to spokeswoman Lucie Baistrocchi. Russell became an international box office success with the 1977 movie ``Outrageous,'' a low-budget, semi-autobiographical film in which he performed many of his impersonations, especially of his idol, Mae West. He acted in nightclubs and on television after that, and in 1986 did a sequel to his film hit called ``Too Outrageous.'' Born in Toronto, Russell began his performing career on the city's homosexual club circuit and was also known for his impersonations of Judy Garland, Bette Davis and other Hollywood stars. At age 17, he lived in Ms. West's house in Los Angeles and worked for a time as her part-time secretary. His survivors and funeral plans were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Mix Entertainment and Elections - And Then There's CNN
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three television networks plan election night coverage in varying degrees of depth, but the Cable News Network is planning its most intensive coverage of an off-year election. ABC and NBC plan their principal coverage in hour-long news specials at 10 p.m. EST, followed by local news at 11 p.m.; CBS plans a two-hour show, from 9 to 11 p.m., and all three plan 11:30 p.m. wrapup reports. CNN's main coverage runs from 7 p.m. EST to 1 a.m., when its 90-minute wrapup show begins. Its final wrapup is at 3 a.m. ``This is the most extensive coverage we've had in an off year,'' said CNN spokeswoman Melinda McIntire. As they did in the last off-year elections in 1986, NBC and ABC are leading into full-time coverage with prime time shows; CBS, the only network that filled all of prime time with its coverage in '86, has cut back an hour. This year, CBS pre-empts its ``Tuesday Night Movie,'' while NBC and ABC, respectively, pre-empt ``Law and Order'' and ``thirtysomething.'' Cliff Kappler, NBC's senior producer of news specials, said technology has cut the time networks must devote to elections. ``I think it compares favorably to the amount of ground that we cover, but we will do it in an infinitely quicker time,'' he said. This is the first year that all four networks pool resources for exit polling and winner projections, in a $12 million joint venture called Voter Research and Surveys, or VRS. VRS gives each network polls and projections for all Senate, House and governor's races, and state and local races of national interest, such as the Washington, D.C., mayor's race and California's propositions. The exit polls ``provide demographic profiles of each candidate's constituents and the role of issues, such as abortion and President Bush's performance, in shaping voters' choice for office,'' CBS said. ABC has scheduled two special reports of between three and five minutes by David Brinkley between 8 p.m. and 10 p.m. EST, when the network opens its main coverage anchored by Peter Jennings. NBC News offers brief reports between 8 p.m. and 10 p.m. EST. Then, at 10 p.m., Tom Brokaw will anchor ``Decision '90,'' with analysis by John Chancellor. NBC will provide analysis of the elections with Ron Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. CBS' special coverage, anchored by Dan Rather in New York City, opens at 8 p.m. EST with a seven-minute report. From 9 p.m. to 11 p.m., CBS offers its ``Campaign '90: Election Night.'' Serious election night junkies will tune into CNN, which opens its coverage at 6:30 p.m. EST with its principal Washington anchor, Bernard Shaw, for an election night preview edition of ``The World Today.'' The main coverage begins at 7 p.m. CNN's political commentators will include analyst Frederick Allen, political columnist William Schneider of the Los Angeles Times, and Patrick Buchanan, Michael Kinsley, Robert Novak and Mark Shields.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Looting Abandoned Embassies, Asians Died of Starvation
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops are looting abandoned embassies in Kuwait and some Asian workers trapped in the country have died of starvation, an escaped Kuwaiti businessman said Wednesday. The businessman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the U.N. blockade against Iraq would fail because Jordanian trucks are bringing in fresh vegetables and in any case, the Iraqis are used to hardship. He said he escaped in an eight-car convoy which took two days to cover a 30-mile trip. His claims could not be independently verified but other escapees have described similar conditions. At a news conference, he painted a picture of a looted and frightened Kuwait with almost no food available. ``Asians were the number one casualties of starvation,'' he said. ``I've seen with my own eyes, some of these laborers digging garbage and looking for food.'' Thousands of Asians were kept in a compound without food and water for 10 days after the Aug. 2 invasion and nobody knows how many died, he said. ``My company had a thousand Asian workers. The first few days, they were surrounded and not allowed to go to their camp or any place. Many of them were sick and God knows how many were dead, not by bullet or anything, but by starvation,'' he said. ``All the hospitals are functioning only for emergency and what the doctor can do with his bare hands. There's no medicine. Nothing,'' he said. The Iraqi army is digging in and camping in schools. Anyone caught with more than a week's supply of food or harboring a foreigner is immediately executed, he said. Kuwaitis are being pressured to become Iraqi citizens and every week, about 100 Iraqi families arrive to move into houses left by fleeing Kuwaitis. ``We are waiting for a big hit,'' he said. ``Nobody is believing in the peaceful solution.'' The Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait may be tired but they are fiercely loyal to Saddam Hussein. They are used to living on meals of dry bread, tea and perhaps some cheese ``if they are good,'' he said. ``They've been living on that for the past eight years,'' he said referring to the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. ``Do you expect the blockade is going to work on them?'' ``Jordanian trucks are all over Kuwait,'' he said. ``I saw them bringing vegetables and taking furniture and computers and hi-tech stuff back.'' He also said Iraqi soldiers had stripped a year's supply of food from Kuwaiti warehouses, and that he had watched abandoned embassies being looted. ``For every embassy he (Saddam) surrounded after they leave, he takes every possession inside the embassy,'' he said. After annexing Kuwait, Saddam ordered diplomats to move to Baghdad. Then, he cut water and electricity supplies and refused to let any food into the diplomatic compounds. Only the United States and Britain still have diplomats in Kuwait City. The businessman said that many Kuwaitis who have held out since the invasion now want to leave as Saddam increases pressure on them to become Iraqi citizens. Saddam has cut gasoline supplies to any car with Kuwaiti license plates. ``To be able to get gasoline you had to change your tag from Kuwaiti to Iraq-Kuwait, you have to have Iraqi citizenship,'' the businessman said. ``And if you change it, that means you have to be drafted,'' he said. The businessman said the Iraqis had looted every piece of high-technology and construction equipment. Some trucks and bulldozers taken by the army got an instant khaki paint job. The only thing left in the Highway Patrol Department, he said, is ``the floor and the ceiling.'' The Iraqis also carted away satellite equipment from the Department of Communications worth about $1 billion, he said. ``Even the light poles are pulled out. Street signs have been pulled out, because it's big, high value. It's made out of aluminum,'' he said. ``In the last days, he started even collecting scrap metal from damaged cars ... for his defense industry,'' he said. ``They put us back 50 years,'' he said. ``It's going to take at least, to my point of view, 25 years of building to repair the damage that has been done in Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Bare-Knuckle Fights in the Mother of Parliaments
DOC.TEXT: It may be the Mother of Parliaments. But lately the House of Commons sounds more like the school yard. Having denounced opposition leader Neil Kinnock last week as a ``crypto-Communist,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is now taunting him about his height. The exchange came on Tuesday, with Mrs. Thatcher feeling combative after another one-woman battle with the other 11 leaders of the European Community. The issue was a single European currency and closer political ties. Mrs. Thatcher's position, as she summarized it for the house, was ``NO, NO, NO.'' Kinnock had disturbed the prime minister by inviting her to declare her support for Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe, who politely disagrees with Mrs. Thatcher's opposition to a single European currency. ``The deputy prime minister is too big a man to need a little man like you to stand up for him,'' Mrs. Thatcher barked at the 5-foot-9 Kinnock.
