Kinnock attempted a counter-punch. ``Don't you appreciate that even now your tantrum tactics won't stop the process of change?'' he asked Mrs. Thatcher. Kinnock, she retorted, would have abandoned Britain's sovereignty and its coinage ``for the sake of being little Sir Echo and saying, `me too.''' Mrs. Thatcher is 4{ inches shorter than Kinnock, but with high heels and an imperious manner she somehow looks taller when glaring at the Labor Party leader across the table that divides the Commons. On Wednesday, the newspaper pundits declared Mrs. Thatcher the winner. She prevailed, wrote Matthew Parris of The Times, ``by neither reason nor persuasion and certainly by no felicity of language. It was won by self-assurance, and by just standing there and shouting.'' The Commons has always been prone to rowdiness. But it's getting worse, especially during the twice-weekly, 15-minute sessions known as prime minister's question time. ``She has lost all inhibition,'' said Andy Roth, an American who edits a House of Commons' in-house bible, Parliamentary Profiles. ``What makes it worse now is the particularly bad relationship between Thatcher and Kinnock,'' he added in an interview. ``Most of them are brought up on the Oxford Union debating tradition of `You're a moron, I'm a genius.' But quite often they have a good relationship outside Parliament. With these two there's nothing. It's become a bare-knuckle fight.'' Even abuse has its formalities: members refer to each other as the Honorable Gentlemen or the Honorable Lady. It makes for bizarre combinations. In an exchange about Iraq, Labor lawmaker Andrew Faulds urged Mrs. Thatcher to try negotiations, and then sputtered: ``You stupid, negative woman.'' ``I seem to hear the stench of appeasement in the air, the rather nauseating stench of appeasement,'' Mrs. Thatcher replied. ``You love war!'' Faulds shouted, and Speaker Bernard Weatherill had had enough. ``That is very bad behavior from the honorable gentleman,'' Weatherill admonished. ``He must not shout in that way.'' All around, Laborites and Tories shouted at each other and pandemonium raged. Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker sat behind Mrs. Thatcher, distractedly chewing a rolled up Order Paper in between dutiful, supportive smiles. That's the British Parliament, the 1,000-year-old body which, as Mrs. Thatcher bayed above the tumult, has shown the way in war and peace. ``I believe the traditions and example of this House have gone the world over, with admiration,'' she said. ``I believe they have served not only this country well, but served Europe well ... this House kept sitting when the lights of Europe went out.''

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact Will Abandon Military Role, Hungarian Official Says
DOC.TEXT: After menacing the West with Soviet-led military might for more than three decades, the Warsaw Pact reportedly will cease to exist as a military alliance next year. A senior Hungarian official said Wednesday the six-nation alliance would end joint military maneuvers in December and would stop operating as a military alliance in June. Thereafter, the Waraw Pact would function ``only as a political forum,'' he added. The official, who spoke to selected reporters on condition of anonymity, gave no further details. The Warsaw Pact was formed in 1955 in the early years of the Cold War as a Soviet response to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Originally comprised of the Soviet Union, Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania, the alliance was reduced to seven members after Albania withdrew in 1968. The pact began to lose cohesion with the start of liberalization within the Soviet Union. That led to the advent of democracy in East Europe last year and a further weakening of the alliance, which was reduced to six members with the unification of Germany. At nearly completed conventional arms talks with the 16-nation NATO, Warsaw Pact members are basically negotiating as individual countries. The pact nations often advocate positions closer to those of the West than to Moscow. The Kremlin is withdrawing its forces from several former satellites, including Hungary, which was among the East bloc nations that ousted the Communist Party last year. Col. Anatoli Kirilov, deputy commander of the Soviet troops in Hungary, said Wednesday that all his soldiers would be out of the country by June 30, 1991, as scheduled under an agreement signed in March. By late October, more than half the 50,000 Soviet troops had left, the state MTI news agency reported. Hungary announced earlier it would leave the military arm of the Warsaw Pact next year unless the military functions ceased. Last week, Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel said the pact's military structure would be abolished and turned into a body with a ``consultative political function,'' the Czechoslovak state news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Years After Slaying, Celebrity Case Goes to Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with opening statement from prosecutor. Picks up 6th graf, `Prosecutors contend...'.
DOC.TEXT: Seven years after New York theatrical producer Roy Radin was shot to death in the midst of a movie deal, the lights went up today on the ``Cotton Club'' case, a tale of drugs and greed in 1980s Hollywood. Deputy District Attorney David Conn opened the trial by telling the jury he would prove that three men on trial killed Radin on the orders of reputed Miami cocaine dealer and chief defendant Karen DeLayne ``Laney'' Greenberger. The trial is expected to explore deal making in Hollywood, its ties to the cocaine trade and how Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt's private militia got involved. The prosecutor alleged that Mrs. Greenberger, 43, ordered the killing because she was being cut out of profits from ``The Cotton Club'' movie deal she had helped organize between Radin and producer Robert Evans. ``Each of the defendants were involved in a conspiracy to kidnap and kill Roy Radin,'' Conn said. ``And each defendant did it for one purpose only, for financial gain and for their own personal greed.'' On trial are Mrs. Greenberger and three former bodyguards for Flynt. All four defendants could face the death penalty. The jury was told how Radin was taken to a remote canyon and shot at least 10 times in the head. Conn said a stick of dynamite was then placed in Radin's mouth and ignited to destroy his face and prevent identification. Prosecutors contend Greenberger's feeling that she was being pushed out of any profits from the movie deal and a dispute over stolen cocaine led her to hire William Mentzer, 41, her former boyfriend, and Alex Marti, 29, to do away with Radin. The fourth defendant is Robert Lowe, 44. He is accused of driving the limousine that took Radin to his appointment with death. Radin, 33, has been described by witnesses as an obese, cocaine-sniffing impresario who sought to expand his show business connections to Hollywood. Among those on the witness list is Demond Wilson, former star of television's ``Sanford and Son.'' He was a cocaine-sniffing buddy of Radin and was with him hours before the slaying. Wilson has since become a minister. In 1983, Mrs. Greenberger introduced Radin to Evans, the producer of such films as ``Chinatown'' and ``Marathon Man'' and former head of production at Paramount Pictures. Soon, Mrs. Greenberger was demanding a share of the profits from ``The Cotton Club.'' Radin was last seen May 13, 1983, stepping into a limousine with Mrs. Greenberger en route to a business dinner in Beverly Hills. They never arrived. A month later, Radin's body was found in a dry riverbed 65 miles north of Los Angeles - a location identified in testimony as a frequent target shooting range for the Flynt bodyguards. He had been shot repeatedly in the head. The case remained a mystery until 1988, when prosecutors filed charges. New evidence from William Rider, former head of Flynt's security force, linked the defendants to the murder through statements he said they made in his presence. Rider also implicated Evans, who invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and declined to testify at a preliminary hearing last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's `Had It' With Iraqi Mistreatment of Americans
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared Wednesday ``I have had it'' with Iraq's mistreatment of American hostages but said the United States has not moved closer to war. He also said he was willing to wait longer for economic sanctions to hurt Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Bush expressed disappointment that the sanctions have not had more impact on Saddam. ``I know some of our partners thought that the economic pressure by now would have come close to compelling him to withdraw,'' he said. ``I've not had a view on that.'' The president also voiced unhappiness that representative of other countries are traveling to Baghdad to deal with Saddam on hostages and the gulf crisis. ``Every time somebody sends an emissary, that gives Saddam Hussein a little bit of hope that there might be some way that he can stop short of doing what he must do - get out of Kuwait unconditionally, free these people that are being held against their will and have the legitimate government restored,'' Bush said. The president did not single out any country, but officials from the Soviet Union, France and Britain have visited Iraq recently. The president used two news conferences and a political speech to turn up the verbal heat on Iraq. It was the third consecutive day of blistering attack by Bush against Saddam. Bush heatedly rejected suggestions that he was trying to divert attention from the budget debacle that sent his poll ratings into a nose dive just before important congressional elections. ``I don't think any decent, honorable person would ever suggest anything of that nature,'' Bush said, adding that he was offended by the suggestion. With 250,000 American troops poised for conflict in the gulf, Congress is pressing Bush to allow more time for sanctions to work. Administration officials said Bush's saber-rattling was intended to signal Saddam that the United States is not bluffing and to call attention to the plight of American hostages. In particular, Bush deplored the conditions endured by American diplomats in Kuwait, where Iraqi forces have cut off water, power and food to the U.S. Embassy. ``Our people inside are being starved by a brutal dictator,'' Bush said. ``And do you think I'm concerned about it? You're darn right I am. ``And what am I going to do about it? Let's just wait and see. Because I have had it with that kind of treatment of Americans.'' Bush said he did not know how long the diplomats could hold out before they might be forced to withdraw. He said that if Iraq blocked a resupply effort, ``it would be directly contravening a mandate from the United Nations and we would view that very seriously.'' Speaking about the U.N. sanctions, Bush said they had not been ``totally effective.'' He said, ``I am prepared at this juncture to wait to see if economic sanctions will work - at this juncture.'' Bush said he did not know how long he would wait. ``There's no date of that nature in mind,'' he said. The State Department said there were ``some signs of real shortages'' in Iraq in industrial goods, raw materials, machinery and other products. The embargo on oil exports is costing Baghdad $2.5 billion a month, based on a $31 a barrel price, said spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``No one can say at this point how rapidly these shortages will translate into meaningful decisions, particularly since Saddam Hussein has made clear this his army will be the last to be touched by shortages and that he does not care how much the people of Iraq may suffer to protect that army,'' she said. She cited press reports that American hostages were being singled out for particularly harsh treatment. ``We understand that conditions are appalling in some detention facilities.'' Miss Tutwiler quoted returning Western hostages as saying that Miles Hoffman, an American who was shot while trying to evade capture by Iraqi forces, was in deteriorating condition and in serious need of medical care. She said Iraq has ignored U.S. demands for the immediate evacuation of all Americans, particularly the sick. ``Detainees with medical needs, like Mr. Hoffman, have become the victims of Saddam Hussein's barbaric `guest' policy,'' she said. At a separate news conference, Iraq's Ambassador, Mohamed Al-Mashat, indicated Iraq will not allow supplies to be shipped to the embassy in Kuwait. ``We have said time and time again there is no reason for those embassies to be there,'' Al-Mashat said. Only the British and the Americans have kept their embassies open in Kuwait City. Bush said his tough comments are not intended as a rationale for military action. ``You don't use pretext when you have force deployed. ... You don't need any pretext, you just do what's right. I am concerned about the lives of Americans held against their will.'' In another development, Bush met at the White House with Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Agostino Casaroli. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush expressed appreciation for the Vatican's support for the U.N. sanctions. ``Both leaders expressed the hope that a peaceful resolution to the current crisis could be found,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Moslem Groups Agree to Truce
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem factions agreed to begin a cease-fire Wednesday and withdraw forces, but past truces quickly collapsed and some officials wonder how much control the warlords are willing to relinquish. Police reported the cease-fire between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal movement began at midnight. Their three-year battle has killed at least 1,100 since June 1987, police estimate. A joint communique indicated they expect further meetings to discuss a possible prisoner exchange pending ``a comprehensive and final settlement under the auspices of Syria and Iran.'' The Moslem Voice of the Nation radio said Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati was due in the Syrian capital of Damascus this week to work on ``an agreement putting an end to the Amal-Hezbollah dispute.'' The pact bolstered President Elias Hrawi's efforts to implement an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, which has claimed more than 150,000 lives. The government said efforts to demilitarize Beirut and surrounding hills is ``progressing quickly.'' There have been dozens of failed cease-fires in the feud for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. The present cease-fire was called after meetings between senior leaders of the two factions. The talks in Anjar, east of Beirut, were attended by Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan, Syria's military intelligence chief in Lebanon, and Iran's Ambassador to Syria, Mohammad Akhtari. Hezbollah, which is blamed for many terrorist attacks, is considered to be the umbrella organization for extremist groups holding foreign hostages in Lebanon, including six Americans. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said fighters of both factions still hold their positions in south Lebanon, where some of the worst clashes took place. ``We don't expect them to withdraw unless Syria and Iran succeed in working out a political settlement to the conflict,'' the spokesman said. Hezbollah and Amal say they will withdraw fighters from a 15-mile coastal strip that includes Beirut. Agriculture Minister Mohsen Dalloul announced earlier Wednesday that the right-wing Christian Lebanese Forces militia, led by Samir Geagea, also agreed to withdraw from the war-battered capital. The other main militia, the Druse Moslem Progressive Socialist Party led by Walid Jumblatt, has also consented to pull out of the city. ``We break the good news to the Lebanese people, who are longing for peace,'' Dalloul announced after a five-hour meeting with Geagea and Defense Minister Albert Mansour. Dalloul, a Shiite, and Defense Minister Albert Mansour, a Greek Orthodox Catholic, have been assigned by the government to negotiate the militia withdrawal. The government has not yet set a deadline for the withdrawal, but Hrawi is expected to press for it as soon as possible. Hrawi announced the plan after the Syrian army and Lebanese troops crushed rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's forces in an eight-hour offensive Oct. 13. Morethan 500 people, including about 200 Syrian soldiers, were killed and 1,200 wounded. The collapse of Aoun, who fled to refuge in the French Embassy, removed a major obstacle to the peace plan Hrawi was elected last November to implement. Aoun opposed the accord because it did not guarantee a complete withdrawal by Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon, who he considered an army of occupation. Aoun and Hrawi are Maronite Catholics, who have dominated Lebaneses politics since the nation's independence from France in 1943. The Syrians have said they will pull out of Beirut and other cities to the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon within six months of the plan being implemented. But many believe other rival commanders fear making the first move to withdraw and leave their forces exposed to attack. Geagea, for instance, faces threats from Syrian-backed Christians. Jumblatt, whose 200,000-member Druse sect if one of the smallest in Lebanon, has been critical of Hrawi's government and has vowed to keep government authority from extending to his stronghold in the Chouf Mountains southeast of Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Battles A Troublesom Free Press
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino once counted the press as an ally in her fight against the late Ferdinand Marcos. Now, she feels like a victim of ``journalistic oppression.'' She told members of the Foreign Correspondents Association of the Philippines on Tuesday that her administration's greatest political contribution was the restoration of democracy, notably press freedom, after nearly two decades of authoritarian rule. ``In that fight, of course, we had the help of a host of local and foreign newsmen,'' Mrs. Aquino said. ``Yet, when the dust of battle settled, one realized almost immediately that the press was never really a combatant, never truly an ally; that it was on the front lines only as observer.'' ``The press,'' she said, ``is not only an inconstant ally, it is also not a proper one and is an impractical one. Not only is it contentious; it is, at its best, critical - of organized government, of history, of humanity itself.'' Mrs. Aquino was thrust into politics and into the anti-Marcos movement after her husband, the former Sen. Benigno Aquino, was murdered in August 1983 on his return from exile to lead the opposition. The local and the foreign press portrayed Mrs. Aquino as a grieving widow, a simple housewife who was a reluctant challenger to Marcos, and later as a champion of democracy after a ``people power revolution'' in February 1986 swept her to power. In the aftermath of the revolt, newspapers mushroomed, and a dozen talk shows competed for television and radio air time. Meanwhile, an army of reporters and photographers hounded Mrs. Aquino wherever she went. In the beginning, the presidential palace tolerated the familiarity of the press towards Mrs. Aquino. The president, sometimes addressed by her nickname, Cory, fielded questions during what reporters call ``ambush'' or curbside interviews. But after a series of coup attempts involving Marcos loyalist officers and later military reformists who plotted the overthrow of the late president, security was tightened and such interviewa were not allowed. The move was understood, but with resentment among some reporters and columnists, who felt presidential aides were taking the first steps in throwing a ``cordon sanitaire'' that deprived Mrs. Aquino of feeling the real pulse of the people. Then, numerous government scandals broke out, dominating the headlines and talk shows. Slowly, the criticism hurled at Cabinet and other government officials was reaching Mrs. Aquino herself. Some of Mrs. Aquino's bitterest critics in the local press were among those who had marched with her in anti-Marcos demonstrations. A common theme of their attacks is that her government lacks direction and is just as corrupt as that of Marcos. Mrs. Aquino has often complained that the press today does not report on the achievements of her government and the effort it is making to improve the lives of ordinary Filipinos. She says that sometimes, officials feel that ``the country we read about is not the Philippines but a terrible, cursed land in an outlandish world created by the imagination of reporters and columnists.'' But Mrs. Aquino has not indicated she is sorry she fought to restore press freedom. ``Nevertheless,'' she said, ``the sometimes abusive and sometimes licentious press that we sometimes have is preferable to a controlled press that reflects only one side of the news.'' She said that there has been no indication of media repression. ``In fact,'' she said, ``the reverse could be true and the harassed government could be the one feeling a bit of journalistic oppression.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Up 1.1 Percent, More Than Double Income Increase
DOC.TEXT: Americans' consumer spending jumped 1.1 percent in September, the government said Wednesday, outpacing a 0.5 percent growth in personal income and contributing to the lowest savings rate in three years. The Commerce Department report ``shows consumer purchasing power obviously is under intense pressure in the aftermath of the (Persian Gulf) oil shock,'' said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist with Morgan Stanley & Co. Nevertheless, Roach added, ``Consumers are really sort of clinging tenaciously to their lifestyles. Their spending is holding up just fine.'' However, the Federal Reserve reported separately on Wednesday that consumers' and businesses' confidence in the eonomy was waning in many regions of the country. Every one of the central bank's 12 districts was reporting either slower growth or an actual decline in economic activity. ``Most districts reported that retailers were generally pessimistic. ... (They) blamed lower consumer confidence brought on by greater uncertainty and higher fuel prices,'' said the Federal Reserve's report based on information collected through Oct. 19. The Commerce Department said that Americans' incomes reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.70 trillion in September, a $23.8 billion increase over August. At the same time, it said spending reached a rate of $3.73 trillion, up $39.9 billion from a month earlier. It was the biggest increase since a 1.2 percent gain last June. In its report on the third-quarter gross national product on Tuesday, the department had said consumer spending from July through September rose 3.6 percent, well above the 0.2 percent advance from April through June. But Roach said spending will drop to ``the 1 percent vicinity'' during the current quarter. ``There's no way we'll be able to hold (the 3.6 percent pace) up in the weak income and low savings environment,'' he said. Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of U.S. economic activity and Roach said the lower level of consumption this quarter means a temporary decline in overall economic growth. But he said his company was not projecting two consecutive quarters of declining gross national product, the total output of the nation's goods and services. The Commerce report said the rate of Americans' savings as a percent of disposable income fell to 3.5 percent, down from 4.1 percent in August and the lowest since a 3.3 percent rate in October 1987. The report said Americans' income after taxes increased 0.4 percent, up from a 0.2 percent gain in August. The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending rose 0.3 percent after declining 0.1 percent in August. Disposable, or after-tax, income fell 0.3 percent on top of a 0.5 percent drop the previous month. A key component of the income category - wages and salaries - rose $17.4 billion, up from $600 million the previous month. The $39.9 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, was up from a $20.1 billion gain in August. Spending on durable goods - ``big-ticket'' items expected to last more than three years - totaled $487 billion, up from $477 billion from August. Non-durable spending rose $11 billion to $1.2 trillion following a $10.6 billion gain in August. Spending on services was up $18.2 billion to $2.0 trillion after a $18.2 billion gain the previous month.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS second item to make IMPORTANT CORRECTION in first graf that the magazine being sued is High Society not High Times; SUBS final graf with no comment from the magazine
DOC.TEXT: Rock 'n' roll pioneer Chuck Berry is suing the magazine High Society, saying it published stolen nude photos of him with several women. In the suit filed Monday in St. Louis Circuit Court, Berry claims that the magazine published eight photographs of him posing with unidentified nude women as the cover story for its January edition. The suit says the photos were stolen, and claims their publication violated Berry's privacy. An official of the magazine who declined to give his name said the magazine would not comment because it had not been served with papers in the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Looting Soldiers Block Food Aid Among Starving Liberians
DOC.TEXT: Looting and pillaging by the remnants of Liberian Army units have disrupted food distribution in areas where dozens of people die each day of starvation, relief workers said Wednesday. Soliders of slain President Samuel Doe's army roam freely through eastern Monrovia and man roadblocks alongside troops from a five-nation West African task force sent to end Liberia's 10-month-old civil war. Refugees who fled to neighboring Ivory Coast claim the soldiers and West African troops are looting what little is left in the capital city's eastern suburbs. ``As soon as the food distribution started last week, the soldiers just moved in and took the rice from civilians. We had to stop giving it out,'' said a European aid worker. He said they hoped to resume distribution this week. The first substantial food shipment arrived last Thursday, but security precautions have slowed offloading of 1,930 tons of rice from the United States and 600 tons from the U.N. World Food Program. Between 50 and 60 people are dying every day in Monrovia from starvation and diseases caused by malnutrition and lack of water, said Joe Goettia, deputy assistant director with the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. ``People are dying like flies,'' said Belgian Dr. Pieter Rykelykhuizen of Doctors Without Borders, an aid group. Between 10,000 and 13,000 civilians have died in the war between the three Liberian factions, the office said. The unrest began when rebel forces led by Charles Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Doe was killed during fighting in September between his troops and forces loyal to Prince Johnson, head of a splinter rebel group. Taylor's forces control most of the nation and he has declared himself president. Johnson on Tuesday threatened to break a cease-fire with the remnants of Doe's troops unless the West Africans force the soldiers back to their barracks, reports from Monrovia said. It was unclear why the West Africans are accompanied by Doe's troops. No immediate comment was available from the West African force, which includes Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia. Some opponents note the multinational command has been taken over by Nigerians, and its president, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, supported Doe. ``If Nigeria wants to try a Vietnam-type of war like the Americans, they can try, but we have absolutely no intention of surrendering our sovereignty to Nigeria,'' Taylor chief spokesman, Tom Woewiyu, told reporters in Abidjan on Wednesday. Nigerian and Ghanaian ships have carried thousands of soldiers, tanks and other weapons to Monrovia. But since they arrived Aug. 5 they have brought only 150 tons of rice. More than half of Liberia's 2.3 million people have fled the country or have been displaced from their homes. Officials in Sierra Leone sent a letter Tuesday to the secretariat of the West African army and the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees saying it cannot cope with the health, security and food problems caused by the refugee influx. The letter claimed the refugee population has swelled to 280,000, while U.N. and other relief agencies are providing food for only 60,000. Last week, the Sierra Leone government threatened to close its borders to Liberian refugees unless it got more international help. In Nigeria, Liberian refugees went on a rampage, throwing stones, plates and food at relief officials, the Lagos newspaper Punch reported Wednesday. It said the fracas Tuesday night was started by refugees charging relief workers were not distributing food and relief materials fairly.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO FIX DEATH TOLL IN OVERLINE
24 Killed In New Attempt To Storm Temple
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to update with additional deaths, State Department comment. Picks up 7th graf pvs ``The dispute...''.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Hindu fundamentalists failed in a new attempt Wednesday to storm an ancient shrine claimed by Moslems, and at least 24 more people died in violence sparked by the dispute. A government minister resigned to protest Prime Minister V.P. Singh's attempts to block construction of a Hindu temple on the disputed site, deepening the crisis in his beleaguered coalition. Armed paramilitary troops blocked about 5,000 Hindus from attempting to re-enter the mosque in Ayodhya, which has been the center of a decades-old dispute between India's Hindu majority and Moslem minority. Hindu fundamentalists broke through police cordons on Tuesday and chipped away bricks and bits of plaster from the one-story mosque, which they want to replace with a temple. At least five Hindus were killed and 20 injured when police opened fire to throw back the rioters. At least two of the injured died Wednesday, doctors said. Press Trust of India said at least 22 other people were killed in street battles between Hindus and Moslems in four widely separated cities. id contributed to the crisis. The Bombay-based newspaper, Free Press Journal, said: ``The magnitude of damage that this one man has done to the country ... cannot be assessed in terms of the number of people killed or maimed. The poses of anguish and remorse that he now strikes are so phony that few in this country would be taken in by them.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says Georgia Used Illegal Confession To Get Death Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for a Georgia death row inmate on Wednesday accused the state of using an illegally obtained jailhouse confession to convict his client and hiding this information from defense lawyers. John Boger, arguing before the Supreme Court in behalf of Warren McCleskey, said the state for nine years withheld from defense lawyers a written statement from the inmate to whom McCleskey allegedly confessed o the 1978 slaying of an Atlanta police officer in a furniture store robbery. ``The reason it was held back is clear,'' Boger said. ``It was the smoking gun.'' But Assistant Georgia Attorney General Mary Beth Westmoreland denied that the state withheld the statement or concealed it from the defense. She said McCleskey's lawyers simply failed to ask for it. ``The state's position is that counsel made a mistake and this man shall die because of that mistake, is that your position?'' Justice Thurgood Marshall asked Ms. Westmoreland. ``Yes your honor,'' she replied, ``That is our position.'' A federal judge last year reversed McCleskey's murder conviction after ruling that the state had violated his constitutional rights in obtaining the confession to inmate Offie Evans. But the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated the conviction, ruling that McCleskey's lawyers had forfeited their right to challenge the constitutionality of the confession when they failed to raise the issue in his initial appeal in 1981. Boger argued Wednesday there was nothing in the written record of the case to suggest that a statement from Evans existed. It was finally obtained in 1987 after a Georgia Supreme Court ruling that police investigatory files are covered by the state's open records law. That statement, he said, provided defense lawyers with their first clue that Evans had been coached by Atlanta police detectives before he was sent into a cell adjacent to McCleskey's to obtain incriminating statements. Boger said the statement also led defense lawyers to an Atlanta prison official who testified that he had witnessed Atlanta detectives coaching Evans before sending him to talk with McCleskey. ``We should not have our client go to the electric chair because we could not ferret through this game of 20 questions the state was playing here,'' he said. Boger said the confession was the key evidence in the state's case against McCleskey. He said the only other evidence was the testimony of McCleskey's co-defendant that McCleskey was the triggerman, and the conflicting testimony of witnesses who were in the furniture store when the police officer was killed. ``The key to this case was the confession that Offie Evans came forward and said Warren McCleskey gave to him in the jail,'' Boger said, arguing that the appeals court was ``profoundly wrong'' to conclude that use of an illegally obtained confession was ``harmless error.'' The appeal marked the second time the justices have reviewed McCleskey's death sentence. In a landmark 5-4 ruling in 1987, the court held that state death penalty laws cannot be challenged on constitutional grounds even if statistics indicate the laws are being applied in racially biased ways. McCleskey's argument in that appeal was based on an exhaustive statistical study showing that killers of whites in Georgia draw the death penalty far more often than do killers of blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Ballet Director Tapped as Arena Stage Executive
DOC.TEXT: Managing director Stephen J. Richard of the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater will become executive director of Arena Stage next February to oversee the long-range financial growth of the 40-year old resident theater company. A Houston native and former managing director of the Los Angeles Theater Center, Richard joins a management triumvirate that will succeed Zelda Fichandler, co-founder and producing director of Arena Stage, who is leaving next July to become artistic director of The Acting Company in New York. Besides Richard, the new executive team will include associate producing director Douglas C. Wager, who will become artistic director, and general manager Guy Bergquist, who will be in charge of productions and day-to-day theater operations. Arena Stage, founded in 1950, is regarded as one of the nation's foremost non-profit resident theater companies.

DOC.HEAD: Poland and Germany Agree on Border Pact, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Polish and German negotiators agreed Wednesday on a treaty confirming their present border on the Oder and Neisse rivers, a pact that would end uncertainty dating to World War II. The text was hammered out by working groups in the first round of negotiations between Poland and the newly unified Germany over their future relations, said Jerzy Sulek, chief Polish negotiator and director of the Foreign Ministry's European department. Progress was also made on a second treaty on bilateral cooperation, Sulek told the government's PAP news agency. Talks are to continue in Bonn on Nov. 26-27. The border treaty still must be initialed by senior officials of each country, signed by the heads of government, and ratified by the respective parliaments to take effect, Sulek said. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl are scheduled to meet Nov. 8 on the Polish-German border to discuss relations, but German and Polish officials indicated that they did not expect the treaty to be signed at that meeting. The pact is only to be discussed by the two leaders, with signing taking place in the ``nearest months,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Wladyslaw Klaczynski. He called it a success that the sides were able to complete the text so quickly. The talks began Tuesday and ended Wednesday afternoon. They were carried out by small teams of experts at a Foreign Ministry palace in central Warsaw. ``Our task was to work out the fundamentals of the rules and structures of the two treaties, and the political decision about the date of signing of the treaty will be left to the two governments,'' said Dieter Kastrup, of the German Foreign Ministry, who headed Germany's delegation at the talks. The Oder and Neisse rivers became the border between Poland and East Germany at the end of World War II by the decision of the victorious Allies. The line allowed Poland to absorb 40,000 square miles of former German territory. It was recognized in principle by East Germany in 1950 and by West Germany in 1970. The former German lands now make up about one-third of Poland. Poland was forced after the war to give up an even larger area in the east to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Testifies To Federal Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Former National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter testified Wednesday before the special federal grand jury that is continuing the investigation of the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter, who is appealing his six-month sentence for lying to Congress and obstructing lawmakers' inquiries about the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and covert military aid to Nicaraguan rebels, was questioned behind closed doors by prosecutors for independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh. It was Poindexter's second appearance before the grand jury, which is known to be investigating whether other former Reagan administration officials obstructed efforts by Congress to learn about the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter, who served as President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until the Iran-Contra scandal unraveled in late 1986, declined to comment about his testimony. Former White House aide Oliver L. North, whose three felony convictions stemming from his involvement in the Iran-Contra affair were set aside in July, has testified on several occasions before the same grand jury. The grand jury has not met since last summer. Walsh has said he will try to conclude his investigation by next spring but his timetable may be delayed by a dispute with the Bush administration. The dispute involves Walsh's request for documents from the office of Bush when he served as vice president in the Reagan administration, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Among other things, Walsh is seeking documents to determine what knowledge former Bush aide Donald Gregg had of the covert operations to arm the Nicaraguan rebels. Gregg, now U.S. ambassador to South Korea, has denied knowing about North's involvement in the Contra resupply operation until an Aug. 1986 meeting with Felix Rodriguez, a former CIA agent who was a friend of Gregg. Before that meeting, Gregg said he had only general knowledge that North was involved in helping private citizens give humanitarian assistance to the rebels. Rodriguez told lawmakers that he sought the meeting with Gregg and his assistant, Samuel J. Watson III, to express concerns about corruption within the covert arms operation. Prosecutors are also trying to determine what knowledge, if any, Bush may have had of the Contra resupply operation. A briefing memo for the vice president's May 1986 meeting with Rodriguez mentioned that the session was being held to discuss ``resupply of the Contras.'' Gregg told Congress that Contra resupply was not discussed during the May 1986 meeting with Bush and said he didn't know why the reference was included in the briefing memo. Gregg said he did not tell Bush about his August meeting with Rodriguez because ``we had never discussed the Contras.'' ``We had no responsibility for it. We had no expertise in it. I wasn't at all certain what this amounted to,'' Gregg said. Gregg testified that he did not tell Bush about Rodriguez's involvement in the covert operation until December, 1986, after Rodriguez told him he had been recruited by North.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Criticizes Judge Who Sentenced Him
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry took a new slap at the judge who sentenced him to jail Wednesday and suggested his own status as a recovering addict could be a benefit if he wins election to the city council. ``One thing I've learned about recovering from substance abuse is that you have to do something meaningful, something that makes you feel good,'' Barry said during a taping of the Phil Donahue Show. ``I'm sharper now and more prepared to do this job than I was two or three years ago.'' Barry, who announced near the start of his drug and perjury trial that he would not seek a fourth term as mayor, is one of eight candidates competing for two citywide council seats in next Tuesday's election. He has admitted being addicted to two prescription drugs and in recent weeks he has also acknowledged being an ``occasional'' user of cocaine. In his remarks on the Donahue show, the mayor had harsh words for U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who sentenced Barry to six months in prison last week. On Tuesday, Jackson himself criticized the jurors in Barry's case during a lecture at Harvard Law School Tuesday. ``If I had taken from the payroll illegally then I should have been held to that higher standard,'' Barry said, referring to a standard that Jackson said during sentencing that the mayor had failed to meet. ``I believe I should have gotten community service,'' Barry said when asked how he felt knowing that Jackson had sentenced former Reagan administration aide Michael Deaver to work release after Deaver's 1988 perjury conviction. ``What we here in Washington don't like is the unfairness.'' A studio audience packed with Barry supporters burst into cheers at that remark. In recent weeks, Barry has suggested that he has been a victim of racial injustice at the hands of the judicial system. Jackson, for his part, said in his law school lecture that he was ``not happy with the way the jury addressed the case.'' ``Some people on the jury had their own agendas. They would not convict under any circumstances,'' the judge said at the forum. ``We did our duty, and that is the only comment I am willing to make,'' juror Johnnie Mae Hardeman said Wednesday when asked about Jackson's remarks. The judge hinted at his displeasure with the panel when he discharged them at the conclusion of Barry's trial. ``Some of you endeavored to do your best ... and the court is appreciative of that,'' Jackson said sternly after the jury convicted Barry of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, acquitted him of another, and deadlocked on a dozen remaining charges. Barry spoke on the syndicated television show only on the condition that the FBI videotape showing him smoking crack cocaine on the night of his January arrest not be shown.

DOC.HEAD: Anchorage Mayor Wins Re-Election, Officals Review Contested Ballots
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tom Fink apparently won his bid for re-election by a little more than 1,000 votes, but city officials worked Wednesday to examine 3,400 challenged or absentee ballots. With all precincts counted, Fink edged Democratic challenger Rick Mystrom by 30,338 to 29,245 votes in Tuesday's runoff. Mystrom did not concede. ``The public deserves a recount if it's real close,'' he said. ``The odds are probably against us but this game is not over by any means.'' The city has two weeks to finish examining the challenged ballots - those cast by voters at polling places outside their own precincts. City Clerk Ruby Veldkamp said the margin was comfortable by Anchorage election standards. ``We consider 100 votes a landslide,'' she said, noting that Fink beat Mystrom by just 29 votes in the Oct. 2 three-way race that included former state legislator H.A. ``Red'' Boucher and forced the runoff. More than 48 percent of registered voters went to the polls. Fink's apparent victory was a turnaround for the Republican politician who was rated negatively by 50 percent or more of Anchorage residents, according to polls six months ago. ``They said Fink was out of step with the public,'' Fink said of his adversaries on the Anchorage Assembly. ``Well, the public said, `No, Fink's not out of step. You are.''' Mystrom, 46, is a former city assemblyman and former advertising executive who led the city's unsuccessful winter Olympics bid. Fink, 62, is an Anchorage insurance executive whose first mayoral term found him variously at odds with the municipal assembly, reporters and unions representing city workers.

DOC.HEAD: Slight Decrease in Active US Military Men and Women
DOC.TEXT: The nation's ranks of active duty military men and women declined slightly to 2,044,069 in September, the Pentagon said Wednesday. The estimate, based on preliminary reports, was down just 375 from actual totals for August. However, the number, as of Sept. 30 represented a sharp decline of 86,160 from last year at the same time. The Air Force suffered the deepest one-month reduction - by 1,984 to a total of 535,233. The Navy personnel number dropped by 104 to 579,781. Both the Army and Marine Corps gained. The Army rose 1,154 to 732,403 while the Marin Corps increased by 559 to 196,652. In September 1989, the Air Force had 570,880 active duty men and women, the Army 769,741, the Navy 592,652 and the Marine Corps 196,956. The overall numbers do not include members of the selected reserves called to active duty in connection with the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Fishermen Rescued After Weeks Adrift
DOC.TEXT: Two fishermen rescued after 25 days adrift in a disabled boat were being treated Wednesday while en route to Puerto Rico, the U.S. Coast Guard said. The men, from the Caribbean island of Martinique, were found by the crew of a sailboat about 300 miles northeast of San Juan on Tuesday. Claude Ballu, 24, and his uncle, Irmi Ballu, 57, were expected to arrive Thursday aboard a Coast Guard cutter. Claude Ballu was suffering from severe dehydration and malnutrition. He lost nearly 55 pounds since their 25-foot vessel, Ruth, became disabled sometime around Oct. 4. His condition is stable, the statement said. The elder Ballu was reported in good condition and remained on board the boat, which was being towed to port by a Coast Guard cutter. Martinique, a French overseas department, is located about 350 miles southeast of Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: New York Candidate Ready to Leave the State
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret says he's ready to leave the state if he loses to incumbent Gov. Mario Cuomo. ``I'm going to pick a state and get out of here. I really am,'' Rinfret said Tuesday. The Manhattan-based economist says he was double-crossed by the state's GOP leadership. ``They promised monetary support, there's none,'' he told radio station WSKG in Binghamton. ``They've double-crossed me and they've given me no assistance whatsoever.'' Meanwhile, Conservative gubernatorial candidate Herb London said the GOP should be ashamed of telling voters to ``hold your nose'' and vote for Rinfret. ``That's very condescending to rank-and-file Republicans,'' London said Tuesday at a campaign stop in Syracuse. ``They should be telling people to vote for the best candidate.'' Rinfret continues to predict that he'll win Tuesday's election, despite polls that indicate Cuomo has a substantial lead. ``Don't bet the ranch on Cuomo,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate Cries Foul in KKK Endorsement
DOC.TEXT: A state Senate candidate endorsed by the Ku Klux Klan says the support is an attempt to sink his campaign. A recording at KKK headquarters says the Klan ``is officially supporting'' Tom Gage. Gage, a lawyer, blasted the Klan and its New Hampshire organizer, Thomas Herman, who records the Klan messages. ``This Herman person is a liar and a complete slimeball,'' Gage said Wednesday. ``He knows how negative he is perceived and, therefore, he is trying to put the weight of that negativism to tie down my ascending campaign.'' Herman, reached at work, said he couldn't talk about the endorsement while on the job. Gage, a Republican state representative, is running against Democratic state Rep. Beverly Hollingworth.
DOC.HEAD: Gang Members Distribute Campaign Literature
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Vice Lords are passing out campaign literature for Senate candidate Paul Wellstone and Gov. Rudy Perpich. ``Other than supplying some literature, we had no real involvement in it,'' said Perpich campaign manager John Stanoch. The participation comes as some gang members appear to be trying to distance themselves from traditional gang activities. Deputy Police Chief David Dobrotka said the Vice Lords gang has been linked to street violence and drug trafficking. Gary Sudduth, vice president of the Minneapolis Urban League, said the gang members have the right to distribute literature because they are voters. ``This effort has nothing to do with the Vice Lords,'' Sudduth said Tuesday. ``This is the first time the African-American community has organized itself to have a massive literature drop for two candidates that we believe are most committed to the needs of our community.'' Both Wellstone and Perpich are Democrats. The Urban League revealed the plan Tuesday on behalf of the Minnesota African American Political Caucus, which is sponsoring the distribution. Mark Anderson, a spokesman for the Wellstone campaign, said he wouldn't discourage the approximately 40 gang members from participating. ``We're not going to discourage anybody from getting people to the polls,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Heflin Called `Political Coward'
DOC.TEXT: Republican Senate candidate Bill Cabaniss says incumbent Sen. Howell Heflin is a ``political coward'' for canceling a scheduled television debate. ``He has become your typical politician who doesn't have the guts to come home and tell us what he's really been doing, what he's been up to in Washington,'' Cabaniss said about his Democratic rival. ``It's clear what Howell Heflin really is - a political coward, who just like every other Washington politician, cries and whines whenever someone puts just a little bit of sunlight on his records,'' Cabaniss said. Heflin, who was campaigning in another part of the state, said he had agreed to the debate after Cabaniss pledged to run a clean campaign. ``Since that time, he has conducted a campaign of distortions, half-truths and misrepresentations,'' Heflin said Tuesday. ``A debate would only provide him a forum to continue his gutter-style politics.'' Cabaniss said he would show up as planned Thursday night at the Montgomery television station. The station plans to show pre-taped interviews with each candidate and won't do a live interview with Cabaniss.
DOC.HEAD: Soviets to Study U.S. Elections
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet delegation is visiting the United States to observe the American election process. Members of the Central Electoral Commission will focus on the involvement of the private sector in elections and the role of the courts. The visit is part of an ongoing exchange between Soviet officials and their U.S. counterparts. The group will study procedures in the District of Columbia before going to Chicago to observe Tuesday's Illinois Senate and gubernatorial races.

DOC.HEAD: Temporary Power Lines To Hatteras in Place
DOC.TEXT: Crews worked on the final steps of restoring power Wednesday to Hatteras Island, cut off from the mainland when part of its only bridge was smashed, and Army landing craft began ferrying pedestrians. ``We expect to be off the generators by Thursday morning,'' said Bob Slade, Dare County manager. Electric Membership Cooperative had three cables across Oregon Inlet by Wednesday morning. They replace cables broken when a storm drove a dredge through the bridge across the inlet last week. ``Today we are trying to stabilize these cables, get them in conduit, and splice the cable that has been installed,'' Slade said. The first runs of the pedestrian ferry using three landing craft carried eight to 10 people across the inlet, Slade said. The military craft also carried emergency supplies, fuel and Department of Transportation equipment. Two more landing craft were being sent in Wednesday. Browning Art Works at Frisco got power on a rotating basis Wednesday. But owner Linda Browning didn't complain. She said her shop and other long-established firms are ``going to do fine.'' ``But those hanging by a thread and those that got a lot of tide from the northeaster, they're coping with a lot of things all at once,'' she said. Among those with problems from the storm itself is Daniel Willis, owner of Willis Boat Landing. The storm washed seven inches of water into his store. He said the water damage and business losses from the bridge cut could amount to as much as $100,000. Getting full power back will help, Willis said. ``We sell LP (liquified propane) gas and our auxiliary power is so low it doesn't have the voltage to pump LP gas,'' Willis said. ``We've got close to 100 people that need gas, and we've got a store full of empty tanks ... but we can't do it until they restore full power.'' Survey teams from the state Division of Emergency Management interviewed business operators Wednesday in preparation for the area's application for a Small Business Administration loan. The work to get things back to normal with ferries replacing the bridge has been very fast compared to the slow recovery after a snowstorm last December, Ms. Browning said. ``This time, grocery stores got supplies immediately and fuel companies are already here ... The first couple of days were real shaky, but after that bottleneck of people trying to leave was cleared up, they started letting supply trucks in,'' she said. ``My first thought was we'd be shut down for six months and the island economy would take a fast nose dive, but it just hasn't happened.''

DOC.HEAD: School Troubles Aired at Laundry
DOC.TEXT: Parents and pupils aired their dirty laundry while washing their clothes at a meeting with school officials in a laundry. In an effort to discuss campus troubles with moms and dads who don't attend parent-teacher conferences, Bain Elementary School officials promised free quarters and wooed 11 parents to the downtown laundry Tuesday. ``There is some fear by parents of coming into the school building,'' said home school coordinator Henry Galvin. ``Everybody does laundry. We figured we'd go out and meet them on their territory.'' The parents brought along 35 children. ``That was part of the deal - you bring the laundry but you have to bring your child also,'' Galvin said. The director of the gang prevention unit at a private mental health agency discussed area gang problems. Parents were urged to volunteer for school programs. Another non-traditional meeting with parents would be arranged again, said Galvin.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Expenses Growing Fast Because of Oil Price Increases
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil prices resulting from the Mideast crisis are driving up farm operating expenses at the fastest pace in eight years, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday. New quarterly figures through October showed farm expenses jumped an average of 2.2 percent from July, when such figures were last available. The expense index was up 5.6 percent from October 1989. ``A sharp rise in fuel prices since July contributed most to the largest quarterly index increase since January 1982,'' the report said. Meanwhile, the monthly report by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said that prices farmers get for raw products declined 0.7 percent from September to October but still averaged 1.4 percent more than a year ago. ``Decreases in the prices of broilers, milk, corn and apples were partially offset by higher prices for hogs, tomatoes, strawberries and eggs,'' the board said in its preliminary report. Prices of most food and feed grains were down from September, although higher prices were reported for oats, rice and durum wheat. Soybean and sunflower prices declined, while peanut prices increased. ``The October all-hog price increased moderately over September while the all-cattle price was up slightly,'' the report said. Prices of steers and heifers sold as beef were at a record high for October, the report said. But broiler prices dropped sharply from September, partly due to large supplies and weaker seasonal demand. Department economists say consumer food prices will rise an average of 5 percent to 7 percent this year, compared with a 5.8 percent gain in 1989, the most since 1981. There has been no official forecast for 1991. The net cash income of farmers in 1990 has been forecast at a record in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about 10 percent from last year. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the amount nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income in a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method of agency accounting, which includes changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during the year, 1990 net farm income may be in the range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with $47 billion last year. Based on preliminary figures that could be revised next month, the October price index for all crops was down 1.6 percent from September and averaged 4.7 percent less than a year earlier. The October index for livestock and products was down 1.2 percent from September but still averaged 5.6 percent more than in October 1989. Milk prices, reflecting stepped-up production, dropped 60 cents from September to an October average of $13.60 per 100 pounds. The October price was down $1.20 from a year earlier. The all-fruit price index in October was down 6.4 percent from September and 8.7 percent the October 1989 average. Lower prices for apples, oranges and grapefruit were mostly responsible for the decline from September. The report said: -Cattle averaged $75.10 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up 10 cents from September. A year earlier cattle averaged $68.70 per hundredweight. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. -Hogs averaged $56.90 per hundredweight, up from $54.30 in September and $46.60 a year earlier. -Corn, at $2.15 per bushel, was down from $2.32 in September and $2.22 a year earlier. -Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.39 per bushel, compared with $2.46 in September and $3.75 in October 1989. -Rice averaged $6.34 per 100 pounds, compared with $6.25 in September and $7.37 a year earlier. -Soybeans were $5.90 per bushel, compared with $5.99 in September and $5.54 in October 1989. -Upland cotton was reported at 66.9 cents per pound, compared with 65 cents in September and 65.8 cents a year earlier. -Eggs were 73.5 cents per dozen, compared with 68.5 cents in September and 71.6 cents a year earlier. -Milk was $13.60 per hundredweight, compared with $14.20 in September and $14.80 in October 1989. -Broilers were 29 cents per pound, live weight, compared with 35.2 cents in September and 30.2 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Mistrial Declared in Sports Agent Case
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared Wednesday during the 14th day of jury deliberations in the trial of a sports agent accused of hiring someone to kill a former business partner. Jurors reported they were deadlocked 9-3 to convict Michael Blatt of murder and conspiracy to commit murder. Blatt, a developer in Stockton and briefly acting general manager of the Seattle Seahawks, was accused of hiring two former University of the Pacific football players to kill Laurence J. Carnegie. The victim was shot with an arrow from a crossbow near Stockton on Feb. 28, 1989, then strangled. Carnegie's body was dumped in rural Sonoma County. The two men Blatt was accused of hiring admitted killing Carnegie. They were guaranteed reduced sentences for cooperating with Blatt's prosecution. ``We went through a very conscientious decision process, and we were unable to reach agreement,'' said jury foreman Bob Peppler. ``There's a lot of frustration on both the part of those who think he's guilty and those who don't think he's guilty,'' Peppler added. ``We were unable to convince each other ... so there's got to be a lot of frustration in that.'' Blatt's trial was in its eighth month in Oakland, where the case was moved because of extensive publicity in Stockton.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq More Concerned That War Coming, Ambassador Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf with 3 grafs to give Kuwaiti reax
DOC.HEAD: With AM-U.S.-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials are growing more concerned about a possible war and are taking measures to defend the country, Iraq's ambassador said Wednesday. ``We seek to avoid bloodshed ... We once more call for a negotiated solution, to have a political and diplomatic solution,'' Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat said at a news conference. But Al-Mashat said the tough rhetoic of President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III over the past few days heightened the possibility of war. ``Certainly we are more concerned,'' he said. ``We are taking precautionary measures to defend our country.'' Should war break out, Al-Mashat said, ``This is going to be a bloody conflict.'' Al-Mashat's comments came the day after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered military commanders to prepare for ``urban warfare'' in Kuwait, according to the official Iraq News Agency. On Wednesday, Bush declared, ``I have had it,'' with the treatment that Americans hostages are receiving in Iraq and Kuwait. He said the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, where several diplomats have been holed up since the Aug. 2 invasion by Kuwait, is being starved out. Bush said, however, he had no timetable for any possible military action to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Al-Mashat insisted the hostages in Iraq are being taken care of, but he indicated Iraq will not allow supplies to be shipped to the embassy in Kuwait City. ``We have said time and time again there is no reason for those embassies to be there,'' Al-Mashat said. Only the British and the Americans have kept their embassies open in Kuwait City. Al-Mashat reiterated his government's position that the Kuwait situation is a Arab problem that ought to be decided by the United Nations in conjunction with resolution of the Palestinian conflict. The purpose of Al-Mashat's news conference was to release a document that Iraq says it seized from files at Kuwait's internal security bureau after the invasion. It purports to be a memo from the director general of the state security department to the Kuwaiti interior minister, detailing a meeting the security chief had with CIA Director William Webster on Nov. 14, 1989. Kuwaiti Brig. Fahd Ahmad Al-Fahd said he and Webster agreed on a number of points, which he outlined in the document. The document was written in Arabic with an unofficial translation into English. ``We agreed with the American side that it was important to take advantage of the deteriorating economic situation in Iraq in order to put pressure on that country's government to delineate our common border,'' the document said. The CIA has said statements contained in the document are fabrications, but officials said they have no doubt that Iraq confiscated files inside Kuwait after the invasion. Ali Al-Sabah, a spokesman for the Kuwaiti embassy, said the document appeared to have been altered. Nevertheless, he said ``obviously a lot of documents'' were taken by the Iraqis when they overran the country, seizing government buildings and files. Al-Mashat insisted on the document's authenticity. ``We have physical evidence of a declaration of war by Kuwait against Iraq,'' Al-Mashat said. ``There was a conspiracy by Kuwait with the cooperation of the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: College Board Announces Sweeping SAT Changes
LaserPhoto BX11
DOC.TEXT: College Board trustees announced Wednesday the most sweeping changes ever in the Scholastic Aptitude Test, but rejected suggestions that charges of cultural bias prompted the revisions. The new Scholastic Aptitude Test, called SAT-I, will be introduced in the spring 1994, said College Board President Donald M. Stewart. It will include less reliance on multiple choice in the math section and more emphasis in the language section on reading comprehension. The revisions, aimed in part at reducing students' reliance on test coaches, also will allow students to use calculators on the math section, Stewart said at the board's annual meeting. Critics have long charged that the SAT - the most widely used college entrance exam - was biased, particularly against women and minorities. ``Nothing could be further from the truth,'' Stewart said. ``The SAT has been in almost continual evolution. It has never been set in concrete. ... ``The new SAT will combine the high, academically demanding standards of the current tests with revisions that increase their educational relevance and quality for all college-bound students.'' The old SAT had 85 verbal and 60 math questions. The SAT-I will have 75-85 verbal and 55-60 math questions. The changes also include the introduction of SAT-II, an expansion of the achievement tests currently offered with the SAT. SAT-II will include a written essay section, language proficiency tests for native speakers of Japanese and Chinese, and proficiency tests for non-native English speakers. Bob Schaeffer, a spokesman for the group FairTest and co-author of the book ``Standing up to the SAT,'' said the changes fail to solve the problem of the test's bias. ``The new SAT amounts to little more than rearranging the deck chairs on an educational Titanic,'' Schaeffer said. ``The SAT should be optional and it should be comprehensively overhauled to address its problems.'' FairTest and other critics have claimed that the SAT tends to cover subjects that white male and affluent test-takers are more likely to be familiar with. Oft-cited examples in the test include the question ``Dividends are to stockholders as ...'' with the answer being ``royalties are to writers,'' and the use of words such as ``regatta'' and ``aria'' in the vocabulary section. Whites as a group have outperformed minority students, and males have fared better than females. In 1988, the National Organization for Women filed a lawsuit that forced the New York State Education Department to stop using the SAT exclusively to award merit scholarships. The department now uses high school grades as well. The SAT, administered by the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J., was first given to 8,040 students in 1926. Now about 1 million college-bound students take it annually. The 2{-hour exam currently consists of two multiple-choice sections that test verbal and math skills. Each section is worth 800 points, for a perfect score of 1,600. Three years ago the board began field trials of possible SAT revisions. In 1988, the board created a committee of educators to evaluate the trials and determine what changes should be incorporated. In September, board trustees voted to postpone for a month a decision on whether to adopt the changes. As with the current achievement tests, the SAT-II will be an optional accompaniment to the SAT-I. Chang-Lin Tien, chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, said the addition of the Asian language achievement tests ``reflects the increasing importance of the Pacific Rim and recognizes the increasing desire among students to study these languages.'' The SAT-II revisions will be phased in, beginning next year.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Sentenced for Palestinian Beatings
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli soldier was sentenced Wednesday to two months in prison for participating in the beatings of two Palestinian brothers, one of who later died. Three other soldiers were given suspended sentences by the military court. All four - who could have faced a maximum of 20 years in prison each - were demoted in rank. The soldiers maintained throughout the trial they were only following orders from top officers to beat Palestinian riot suspects. The order has since been changed. Also Wednesday, a spokesman for Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the minister proposed limiting the number of Palestinians working in Israel. The plan would reverse Israeli policy begun in 1967, when Israel captured the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Last month, Israeli authorities closed off the occupied lands for four days following a wave of violence between Palestinians and Jews. The case of the four soldiers was seen as a test of the army's willingness to punish troops convicted of brutality in suppressing the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising. The three-judge court earlier this month found the defendants guilty of the Feb. 7, 1988, Gaza Strip beating of brothers Khaled and Eyad Akkal. Eyad died hours later at Shifa Hospital in Gaza City. They were charged with aggravated assault because prosecutors found no direct connection between the beating and the death. Israel army radio also quoted the judges as saying the defendants ``violated basic norms of an advanced society ... (and) operated under the distorted concept that everything is justifiable for the sake of a military mission.'' 1st Lt. Ofer Reshef was ordered to serve two months in prison, given a six-month suspended sentence and reduced in rank to sergeant. Maj. Yitzak Levitt, 32, received a three-month suspended sentence and was demoted him to 1st lieutenant. The panel said he was not directly involved in the beatings, but was responsible for them. Staff Sgt. Eli Shukrun and Sgt. Gad Zinbar were each given a five-month suspended term and reduced in rank to private. Earlier this month, the chief army prosecutor ordered an investigation of Col. Effie Fein, who was commander of the soldiers' unit at the time of the beatings. In the early months of the uprising, officers said they were ordered to beat people caught rioting, but not strike those in custody. But many soldiers said the orders were not clear. The army has since banned beatings as punishment. Arens's proposal to limit the Palestinian work force in Israel was made Tuesday before Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, said spokesman Dan Naveh said. It would have to be approved by the government. Meanwhile, Israel is under pressure to find jobs for tens of thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants in a country with an unemployment rate above 10 percent. ``It is now time to start changing this so Israelis will get the opportunities in Israel and Arabs will find jobs in the (occupied) territories,'' said Naveh. The four-day closure of the borders was taken after Arab-Jewish street violence left five dead following the Oct. 8 Temple Mount killings of 20 Palestinians. It kept about 110,000 Arabs off from their jobs in Israel. A three-man commission appointed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to look into the Temple Mount shootings released its findings Friday, stating that Palestinians had caused the violence by throwing stones at police and that police were justified in using gunfire because their lives were in danger. The report was criticized by Israeli left-wing groups and parties as well as by Palestinians. Betselem, an Israeli human rights group, said Wednesday that probe failed to seriously examine whether police were justified in firing live ammunition. It said the commission had a ``distinct preference for the police version over other descriptions of the same events.'' Also Wednesday, Arab reports said Muti Al Haj, 19, from the West Bank village of Jalkamous, died of injuries suffered in a clash with Israeli soldiers Sept. 10. The army was checking the report. In the Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis, masked assailants stabbed to death Fayed Abu Irgayleh, 28, suspected of collaborating with Israel, Arab journalists and Israel's news agency Itim said. At least 769 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis in the uprising. An additional 293 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators. Fifty-one Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Device Capable Of Detecting Plastic Explosives Goes Into Service
DOC.TEXT: A device capable of detecting the kind of plastic explosive that officials say destroyed Pan Am flight 103 went into service Wednesday at Dulles International Airport. James B. Busey, administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, said the Thermal Neutron Analysis or TNA device represents a ``significant improvement in performance'' over earlier generations of detection technology. ``The machine has the capability of detecting the explosives that we think were present on Pan Am 103,'' the airliner destroyed over Scotland two years ago, Busey said. The Dulles detector is the fourth to be installed at international airports in an FAA program to test capabilities and build an enhanced anti-terrorist security system at airports worldwide. Other TNA units are at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, the Miami international airport and Gatwick Airport near London. Busey said tentative plans call for similar explosive devices to be installed at airports in Frankfurt, Germany and at the Baltimore-Washington airport in Maryland. Adaption of the TNA device, the only technology now believed able to detect plastic explosives of the kind that brought down Pan Am 103, coincides with a report from the National Academy of Sciences concluding that the FAA is essentially on the right track. The academy concluded that a combination of the TNA automated explosives detection system and sophisticated X-ray screening ``may offer the optimal approach for detection of bulk explosives.'' The TNA device installed at Dulles uses X-ray screening to identify suspect items or areas inside specific pieces of luggage. The TNA machine, developed by Science Applications International Corp. of San Diego, Calif., bombards checked luggage with low-energy thermal neutrons and is programmed to detect concentrations of nitrogen, an element found in explosives. The Dulles unit will be used to screen luggage on United Airlines international flights. It is 40 feet wide and 20 feet long, weighs 28,000 pounds and cost about $1 million. Demonstrating the device for reporters, technicians used it to detect simulated explosives concealed in a sneaker, in a champagne bottle and in the false bottom of a suitcase.

DOC.HEAD: Former Mayor, a Convicted Felon, in Thick of Mayoral Race
DOC.TEXT: Mayoral candidate and convicted felon Vincent ``Buddy'' Cianci says he has learned from his mistakes. It remains for voters to decide whether they forgive him. Cianci was forced to resign as mayor in 1984 after 10 years in office when he pleaded no contest to assaulting his estranged wife's alleged lover. In Rhode Island, such a plea is equivalent to a conviction. When he was mayor, 30 people associated with his administration were indicted, 22 convicted. His restaurants are in financial trouble and he is behind on his taxes. But now Cianci, an independent, is in a dead-heat mayoral race with Democrat Andrew Annaldo and independent Frederick Lippitt. The current mayor, Joseph Paolino Jr., who took office after Cianci resigned, did not run for re-election this year. Instead he made an unsuccessful bid for governor in the Democratic primary. Providence ``is the only place where you could see the re-emergence of someone like Buddy,'' said Victor Profughi, a political science professor at Rhode Island College. A poll of 401 likely voters about two weeks before the Nov. 6 election showed Cianci was favored by 25 percent, Lippitt 28 percent and Annaldo 29 percent. The WJAR-TV and Alpha Research Associates Inc. poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 points. The survey also found the 49-year-old Cianci had the least favorable rating, but 50 percent of the survey's respondents liked his experience and record. Annaldo, 34, is a businessman with eight years on the City Council. Lippitt, 73, a Yale-educated lawyer, has racked up a long record of public service with 22 years as a Republican state representative and two years as Gov. Edward D. DiPrete's administration director. In the late days of the campaign, issues such as improving the city's 42 percent school drop-out rate, revitalizing neighborhoods and fighting crime increasingly have been replaced by personal attacks. At a debate Monday, Annaldo took exception to a Lippitt commercial that compared him to an old watchdog. Lippitt defended it, saying Annaldo should have better scrutinized city spending when he was with the Providence Board of Contract and Supply. Cianci accused both opponents of dipping into special pensions at taxpayers' expense. Lippitt received a $50,000 state pension in 1987 that he later said he would give to charity, while Annaldo is enrolled in the pension plan of the city's largestmunicipal union. ``I'm getting caught in the crossfire here from the Little Dipper and the Big Dipper,'' Cianci said. ``If I believe either one of them, one is a cheat, the other is a liar, the other looks like a dog.'' Cianci has been campaigning on a theme that he ``never stopped caring about Providence.'' ``Yes, I made mistakes, but at least I admit them,'' Cianci told elderly residents at a high-rise in the city's Italian section. Annaldo has promised to relieve the city's taxpayers by making tax-exempt universities pay ``their fair share.'' That issue alone is credited with helping him win a tough four-way Democratic primary. Lippitt is calling for a city tax on meals, concerts and sporting events. Cianci, who backed a mid-year tax hike in 1981, opposes new taxes. Disclosures by The Providence Journal-Bulletin show that Cianci and his businesses owe $10,000 in overdue property taxes and that he missed the deadline for filing his state and federal tax returns even after receiving a six-month extension. Still, Cianci keeps the pollsters guessing. ``With all the negative press about Cianci, a lot of people are ashamed or embarrassed to tell their friends or family - never mind a pollster - that they are going to vote for Cianci,'' said Tony Pesaturo, president of Alpha Research. ``There's a lot of closet support for Cianci. How large it is, we have no way of knowing.''

DOC.HEAD: Missing Ring Turns Up 22 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: Harry Heath says the next time he sees his old girlfriend, he may show her the high-school class ring of his that she lost 22 years ago - but he probably won't let her hold it. A man with a metal detector found the ring this month in the same park where it was lost in May 1968. ``I only had it for a few weeks when it was lost,'' Heath said Monday. ``I was only 15 or 16. I had forgotten ompletely about it.'' Heath, of Annawan, said he was a sophomore when his high school sweetheart, Sharon Hulteen, lost his ring during a prom picnic at White Pines State Park near Dixon. Twenty to 30 couples scoured the park that day, and Heath eventually forgot about the ring until John Jackowski of Freeport found it under 2 inches of dirt. ``His daughter said he found things before but never had a chance to return it,'' Heath said. Jackowski called Annawan High School after he found the ring on a chance that someone there might know whose it was.
