A teacher in the office when Jackowski called knew the ``H.H.'' initial on the 1970 class ring must belong to Harry Heath, and Heath was called. ``I couldn't believe it,''' said Heath. ``I thought it was a joke. ``It was in good shape. To look at it, you'd never know it had been outside.'' Heath said he will get a kick out of showing the ring to his former girlfriend - now married and living in Oswego - the next time he sees her. ``I'll show her it, but I won't let her hold it,'' he joked. ``I don't want to go through this again.''

DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 6-7 pvs bgng: ``Jackson, 19'' to CORRECT that jurors unable to decide White House charges sted acquitted him, adds additional details about other charges
DOC.HEAD: Judge Suggests Bush Exercise Clemency For Teen-age Cocaine Pusher
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager once accused of supplying cocaine that President Bush held up during a televised speech received a 10-year sentence Wednesday from a judge who said the mandatory penalty was too harsh. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin suggested to Keith Jackson that he ask Bush to exercise clemency to reduce the sentence that was mandated by Congress for defendants who sell drugs near a schoolyard. ``He used you in making a big speech on the drug trade,'' Sporkin said, referring to the Sept. 5, 1989 address in which Bush held up a bag of crack that prosecutors charge Jackson had sold to an undercover drug agent. The judge called Bush ``a very decent man,'' adding that ``maybe he can find a way to reduce some of that sentence.'' The routine drug case of a teenager who had never before been arrested became controversial when it was reported that White House aides arranged for a drug sale to an undercover Drug Enforcement Administration agent so that Bush could hold up a bag of crack as a prop during the speech. In two separate trials, jurors deadlocked on charges that Jackson, 19, sold crack cocaine to an undercover agent in Lafayette Park near the White House just four days before Bush's address. But he was found guilty during the second trial of selling the drug on two separate occasions in July 1989 to undercover agents who met him near a high school on Capitol Hill. Those sales were part of the same undercover operation that led to the charges Jackson sold drugs near the White House. ``I regret that the law compels me to sentence Mr. Jackson to a mandatory 10-year term,'' Sporkin said, echoing criticism expressed by other federal judges of the mandatory minimum sentences passed by Congress in recent years for drug offenders. Critics say compulsory minimum sentences contributed to prison overcrowding and deprive judges of power to show leniency in appropriate cases. ``This is a case in which I believe that the mandatory minimum benefits neither the defendant nor society,'' Sporkin said. ``Both would be better served by a lower sentence that would enable this high school senior, a first-time offender, to rehabilitate himself and re-enter society rather than spending his youth in prison.'' While Sporkin was required to impose the 10-year minimum, he declined to sentence Jackson to a longer term recommended by federal sentencing guidelines for drug distribution near schools. Those guidelines would have provided for a sentence between 12 years and more than 15 years. Sporkin noted that DEA's intentional selection of the site, near Eastern High School on Capitol Hill, was a mitigating factor in departing from the guidelines. ``Nothing in the trial testimony indicated that the defendant would have transacted any business near Eastern High School - a school which he did not attend - but for the suggestion of government agents,'' Sporkin said. ``The purpose of the schoolyard statute is to deter drug transactions near schools, not to encourage the government to set up dangerous drug deals near school children,'' Sporkin said. But ``in this case the government has chosen repeatedly to bring drug transactions to locations where they would not otherwise occur.'' Sporkin also noted Jackson's ``youth and the intense media coverage his case has received warrant a downward departure,'' the judge said. ``The defendant has already endured far greater public humiliation than most similarly situated drug offenders,'' Sporkin said.

DOC.HEAD: Food Stamp Benefits Rise
DOC.TEXT: Millions of low-income Americans are getting an increase in food stamp benefits, retroactive to Oct. 1, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Assistant Secretary Catherine Bertini said the increases include an annual cost-of-living adjustment and a 3 percent boost in basic benefits mandated by law. The food stamp program is expected to cost about $18.1 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 and serve around 20 million people, according to department budget analysts. Bertini, who oversees USDA food and consumer services, said the maximum food stamp allotment for a family of four in the 48 contiguous states and the District of Columbia was increased to $352 a month from $331, about 6 percent. Income levels, which are used to determine eligibility for households, also were increased, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Winter-like Weather in the Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Cold, wet weather spread across the Northwest on Wednesday, while sunshine prevailed east of the Rockies. Showers along and behind a cold front produced rain from Northern California and the northern Pacific Coast to the northern Rocky Mountains. Heavy rain drenched coastal sections of Washington, Oregon and Northern California during the morning and spread into the northern Rockies. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up to 7 a.m. EST included 2.07 inches at North Bend, Ore., and 1.17 inches at Shelter Cover, Calif. Eugene, Ore., got 2.75 inches of rain Tuesday, a record for the date. Six to 12 inches of snow was possible during the night in the mountains and passes of northwestern Montana, the National Weather Service said. A winter storm watch in effect into early Thursday was posted for the mountains of northern Utah, and a winter storm watch was posted for Thursday for the mountains of southern Utah. Midday temperatures were only in the 40s and 50s behind the cold front. The sky was mostly clear east of the Rockies and strong southerly wind blew from the southern Plains region to the upper Mississippi Valley. Kansas City, Mo., warmed to a record 79. Morning lows only in the 30s were reported over parts of the Great Basin, which includes most of Nevada and western Utah, and the Rockies. Morning lows were in 30s and 40s across much of the Southeast, except for Florida where Miami had a low of 75, and across the northeastern and north-central states. Temperatures dipped below the freezing mark around the upper Great Lakes. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Another Dry Year Poses Serious Problems
DOC.TEXT: Unless the 1991 rainy season is wetter than last winter, water supplied to California farmers for irrigation could be reduced by half to two-thirds, state and federal officials say. Urban water users who rely on state reservoirs could suffer cuts of 13 percent if the drought runs into a fifth year, officials said. Federal deliveries to municipal customers could drop 25 percent to 50 percent. In an annual drought-outlook conference titled ``What if ... 1991 is Dry?'' state, federal and local officials said Tuesday that another critically dry winter could be catastrophic for many sectors of California's economy and the environment. ``I hope we don't have to experience the `what if' situation,'' said Chet Bowling, drought coordinator for the federal Central Valley Project, the largest water supplier in California. A draft report released Tuesday by the state Department of Water Resources said a fifth drought year would leave California as bad off as it was in 1977, the driest year on record. This year, the State Water Project and the Central Valley Project cut farm deliveries by 50 percent, and the CVP cut municipal supplies by 25 percent to 50 percent, depending on each city's contract. It was only the second time in the history of both projects that deliveries were disrupted - the first time was 1977. Agriculture suffered an estimated $480 million in drought-related losses in 1990. If the drought continues, the State Water Project estimates reductions to agriculture of 63 percent, while the federal project cuts would be about 50 percent. The state report said San Francisco and some other Bay area cities could be forced to cut water use by half. Some cities in southern California already are curtailing some water uses. Most of California's available water - 82 percent, according to the U.S. Geological Survey - is used for irrigating crops. California leads the nation in water use, at 30.3 billion gallons a day. Agriculture accounts for more than $16 billion of the state's $300-billion- plus annual economy. While the drought that began in 1986 is less severe than 1976-77, the state report said it poses an unprecedented threat to fish and wildlife. ``California's population of 30 million people and their needs for water and space has combined with the drought to create what is truly a natural disaster,'' the report said. Although water authorities acknowledge that it is too early to forecast what kind of winter California will have - most of the state's rainfall is recorded in December, January and February - the report said there were some disturbing historical trends. ``Looking back in history, dry years and wet years seem to cluster slightly more than would be expected by chance. But no one so far has been able to develop a predictive model for California for next year from these irregular patterns.'' Storage in California's major reservoirs as of Oct. 1 was about 60 percent of average.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Want Greater Pre-Mortgage Checks on Homes
DOC.TEXT: Banking regulators moved Wednesday toward greatly expanding the requirement that independent appraisers assess the value of many homes before buyers receive mortgages. The Federal Reserve Board, by a 5-1 vote, offered for public comment a rule change that would require appraisals on all real estate-based loans of $50,000 or more. The current rule, adopted in June, set a $100,000 cut off. But members of Congress, led by Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga., complained that the higher limit excluded too many home sales and that regulators were ignoring legislators' intent in the appraisal reforms included in last year's savings and loan law. Acording to the National Association of Realtors, 53.5 percent of home sales in September would have required appraisals under a $100,000 cut off, while 84.5 percent would need an appraisal under the $50,000 limit. Barnard, who sponsored the appraisal reforms, argued in a letter to the Federal Reserve that faulty appraisals were one of the chief factors contributing to the S&L crisis. S&Ls lost huge sums on loans secured by property worth much less than appraisals indicated. The 1989 S&L law, starting in July 1991, requires banks, S&Ls and credit unions with federally insured deposits to use state-licensed appraisers before making real estate-based loans. Federal Reserve Board member Martha R. Seger, who voted against considering a lower cut off, argued that most S&L problems were found in commercial real estate loans well over $100,000, not in the single-family home loans which would be affected by a lower cut off. ``This is an anti-consumer piece of legislation when you get right down to it because the cost of these appraisals will be borne by the consumer, the person who wants to buy the existing home,'' she said. Board member Wayne D. Angell voted in favor of seeking comment on changing the rule, but he said he would probably vote against the change. However, the other four board members said they were concerned that a $100,000 cut off would be out of line with Congress' intent in last year's law. And, they said the Fed's rule should be consistent with other agencies' standards. Other financial institution regulators already have adopted the $50,000 cut off. They are the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Gulf Situation Very Dangerous, Explosive
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak warned Wednesday that the Persian Gulf crisis ``could explode at any time.'' Mubarak urged ``our Iraqi brothers'' to realize the danger in which they have placed the Middle East. ``We should not take lightly the force stationed there because it's very powerful,'' Mubarak said of the multinational force in the gulf. If war comes, ``Iraq will be ruined, and (it) will harm all of us.'' ``I hope our brothers in Iraq will understand well that the situation is very dangerous and could explode at any time,'' the Egyptian leader told reporters. About 310,000 troops from 13 nations are stationed in Saudi Arabia and on warships in the gulf region to force Iraq out of Kuwait, which Baghdad invaded Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, oil and money. Egypt has contributed 16,000 troops - the largest of the Arab contingents. Arab troops form the first line of defense against Iraq and are positioned in Saudi Arabia, just across the border with Kuwait. Baghdad has 460,000 troops in southern Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Mubarak's warning came a day after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reportedly told his military commanders the United States might attack Iraq within days and to prepare for battle. Asked about a proposal by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev that leaders of Arab nations meet to solve the gulf crisis, Mubarak noted that previous Arab summits had not been successful. ``Arab countries held a summit meeting on Aug. 10 and did not achieve anything. Arab countries have tried and are still trying to get a peaceful solution,'' Mubarak said. The Soviet leader made the proposal in France on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Prime Minister Wins Vote of Confidence
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Charles Haughey won a vote of confidence in Parliament on Wednesday after bowing to pressure and dismissing a top aide. The aide, Brian Lenihan, is running for president, but his campaign has suffered because of a scandal arising from reports that Lenihan lied about his role in a political crisis eight years. ``What I have to do, I do with great sadness and great sorrow,'' said Haughey. After he stripped Lenihan of his titles of deputy prime minister and defense minister, Parliament gave Haughey's government an 83-80 vote of confidence. Haughey's Fianna Fail party has 77 seats in the 165-seat Parliament and governs with the support of the Progressive Democrats, who hold six seats. The Progressive Democrats reportedly had insisted Lenihan leave the government. The main opposition parties, Fine Gael and the Labor Party, voted against the confidence motion. Two opposition lawmakers did not vote. In an act of political loyalty, Lenihan and his sister, Education Minister Mary O'Rourke, who are also members of Parliament, both voted to support Haughey despite his dismissal of Lenihan. Labor Party leader Dick Spring had earlier called Haughey a liar and Lenihan ``an Irish version of Richard Nixon.'' ``This is a debate about greed for office, disregard for truth and about contempt for political standards,'' Spring said Wednesday. The controversy stems from events that occurred in 1982, after the Fine Gael-led government of Garret FitzGerald lost a confidence vote. Haughey, Lenihan and other leaders of the Fianna Fail party were accused at the time of trying to persuade then-President Patrick Hillery to call them to head a government without holding a national election, which would have been illegal. Haughey and Lenihan had always denied the charge, but last week a political science graduate student produced a tape recording of an interview in which Lenihan gave a detailed account of telephoning Hillery. Lenihan has insisted he never phoned Hillery. But his conflicting accounts of the event elevated an arcane political issue into a question of his truthfulness. Lenihan, the early frontrunner for next Wednesday's presidential election, has fallen far behind Mary Robinson, the candidate backed by Labor. A poll published Wednesday by the Irish Independent newspaper showed Mrs. Robinson favored by 52 percent, Lenihan by 31 percent and Fine Gael's Austin Currie with 17 percent. Haughey said he continued to support Lenihan for president of this nation of 3.7 million people. ``Brian Lenihan has been a friend, a loyal and trusted colleague with whom I have served for well over a quarter of a century. He has done great service to the Irish people,'' Haughey said. Haughey, 65, and Lenihan, 59, are allies from the days they were Cabinet members in the 1970s under Prime Minister Sean LeMass, Haughey's father-in-law.

DOC.HEAD: Former Dissident Elected Mayor of Budapest
DOC.TEXT: Gabor Demszky, a former dissident and leading member of the parliamentary opposition, was elected mayor of Budapest on Wednesday, the official MTI news agency reported. His appointment had been expected after municipal elections in which the center-right coalition parties governing nationally fared poorly. Opposition liberal parties made strong gains, particularly in urban centers. Demszky is a leading official in the largest opposition party, the League of Free Democrats. Under the former Communist leadership, Demszky was one of the country's leading dissidents who was often detained for his anti-Communist activities. Demszky was elected mayor by the new Municipal Assembly. Under Hungary's complex electoral procedures, the assembly is elected in direct balloting and it, in turn, elects the mayor. The 38-year-old lawyer was the only candidate for the post, MTI reported. The position is one of the most important in the country. About one-fifth of Hungary's 10.5 million people live in the capital, and the job of mayor was expected to be complicated by a sense of restiveness in Budapest following an unprecedented show of defiance against the newly elected national government. It was forced to reduce a 70 percent gasoline price increase after taxi and truck drivers brought traffic to a standstill in the capital and elsewhere with a three-day blockade last week. President Arpad Goencz, a founding member of the Free Democrats who gave up his political affiliation upon his appointment as head of state, said the country's affairs would have to be handled differently afer the recent unrest. Goencz told MTI it was also likely to affect the capital and the new municipal leadership would face a wide range of difficulties.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Indicates Government Might Open Talks With Cartel
DOC.TEXT: The interior minister indicated Wednesday the government might be ready to hear the demands of the Medellin cocaine cartel in hopes of freeing seven kidnapped journalists. Julio Cesar Sanchez said his government is prepared to ``listen to the complaints even of those who find themselves outside the law.'' The interior minister's statement, aired over the RCN radio network, could signal a reversal in the government policy of not negotiating with drug traffickers. His comments came in response to a question about seven journalists kidnapped by the Medellin cartel the past two months, including Francisco Santos, editor of the country's leading newspaper, El Tiempo, and Diana Turbay, daughter of former president Julio Cesar Turbay. In a speech Wednesday, President Cesar Gaviria did not refer to his minister's comments, saying only that Colombia would ``meet its international obligations'' concerning narcotics. However, the president did not publicly reject last week's proposal by a representative of the drug traffickers to seek United Nations' mediation in their conflict with the government. The cartel issued a statement Tuesday saying it kidnapped the journalists and Marina Montoya, the sister of Colombia's ambassador to Canada. It threatened to kill its hostages if the government launches a new offensive against drug traffickers. In his radio interview, Sanchez said the cartel may have some legitimate complaints. He added: ``The goverment is ready to hear the legitimate complaints of any citizen. The reason for being a democratic government is that even those at the margin of the law can demand guarantees.'' In a statement to local media, the cartel said it had learned of a government plot to kidnap the relative of a drug baron and exchange him for the journalists. ``If something of this nature happens, our response will be immediate and we will execute the detained journalists,'' the statement said. Sanchez responded: ``using threats to ask for justice is not appropriate.'' Judicial Police Chief Col. Oscar Pelaez said security forces never planned to kidnap anyone, but rather only intend to ``capture criminals.'' The Medellin gang has been blamed for killing about 550 Colombians since the government and drug traffickers began battling each other in August 1989. A group of political and church leaders have offered to try to mediate between the government and the cartel. They were responding to a request by drug traffickers, presented last week by lawyer Guido Parra, to find a negotiated solution to the conflict. Parra's proposal included seeking mediation by the United Nations. Colombia's Cali and Medellin drug cartels supply most of the cocaine consumed in the United States and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Bombing Ring Leader Gets Stiffee
DOC.TEXT: A Tunisian man who led a wave of bomb attacks in Paris that left 13 people dead and 250 injured must serve at least 13 years in prison, an appeals court ruled Wednesday.r Prison Sentenc The Court of Appeals also ruled that Faoud Ali Saleh, 31, will be barred from France for life once he is released from jail. Saleh was sentenced in February to 20 years in prison for associating with terrorists and trafficking in arms. Previous to the appeal court's ruling, Saleh's parole could have come at any time. Saleh's French wife, Karima Ferahi, had her 10-year sentence upheld by the appeals court and will be barred from France for 10 years after hhe layoffs represent 6 percent of the British payroll and 3 percent of its total workforce. Renfrew said severence pay for those let go will cost the company about $19.4 million in 1990. After absorbing this, the company expects pre-tax profits for 1990 to be about $620 million, he said. Reuters said it will make a statement on business conditions in early December, when analysts meet in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Over Retracted $10 Million Prize
DOC.TEXT:
A woman who won $10 million in a contest sponsored by McDonald's and NBC but lost it because her daughter works for the fast-food chain has sued to regain her prize. Charles and Thelma Bellows filed a lawsuit Tuesday in Bay County Circuit Court seeking the $10 million prize plus damages and legal fees. ``From 10:30 a.m. to 8 o'clock at night we were millionaires. It was so fast it was hard to believe,'' Charles Bellows said. The lawsuit names McDonald's Corp., NBC Inc., the McDonald's franchise where they bought the ticket and a company that judged the contest. The Bellows say they should be allowed to keep the prize because their married daughter is not a member of their immediate family. Mrs. Bellows, 49, was named on national TV Oct. 12 as the winner in the ``McMillions on NBC'' contest. She received the winning ticket the day before when she bought a meal at a McDonald's restaurant in Auburn where one of her six children, Charlene Saunders, works. The couple spent a day in Detroit with representatives from McDonald's, taping a commercial. They planned to buy a new house and furniture, and take a trip to the Caribbean.
By evening, the dream fizzled. McDonald's told her she was ineligible. ``I think the worst part is knowing that they fully understood our daughter worked there, let Thelma go on TV and still declared her the winner,'' said Bellows, co-owner of a Sanford construction company. But McDonald's spokesman Charles Rubner said the company had been unaware of the relationship. He said the company was obligated to declare Mrs. Bellows ineligible. ``People trust McDonald's,'' Rubner said. ``We want them to continue to trust us.'' The Bellows' attorney, Ramon Rolf Jr., said the case is similar t one in Utah in which a man was disqualified for a prize because his son worked for the newspaper sponsoring the contest. The Utah Supreme Court ruled the married son, who was financially independent, wasn't part of his father's immediate family. The man got his prize, a Plymouth sedan, Rolf said. ``This case is real similar,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Acclaimed Author Was Drunk, Drugged When He Died
DOC.TEXT: Seth Morgan, a transient ex-convict who wrote an acclaimed novel, was drunk and on drugs when he and a companion died in a motorcycle accident two weeks ago, according to police. Morgan told an interviewer several months before that being in New Orleans helped him kick an alcohol-drug addiction and write ``Homeboy,'' a novel that won critical acclaim when it was published last spring. But tests by the Orleans Parish coroner's office showed a 0.3 percent alcohol level in Morgan's blood, police said Monday. Intoxication in Louisiana is defined as 0.1 percent. The tests also showed the presence of cocaine and Demerol in Morgan's body, police said. Morgan's passenger, Diane Suzy Skidmore Levine, 37, had a blood-alcohol level of 0.28 percent, the coroner's office said. Morgan and Levine were killed Oct. 17 when Morgan's motorcycle hit a bridge piling. Police said Morgan, 41, had been arrested a day before his death for drunken driving. Morgan, plagued much of his life by addictions to alcohol and drugs, came to New Orleans four years ago. He had begun writing while serving three years in California for robbery. New Orleans was ``where I regained sobriety, sanity,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Fund-Raising Lagging Compared to Past Campaigns
DOC.TEXT: National Republican campaign committees have suffered multimillion-dollar drops in receipts and spending compared to the last non-presidential election campaign, a federal agency said Wednesday. The GOP committees still have spent far more this time around than their Democratic counterparts, which did not experience a decline in campaign fund-rasising, the Federal Election Commission said. As of Oct. 17, the FEC said, the Republican national, senatorial and congressional committees had received $30 million less and spent $26 million less than in the same period during the 1985-86 cycle. At the same time, the level of financial activity at the Democratic committees remained on a par with the previous off-year campaign cycle. Republican Party strategists have said GOP fund-raising efforts were hurt by President Bush's change of heart on taxes. Bush abandoned his no-new-taxes campaign pledge this fall and agreed to a package of spending cuts and new taxes to help reduce the federal deficit. Nevertheless, the GOP managed to outspend the Democrats this year by more than $118 million, according to the FEC. The three GOP committees raised and spent $159 million from Jan. 1, 1989, to Oct. 17, 1990. The three Democratic committees raised $37 million and spent $40 million in the same period. The Republicans contributed nearly twice as much as the Democrats directly to candidates - $1.8 million compared to just over $900,000, the FEC said. Coordinated expenditures, or indirect aid to candidates, came to $7.4 million for the GOP and $5.8 million for the Democrats. The GOP also has transferred much more money to state party committees than the Democrats - $3.7 million compared to $1.6 million. In addition, the national Republican Party operates two joint fund-raising committees that have distributed $1.9 million to 49 Senate candidates, the FEC said. Democrats have filed a complaint alleging that the committees - the Republican Senatorial Inner Circle 1990 and 1990-91 - are illegally circumventing campaign spending limits.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Accused of Arranging Wife's Killing
DOC.TEXT: A policeman's plan to have a teen-age informant kill his wife failed when the gunman decided to back out of the deal, authorities said. Duncannon Police Officer David Paul Wagner, 31, bribed Ramon Lee Rousch, 19, of Dauphin, to kill his wife in exchange for negotiating a deal on the teen-ager's burglary conviction, police said Tuesday. A police affidavit said Wagner showed Rousch the layout of his home, gave him the keys and waited at a shopping mall for Rousch to finish the job. Rouch was supposed to enter the Shamokin Dam home, find a weapon in the Wagners' bedroom and shoot Wagner's wife, Lori, when she got home. Rousch held Mrs. Wagner at gunpoint for nearly two hours on Sept. 5, but ``he chickened out'' of killing her, said Shamokin Dam Police Chief Robert Lockcuff. Shamokin Dam lies on the Susquehanna River, about 60 miles north of Harrisburg in central Pennsylvania. When Rousch was arrested, he gave police a taped confession outlining the plot, Lockcuff said. ``There have been some marital problems,'' Lockcuff said of the Wagners. ``Your basic falling out of love type thing.'' Wagner, who was off-duty, was arrested at the Duncannon police station Monday, Lockcuff said. Wagner was charged with criminal attempt at murder, criminal solicitation to commit murder and criminal conspiracy to commit murder, said District Justice Willis Savidge. He was being held in jail in lieu of $175,000 bail. Rousch was charged with robbery, burglary, recklessly endangering another person, firearm violations and theft. He was being held in the same jail in lieu of $25,000 bail. Lockcuff said police were investigating two other alleged attempts on Mrs. Wagner's life. He would not give details of the investigations. Wagner had been a police officer in Shamokin Dam before joining the police force in Duncannon, a town about 40 miles to the south, Lockcuff said. ``He was a good officer,'' he said. ``We never had any problems with him.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Jury Finds Fighter Fondled Woman; Awards $100
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with verdict, comment. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `You should...' A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Wednesday decided that prizefighter Mike Tyson fondled a woman at a dance club in 1988 and awarded the woman $100 in compensatory damages. The five-women, one-man jury was scheduled to return to federal court Thursday to hear testimony on Tyson's financial status before ruling on punitive damages. The woman, Sandra Miller, asked for up to $2.5 million in punitive damages in her civil lawsuit. The jury deliberated about 4{ hours before finding that Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, grabbed Miller's breasts and buttocks after she refused his advances at Bentley's Disco on Dec. 10, 1988. Tyson, who had denied that the incident ever took place, showed no outward emotion as U.S. District Judge Michael B. Mukasey read the verdict, which found the fighter had committed battery but not assault. Tyson said he was satisfied with the verdict. ``If they thought it was serious, they would have given her more than 100 bucks,'' he said. When asked how she felt, Miller, a 26-year-old computer operator, said, ``Great that they know that he did it.'' In closing arguments earlier Wednesday, Tyson's attorney, Robert Hirth, told the jury Miller had concocted the allegations to obtain money from Tyson. ``You should send a message that if Sandra Miller wants to engage in a get-rich-quick scheme she should buy a lottery ticket,'' Hirth told jurors. U.S. District Judge Michael B. Mukasey instructed the jury to decide separately whether Tyson committed assault or battery. He said assault did not require a finding of contact but could include ``an overt menacing act.'' A finding of battery requires actual contact, he said. The trial was in federal court because Tyson lives out of state.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Gov't Starts Moving Displaced Southerners Out of Khartoum
DOC.TEXT: Police drove 14,000 displaced people out of a shantytown and burned their makeshift hovels to ensure they do not return, witnesses said Wednesday. The displaced people, who fled war and famine in southern Sudan, have been moved to a camp in Jabal Awlia, about 25 miles south of Khartoum. Their movements can be controlled more easily there, because they have to pass checkpoints to go to the capital. Although the government says 80 percent of the facilities in the new camp are finished, witnesses say it has no water. And those now living in the area are not happy to have the southerners come in. The government announced last year it would dismantle shantytowns around Khartoum where an estimated 2 million displaced southern and western Sudanese have been living. A 1984-85 drought in the western Sudan brought many refugees to Khartoum. Because of the war, the southerners are not welcomed by the northerners. The government has accused the war refugees of straining the capital's limited resources and increasing the crime rate. Rebels in the south claim that the Christian and animist residents of the region are persecuted by the central government of the north, where the population is Moslem. War has been raging in the south for seven years. When the military government decided to dismantle the camps last year, the three southerners on the ruling 15-man revolutionary command council protested. It was unclear why the government decided to enforce the decision now. Witnesses said the evacuation of the Bentiu camp started Saturday evening and ended Tuesday. They said smoke could still be seen Wednesday coming out of the camp that police burned down after the evacuation. There were no reports of violence being employed to empty the camp. The Bentiu camp, named after a town in the Upper Nile region where most of the inhabitants fled from, was made up of makeshift huts made of wood sticks, tin and orange plastic sheets. It was better know as Hilat al Shook, or village of the thorns, because it was full of thorn trees. The government has been having problems carrying out its evacuation of another shantytown called Takamul. The inhabitants there have built mud huts and are refusing to move.

DOC.HEAD: Duke Says He's `Inclined' to Run for Governor in '92
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana legislator David Duke said Wednesday that he's ``inclined'' to run for governor in 1992. Duke, a Republican state representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader, ran an unsuccessful but stronger-than-expected race for the U.S. Senate this fall. Duke's comments came as part of a heated discussion on Jesse Jackson's syndicated television program, which is scheduled to be broadcast over the weekend. When Jackson asked Duke if he was inclined to run for governor of Louisiana in 1992, he replied: ``I am inclined.'' Duke supporters cheered his responses, but often jeered at comments from others in the audience and on the panel of which Duke was a member. Duke's sharpest exchanges were with Gloria Allred, a women's rights lawyer who shook her finger at him and described his remarks about reverse discrimination as ``garbage.'' ``You give women's rights a bad name,'' Duke shot back, amid cries of ``witch'' from his supporters. Jackson urged both panelists to ``calm down.'' The overflow crowd of about 200 included supporters of both sides, ranging from members of the conservative Young Americans for Freedom to representatives of the liberal American Civil Liberties Union. When a black man in the audience came forward with what he said were photographs of Duke in Nazi and Klan uniforms, Duke said: ``I am sorry to say that I participated in these organizations. I have certainly grown up in my life, and we all have the right to do that.'' Much of the program focused on the civil rights bill recently vetoed by President Bush. ``This bill is about racial discrimination,'' Duke said. ``We have got massive racial discrimination going on right now in America, but now it's against whites.'' Some booed that remark. Duke's legislative assistant, Glenn Montecino, said Duke originally accepted an invitation to appear on the show with the understanding it would be a one-on-one discussion with Jackson. Duke withdrew after being told he would be on a panel with several black activists, but agreed to appear when the panel was revised. Also on the panel were Rep. Kweisi Mfume, D-Md., and Richard Viguerie, a conservative fund-raiser. Duke, Viguerie and Ms. Allred are white; Jackson and Mfume are black.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Delays Atlantis Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to CORRECT spelling to Hauser sted Houser in 2nd graf; ADD detail on Pentagon shuttle flights. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The delay ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force on Wednesday delayed Atlantis' classified flight next week because of problems with a spy satellite aboard the shuttle. ``Details are classified, and it is too early to predict a new launch date,'' the Air Force said in a two-sentence statement. The Air Force described the problem as ``anomalies discovered during cargo testing.'' Capt. Marty Hauser, a Pentagon spokesman in Washington, refused to say when the problem was detected and declined to discuss the flight further. Sources speaking on condition of anonymity have said the satellite was to spy on Iraq. Top NASA managers on Tuesday scheduled Atlantis' launch for Nov. 9. The shuttle was cleared for flight following a fueling test last week that found it free of dangerous hydrogen leaks. A fueling test on Tuesday cleared the shuttle Columbia for a December astronomy mission. NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said it was too soon to know whether that mission would be affected by Atlantis' delay. ``We don't know how to set dates or how to plan'' because the extent of the problem the satellite aboard Atlantis is unknown, she said. Sources estimated the delay would be one to two weeks. It is the seventh shuttle flight dedicated entirely to the Defense Department. Two more Defense Department missions are planned, both next year, but their cargoes are unclassified. ``The bottom line is it's no longer affordable'' to maintain secure operations for a mission, said a Pentagon official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The delay was disappointing news for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which had been hoping to close the year with six shuttle flights. NASA had planned for nine missions this year, but was plagued by hydrogen leaks on Columbia and then on Atlantis. Columbia's leaks were detected in May during fueling for the astronomy mission's first launch attempt. Three more tries followed before NASA stopped to send up Discovery with a sun-exploring satellite earlier this month. Atlantis was grounded in June when hydrogen escaped during a fueling test.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Backs Resolution to Set Up Escrow Accounts for Iraqi Assets
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council's next move against Baghdad is a resolution that would put Iraq's frozen assets into an escrow account to pay for war damages, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said Wednesday. Pickering told reporters the resolution would allow Iraqi funds and property frozen for the duration of the crisis to be put into a ``compensation account.'' The assets from each country's escrow account would not be divided until the crisis has run its course, because there is no way of assessing total costs until then. On Monday, the Security Council voted to hold Iraq liable for human rights abuses and war damages during its occupation of Kuwait. But that resolution did not contain a means of distributing Iraqi funds. The new resolution apparently would provide such a mechanism. Pickering said the council could begin deliberating the measure later this week or early next week. He becomes president of the council for the month of November, with powers to sway the pace of negotiations and help set the body's priorities. Pickering alluded to the escrow account plan Monday, when he told the Security Council that Iraq would be liable for full compensation for the losses and damages it has caused by its illegal invasion and occupation of Kuwait. Iraq has about $4 billion in overseas assets, of which about $800 million are in America. That money could be used to help rebuild Kuwait if its government is restored after an Iraqi withdrawal. Other countries are suffering billions of dollars in losses in indirect economic losses due to higher oil prices, loss of trade, and loss of remittances from foreign workers who had been in Iraq and Kuwait. Jordan alone figures it will lose about $2 billion; Poland estimates similar losses.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins in Killing Witness Remembered After 21 Years
DOC.TEXT: A woman's recollection of watching her father molest and kill a playmate with a rock 21 years ago is full of inconsistencies, his lawyer said Wednesday at the start of his murder trial. A prosecutor promised during her opening statement to provide evidence that George Franklin Sr. asked his wife to wash a bloodstained shirt a few days after the slaying. Franklin's daughter, Eileen Franklin-Lipsker, told police she saw her father use a rock to kill 8-year-old Susan Nason on Sept. 22, 1969. She said she repressed memories of the slaying until last year, when they flooded back as she looked at her own young daughter. Douglas Horngrad, one of Franklin's lawyers, said Franklin-Lipsker's memories are faulty. ``The truth is that Mrs. Lipsker tells different versions of different stories to different people at different times,'' he said. Horngrad told a San Mateo County Superior Court jury there is no evidence linking Franklin to the girl's slaying. Defense attorneys have suggested police overlooked other possible suspects in the investigation more than two decades ago. Franklin, 51, a former San Mateo firefighter, faces a possible life sentence if convicted. ``The (last) touch that Susie felt was not one of love. ... It was a touch of lust and perversion,'' prosecutor Elaine Tipton said. Franklin-Lipsker has said her father threatened to kill her if she told anyone what she had seen. She has said she saw her father sexually attacking her friend, then moving toward the girl with a rock raised over his head. The girl's body was discovered three months later in a ravine off a highway. A blood-stained rock was lying neaby, authorities said. ``For 20 years this crime remained unsolved,'' Tipton said. ``The terrible event remained deep in the mind of Eileen Franklin. For 20 years, the defendant lived his life pretending to know nothing of the disappearance and death of this young child.'' The Franklin family lived down the street from the Nasons in Foster City, south of San Francisco, when the child was slain. Horngrad said Franklin-Lipsker initially told her brother and mother her memory returned during a hypnotic trance. Later, she said she had lied because she thought the story was more believable than the truth, Horngrad said. Horngrad suggested the real reason she had changed her story was that her mother, a lawyer, told her hypnotically-induced evidence is inadmissible in California courts. Franklin-Lipsker also has changed details of her story, such as whether her sister was with her when the slaying occurred, the time of day it occurred, the setting and where she was when she first remembered the incident, Horngrad said. Franklin-Lipsker was expected to testify next week. Her sister, Janice Franklin, who testified during a preliminary hearing in May that she and Eileen were molested by Franklin when they were children, was also scheduled to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Denies Extradition of Son of Dictator Stroessner
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected the Paraguayan government's request to extradite the son of deposed dictator Alfredo Stroessner. All 10 justices on the court voted against the extradition of Gustavo Stroessner, held under preventative detention since August, court spokesman Celso Mello said. Stroessner, 46, an ex-colonel in the Paraguayan Air Force, had been accused by Paraguay's new government of corruption and misuse of public funds. Mello said documents presented by Paraguayan authorities did not indicate places or dates of the alleged crimes, and gave no guarantee that Stroessner would face only the charges listed in the extradition request. Stroessner fled to Brazil in February 1989 after a military coup ousted his father, who had ruled Paraguay since 1954.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Terrorist Turned Over to Israel
DOC.TEXT: Mahmoud Atta, wanted in Israel on terrorism charges, has been turned over to Israeli authorities, the State Department said Wednesday night. Atta, who also uses the name Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad, was placed in Israeli custody ``last evening'' and immediately taken out of the United States, said spokesman Adam Shub. Last Friday, the imminence of the transfer and threats from a terrorist group to act if it were carried out prompted the department to issue an unusual alert that terrorists might be planning an attack on passenger ships in the eastern Mediterranean Sea. The department said then it had ``specific and credible'' information about such an attack that ``may be undertaken at any time.'' Wednesday evening, Shub said he had nothing to add to the alert. Atta, 37 and a U.S. citizen, has been accused of taking part in the 1986 machine gun attack on a bus carrying Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank. The driver was killed and a passenger wounded. He was arrested in the United States three years ago. On Aug. 31, the Supreme Court rejected his last appeal in a court battle to avoid extradition. The Abu Nidal Organization, a terrorist group of which Atta was a member, has threatened ``to attack U.S. interests'' if Atta were extradited, the department said. The Abu Nidal Organization is believed responsible for some of the bloodiest terrorist attacks in recent years. It was another group, however, led by Abu Abbas that hijacked the Italian cruise liner in Egypt in 1985. One of the hijackers shot and killed a wheelchair-using American, Leon Klinghoffer, in that two-day episode.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Parliament Says It's Starting 500-Day Plan, Despite Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Russia voting to take control of resources. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Ivan Silaev...'
DOC.TEXT: The Russian parliament voted Wednesday to start a 500-day transition to a market economy on Thursday, putting it on a collision course with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the national legislature. Gorbachev and the Supreme Soviet legislature agreed Oct. 19 on a compromise economic rescue plan that is slower and less radical than the 500-day plan. Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, has declared sovereignty from the central Soviet government. It claims the right to put its own economic reform plan into effect on its territory, which covers two-thirds of the Soviet land mass. It is unclear who will be obeyed if the Russian government, led by Gorbachev's leading political rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, gives economic orders that contradict the national government. Already, the central government has warned bank officials they will be fired if they carry out a new Russian republic law creating independent banks, according to Deputy Russian Premier Gennady Filshin. The Russian parliament also challenged the Kremlin by claiming control over the republic's natural reso for the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda. ``I spent the whole day here asking people what concrete steps they planned to take, and no one could give me an answer,'' he added, gesturing from a balcony overlooking the parliament's marble meeting hall. Grigori Yavlinsky, a deputy prime minister of the Russian republic and one of the authors of the 500-day plan, told reporters the parliament should set up a committee of economic advisers to suggest specific measures. But Yavlinsky expressed doubt that Russia would be able to put the 500-day plan into effect, at least in its original form. ``Maybe in August we could have done it, but it's too late now,'' he said, noting that the national parliament has adopted the compromise plan and the country's economy has worsened. Figures released Wednesday by the Russian republic's committee on statistics show that production of consumer goods rose 5.8 percent in the first nine months of 1990, but demand rose even faster, creating chronic shortages. The committee said rationing of food and consumer goods is widespread, and prices are rising. It also said industrial output dropped 2.5 percent, housing construction is down, and Russia's exports to foreign countries declined 7 percent. The 500-day plan contains a detailed timetable for scrapping the 70-year-old central planning system, under which Moscow bureaucrats have told thousands of factories, farms and small businesses what to produce and how much to charge. The plan calls for transferring significant economic power, including the right of taxation, to the republics. It also envisages breaking up government monopolies, selling state-owned property to private citizens, and converting collective farms into private plots. Gorbachev's program was a compromise between the 500-day plan and a more cautious reform plan proposed by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. The compromise omits any timetable, although officials suggested it would take one and a half to two years to put into effect. The compromise also would leave the central government with strong economic powers, including control over the money supply, banking and taxes. It hedges on decollectivization, calling for the rental, rather than sale, of land to private farmers. Yeltsin and other critics of the compromise have charged it would produce rapid inflation by lifting state price controls and indexing workers' wages and benefits to rise accordingly. The 500-day plan calls for retaining price controls on key commodities and household necessities, such as food and clothing, throughout the transition period.

DOC.HEAD: Office at Candidate's Home Burglarized
Precede Washington
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 9 grafs new with breakin at challenger's home, question raised of possible political motivation; pick up 2nd graf, Through Oct. 24
DOC.TEXT: An office was burglarized in the home of Democratic Senate candidate Harry Lonsdale, and computer discs containing campaign material were stolen and files were ransacked, campaign aides said. The intruder broke a door to get into Lonsdale's house Tuesday night or early Wednesday in a remote area 12 miles west of Bend, said campaign press aide Dan Walter. Walter wondered if the break-in was politically motivated. ``We're not saying it is, but certainly six days out from the election it raises questions,'' Walter said. Lonsdale's opponent, Sen. Mark Hatfield, called it ``deeply troubling to us'' that such an incident would happen. ``It's extremely unfortunate, but even more unfortunate ... to try to pin that on the Hatfield campaign,'' said the Republican senator. Also missing were an office computer, printer, video recorder and telephone. A secretary discovered the burglary when she arrived at work Wednesday. Campaigning in southern Oregon, Lonsdale said ``I wouldn't want to accuse anybody of anything.'' Meanwhile, campaign finance reports show Hatfield has raised more than $379,000 since Oct. 1, much of it from congressional Republicans and wealthy industry groups. Through Oct. 24, the Senate's second-most senior Republican had gotten campaign contributions totaling more than $1.3 million. That doesn't include more than $100,000 Barbara Bush helped raise for him in Portland on Monday. The campaign of Democrat Lonsdale also reports donations in excess of $1 million, but $729,000 came out of his own pockets. He refused to take money from political action committees. The latest polls show Lonsdale with a slight lead. About $150,000 of Hatfield's money collected since Oct. 1 has come from PACs and another $40,000 has come from Republican candidates, GOP committees and clubs. For the year, his PAC total is more than $416,000. As the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee, Hatfield plays an influential role in spending bills cutting across a wide range of industries. His biggest PAC donations since Oct. 1 include: McDonald's PAC of Oak Brook, Ill., $5,000; American Family PC of Georgia, $5,000; Reynolds' Metals Co., $4,000; Fred Meyer Federal PAC of Portland, $4,000; Realtors PAC of Portland, $4,000; AMOCO PAC, $3,000; Union Pacific Fund for Effective Government, $3,000; and Weyerhaeuser Special Shareholders PAC, $3,000. The Republican Senate Inner Circle, a fund-raising arm of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, has given Hatfield $62,800 this year, including $20,000 on Oct. 9. Since Oct. 1, he has received $1,000 each from committees set up by: Sens. John Chafee of Rhode Island, Thad Cochran of Massachusetts, William Cohen of Maine, Pete Domenici of New Mexico, Jake Garn of Utah, John Heinz of Pennsylvania, James Jeffords of Vermont, John McCain of Arizona, James McClure of Idaho, Frank Murkowski of Alaska, Don Nickles of Oklahoma, Bob Packwood of Oregon, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Alan Simpson of Wyoming, Steve Symms of Idaho and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina. Hatfield also picked up $5,000 each from the Colorado Republicans Federal Campaign Committee, Texas Republican Congressional Committee and National Republican Congressional Committee. He got $4,000 from the Senate Victory Fund and $1,000 from the Paul Laxalt Group.

DOC.HEAD: Stanford Band Chopped Down For Offending Oregon Fans
DOC.TEXT: Stanford University's marching band won't be marching for a while after offending Oregonians with a halftime spoof of the spotted owl timber controversy. The ``Incomparable Leland Stanford Junior University Marching Band,'' known for shows that poke offbeat fun at current events, was banned from the field for one game because of a weekend performance in Eugene, Oregon. Offended spectators from the University of Oregon booed and Stanford's own supporters swamped its athletic department with angry telephone complaints. The band Saturday took on the northern spotted owl, a threatened species at the center of a bitter battle between the logging industry and environmentalists. Measures to protect the owl's habitat in the old growth forests of the Pacific Northwest are opposed by loggers who say their livlihood is threatened. ``Trees and spotted owls are disappearing like crazy and everybody wants to know why,'' the announcer said during the halftime show. ``Mr. Spotted Owl! Mr. Spotted Owl! Your environment has been destroyed, your home is now a roll of Brawny (paper towels) and your family has flown the coop,'' the announcer continued. ``What are you going to do? `Me, I'm going to Disneyland!' '' Band members spelled out ``spot,'' then formed ``pot'' on the field. Slogans and signs at demonstrations over the owl controversy often depict the threatened bird as a menu item. The Oregon Ducks and their fans were not amused by the show. ``The Stanford band is known for this kind of shtick. I guess they must try to be obnoxious,'' said Steve Paul, band director at the Oregon school. ``This game, they ridiculed the logging industry and the environmental movement and lots of fans were offended.'' ``It would be like if my band came down to the Oakland Coliseum and made light of the earthquake,'' said Don Jackson, principal of South Eugene High School. Many Oregonians have suffered personal losses from the closing of paper mills, he said. It wasn't the first time the Stanford band has been banned. The marchers were suspended in 1986, when six band members dropped their pants during a nationally televised game. In a 1975 performance, the band offended spectators over the Patricia Hearst kidnapping when they formed a ``Hearst-Burger'' - ``all buns and no Patty.'' The band won't be marching in this weekend's game against Washington State. Stanford said the musicians could march in two later games, including the big game against the University of California at Berkeley, only if the scripts were acceptable. ``The band is controversial, so we always have fans who really like them and some who don't like their performances. But this one reached a point where we needed to act,'' said Cheryl Levick, associate athletic director at Stanford. ``They were angry at the band's performance, the selection of the script, the insensitivity to the situation in Oregon. They were embarrassed,'' she said of the complaints. The band's student manager, Linda Kaye Brown, agreed the players should have shown greater sensitivity. ``What we do is political satire. We are certainly sorry that some people misinterpreted it. It wasn't an attempt to mock them or their way of life,'' she said. But Brown also called the suspension unduly harsh. ``Our goal was to entertain, not to offend,'' she said. Alan Cummings, Stanford's acting athletic director, blasted the band's ``insensitivity and disrespect to the Oregon community'' and said his department ``will not be embarrassed again by the band.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Poll Rating Reported Stabilized
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's approval rating has stopped falling, according to another poll reported Wednesday night. ABC News said a survey of 1,010 people from Friday through Tuesday showed 55 percent approving the president's job performance, up from 51 percent in a group surveyed Oct. 24 through Sunday. The difference in the two figures is only slightly larger than the likely margin of uncertainty in the polls. Some other recent polls have shown the president dipping as low as 48 percent. Seventy-five percent of respondents in an ABC poll on Sept. 9 approved of Bush's handling of his office. That proportion fell to 65 percent on Oct. 7, 56 percent on Oct. 14 and 51 percent Sunday. During that period, the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf continued with no resolution of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. Also, Bush and Congress could not agree on a new budget, a struggle that was resolved only this past weekend. ABC said the likely margin of uncertainty in its latest poll was 3{ percentage points either way.

DOC.HEAD: Mother of Child in Trunk Regains Custody of Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old girl who was taken away from her mother after police found her in a locked car should be returned home, a judge ruled Wednesday. The child will be reunited with her mother ``as soon as therapy and other supports are put in place,'' but no later than Friday, said Family Court Judge John Callahan. The case attracted national attention and an outpouring of support from New Jersey residents after Chante Fernandez, a single mother, told authorities she left her daughter in the car while she worked because she couldn't find adequate or affordable child care. Ms. Fernandez said she received offers of jobs and child care services, hundreds of letters and more than $1,000, which she used to start a trust fund for her daughter. She said she has yet to decide on a job, but will choose one full-time, week-day position. ``Weekends belong to my daughter from now on,'' Ms. Fernandez said. Ms. Fernandez spoke at a news conference at her attorney's office in New Brunswick, 20 miles southwest of Newark. She also said she would cooperate with state officials overseeing her daughter's care. The New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services placed the girl, Anjuli, in foster care after her mother's Oct. 20 arrest. Ms. Fernandez, 24, was jailed after police found her pajama-clad daughter locked in a car in a shopping mall parking lot. The mother had a weekend sales clerk job at a department store. Ms. Fernandez pleaded guilty Oct. 26 to a disorderly persons offense and was given a $100 suspended fine. Callahan said the state would maintain legal custody of the child, pending a progress report to the court within 30 days. Division and state officials The Associated Press reached by telephone Wednesday night declined to offer specifics on the therapy or support being offered the Fernandez family. Ms. Fernandez' attorney, Ken Weiner, told the news conference his client took the weekend job at a department store to help pay for her child's schooling. She also worked weekdays as a secretary at a lumber company, and her combined salary was less than $500 a week, she has said. Ms. Fernandez' father had provided $300 a month toward school expenses, but he died in January, Weiner said. ``This is a poor woman's plight,'' Weiner said. ``She is a single custodial parent working not five days a week, but seven days a week. This was one lapsing judgment.''

DOC.HEAD: Greed, Drugs and Glamor Figured in `Cotton Club' Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Greed, drugs and a lust for Hollywood glamour led to the producer Roy Radin's murder, a prosecutor told jurors Wednesday as the ``Cotton Club'' case began. But the lawyer for a key defendant called the case as a frame-up. Deputy District Attorney David Conn said he would prove that three men on trial killed Radin seven years ago on the orders of Miami cocaine dealer Karen Delayne ``Laney'' Greenberger, a co-defendant. Conn said Mrs. Greenberger feared being cut out of profits from ``The Cotton Club'' movie deal she helped arrange between Radin and producer Robert Evans. Evans is a former head of Paramount Pictures who invoked Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination and declined to testify at a preliminary hearing last year. He is under subpoena for the trial. Mrs. Greenberger's lawyer blamed the Radin killing on one of her lovers, alleged Cuban drug dealer Milano Bellechasses, and implicated another former lover who is on trial with her. ``Laney Greenberger did not hire, did not pay anyone to kidnap or murder Roy Radin,'' said Miami lawyer Edward Shohat. ``She didn't do it. ``It is true, unfortunately, that Laney Greenberger was at that time of her life a drug dealer,'' he added. ``But that does not make her Roy Radin's killer.'' He suggested Radin's death was the result of a drug theft unrelated to the movie deal and that men who surrounded Mrs. Greenberger framed her. ``You will see that Laney Greenberger was set up, was used, was literally and figuratively framed to the take the rap for the murder of Roy Radin,'' Shohat said. The attorney said Mrs. Greenberger tried to warn Radin he was in danger the night of the killing, telling him: ``There are all these men around me and I have no control.'' Mrs. Greenberger, 43, once was Evans' girlfriend. The three men on trial with her were once bodyguards for ``Hustler'' magazine publisher Larry Flynt. She is accused of hiring William Mentzer, 41, her former lover, and Alex Marti, 29, to do away with Radin. The fourth defendant, Robert Lowe, allegedly drove the car to the killing site. ``Each of the defendants were involved in a conspiracy to kidnap and kill Roy Radin,'' Conn said. ``And each defendant did it for one purpose only, for financial gain and for their own personal greed.'' Radin, 33, has been described as a man of excesses, an obese, cocaine-sniffing impresario from New York's Long Island who sought to expand his show business connections to Hollywood. The jury was told how Mrs. Greenberger arrived at Radin's hotel in a chauffeur-driven limousine the night of May 13, 1983. Conn said that en route to dinner at La Scala in Beverly Hills, the limousine stopped, Mrs. Greenberger got out and Mentzer and Marti, toting guns, got in. Radin was taken to a remote canyon and shot at least 10 times in the head, Conn said. He described Mentzer putting a stick of dynamite in Radin's mouth, then igniting it to destroy his face and prevent identification. Outside the jury's presence Shohat asked again to sever Mrs. Greenberger's trial from her co-defendants so that he could more openly discuss the three men. Superior Court Judge Curtis Rappe refused. Shohat suggested to jurors that Mentzer, who was hired by Mrs. Greenberger as a bodyguard and became her lover, also worked for Bellechasses. He was Mentzer first warned her she might be cut out of profits from the ``Cotton Club'' deal. Shohat acknowledged that Mrs. Greenberger worried about losing her share in ``The Cotton Club.'' But he insisted she was more upset about the theft of $1 million in cocaine and cash from her Sherman Oaks home. He said she hoped the ``Cotton Club'' profits would help make up the loss. All four defendants could face the death penalty if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: State Makes Last Ditch Effort to Fight Stay of Execution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. Supreme Court upholding stay. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Byrd, who...
DOC.TEXT: Two federal courts on Wednesday upheld a stay of execution for a man convicted of killing four people during a robbery a decade ago. Maurice Oscar Byrd had been scheduled to die by lethal injection at 12:01 a.m. CST Thursday. But the execution was blocked last week by a three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which wanted to hear more arguments in the case. That ruling was appealed to the entire court by the Missouri Attorney General's office, but the nine judges - in a 5-4 decision - refused Wednesday afternoon to lift the stay of execution. The state appealed again, but the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the stay Wednesday evening. Byrd, who has been on death row since 1982, would be the fifth Missouri death row inmate to be executed this year and the sixth in two years. Since the U.S. Supreme Court allowed states to resume use of the death penalty in 1976, there have been 141 executions nationwide. Officials at the Potosi Correctional Center, about 75 miles south of St. Louis, said they were making preparations to carry out the execution in case the stay was lifted. ``He seems to be in a good frame of mind,'' said prison spokesman Phil Banks, who said he had spoken with Byrd. ``He's just quietly watching television.'' Byrd, 35, was convicted in 1982 of shooting to death a cafeteria manager and three cooks in a shopping mall in the St. Louis suburb of Des Peres. Authorities said the employees were herded into the manager's 10-by-10 foot office Oct. 23, 1980, and gunned down one by one as they stood. Byrd confessed to the murders in May 1981 after being arrested in Savannah, Ga., for the murder of a liquor store employee. Byrd's appeal is based on two issues: the composition of the jury and the requirement for unanimity among jurors on certain instructions during the sentencing phase. The 8th Circuit found that the Missouri Supreme Court refused to review those issues when it said that Byrd had exhausted his state remedies.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Have New Gubernatorial Nominee, Second Spot On Ballot In Doubt
DOC.TEXT: Less than a week before the election, Minnesota Republicans have a new gubernatorial candidate, but the lieutenant governor spot on the GOP ticket remained in doubt Wednesday. The secretary of state delayed the printing of supplemental ballots to reflect John Grunseth's withdrawal from the gubernatorial race until after his running mate makes her case in court for staying on the ballot. ``There's no precedent for any of the decisions I've made,'' Secretary of State Joan Growe said. ``I think we have to anticipate anything at this stage, given the kind of year we've had.'' Grunseth, the GOP nominee, dropped out of the race Sunday amid allegations he tried to get teen-age girls to swim nude with him nine years ago and had a mistress during both of his marriages. Arne Carlson, the runner up in the GOP primary who later mounted a write-in campaign, was chosen by the state Republican Party's executive committee to take Grunseth's place on the ballot. The 14-member committee later decided the party wasn't empowered to fill the vacancy, but Growe said state law required Carlson, as the GOP primary runner-up, to become the nominee. He faces the Democratic incumbent, Rudy Perpich. Because the governor and lieutenant governor run as a team in Minnesota, Growe also decided that Joanell Dyrstad, Carlson's write-in running mate, should replace Grunseth's running mate, Sharon Clark, on the ballot, even though Clark didn't withdraw. Clark petitioned the Minnesota Supreme Court to reverse Growe's decision. Arguments were scheduled for Thursday. ``I have won the endorsement of the party. I have won the primary election and I have been certified by the state Canvassing Board,'' Clark said. ``I have a constituency of my own and that constituency deserves to be represented on the Republican ticket.'' Growe, a Democrat, said she also delayed the printing of ballots because it was possible other legal challenges may be filed. She said she will wait until Friday before directing county auditors to print ballots with Carlson's and Dyrstad's names. ``I believe we need to wait until the final resolution of the matter in the courts,'' Growe said. Republican Party Chairman Bob Weinholzer said he hadn't heard of additional legal challenges. ``It appears like she (Growe) is encouraging somebody to file a lawsuit because she keeps talking about it,'' he said. Carlson, a moderate who often has been at odds with the GOP's dominant conservative faction, won unanimous support from the party's executive committee. ``Realistically, 99 percent of the people vote for governor, not lieutenant governor,'' Weinholzer said.

DOC.HEAD: Craig Russell, Mae West Impersonator, Dead at 42
DOC.TEXT: Craig Russell, who delighted and sometimes shocked audiences with his impersonations of Mae West, Judy Garland and Peggy Lee, has died of a stroke resulting from AIDS. He was 42. Russell died Tuesday night at Toronto Western Hospital, said spokeswoamn Lucie Baistrocchi. He had learned he had AIDS in March. Born in Toronto, Russell became enamored of show business after a brief meeting with Mae West in 1965. At 17, he moved into her house in Los Angeles and worked as her part-time secretary. After an apparent dispute, Russell returned four months later to Toronto to study hairdressing. ``She was about as funny as the Ten Commandments,'' he was later quoted as saying. Russell remained a devoted fan, however, and years later the walls of his apartment remained covered in memorabilia given to him by the movie legend. His first stage appearance was during Christmas 1970, when he impersonated Tallulah Bankhead at a gay club in Toronto. For years he was among the best-known female impersonators in North America. His performance in the 1977 film ``Outrageous,'' in which he played a flamboyant drag queen, won Russell an unusual distinction - both the best female and best male actor awards at the Virgin Islands Film Festival. His career soured in 1981 when a four-city tour of Western Canada was canceled after Russell undressed onstage and threw wigs and jewelry at the audience. He was later barred from a talk show in Vancouver when he advised the women viewers, ``If you can't sing, dance or act, you'd better marry a politician.'' Margaret Trudeau, wife of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, happened to be on the set and slapped him in the face backstage. ``He had no discipline,'' said Gino Empry, Russell's publicist and manager. ``If he had harnessed his talent, he would have been a world star. It was his lack of discipline that defeated him.'' Russell recently released an album featuring a song titled ``Glamor Monster,'' Empry said. Profits from the record will go to AIDS research. In 1982, swaddled in fur and tottering on red high heels, Russell married Lori Jenkins, a fan with whom he shared what he called a ``legal friendship.'' Ms. Jenkins was by his side when he died, Empry said.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Price Rise Could Boost Government Subsidies to Commuter Airlines
DOC.TEXT: The Transportation Department said Wednesday it is considering boosting subsidies to commuter airlines to help them cope with fuel price increases caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Big Sky Airlines, which provides service to Montana and adjoining states, has appealed to the department to renegotiate its subsidy, said department spokesman Bill Mosley. Other carriers are talking with the department informally, he said. ``We are looking into it with the eye to doing something about it, but nothing yet,'' Mosley said. The department could cut some service or ask Congress next year for an emergency appropriation, he said. Congress provided $26.6 million for commuter air subsidies in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Jet fuel, also used in the turboprop engines of many copmmuter airline planes, has roughly doubled in price since Aug. 1, from 60 cents a gallon to about $1.20. Big Sky stands to lose $12,000 a month despite $1.5 million in annual federal subsidies, said Gary Ness, director of the North Dakota Aeronautics Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tired of Hostage Treatment, Iraq Offers Holiday Visits to U.S
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 11th pvs `The offer' with U.S. hostage wife's comment. Picks up 12th pvs, `A few...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DOD90,109
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he was fed up with Saddam Hussein's harsh treatment of U.S. hostages. Iraq later said it would allow American families to visit the captives for the holidays. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and a British commander meanwhile warned the likelihood of war in the region was increasing. But Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed al-Mashat, said he sought to avoid bloodshed and reiterated Iraq's offer to negotiate - if other Middle East conflicts were included on the agenda. The United States has rejected such linkage. Mubarak said the Persian Gulf crisis has become so dangerous it ``could explode at any time.'' And he urged ``our brothers in Iraq'' to realize the danger their Aug. 2 invasion of oil-rich Kuwait has caused. The commander of British forces in the gulf warned that an attack against Iraq is increasingly likely. Air Chief Marshal Sir Paddy Hine said a joint team culled from the Royal Air Force, Royal Navy and Army is developing plans for military strikes. ``Saddam Hussein seems reluctant at the moment to accept the judgment of world opinion,'' he said. ``It is looking increasingly unlikely that Saddam Hussein will withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait.'' Bush said his patience was wearing thin with Saddam over the 1,000 American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. ``The embassy is being starved,'' Bush said of the besieged U.S. mission in occupied Kuwait. ``The people out there are not being resupplied. ``Do you think I'm concerned about it? You're darn right I am. And what I'm going to do about it - let's just wait and see, because I have had it with that kind of treatment of Americans,'' Bush said. Later Wednesday, an Information Ministry spokesman in Baghdad said the Iraqi government is prepared to allow families of Americans in Iraq to visit during the Christmas and New Year's holidays. No other details were available, and there was no immediate reaction from the State Department. The offer to American relatives appears to be part of an overall Iraqi offer to all relatives of its ``foreign guests'' to visit the captives. Several Britons have already done so, including wives visiting their husbands being held in Iraq. ``It's probably just another psychological ploy,'' said Dawn Bazner, whose husband, Mark, early in the crisis was videotaped asking Saddam to let foreign women and children go. Speaking from Palm Desert, Calif., she said, ``I'm hoping that we won't have to visit (Mark) there ... but if it comes down to it, I will go.'' A few diplomats have held out at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, defying an Iraqi order to close missions in the annexed nation. Iraq has cut utilities and surrounded the compound with troops. The British Embassy also remains open. The administration of former President Reagan used the safety of Americans as a justification to invade Grenada in 1983. The Bush administration also cited the safety of Americans when he sent troops to Panama in 1989. In Baghdad, Information Ministry Spokesman Latif Jassim said the United States was spreading ``false reports'' on the conditions of ``foreign guests'' to seek an excuse to attack Iraq. Baghdad calls the hundreds of Westerners held in Iraq and Kuwait to deter attack by the multinational force deployed in Saudi Arabia ``guests.'' Many have been sent to strategic sites as human shields. ``I want to tell you that our guests live in good conditions at some places better than many Iraqi families, but Bush perhaps wants an excuse,'' Jassim said. CBS Radio quoted Jassim as saying he will make available to U.S. television networks videotaped messages from American hostages to their families to show they were not being mistreated. The United States has more than 210,000 troops in the gulf region - the largest force sent abroad since the Vietnam war - and Washington plans to send 100,000 more. About 100,000 soldiers have been deployed by other nations. The 13-nation force - including troops from several moderate Arab nations - faces about 460,000 Iraqi troops stationed in southern Iraq and Kuwait. Egypt, along with Saudi Arabia, has led Arab opposition to Saddam. Speaking to reporters Wednesday in Cairo, Mubarak said he hoped ``our brothers in Iraq will understand well that the situation is very dangerous and could explode at any time.'' If war comes, ``Iraq will be ruined, and (it) will harm all of us,'' Mubarak said. At a news conference in Washington, Iraq's al-Mashat spoke of peace. ``We once more call for a negotiated solution, to have a political and diplomatic solution. We seek to avoid bloodshed,'' he said. He reiterated that Iraq was ready to begin negotiations on the crisis if issues such as Israel's occupation of the Gaza Strip and West Bank were included in the talks. ``We seek a peaceful solution to all of these questions,'' al-Mashat said. ``All of them together. Now.'' Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt announced he is traveling to Baghdad next week at Saddam's invitation. ``I think it's most important now to listen to what the people in Baghdad think, to listen to whether they think there's a way out of their isolation,'' said Brandt, who won the 1971 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to bridge the Cold war gap between West Germany and the Soviet Union. About 400 Germans are among thousands of foreigners stranded or held in Iraq. Brandt said he was going as a private citizen, not a representative of Bonn. Al-Mashat also reiterated claims that Iraqi agents in Kuwait had seized a secret document showing the CIA and Kuwaiti intelligence were plotting against Iraq before the invasion. Peter Earnest, a spokesman for the U.S. intelligence agency, said the document is fake. In other developments: -In Israel, a Defense Ministry official said the army has distributed 3 million gas masks to protect civilians from a possible Iraqi chemical attack. -Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said his country had asked Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait, Tehran television reported. -The official Iraqi News Agency said Switzerland would ship about 30 tons of medicine to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 March in Duvalierist Demonstration in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - About 1,000 people marched Wednesday to support the presidential campaign of the former head of a paramilitary army that terrorized the nation for nearly 30 years. Supporters of candidate Roger Lafontant brandished placards hostile to foreign intervention and to the council that is organizing the elections, Radio Metropole reported. About 250 Organization of American States and 300 United Nations observers will monitor elections slated for Dec. 16. The Electoral Council is still determining whether Lafontant is eligible to be a candidate.
