DOC.HEAD: Militants Use Confrontation to Fight Anti-Gay Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language, 14th graf
DOC.TEXT: It was a quiet night at King Tut's Wah-Wah Hut bar - if quiet is the word for an East Village saloon where tattooed toughs gather to booze, play pool and listen to heavy metal. Gradually, a very different crowd filtered in. They wore T-shirts with the legend ``Queer Nation'' emblazoned over a map of the United States, and settled in under the ultraviolet-lit painting of a skull on fire. A beefy pool player was about to take a shot when he noticed a pair of the newcomers standing beside him. His jaw dropped. The two men were kissing, mouth to mouth. ``Oh no! Oh no!'' the man with the cue cried, retreating in revulsion to the other side of the table. ``Stop that.'' They ignored him. This was why they had come - to agitate, to confront people they blame for an increase in attacks on homosexuals. They are Queer Nation - one of several militant gay organizations which have discarded polite persuasion in favor of grab-them-by-the-lapels defiance. There are Queer Nation chapters in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Boston, Detroit, Philadelphia, Providence, Toronto, Boulder, Colo., and Ithaca, N.Y. Four-hundred people attend bi-weekly meetings in New York. Where groups like the Gay Men's Health Crisis responded to AIDS by lobbying for help and by providing services to sufferers, the new generation - ACT-UP, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power - takes to the streets. ACT-UP has thrown bagels and noodles at a hotel where President Bush was appearing, blocked Wall Street, disrupted services in St. Patrick's Cathedral - all protests against what it claims is political, business and religious indifference to the epidemic. It is ``a whole new attitude,'' said Randy Shilts, a national correspondent for the San Francisco Chronicle and author of the critically acclaimed account of the AIDS crisis, ``And the Band Played On.'' The new militants are ``rebelling against straight society but also against older gay people,'' said Shilts, 39. It is a pattern that repeats itself in many social movements - radicalization followed by retrenchment and new radicalization, said Jim Jasper, an assistant professor of sociology at New York University. ``The newcomers become disappointed in how ossified the old groups are'' and take their own action, Jasper said. ---

``Any faggot gets within a one-foot range, I'm going to knock him out,'' the pool player declared loudly to anyone who would listen. But more militants crowded into the little room, outnumbering the regulars. ``We're here and we're queer, we're here and we're queer,'' they chanted. The chanting grew so loud it drowned out the heavy metal music and the pool player, who was shouting ``Shut up, shut up'' to no avail. Later, outside the bar, the homosexuals singled out a skinhead who had shouted a slur. They shouted ``Homophobe'' and pointed their fingers at him. They left. ``We'll be back and we'll be stronger,'' they chanted. And: ``We're here, we're queer, we're fabulous - get used to it.'' ---

It is safe to say that the 50 demonstrators who visited King Tut's Wah-Wah Hut on that summer night - and had staged a ``kiss-in'' at the Alcatraz bar down the block earlier in the evening - won no converts. They didn't expect to. ``We are breaking down the barriers of unspoken segregation,'' said Queer Nation spokesman Jay Blotcher. ``It isn't going to happen in a week. This harkens back to the Woolworth counter in the South and the blacks coming back again and again and again. Like them, we are a disenfranchised minority fighting for our rights.'' Queer Nation's founders were active in ACT-UP, and remain members. ``We felt that there were other issues, such as the increase in violence against gays and lesbians, that had to be addressed,'' said co-founder Alan Klein. Two of the four men who helped found Queer Nation had themselves been victims of gay bashing, and Klein said the group was formed because the men felt there was no organized response to attacks on homosexuals. The group organized its first demonstration in April, when a thousand marchers protested a pipe-bombing outside a gay bar that injured three people. Through Sept. 30 of this year, there have been 88 anti-gay crimes in New York City, said Capt. Charles Senzel of the police department's bias unit. Police said there were 47 such crimes for all of 1989 and 43 for 1988. But the Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project, which provides legal help and counseling for victims of gay bashing, gave much higher figures. It listed 425 anti-gay crimes in the city through the end of September, compared to 338 for all of 1989, according to David Kirschenbaum, a spokesman for the group. Police said privately the wide discrepancy may be due to the fact that police have to prove an attack was based on the victim's sexual orientation. ``Our message is gays and lesbians will no longer be silent victims,'' Blotcher said. ``We are here and we're a force to be reckoned with.'' Another group, the Pink Panthers, patrols streets to protect gays. The members carry no weapons, but walkie-talkies, cameras and whistles. The purpose of the cameras are to photograph gay bashers the patrols apprehend. The group claims 200 members - all trained in self-defense, according to founder Gerri Wells - and is patrolling Greenwich Village. ``We will hold people for the police and we will bash back if necessary,'' said Ms. Wells, a lesbian. ``We will use equal force (to hold a gay basher fighting to escape).'' The Panthers have not detained anyone since the group was formed in June but patrols have appeared as gays were harassed on four or five occasions, she said. The culprits ran when the Pink Panthers arrived, she said. ``Everyone has a right to defend themselves,'' said Inspector Paul Sanderson, head of the police department's bias unit. ``The local patrols are good as long as they don't get out of hand. If they grab someone who's been beating up homosexuals and hold him until officers arrive, that's the kind of citizens' action that's needed.'' ``If I walk with my lover down the street, I face physical or verbal abuse,'' said Klein. ``That's intolerable. I have to make important choices. I have to confront that bias. We have to fight for our rights and I think that can't be compromised.'' The militants are not always so confrontational. Queer Nation goes to shopping malls to distribute leaflets which note that gays have existed for centuries and which list some famous people who were homosexual. The leaflets are partially aimed at gay youths who may be despondent or even suicidal about their homosexuality, Blotcher said. ``There's no positive reinforcement from society for them,'' he said. ``All you're told is you will live a life of alienation and disappointment. Adolescents crave acceptance, and this puts some of them over the edge. ``There's nothing out there to tell the kids, `Hey, it's OK,' and that's why we do this.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Tues PMs, Nov 6

DOC.HEAD: In Investing, an Extra Stress on Safety
DOC.TEXT: In these touchy economic times, people with money to manage are subjecting even supposedly safe investments to some painstaking scrutiny. When they see the labels ``insured'' or ``guaranteed'' on a piece of financial merchandise, they are increasingly asking ``by whom?'' and ``against what risks?'' This pickiness is only prudent, many advisers on money matters agree, given the troubled state of the nation's bank industry and of the markets for investments ranging from real estate to stocks. ``Credit contraction is happening,'' says Barton Biggs at Wall Street's Morgan Stanley & Co. in a current financial-strategy report. Or as Martin Zweig, a widely known investment adviser, told subscribers to his market letter: ``The contraction within the banking system is beginning to starve the economy for liquidity. Debt is way too high and is unraveling.'' This doesn't mean that such peers of the forecasting realm are predicting the end of the world. Indeed, they suggest, as the gloom on Wall Street deepens the markets may be getting closer and closer to a turning point. At the bottom of the economic cycle, abundant opportunities traditionally arise to buy good investments cheap. But ``I don't think we're there yet,'' Biggs declares. And the current slump has produced some peculiar phenomena that are causing reappraisals of what is safe and what is not. The savings and loan crisis, for example, has raised major questions about how far federal deposit insurance can be stretched. The depressed share prices of the nation's biggest bank holding companies - some of which stand at their lowest levels in a generation - have also challenged long-held assumptions about the foundations of the financial system. In this kind of environment, savers - and government regulators - are wary of taking promises of safety at face value. In the mutual fund business, for example, the Securities and Exchange Commission has just effectively barred funds investing in government securities from using the words ``guaranteed'' or ``insured'' in their names. The message to the public, the SEC said, must be clear that government backing covers only the items, such as Treasury bills or bonds, in the funds' portfolios, and not the funds themselves. And the government guarantee extends only to timely payment of interest and principal on its obligations. It offers no protection against fluctuations in market value that occur with the ups and downs of interest rates. The SEC action comes at a time when enthusiasm is running especially high for funds investing in government securities. As bad as Uncle Sam's own budget problems may be, advisers say, investors recognize that his promise to pay off on his debts is still as trustworthy as just about anybody's anywhere. This is not necessarily a testimonial to governmental virtue. Rather, it involves the recognition that the Treasury commands vast resources. Unlike many other borrowers, furthermore, it has the power to print new money should its hoard ever threaten to run short. Donoghue's Moneyletter, an advisory publication on matters of personal finance, seemed to capture the mood of the moment with a recent suggestion: ``All of our recommended domestic bond funds are either in U.S. Treasuries or in high-grade corporate bonds. ``Our choice of these types of funds was deliberate. Quality is king.''

DOC.HEAD: As Cold War Ends, So Does a Battler in It for Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The information came by various routes and methods, often by telephone or courier, from sources in communist countries to Western European friends who relayed it to the Rev. Blahoslav Hruby in New York. He had developed contacts across Europe before, during and after World War II in drama-packed experiences that enabled him to alert Americans to communist repressions throughout the Cold War. After its end, the old ``cold warrior,'' a moniker he gamely bore, died Oct. 22 of congestive heart failure at the age of 78. ``One way or another, the documents get to me,'' he once said in an interview. ``Sometimes I don't know all the details of how, and don't want to know because it might jeopardize someone. But we get them.'' A native Czech, Presbyterian minister and wartime U.S. Army intelligence captain in the Office of Strategic Services, Hruby for his last 28 years edited the monthly journal Religion in Communist Dominated Areas. The interreligious-sponsored journal, a prime source to churches, embassies, U.S. intelligence offices, universities and other periodicals, kept a steady, revealing watch on religious abuses under communism. ``The churches must help those who are being harassed because of their faith, and they must tell the truth to the world,'' he said, often exhorting church conventions to take stronger stands against Soviet religious persecution. His information on arrests, imprisonments and religious suppression, gathered in smuggled documents and other roundabout ways, focused early attention on many eventually freed prisoners. Only last July, after communist rule ended in Czechoslovakia, Hruby visited his homeland and met with many dissidents whose freedom he had worked for. One of them, now the country's president, Vaclav Havel, thanked him, saying: ``You were among the few who paid attention to the oppressed at a time when it was not at all lucrative.'' Hruby, who studied theology and philosophy in Czechoslovakia, Switzerland, France and Germany, was involved as a Protestant minister in early struggles against Nazism, broadcasting on French Radio to Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia. He escaped from Paris just before the Nazi takeover and aided fleeing Jewish refugees in Marseille and later in Portugal, providing them with false baptismal certificates. In the United States, he joined the OSS in 1942, and after assignments in Washington and London, served in Gen. George Patton's Third Army and was with it when it entered Czechoslovakia in May 1945. After the war and the communist coup in Czechoslovakia, he returned there as a naturalized American to establish contacts with people devoted to democracy. Several close friends later were executed. Back in the United States, he served Radio Free Europe as editor and adviser on religion behind the Iron Curtain, and later was European director of the American Fund for Czechoslovak Refugees in Munich, Germany. In 1962, he launched Religion in Communist Dominated Areas, initially under auspices of the National Council of Churches, which includes most major Protestant and Orthodox denominations. The council dropped the project in 1971, but the work was continued under a separat interreligious organization, the Research Center for Religion and Human Rights in Closed Societies. ``I saw so much under Hitler's dictatorship and what happened under the communists,'' he once related. ``I watched it with my own eyes.'' He said people must never ``remain silent'' about such crushing of human rights. He sometimes worried that people seemed ``brainwashed by rhetoric of detente which approves of all Russia's conquests and oppression.'' He called such appeasing gestures a ``deceptive fraud.'' However, he said there always remained ``a spirit of resistance in the free world - a resistance to the pressures of the communist bloc not only on religious freedom but on political and national freedoms.'' Hruby was regularly attacked in the communist press prior to the 1989 collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. He had been ailing in recent months and his wife, Olga, also a Czech native, has served as the journal's co-editor. In a brief telephone conversation after communism fell, he said: ``It's like the sun coming out. There still will be plenty of problems after all the years of oppression. But it's a new chance now to build free societies. We should all thank God.''

DOC.TEXT: Members of an ecumenical mission to Eastern Europe reported a ``tremendous upsurge'' in religious affiliation in Yugoslavia, Hungary and Romania. The delegation, sponsored by the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, said more and more people in those countries are turning to religion for solace and hope in the face of vast economic and political changes. However, the group also reported a growing chauvinism combined with strong religious and ethnic rivalries that threaten to heighten tensions and destablize new governments formed since the end of communist rule. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, president of the interfaith foundation, which works to promote religious freedom, said that ``at a time of economic hardship and social upheaval, many East Europeans are turning to God,'' but some also ``are turning against their neighbors of a different ethnic, religious or national origin.'' --- PRINCETON, N.J. (AP) - A Gallup poll found that 88 percent of families who attend religious services weekly contribute to charity, but of those who don't worship regularly, only 58 percent contribute to charity. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Sociologist Dean Hoge said at a conference on the Roman Catholic church's future that the shortage of priests will last ``as long as any of us in the room are alive.'' ``For us, it's permanent,'' said Hoge of the Catholic University of America. ``The problem exists in all modern European nations as well. This is a widespread phenomenon.'' He said that for every 100 priests who leave active ministry in this country, only 59 are being ordained. --- FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) - Thousands of United Methodist clergy and lay people are holding a five-day meeting on encouraging future growth and vitality of the 9 millon-member denomination. The meeting ends Sunday. --- ST. LOUIS (AP) - A federal appeals court has upheld a lower court ruling that classes on the Bible provided by the Gravette, Ark., elementary school are unconstitutional. The rural school district, which had offered the voluntary classes for 51 years, recently moved them off campus. District officials contended Bible classes are part of a well-rounded education and were popular in the community. George Oleson, a Fayetteville, Ark., lawyer for the plaintiff, said it was irrelevant that most people favored the classes. ``Even if there is one dissenter, he is protected under the First Amendment rights.'' Oleson also argued that information from the Bible should not be presented because ``children perceive what they are told by adults to be facts. They aren't rational thinkers at that age.'' --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Wilford V. Bane Jr., a longtime United Methodist communications employee who helped organigze the Vision Interfaith Satellite Network, has been named head of the denomination's public media division. He succeeds Nelson Price, now president and chief executive of the network, VISN. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The Conservative Baptist Association of America and the Salvation Army have been accepted into membership of the National Association of Evangelicals. That brings the association's membership to 48 denominations with a combined 4.6 million members. The Rev. Billy A. Melvin, executive director of the association, said the joining of ``two distinct but rich heritages and expressions of the Christian faith ... will contribute signficantly to the ministry and vision of NAE.'' The organization represents a conservative, evangelical counterpart to the National Council of Churches, whose older, more inclusive and mostly larger denominations have a combined membership of 42 million.

DOC.HEAD: Homebrew Craze: For Some, the Best Beer is Made in the Kitchen
DOC.TEXT: The Outlaws had made a sizeable dent in the evening's beer supply by the time Charlie Papazian rose to deliver the invocation. He raised a glass of frothy ale, grinned through his beard and led the crowd in the familiar chant: ``RELAX! DON'T WORRY! HAVE A HOMEBREW!'' Up went a hundred glasses and down went the beer. Down went Sal Pennacchio's BME Porter, a rich, black ale with a toasty aroma, and down went John Quinn's Spiced Brown Ale, redolent of chocolate and cinnamon. Down went a nutty German-style ale and a malty, golden Pilsener, and down went several other brews that will never be found at your neighborhood tavern. The beers were the star attraction at the annual dinner of the Outlaws of Homebrew, one of a growing number of clubs around the nation devoted to home beer brewing. The dinner (the food was bratwurst and sauerkraut) drew more than 100 people to Brooklyn Brewery's distribution warehouse on a dark industrial block in Brooklyn. It's estimated that somewhere between 500,000 and 1 million people in the United States brew their own beer. Homebrewing has been legal since 1978, and by all accounts is in the midst of a heady spurt of growth. ``I think people are paying more attention to what they're putting down their mouths,'' said Papazian, whose book, ``The Complete Joy of Homebrewing,'' is the hobby's bible. Membership in the American Homebrewers Association, which Papazian founded in 1978, is up 41 percent in the past year and is expected to top 10,000 by year's end. There are at least 150 homebrew clubs in the country and 1,200 retail supply shops. ``It's growing tremendously,'' said Seth Schneider, the general manager of Crosby & Baker, a brewing supply manufacturer and distributor in Westport, Mass. ``We're still on the steep part of a growth curve.'' The growth in homebrewing has mirrored the development of microbreweries - small breweries that typically devote themselves to full-bodied, high-quality beers. These beers account for a microscopic .15 percent of the national market, but loom large in the world of homebrewers. There is a strong symbiotic relationship between homebrewers and microbrewers. Homebrewers are microbrewers' most loyal customers; microbrewers frequently sponsor the homebrewers' organizations and events. The Outlaws of Homebrew dinner, for instance, was sponsored by Brooklyn Brewery, which provided the warehouse and two varieties of its own beer. Company founder Steve Hindy is himself a homebrewer who likes to tinker with recipes in his kitchen before trying them out in the brewery. ``Actually, right now I'm brewing something I call a chocolate stout at home,'' he said. The attractions of homebrewing are several. Foremost is the ability to make good beer; quality has improved mightily in the past decade as homebrew suppliers have become increasingly sophisticated. ``A homebrew rivals the best beer you've ever had,'' said Schneider. ``It hasn't traveled, it has more body, it hasn't been filtered ... and you can make it exactly to your taste.'' Some of those tastes are exotic - some would say bizarre. Homebrewers have been known to toss all manner of ingredients into their brew. Spruce beer, cherry beer and ginger beer are among the more common of the strange brews. Sal Pennacchio, treasurer of the Outlaws of Homebrew, recalls what happened last November when his wife was about to toss out the Halloween pumpkin. The result was is Pumpkin Ale, which won third prize in a national homebrew competition; it tasted, he said, ``just like pumpkin pie.'' ``I think that's the great thing about homebrewing,'' Pennacchio said. ``With a little experience, you can create anything you want.'' Not everyone wants a Pumpkin Ale, of course, but a more run-of-the-mill brew is a simple thing to make. Beer essentially consists of malted barley, yeast, hops and water. With those ingredients and a few rudimentary pieces of equipment - a bucket, some plastic tubing, a siphon, an air-lock valve, a capping tool and caps and bottles - anyone can make beer in their kitchen. Equipment for a novice costs about $45. Ingredients for two cases of beer run about $15, or roughly 35 cents a bottle. But that can vary widely depending on the kind of beer being made. A survey a few years ago by the American Homebrewers Association found that the overwhelming majority of homebrewers were white males, somewhat to the chagrin of those who champion the hobby. Brewers also tend to be married, well educated and divided almost evenly among cities, suburbs and small towns. ``The glibbest generalization,'' said Schneider, ``would be adult males with facial hair.'' Beyond that, he said, he's noticed that homebrewers are frequently computer buffs. Indeed, one of the busiest meeting places for homebrewers is on CompuServe Information Service's beer ``forum'' - a sort of electronic saloon for personal computer owners. The fact is, brewers are a gregarious lot. They are in their element at an event like the Outlaws dinner, drinking beer and swapping brewing notes with abandon. ``We're out for a good time,'' said Pennacchio, ``and to have good beer.''

DOC.HEAD: Monaco Woos Industrialists Along With Jet Set
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In this glamorous tax haven, money's playground by the sea, the idle rich are making room for the busy, bustling rich. Aristocrats still risk fortunes at the Casino's velvet-covered tables, but the 380-acre principality is catering to a new breed of wealth and power. It seeks the working rich who may spend a week in Monaco, not six months like the grand dukes of a century ago, to check on an industrial investment, watch the Grand Prix or attend a business convention. On a stroll through the Casino gardens, you're more likely to meet carpet salesmen from Toronto than European royalty. Last year, Monaco welcomed 50,000 convention-goers. Tourism now generates only one-fourth of the $5 billion gross national product. Gambling, once the government's mainstay, brings in only 4 percent. Banking accounts for 35 percent and light industry 27. Monaco now has 50 banks, and more are coming. Prince Rainier, who has ruled since 1949, sought to preserve and capitalize on Monaco's reputation for glamor when he called for economic diversification. ``The government has put its money behind prestige and luxury,'' said a public relations officer for the principality. ``It used to bank on the very rich. Today it has sought to develop a clientele of the slightly less rich.'' Hotel statistics are revealing. Monaco has 2,400 rooms, 80 percent in the luxury category going for $200 to $450. Fewer than 100 rooms cost less than $50. Officials try to keep industry and tourism apart. Hardly any of the 3 million daytrippers who spilled from trains and buses last year went near the industrial park on Fontvieille, a peninsula reclaimed from the sea. Many of the Monaco's 700 industrial companies are there. Most are in such high-tech, non-polluting fields as pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and engineering. A value added tax on the new commercial activities is the largest source of revenue in Monaco's annual budget of $510 million. Fontvieille accommodates both factories and company headquarters, stacked atop each other in skyscrapers. Nearby are a new sports stadium, three-star hotel, heliport and Monaco's only low-income housing. It was the brainchild of Prince Rainier, who saw the future of his tiny realm in real estate. A forest of skyscrapers, eyesores to many visitors, looms against a background of steep mountains, dwarfing hillside villas built in the 19th century. Commercial or residential space in Monaco generally is more expensive than in Paris and New York. A two-room apartment in Fontvieille rents for $3,000 a month, and cheaper accommodations are hard to find. Housing has become a major headache. The government gives priority for state-owned housing and rent subsidies of up to 50 percent to the natives, called Monegasques, but demand exceeds supply. Many apartments are owned by investors who spend little time in them. At night, dark windows make patches on luxury high-rises. Nightlife revolves around a few expensive discotheques and clubs, and cultural events geared to the wealthy establishment. Young residents complain of little to do. Monaco has only one movie theater, no discount or department stores, no major shopping center. There is virtually no unemployment, yet Monegasques - about 4,500 in a population of 27,000 - worry about the future. ``The problem is not finding jobs for young Monegasques, it's finding jobs suited to their educational degrees and qualifications,'' said Stephane Valeri, 28. He heads the Association of Young Monegasques, founded in 1986 to handle their employment and housing problems and help them start businesses. Citizens now own less than 3 percent of commerce and industry in Monaco, but Valeri said new opportunities were opening in services and the law. ``We're very attached to our history, our traditions and to the royal family,'' he said. ``We're just trying to make Monaco better for the year 2000.'' In addition to the myth that all ar rich, which the government tries to dispel, Monegasques have a reputation as poor workers. ``Some Monegasques ... adopt a superior attitude and feel they can get away with anything because they know they can't be fired,'' a government spokesperson said, on condition of anonymity. The 5,000 Italians who cross the border each day to work in hotels and restaurants envy the privileges of Monegasques, including comprehensive health insurance, higher wages and the first crack at vacant jobs. Residents of this fiscal paradise, except for French nationals who have arrived since 1957, pay no taxes on income, capital gains or on an inheritance if it comes directly from a parent or spouse. Security and respectability are basic tenets. The police force has 400 members, who help tourists, direct traffic and discourage purse-snatching and other crimes. ``Monaco is the type of place where you think twice about dropping candy wrappers,'' said a retired Greek executive who has lived here 35 years. ``You feel very safe and life is very calm.'' A dress code confines bathing suits to the beach and forbids going barefoot. Shorts are permitted, but men are not allowed to go bare chested. Expulsion from Monaco is the punishment for violations. Officials know the future depends on physical expansion. Besides putting the train station underground, architects unveiled plans last year for three floating islands with their own stores and homes, connected to the mainland by bridges and ferries. ``It sounds like ... Jules Verne, but it's something I'm sure my successors will have to deal with,'' said Jean-Louis Medecin, the mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Media Fight Headline War Over Yugoslavia's Future
DOC.TEXT: Truth has been critically wounded, at the very least, by partisan journalism that inflames the bitter ethnic rivalries of this patchwork nation. Yugoslavia's freewheeling press, once the most open of Eastern Europe, has become increasingly provincial, entangled in local conflicts. The trend is evident in all six Yugoslav republics, but the state-run press and television of Serbia seem to lead in the way. Headlines scream ``Hellish Police Hunt on Serbs'' over accounts of routine investigations in Croatia. An article on federal reforms aimed at creating a market economy is introduced with: ``Serbian Economy Knifed in Back.'' Accusations flying between Communist-ruled Serbia, the largest republic, and the freely elected governments of Slovenia and Croatia have created such animosity that Yugoslavia may not survive. Serbs and Croats, the largest ethnic groups in this nation of 24 million, have been rivals since 1918, when the country was born as the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes. It was reconstituted as a communist republic in 1945. Political and economic differences accentuate the ethnic divisions in a power struggle that began with the death in 1980 of Josip Tito, who founded the postwar nation and held it together. Croatia and Slovenia want Yugoslavia to be a loose confederation of sovereign states. Serbia insists on a ``modern federation'' with power still centralized in Belgrade, the Serbian and federal capital. Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's populist leader, says he will enlarge the republic to take in Serbs from other regions if the federation disintegrates. When Croatian police tried to recover hundreds of guns stolen from government armories by local Serbs, banner headlines in Serbia said: ``Croatian Police Throw Serbian Infants Around'' and ``Fascist Terrorists Sent to Subjugate Serbs.'' Stories below the headlines in the dailies Politika and Politika Ekspres did not support the allegations. They quoted ``well-informed sources,'' unnamed and not described, echoing Serbian claims that Croatian police recruited ``fascist terrorists'' to harass the 500,000 Serbs in Croatia. ``Poison seeps from the pages of Politika in all directions,'' said Croatian writer Slavko Mihalic. ``Everybody is denounced for one thing or another, and that includes any Serbs who dare oppose Milosevic.'' Media in Slovenia and Croatia have accused Milosevic repeatedly of fomenting ethnic turmoil. In the Croatian parliamewnt, deputy Stjepan Mesic waved a copy of Politika and declared: ``Milosevic is guilty of stirring up the trouble in Croatia.'' Belgrade television reported ``all-out civil war'' between Serbs and Croats in Croatia, although no one had been killed or seriously injured. To tighten the gripon Serbian media, Milosevic and his Communist supporters have fired or demoted hundreds of independent-minded journalists. After the latest round of 20 demotions, the daily Vjesnik in Zagreb, capital of Croatia, accused Serbs of ``pushing their hard-line concepts to the brink of intercommunal violence to avoid holding free elections.'' Serbia has scheduled elections for Dec. 9. ``Civil war may be the last refuge for hard-line Communists,'' Vjesnik declared. Calls for fairness by opposition parties and independent journalists are ignored by Serbian television and the once-respected Politika. In June, police with clubs broke up a demonstration against biased coverage, beating several intellectuals and opposition leaders. Television did not show what happened and said protesters attacked the police. A television newscast in Croatia that included footage of the violence was not broadcast in Belgrade. ``Two-thirds of what the Belgrade media say is lies,'' said Vuk Draskovic, head of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, which threatens to boycott the December elections unless unbiased coverage is guaranteed. Serbian television, nicknamed ``Milosevision'' in Belgrade, agreed to carry brief opposition statements. It insisted all 39 registered groups have equal time, however, even though only three have significant followings. Serbian television, nicknamed ``Milosevision'' by residents of Belgrade, carries short campaign speeches by opposition leaders only on its third channel, seen in just one-sixth of the republic. Ante Markovic, the federal premier, is popular with Yugoslavs generally, but not with Milosevic, who objects to his market-oriented economic reforms and attempts to form a national political party. Markovic has described in the press as an ``enemy of the Serbian people out to plunder our republic.'' In an effort to counter such treatment, the premier announced a weekly federal television program to present fair coverage of national issues. TV Belgrade refused to cooperate, effectively keeping the one-hour program off the air in Serbia. Serbian media make their most abusive attacks on the ethnic Albanian majority in the republic's southern province, Kosovo. Albanians in Kosovo have demonstrated regularly against Milosevic's abolition of self-rule in the province, and Serbian police have killed at least 60 in the past 18 months. The Serbian press portrays the demonstrators as ``terrorists'' who attack security forces with ``heavy machine guns and mortars.'' No Serbs have been killed or seriously hurt. International human rights groups that condemn the repression are ``sworn enemies of the Serbs'' and members of the U.S. Congress who visited Kosovo were ``mercenaries in the pay of the Albanian lobby,'' the Belgrade papers say.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Bronco: High and Mighty
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: In its 25th year, the brawny Ford Bronco continues to be the leader in the full-size utility vehicle segment. Bronco sales may have fallen 13 percent in the 1990 model year, but Ford still sold 54,505 of the hardy trucks. Sales for the category as a whole, meanwhile, dropped 20 percent. Introduced in August 1965 as a 1966 model, the Bronco won early raves for its mix of car and truck attributes and its ability to offer both utility and personal transportation. Its biggest year was 1978, when 82,343 Broncos were sold. In the 1980s, Ford began producing a smaller version, the Bronco II, which Ford replaced with the 1991 Explorer. The test vehicle, a 1991 Silver Anniversary Bronco, carries on the tradition of the original. The lowest part of the door opening was at my knee level. There was no handle to help me climb up and inside, so I had to grip the steering wheel and hoist myself in. It wasn't graceful; it was a challenge. The engine was a gas-hogging, 5.8-liter V8 that got about 13 miles per gallon in mixed city-highway driving. Coupled with a four-speed automatic transmission, it produced 200 horsepower. The Bronco operated in both two-wheel and four-wheel drive. I just pushed a button on the dash to go from one to the other, since the front wheels had automatic locking hubs. Four-wheel drive allowed me to climb over everything, though the off-road ride was quite bouncy as I hit rocks and potholes. Two-wheel drive also offered a rather mushy ride, and it took some planning to make turns without going over curbs and hitting tree limbs. The Bronco's rear antilock brakes worked wonderfully, keeping the large rear end from swaying out of control in sudden stops. Inside, there was plenty of room for anyone to stretch out in the two front bucket seats. A huge, deep storage box - in addition to a regular glovebox on the dashboard - was located between the seats and kept front-seat passengers a good distance apart. Letters and numbers on dashboard gauges were large and easy to read. But I did have a problem finding the power window and door lock buttons at night. The buttons were on the lower half of the doors but they were not lit. The Bronco's front seats leaned forward to allow passengers to climb up and into the rear seat area. The door openings were wide, allowing good access, but I had to give the front seatbacks a really good shove to return them to their locked position. The rear bench seat was cushioned and comfortable for two adults but might be a bit confining for three good-sized adults, since the seat is squeezed between the vehicle's two wheel wells. The rear cargo area behind the seat was spacious and nicely carpeted, and you could fold up and take out the rear seat for even more storage area. But watch the tailgate. It's big and heavy and requires both hands for a smaller person to handle. Fit and finish on the test truck was good, save for some grease that oozed up from where the transmission shifter attached to the steering column. Bronco buyers are predominantly men - 82.2 percent - and married - 73.4 percent. Ford spokesman Woody Haines said California has the highest Bronco usage, followed by Illinois, Michigan, Florida, New Jersey and Texas. Most Bronco buyers have annual household income of between $30,000 and $45,000. Nearly a third have some college education, and 13.3 percent are in managerial jobs, Haines said. He added that the major competitor is the Chevrolet Suburban, which starts at more than $15,600 for a base model. The test 25th anniversary Bronco had a base price of $24,866, but the lowest-priced Bronco starts at $18,195, according to Haines. Consumer Reports magazine ranked the 1988 Bronco average in owner reports of trouble.

DOC.HEAD: TV's Ever Encroaching Presence
DOC.TEXT: To Cable News Network, Turner Network Television and Headline News, media mogul Ted Turner has added yet another building block atop his TV empire. You can find in the supermarket checkout line. No, it's not TV Guide. But it is near the National Enquirer. You know how it is. You're stuck behind someone with an overburdened cart, waiting patiently to purchase your piddling pile of groceries. They're writing a check. You've got cash. What to do? Watch television. In 13 stores across the country, the Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System and Connecticut-based ActMedia have just completed an unprecedented, six-week test in which TV monitors were installed in every checkout line. It provides the latest example of how far Turner will go in attempting to create his own global village. It also represents a new marketing tool brilliant in its simplicity: What better way to sell something than to flash it before the eyes of a captive consumer audience? ``Some of the networks hemmed and hawed,'' said Wayne LoCurto, president and chief executive officer of ActMedia. ``Turner went bonkers.'' Pushing products on people going nowhere in a hurry is nothing new. Efforts are underway to pipe television and advertising into doctors' waiting rooms. But Turner and ActMedia are the first to beam live television into grocery stores. The Checkout Channel, as they call it, works like this: TV monitors with built-in sound sensors blink on whenever someone stands in line. On the tube are eight-minute segments culled from CNN's Headline News. Each segment contains two minutes of commercials. During the daytime, the spots are tailored to women. In the evenings, they are geared to working couples and singles. On the weekend, they are family oriented. ``One of Ted's missions is to have CNN available everywhere, all the time,'' said Scott Weiss, vice president of special products for TBS. ``We have a division that has licensed CNN for use in hotels and airlines.'' Rest easy. To date, there are no plans to pipe the 24-hour news channel into public restrooms. But no place, it seems, is forever safe from the intrusion of the boob tube and attempts to make bigger advertising bucks. ``We are exploring every opportunity where you might find yourself standing in line with nothing to do,'' Weiss said. The concept for the Checkout Channel originated at ActMedia, LoCurto said, and was offered to the major networks. Only Turner, however, was ready to put up money immediately. At a cost of $75 million, ActMedia, one of the country's largest in-store advertising firms, installs the hardware. TBS, at a cost it won't disclose, provides the programming. To do so, Turner assembled a new department of about 30 editors, writers and producers to furnish the 24-hour channel with its eight-minute (the average wait in the checkout line) segments via satellite. Each installment is updated as news events dictate and the channel can go live with major breaking stories. The test period ended two days before Halloween. For the next few months, Turner and ActMedia will review the channel's performance, confer with advertisers and store managers and try to make sure all are happy. If ActMedia's revenue projections prove true, everyone should be. The advertising firm has estimated that the channel will bring in $100 million annually by 1993. ActMedia plans to equip 275 stores a month beginning next spring, resulting in 5,000 stores with television monitors by 1992. That means 60 million people each week will be watching. ``There is substantial cost to program a network of this nature,'' Weiss said. ``But this is really the wave of the future. You're going to see television everywhere you go.'' According to Weiss and LoCurto, the reception has been overwhelmingly positive. ``The only negative response came from people thinking that this was going to increase the costs of their groceries,'' LoCurto said. ``Once we explained that we were paying for it, the response was terrific.'' Not one of the 13 test markets, which represented more than half of the nation's top supermarket chains, asked that the monitors be removed, LoCurto said. The financial payoff for the stores comes from a split of the advertising profits with ActMedia. For Turner, the benefit comes in getting two free commercial segments in each eight-minute installment and the opportunity to expose CNN to a greater number of people than its current 50 million subscribers. At the A&P in Atlanta, shoppers loved the Checkout Channel. ``We're doing excellent,'' said assistant store manager Mike Jackson. ``It pacifies people in the lines, especially on our busiest days.'' LoCurto insists that the Checkout Channel's advertising is not intended to encourage impulse buying. Foods such as Campbell's soups are advertised next to non-edible products such as Ford Escorts and Florida's Walt Disney World. ``We look at it as another (television) network,'' LoCurto said. ``It's another way to expose all kinds of products.'' But Jackson at the A&P said he saw a lot of shoppers leave the checkout line to pick up things that caught their eye on the TV. The flickering monitor also reminded people of things they had forgotten to put on their grocery lists, Jackson said. Weren't some customers annoyed by the new machinery? Weren't the checkers distracted by the noise? ``Naw, the girls up at the registers didn't mind it one bit,'' Jackson said. ``I did have one complaint, though. Some guys wanted to know why we couldn't keep it tuned to a certain football game so they could sit there and watch it.'' Is every potentially boring circumstance now open to television? Is nothing sacred to television's cable czar? Well, Weiss replied laughing, they did think about churches. ``I don't think they would have let us in,'' he said, ``but I bet somebody would watch it.''

For release Sunday, Nov. 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Middle Class Struggling With Economic Downturn
With BC-Recession-Guide; Graphics, Logo
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Four months ago, The Associated Press first reported evidence of an ``Unofficial Recession'' in many parts of the country. While statistics have yet to qualify the downturn as a full-blown recession, American belts continue to tighten. Below, in a follow-up to a July series, the AP explores the mounting human toll. ---

When business was booming, carpenter Tony Gonzalez stood atop his world, Chicago's gleaming new high-rises. Now he's back to earth, remodeling an occasional kitchen or adding a room. Medical-equipment salesman Brian Dillon makes fewer trips through his Rocky Mountain territory since higher gasoline prices nearly doubled travel costs. In Florida, new mother Myra DeLessio put off buying a dining room set, clips discount coupons more often and watches for sales. Growing numbers of middle-class Americans, jolted by job insecurity and other forces beyond their control, have been retrenching and rethinking in preparation for what some experts believe will be a long economic winter. Government figures released this past week show the nation is still enjoying the longest economic expansion in peacetime history, but many private economists say that information masks the truth. They point to rising unemployment, falling home sales and the grim Christmas foreseen by storekeepers. On a historical scale, the suffering is relative. Bread lines aren't forming, but average people are definitely feeling a pinch. In the fading glow of the high-flying 1980s, cutbacks at home, office and factory have the look and feel of bad times. Matters seem to have worsened just in recent weeks. Part of it is due to higher energy prices from the Persian Gulf crisis, which has made many Americans more careful with their money. Others fret about paying more taxes as a result of the long-delayed federal budget agreement. ``We think we're in a recession and the recession began some time in the summer,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist for Nomura Securities Inc. in New York. Albert Sindlinger, a veteran forecaster whose Wallingford, Pa., firm tracks household-spending trends as a measure of the economy's health, is even more convinced. He says the recession began in January. Part of the debate about whether the country is in a recession stems from the enormous size of the U.S. economy, which by some analyses is a hodgepodge of economies that don't behave the same way. While factories in Seattle work overtime, Wall Street fades; while Silicon Valley prospers and Dallas rebounds, Philadelphia and Detroit struggle. ``I'm not sure the word (recession) fits any more. The country is not one,'' said Jay Goldinger of Capital Insight Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., financial consulting company. ``Consumers and investors in the West for the most part still have a positive outlook.'' But for people like Gonzalez, the Chicago carpenter; Dillon, the Denver salesman; or Mrs. DeLessio, the new mom from Jacksonville, Fla., economic semantics aren't important. ``People aren't coming in and saying, `I'm in a recession.' They're saying, `I'm really worried about our finances and feel we're not doing as well as we ought to be doing,''' said Victoria Felton-Collins, a financial planner and psychologist with offices in California. ``The psychology has such a greater effect than the actual (economic) indicators.'' Donald L. Badders, president of the National Foundation for Consumer Credit in Silver Spring, Md., said the number of families seeking advice from the foundation's 500-office network has risen noticeably in the past month alone. Arthur Andersen & Co. executives report that in recent months about 50 percent more companies have asked them to hold financial planning seminars for employees, current and laid off, partly due to the tenuous economic picture. Badders said his counselors are seeing more people from layoff-plagued financial services and banking companies in the Northeast. Elsewhere, others have complained of a drop in income due to cutbacks in hours or the loss of a spouse's part-time job. ``What they need is some general help in figuring out how to get by on the income they have,'' Badders said. Sindlinger's latest ``household liquidity'' survey shows more families are reporting less cash on hand after bills are paid. As of late October, more than half those polled in 38 states reported less liquidity and felt they were in a recession. In July it was 28 states. ``For the last three or four months, eight out of 10 (households) are telling us income is down because their fixed costs are up - insurance, medical cotate taxes,'' Sindlinger said. ``And what does the federalsts, local and s government do? It raises taxes. We're setting ourselves up for a depression that is parallel to the 1930s. I know; I've lived through it,' said the 83-year-old forecaster whose business was started with help from President Herbert Hoover. So far, there appear to be few changes in Americans' bill-paying patterns. Delinquencies of outstanding installment loans, such as credit cards and auto loans, have held steady over the past few months at around 2.5 percent, saysov. 4

For release Sunday, Nov 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Tips for Belt-Tighteners in an Unofficial Recession
With BC-Unofficial Recession Revisited
DOC.TEXT: Tough times call for tough measures in household financial planning. Here are some basic suggestions from a few of the experts: -Draw up a budget, listing all monthly income and expenses. Stick with it. -Put aside emergency cash to cover anywhere from three months' to a year's expenses. The amount will depend partly on factors like job security. Job counseling centers say it takes an out-of-work person at least a month to find another job for each $10,000 he or she might have been been earning. -Keep emergencymoney in a safe, easily accessible account like a money market fund, short-term certificates of deposit or Treasury bills. -Should a layoff occur review all options concerning severance pay. An average worker receives a week's pay for each year employed at a company, either in a lump sum or periodic payments. Whether you receive it all at once or over time depends on when a layoff occurs and the company's financial health. If it's just before year end, it might be better to take the money in separate payments because severance is taxable in the year it's received. If the employer is shaky, it could be best to take the lump sum, says Steve Weinstein, tax manager for the Arthur Andersen & Co. accounting firm. But he says that option can terminate any obligation of the employer to continue paying benefits such as health insurance. -Review all borrowing options. Can you get an interest-free loan from a relative? A home-equity line of credit? You can ``borrow'' from your Individual Retirement Account without penalty provided you return the money within 60 days, says Weinstein. But it's wise to avoid credit card cash advances, which usually carry hefty rates of interest, some near 20 percent. -Lower debt. It may be more beneficial to reduce your outstanding credit card balance than keep money in a 6 percent savings account. -Get help if you can't pay your bills. The nonprofit National Foundation for Consumer Credit will work out a payback plan with your creditors for a nominal fee, and in some cases, free of charge. It has 500 offices throughout the country. Call 1-800-388-CCCS to find one close to you. -Be honest with your creditors. In many cases, if you're a month or two behind in your mortgage payments, the mortgage holder will try to work out some type of temporary, revised payment plan. ``There's no way lenders can help any if you don't communicate with them,'' said Ronnie J. Wynn, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association. -Review your investment mix and goals. Set some money aside - no matter how little - for things like your children's college education, home improvements, or retirement. ``You can't do effective asset building as an afterthought,'' says Weinstein.

DOC.HEAD: Slumping Economy is Key Election Issue in Recession-Struck Northeast
DOC.TEXT: As Northeastern voters prepare to go to the polls on Tuesday, their mood can best be described as anger - at an enveloping recession, at record taxes and billion-dollar budget deficits, and at incumbents. ``The three biggest issues are the economy, the economy and the economy,'' said Thomas Ferguson, a political science professor at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. ``You're looking at declining real estate values. And you've got a lot of people losing their jobs.'' In Massachusetts and in three Maryland counties, residents will vote on tax-busting referendums. Incumbents in some hard-hit states are running for their political lives - and some quit rather than face the voters' wrath. Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts rode his state's prosperity to the Democratic presidential nomination. But when he lost, and Massachusetts went into a tailspin, he raised taxes and said he would not run for re-election. Democratic Govs. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut and Madeleine Kunin of Vermont also raised taxes and bowed out of the primaries. Still, Republican candidates seized on their unpopularity, accusing them of budget mismanagement and big spending. Their Democratic replacements tried to disassociate themselves from the incumbents they dubbed as political insiders. Two incumbent Republican governors, John R. McKernan of Maine and Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island, ran for re-election and faced tough challenges. The ramaining four incumbent governors who are up for re-election seem safe. Govs. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania and Willaim D. Schaefer of Maryland, both Democrats, held the line on taxes and both states declared budget surpluses for the fiscal year ended June 30. New Hampshire has no income or general sales tax and Republican Gov. Judd Gregg opposed both. Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York appears assured of winning a third, four-year term despite a record $1.8 billion tax increase; a state credit rating that is the third worst in the nation; and a recent poll that found that 56 percent believed New York was headed in the wrong direction. He faces a weak, campaign-bungling opponent, Pierre Rinfret, an economist and political novice who was chosen when no more prominent politician agreed to run. And Cuomo has been able to stay in front of the issues. ``He anticipated the economic downturn and began to address it last January, talking about how the problems in New York were of a national scope starting from Washington,'' said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. ``He was able to deflect a lot of tension otherwise laid at his doorstep by talking about national political leadership.'' The only question is whether Cuomo can reach or top his record 65 percent of the vote he received in 1986, a boost for a possible run for the presidency. The tightest races appear to be in Massachusetts, Maine and Rhode Island. In Massachusetts, Democrat John Silber, on leave as president of Boston University, and Republican William Weld, a former assistant U.S. attorney general, both cmpaigned as outsiders who would return the state's economy to good health. Both defeated their party's endorsed candidate in the primary. Silber opposes ``Question 3,'' a referendum that would roll back taxes and some fees to their 1988 level. Weld supports it. Backers say Massachusetts residents already pay the sixth highest taxes in the country and that during the last seven years the Dukakis Administration has increased spending from nearly $7 billion to more than $13 billion. If the referendum is approved, opponents say, it would roll back $1 billion already collected and spent and cost Massachusetts $6 billion over three years, forcing cutbacks in education, programs for the elderly and other services. Referendums in Montgomery, Anne Arundel and Baltimore counties in Maryland would limit annual increases in property taxes to as low as 2 percent a year or would peg them to the previous year's inflation rate. Montgomery County, one of the wealthiest in the nation, is a suburb of Washington. In Maine, U.S. Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, a Democrat, is trying to unseat the Republican incumbent McKernan. Brennan charged that McKernan failed to move quickly enough to counter the faltering economy. Brennan served two four-year terms as governor before changing offices with McKernan in 1987. Rhode Island's DiPrete is in danger of losing the governor's office to Democrat Bruce G. Sundlun, a millionaire businessman who is trying to unseat him for the third time. DiPrete reversed himself on a pledge of no new taxes. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., former three-term Republican U.S. senator who is running as an independent for the Connecticut governor's seat, is favored to break the Democratic Party's two-decade hold on the office. In Vermont, Republican Richard Snelling, Gov. Kunin's predecessor, is the favorite to succeed her. The only major races in New Jersey and Delaware are for the U.S. Senate. The Democratic incumbents, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, often mentioned as a presidential candidate, and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, are expected to win re-election by wide margins. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - George Esper is the AP's Northeast Regional Reporter, based in Boston.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Nov 4

For release Sunday, Nov 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: A Decade of Republican Advances Could Turn in the South and Southwest
DOC.TEXT: After a decade of gains in the traditionally Democratic South and Southwest, Republicans are in danger of losing some of their most prized possessions Tuesday, including four governorships and conservative flag-carrier Jesse Helms' U.S. Senate seat. Texas and Alabama have had only one Republican governor since Reconstruction; Florida and Oklahoma only two. Yet the GOP is embroiled in neck-and-neck, if not cutthroat, races to retain those offices. Add in Helms, who some polls show trailing Harvey Gantt, the first black North Carolinian to win his party's nomination for the U.S. Senate, and Tuesday could yield a southern shift back to the Democrats. ``If the Democrats are able to win, then what had been very steady Republican gains over the last 10 years may be held in check, and that's a very dramatic thing,'' said Bob Joffee of Mason-Dixon Opinion Research, a non-partisan polling firm. In Florida and Alabama, incumbent Republican governors Bob Martinez and Guy Hunt are running no better than even in some polls. Martinez trailed former Sen. Lawton Chiles early on, and Hunt, the first Republican governor in Alabama since 1874, appears to have lost an early lead to Democrat Paul Hubbert, who built the state teachers' union into a powerful political lobby. In Texas and Oklahoma, states with retiring Republican governors, the races have been particularly nasty. Texas Republican businessman Clayton Williams appears to have lost his lead after refusing to shake hands with Democrat state Treasurer Ann Richards. Oklahoma Democrat David Walters is slugging out a political brawl with Republican Bill Price. Walters has accused Price of oil-price gouging. Price denied that allegation and filed a libel suit against Walters. In Georgia, the Democrats appear likely to retain the governor's mansion, with Lt. Gov. Zell Miller, who beat out Andrew Young in the primary, favored over state House GOP leader Johnny Isakson. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton is expected to have a easy win over Republican challenger Sheffield Nelson, a former natural gas company executive, as is South Carolina Gov. Carroll Campbell, who faces black state Sen. Theo Mitchell. Mitchell's campaign has been in disarray and Campbell, who is white, has picked up endorsements from blacks. In Senate races, four Democratic incumbents in the region are favored for easy re-election victories. Alabama's Howell Heflin faces Republican state Sen. Bill Cabaniss, Oklahoma's David Boren has a commanding lead over the GOP's Stephen Jones, Tennessee's Al Gore meets Republican economist William Hawkins, and West Virginia's John Rockefeller is heavily favored over Republican attorney John Yoder. Two Republicans in the Senate are also expected to win re-election easily. Kentucky's Mitch McConnell is being challenged by Judge Harvey Sloane and Texas' Phil Gramm faces Democratic state Sen. Hugh Parmer. Four senators are running unopposed: Arkansas' David Pryor, Georgia's Sam Nunn, Mississippi's Thad Cochran, South Carolina's Strom Thurmond and Virginia's Sen. John Warner. Arkansas' David Pryor faces only write-in opposition. Helms has been low-key through his campaign, keeping public appearances to a minimum and holding back on the ``attack'' television ads that have been his trademark. The three-term Republican told reporters at one point he was ``trying to be restrained.'' ``I just wonder whether there's something about having Harvey Gantt running that may be causing them problems,'' said Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Polls show Helms and Gantt virtually deadlocked at about 45 percent of the vote each, with about 10 percent undecided. That's standard for a Helms race, experts say. Some slippage in a black candidate's support could be expected when voters actually go to the polls, they add. Ethics has been the issue at which candidates have hammered away, especially in Texas and Florida. Chiles, who retired at the end of his third U.S. Senate term in January 1989 as one of Florida's most respected politicians, has waged an attack on big-money politics, and has imposed a $100 limit on contributions. He has raised $4 million, against Martinez' $10.2 million. In Texas, Ms. Richards, best-known nationally for her biting keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, has accused Williams of financial misdeeds with his companies. Williams has raised Ms. Richards past abuse of alcohol, and questioned whether she used drugs. Blacks in the South will add to gains in the region following Virginia Gov. Doug Wilder's election. Louisiana will elect its first black congressman since Reconstruction. Two black Democratic lawyers are campaigning for retiring Louisiana Rep. Lindy Boggs' seat, the only black majority district now represented by a white. Marc Morial, son of the late New Orleans Mayor Dutch Morial, faces state Sen. William Jefferson. In the nation's capital, residents will elect a new mayor to succeed Marion Barry who is stepping down after being convicted of misdemeanor cocaine possession. Democrat Sharon Pratt Dixon is expected to defeat Republican Maurice Turner, in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans 9-1. Barry is seeking one of the two at-large City Council positions. As the district's efforts to gain statehood continue, Jesse Jackson is running for one of the two ``shadow'' senator positions. Those slots were created by the district to lobby Congress. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Scott McCartney is the AP's Southwest Regional Reporter, based in Dallas.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Nov 4

For release Sunday, Nov. 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Taxes Spell Trouble in Key Gubernatorial Races in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Taxes loom like storm clouds over the prairie in key elections Tuesday in the Midwest, threatening two governors scrambling for their jobs and a third candidate bidding for his first term. In a political turnabout, Republican Govs. Kay Orr of Nebraska and Mike Hayden of Kansas, both first-termers, have been cast by their Democratic rivals as big spenders, responsible for raising income or property taxes. And in Illinois, Democrat Neil Hartigan has appointed himself the penny-pinching conservative, while branding GOP opponent Jim Edgar the tax-promoting liberal. ``In this year, the candidate who grabs the tax issue first gets the benefit out of it,'' said Jim Nowlan, a public policy professor at Knox College in Galesburg, Ill. ``People are responding to the anti-tax rhetoric because of this concern that spending more won't change anything,'' he added. ``There's a very sour mood toward government and politicians on the part of the public.'' The impact of such sentiments will be realized Tuesday as nine Midwest governors - seven incumbents are seeking re-election - are chosen and eight U.S. senators bid for new terms. The Kansas gubernatorial and Illinois Senate challengers hope to make the record books as the first women in those jobs. Iowa's Senate race already is historic - the $11-million campaign is the most expensive ever. Though hot-button issues such as abortion have been debated, the dominance of the anti-tax mood reflects wider economic concerns in a region still vulnerable, despite its recovery from the '80s farm crisis and manufacturing decline. In September, for example, Michigan and Illinois posted 7.2 percent jobless rates, highest among 11 major states. And rising oil prices and the Persian Gulf crisis have escalated talk of recession. ``The Midwest is particularly sensitive to dislocation in the economy,'' said David Axelrod, a Chicago-based political consultant. ``We were the first ones in the recession in the early '80s and the last ones out. When there's economic turmoil, it tends to favor challengers,'' he added, citing the GOP in Ohio and Democrats in Illinois. In those states, two governors who've had presidential hankerings leave office: Illinois' Republican James Thompson retires after a record 14 years; Ohio's Richard Celeste, a Democrat, is legally barred from a third consecutive term. Nationally, the GOP regards Ohio as one of its best opportunities to grab a Democratic gubernatorial seat. State Attorney General Anthony Celebrezze Jr. has emphasized populist themes; Republican George Voinovich, a former Cleveland mayor, claims credit for his city's fiscal revival. In Illinois, taxes have seized the spotlight. Edgar, secretary of state, favors making permanent a two-year, 20 percent income tax increase. Hartigan, state attorney general, opposes it. In Kansas, Democratic State Treasurer Joan Finney blames Hayden for high property taxes resulting from statewide reappraisal and implementation of a classification system completed in 1989. Hayden counters by claiming Mrs. Finney doesn't know anything about state government. The race is a Hobson's choice with both registering ``mammoth negatives'' in polls, said Burdett Loomis, a University of Kansas political science professor. ``You've got a governor presiding over a huge property tax increase, who's not especially popular,'' he said. ``You've got this woman who's not perceived as especially competent, maybe even dangerous, in not being up to the job.'' Abortion also is an issue. Mrs. Finney opposes it, Hayden is pro-choice. In Nebraska, Mrs. Orr, the state's first woman governor, has been criticized by opponent Democrat Ben Nelson, an attorney, for her 1987 endorsement of an overhaul of the state's income tax system. She initially denied it caused increases, but now says steps have been taken to remedy the situation. In Minnesota, Gov. Rudy Perpich, once considered vulnerable, has been on the sidelines watching the tumult in the GOP Party created by the 11th-hour withdrawal of challenger Jon Grunseth, who was accused of marital infidelity and swimming nude with teen-age girls. State auditor Arne Carlson, who had launched a 11th-hour write-in campaign, replaced Grunseth on the ballot. Minnesota GOP Sen. Rudy Boschwitz says the Republican turmoil has overlapped into his race against college professor Paul Wellstone, who has surged dramatically in the polls in recent weeks. In Iowa, two Capitol Hill pros are clashing in the Senate race: Rep. Tom Tauke vs. incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin. Tauke calls Harkin a big spender; the senator says his opponent votes against programs that would help Iowa. Tauke opposes abortion, Harkin is pro-choice. In Illinois, a Republican House member also hopes to knock off an incumbent. However, Lynn Martin, initially considered one of the GOP's brightest prospects, has failed to dent Sen. Paul Simon's popularity. In three gubernatorial contests, state lawmakers are challengers: -Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad faces Democrat Don Avenson, state House speaker. -Michigan Gov. James Blanchard is opposed by GOP state Senate Majority Leader John Engler. -Wisconsin Republican Gov. Tommy Thompson is challenged by Assembly Speaker Tom Loftus. And in the Senate: -South Dakota Republican Sen. Larry Pressler faces businessman Ted Muenster. -Indiana's Dan Coats, who inherited Vice President Dan Quayle's seat, is running against Democratic state Rep. Baron Hill. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest Regional Reporter, based in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign '90: The Issues Changed Faster Than the Weather
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 campaign has been a little like the capricious New England weather. If you don't like it, just wait a minute. Less than six months ago, politicians were at fever pitch over a constitutional amendment to ban flag-burning. Reluctant Democrats feared for their patriotic reputations; crusading Republicans smelled blood. It's hard now to recall the passion and acrimony generated by that once blazing concern, and harder still to find traces of it on the campaign trail. Ephemeral, fickle, call the season what you will, but issues came and went almost as quickly as movies of the week - until the campaign came home to roost in voter pocketbooks. ``The only national issue is the economy - taxes, economic leadership and fairness. It's driving the entire electorate,'' said analyst Stuart Rothenberg, publisher of The Political Report. When candidates first hit the campaign trail months ago, recession worries were hypothetical and budget negotiations were a speck on the distant horizon. Emotional ``values'' issues were the political currency of the moment. Some candidates pledged their allegiance to the flag-burning ban. Others stoked the controversy over federally funded obscene art. Big-state gubernatorial candidates waged a spirited competition over who would order the most executions, deny the most paroles, propose the harshest penalties for drug-users. Congress was put on the defensive for voting itself a pay raise and then became enmeshed in the savings and loan scandal. The issues proved potent in a smattering of races, and planted the first seeds of anti-incumbent, rich-vs.-poor sentiment among voters. Abortion also took a brief turn on center stage. But the waters got muddied and the issue lost its fire. Both parties ran candidates with a full range of positions. States, meanwhile, failed to impose the serious restrictions anticipated in the wake of a 1989 Supreme Court decision, and abortion moved to the wings in most races. The spotted owl flew by and prompted intense debate in the Northwest. But the conflict over whether to protect forest habitat for the tiny owl at the expense of logging jobs never broadened into a compelling national issue, and environmental concerns colored only scattered races across the country. Communism fell and the peace dividend arose. Early in the campaign, candidates proposed 50-percent cuts in military spending and argued over whether to use the money saved from the Cold War thaw to expand domestic programs or reduce the deficit. Then came the late-summer Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia. The peace dividend vanished like a mirage in the blinding desert sun; the nation worried about war, incumbents looked like statesmen and other issues temporarily were swept aside. Politicians of both parties rallied behind President Bush's policies, few of them daring to raise questions or reservations. As the standoff dragged on without shooting, the gulf crisis waned as a cutting election issue. Finally, in September, an economic decline and explosive federal budget negotiations combined to produce the potent pocketbook themes that dominated the campaign's final weeks. The battle cry of no new taxes turned into a debate over whose new taxes and voters witnessed a confusing, chaotic struggle over their economic futures. Democrats railed at ``high-flyers'' and the rich who got richer in the 1980s at everyone else's expense. ``Let's go and get it from those who got it,'' Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., declared during floor debate over whether to raise taxes on the wealthy. The ``fairness'' pitch hadn't been particularly successful in the past and Democratic leaders were not making much headway this year from the launchpad of the bipartisan S&L scandal. The theme was largely ineffective until the Democrats received a series of assists from Bush - his reversal on the need for new taxes, his insistence on a capital gains tax cut, his painful public wavering on whether to raise taxes on the rich, his failure to adequately explain his positions. ``Bush can truly take responsibility for whatever happens on Tuesday,'' said University of Virginia political scientist Larry Sabato. ``He created the Democrats' best issue, one that they could never have created for themselves.'' ``The Republicans gave the Democrats the ammunition,'' agreed Rothenberg. Analysts were not surprised that pocketbook issues ended up being pivotal. Democratic pollster Geoff Garin said the earlier ``boomlets'' were brief because ``it's hard to sustain a political debate when there is no debate. Everybody's against drugs. Everybody's against S&L crooks.'' The budget, by contrast, is ``a real live issue that really does raise differences,'' Garin said. Others suggested that some Republicans drew the wrong conclusions from Bush's successful use of patriotism and crime issues two years ago. ``Politicians thought they had learned a lesson from 1988 - the importance of certain symbols, the Republicans pushing identification with them and the Democrats trying not to look weak on them,'' said Rothenberg. But those were better days. ``Symbolic issues only work in times of peace and prosperity,'' said Sabato. ``Whenever the economy weakens, it always takes first place on the campaign agenda.''
