DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia, Thrust Into World It Avoided, Rethinks Policies
DOC.TEXT: No longer sheltered from the world by its checkbook and rigid codes, Saudi Arabia is wielding power in the region, building its defenses and rethinking its basic tenets. Whatever happens with Iraq, knowledgeable Saudis say, there will be change. In a conservative kingdom without revolutionaries, however, most predict a supercharged evolution at best. ``There is bound to be change - economically, politically, socially,'' said a prominent Jiddah businessman. ``With outside pressure, it could take two or three years. Without, maybe five.'' He said he expected freer expression and more criticism in the press; there might be pressure groups, such as professional associations. In the meantime, he added, he did not want to named. Barring an uprising, change depends only on King Fahd and accord among the nearly 5,000 members of the al-Saud family. Saudi Arabia is a private company with little pressure to go public. ``The shock of the crisis will make us think about ourselves,'' said an influential prince who also asked for anonymity. ``I think we have too much power. We need checks and balances.'' He said the crisis has opened the society somewhat, as hundreds of foreign reporters probe matters once kept strictly private. Substantial change is coming, he added, but at Saudi pace. Since the early 1970s, Saudi rulers have kept the outside world beyond the horizon, avoiding political entanglements and buying security with generous grants to Arab states and the Palestine Liberation Organization. They spent heavily on sophisticated weaponry and hired Western defense technicians. Visas were granted sparingly and only with a purpose - for consultants, salesmen, managers, laborers. Moslem pilgrims were welcomed to Mecca and Medina, but then sent home again. After fundamentalist Saudis seized the Holy Mosque at Mecca in 1979 and were dislodged only after days of bloody fighting, the kingdom retreated farther into strict Islamic conservatism. Secure in a microcosm of its own design, Saudi Arabia lavished hundreds of billions of dollars on gleaming new cities, storybook palaces, industrial complexes and luxuries unequaled in the world. ``When Saddam Hussein took Kuwait and headed toward us, we called the army and found no one there,'' said one Saudi official. ``We realized we had better do something fast.'' Western defense contractors said they epect Saudi Arabia to triple its armed forces quickly, adding conventional land weapons to support its high-tech air force. Already, Saudi Arabia is using new muscle in the neighborhood. When Yemen objected to Western troops in the area, the Saudis withdrew special status for nearly 2 million Yemenis in the kingdom. Perhaps as many as 750,000 went home within a month. Similarly, Saudi Arabia abruptly halted aid to Jordan and then cut off its oil supply. ``We learned who our real friends were,'' said Prince Abdullah bin Turki bin Faisal, secretary general of the Royal Commission for Jubail and Yanbu and a widely respected young Saudi. Many Saudis expect the greatest impact to be on the society itself, caught between a strict reading of the 1,400-year-old Koran and the latest texts of the Harvard Business School. An English-language television network offers American sitcoms, but ``Roseanne'' has a prayer intermission. Censors blank out words that might offend, such as underwear, Jews and beer. In one, a character delivered the old line, ``Hum a few bars of it,'' and the word ``bars'' came out. Liquor is banned and selling it is a felony, but favorite brands are available on the black market, with an extra zero behind their normal price. Faced with a threat, Saudi Arabia realized how much it depended on its 4 million Asian, African and Western workers. A third of its nurses went home within days of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``Saudi Arabia will be kinder and gentler toward foreigners,'' said a Filipino business executive. ``But, also, its people will start to question things, not take them at face value.'' Saudis echoed this theme. ``We must be strong because we are strong, not because we have the money to be strong,'' said Nihal al-Omari, a Riyadh journalist. ``Crisis opened us up to a new reality,'' said Mohammed Ishgi of the Jiddah Chamber of Commerce. ``We want to be a nation that the West respects, that can dirty its hands, do the work, and not have to call a Sri Lankan to fix the plumbing.'' He added a proviso heard widely among Saudis, foreign diplomats and Western residents with long experience in the kingdom: ``There will be change, but at our pace. The shah modernized Iran so fast that people got lost. Now they have to go back again.'' When the United States dispatched 200,000 troops to the region, many Saudis expected reverberations from such heresies as pistol-packing women wearing trousers and driving. But most found a greater effect from nearly 200,000 Kuwaitis seeking refuge from an emirate where men voted and women went unveiled. ``I've never seen an American, but I see Kuwaitis,'' said an executive of a bank branch reserved for women. ``They tell their leaders what they think. This is a good idea.'' She said she was shocked after the invasion of Kuwait when some members of the Saudi royal family sought shelter at a palace in Jiddah, protected by a private army. ``It was only for them, not for us,'' she said. ``After that, things become clear.'' No serious opposition challenges the al-Saud family, not only because of strict censorship and rigorous measures against dissidents, but also because Saudi Arabia offers a comfortable life. ``You don't get many bomb-throwers here,'' a senior Western diplomat said. ``It's not that kind of place.'' The last time Saudi Arabia faced a major threat, when Egyptian leader Gamal Abdel Nasser sent troops to Yemen and moved north in the early 1960s, President John F. Kennedy sent help but also demanded reforms. As a result, Saudi Arabia abolished slavery in 1962 and introduced education for women. This time, U.S. officials said privately, such pressure is not likely. How the kingdom evolves depends largely on events, Saudi and foreign analysts say. Investment has stalled and billions of dollars have been transferred elsewhere. At the same time, oil production rose toward 8 million barrels a day at windfall prices. Under most scenarios, the economy is unlikely to change drastically. More in doubt, the analysts say, is how King Fahd and his brothers will react to the political and social lessons. There already is stiff religious resistance to U.S. troops, called ``the children of Satan'' by some, guarding holy soil. ``A lasting American presence would drastically change the way of life here,'' said Thierry Mauger, a French author and veteran Saudi observer. The most radical proposals suggest an elected consultative assembly, such as the one Kuwait had before it was suspended under emergency conditions in 1986. King Fahd has hinted of a consultative body, and chambers were built in Riyadh for that purpose, but nothing has materialized. A leading Jiddah journalist said the royal family will provoke serious discontent if it does not allow greater press freedom, lobby groups and other means of airing public opinion. ``Major change is inevitable, there is no doubt about that,'' observed an intellectual who also directs a major Saudi company. ``If the rulers are smart, they will stay ahead of it.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Nov. 4

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy grew at a faster-than-expected 1.8 percent rate in the third quarter, the government said. But the report failed to dissuade many analysts who believe the economy is entering a recession. The Commerce Department report Tuesday on the gross national product showed that consumers buying cars and other items had continued to drive the longest peacetime economic expansion in U.S. history through September. Whether the expansion reaches its eighth anniversary in November was a matter of debate. Also Tuesday, the government said sales of new homes tumbled 6 percent in September to the lowest level in nearly eight years. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Gasoline prices showed no increase Tuesday from the previous week, the first time since Sept. 18 that they failed to go up, the American Automobile Association said. The nationwide average price for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded stood at $1.38 per gallon, the same as the Oct. 23 figure, AAA said in its weekly survey. Also Tuesday, oil prices slid back in very sluggish trading. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A major credit-rating agency downgraded slightly its opinion of the debt of Dow Jones & Co. Inc., citing lower ad revenue at the company's publications, including The Wall Street Journal, and lower revenue from its electronic information services. Moody's Investors Service Inc. Tuesday downgraded about $200 million of Dow Jones' long-term debt from Aa3 to Aa2. The numbers, from 1 to 3, indicate gradations within the Aa category, which Moody's uses to indicate high-grade investment bonds. --- NEW YORK (AP) - International Business Machines Corp. unveiled several new high-end personal computers and workstations that indicate the computer giant intends to keep its machines in the performance lead. IBM also Tuesday announced a new version of its operating system for personal computers, which could intensify IBM's tussle with software giant Microsoft Corp. over which system will take the lead. ---

Losses in normally profitable overseas operations contributed largely to a 78.7 percent drop in Ford Motor Co.'s third-quarter earnings. The decline at the No. 2 automaker, reported Tuesday, was much steeper than Wall Street analysts had expected. Also Tuesday, General Motors Corp.'s financing, computer services, and defense and electronics subsidiaries said that their third-quarter profits rose by a combined 17.3 percent over the same period last year. In other Detroit news, the United Auto Workers and Chrysler Corp. reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract, matching an industry pattern the company repeatedly had said it couldn't afford. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - About 330,000 farmers participating in the long-term Conservation Reserve Program soon will be getting $1.6 billion in rental payments for taking cropland from production, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. The payments, announced Tuesday and to begin immediately, are for the 1991 fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Yeutter said the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service will notify county offices to begin payments immediately ``without any further delay.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Michael Milken's lawyers say the government failed to prove charges aired at a special hearing that the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond financier was a ``master criminal.'' In written arguments Tuesday after eight days of testimony, the defense once again denied charges beyond those Milken admitted in his April guilty plea to six felony counts. The defense also said a government witness lied during the hearing, and it attacked arguments that Milken alone had the power to order corrupt activity at Drexel. --- CHICAGO (AP) - United Airlines said it will raise fares on most domestic flights by 5.8 percent on Halloween, joining other major carriers in a price increase prompted by a jump in fuel prices. United spokeswoman Sara Dornacker said Tuesday the carrier was boosting prices to match the fares of other airlines that announced increases earlier. The industry-wide fare increase on domestic routes takes effect Wednesday. Also Tuesday, America West Airlines said it will freeze hiring and eliminate some flights after reporting a $22 million loss for the third quarter of 1990. --- PITTSBURGH (AP) - USX Corp.'s steel operations will become a separate company under a plan approved by the energy and steel giant's board of directors. USX Tuesday also reported its third-quarter earnings dropped 6.8 percent from a year earlier, with gains in the energy segment but a 26 percent income drop from the steel division. ---

The stock market turned in a mixed performance as some late buying sent blue chips higher but the broader market was mired in Wall Street's economic doldrums. The Dow Jones industrial average, which reversed course several times during the day, Tuesday ended up 17.82 at 2,448.02. Bonds rose, strengthened by news of weaker oil prices and a better-than-expected auction of new U.S. Treasury debt. The dollar finished higher in Europe following a better-than-expected report on the U.S. economy, but the advance ran out of steam in domestic dealings. Gold prices were up sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Aging Founder More Active In Restructured Hewlett-Packard
DOC.TEXT: David Packard, one of the patriarchs of Silicon Valley, is more visible these days at the computer giant he helped build as the firm copes with dramatic corporate changes. Neither Packard, 78, nor William Hewlett, 77, both multibillionaires, are returning to day-to-day management of Hewlett-Packard Co. But Packard, still chairman, and Hewlett, retired director and former president, participated in an analysis of the company's recent woes that led to a shakeup at the highest levels earlier this month. Chief Executive Officer John A. Young now shares top decision-making powers with chief operating officer Dean Morton. Several vice presidents - notably Lewis Platt, Richard Hackborn and Bill Terry - were given more authority and are considered as successor to Young in the next few years. Packard is careful not to suggest that he's taking over command again or undermining Young in any way. ``He's going to be managing the company and he has Bill's and my complete support on what he's plans to do,'' said Packard. But the fact that Packard is getting more involved is an indication of the company's concern about its direction. ``Packard has been more visible and more involved in consulting with John on changes in the company's management structure and its organization,'' said company spokesman Roy Verley. ``What is significant about this change is we've attempted to set ourselves up a bit for ultimate succession of management in the next few years.'' Analysts say the change in Young's duties obviously made him weaker and cast some doubt on the company's leadership. ``My opinion is Young didn't do that on his own volition. He got pressure from his board to create that office and bring Morton in,'' said John B. Jones of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. But Packard looks at it in a more benign way, comparing Young to a star quarterback and saying ``Bill Hewlett and I are going to be coaching him from the sidelines. We're not going to be calling the plays, but we are going to give him whatever help and coaching he needs.'' Hewlett-Packard ends its fiscal year today on Halloween, but unless it comes up with a quick trick it's not likely to be treated any better on Wall Street. The stock price has dropped during the past year, from a high of 50] to a close Tuesday of 26|. In the first nine months the company posted revenues of $9.6 billion, up from $8.5 billion in 1989, but earnings during the period fell to $537 million from $583 million. Analysts anticipate Hewlett-Packard's year-end numbers, when released in two weeks, will show similar growth in revenues to about $13.2 billion, and a further drop in earnings. ``Unless they produce some surprises, the investment community will be very critical of them,'' said Jones. Packard said he is more concerned about making sure that his company's ``corporate values are right and that our business direction is sound.'' The company is looking to strengthen itself for the long run, he said, and isn't worried about quarterly profits or the current stock price. ``What Packard is signaling is that they have not made analysts happy for some time, which is why the stock is sitting at a buck or two above book value,'' Jones said. Historically, Hewlett-Packard is not a company that hacks expenses to please investors. Rather, the company believes in building morale and camaraderie for the long-term. Its benevolent attitude toward employees and customers - dubbed ``the H-P Way'' - has made it a model for high-tech companies in Silicon Valley for half a century. That attitude, which some disgruntled employees say was beginning to wither, is evident in the company's effort to pare down from a peak of 95,000 workers in 1989 after the purchase of Apollo, a workstation maker. Current employment is 92,000 worldwide, including more than 20,000 in the San Francisco Bay area and 37,000 overseas. ``The cuts are gradual and continuing,'' said Verley. Rather than firing workers, the company is trimming through attrition, hiring controls and a workforce rebalancing program that allows workers to find other jobs in the company. Perhaps as significant as the sharing of power between Young and Morton, is the streamlining of the organization below them. The new system is more centralized and allows, for example, all the computer systems businesses and sales forces to report to one individual, Platt, who has responsibility for profits and losses. Hackborn, likewise, is in charge of peripherals, and Terry is in charge of measurement systems. Those three areas comprise the bulk of Hewlett-Packard's business. Platt has the largest revenue sector - nearly 50 percent of the company's total - with minicomputers, workstations, service and computer systems software.

DOC.HEAD: USX Makes Steel Division Separate Company
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp.'s decision to make its steel operations a separate company came as no surprise to many analysts, who expect the energy and steel giant to sell its metals business eventually. ``Someday you're going to see this company in two major pieces, two separate entities,'' said Greg Drahuschak, a steel analyst with Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh. ``It's the only way I can ever see that the shareholder is going to get the benefits of the two businesses.'' USX said its board of directors voted Tuesday to transfer the business carried out by the USS steel division to a wholly owned subsidiary. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said the move ``will provide the flexibility for any steel restructuring undertaken by the company.'' USX also reported its third-quarter earnings dropped 6.8 percent from a year earlier, with gains in the energy segment but a 26 percent income drop from the steel division. USX spokesman William L. Keslar said the move to separate the steel division was not prompted by takeover strategist Carl Icahn's proposal to spin off at least 80 percent of the steel business in the form of a dividend to shareholders. The proposal by Icahn, USX's largest shareholder with a 13.3 percent stake, was rejected by other shareholders May 7. Icahn considers steel a drain on USX's Marathon Oil Co. and Texas Oil and Gas Corp. Keslar said the board's vote ``simply puts USS on the same footing as Marathon, making it a subsidiary.'' ``Somewhere down the road if you want to spin it off, it's certainly easier to do it as a subsidiary than as a part of the company,'' he said. ``It's simply providing the means to have that flexibility.'' Icahn said in a telephone interview from his Mount Kisco, N.Y., office that the change is ``a step in the right direction, but they have to take a lot more steps to separate the two companies.'' ``So far, it's lip service to what has to be done,'' he said. ``This does not really help to reflect the values of the stock.'' Charles Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York, said he expects USX to try to sell a small part of the company, perhaps 20 percent, in a public offering by the end of the year. ``That will establish what the company is worth,'' he said. ``They can sell a small piece now and sell the rest later on.'' Andrew V. ``Lefty'' Palm, chairman of the United Steelworkers of America's chief negotiating committee, said the steel division's new status raises questions that will be addressed in contract talks. ``Essentially, we're not supportive of the idea of splitting up USX,'' said USW President L. Lynn Williams. ``We think the long-term best interests of our members are best served by the steel division remaining a part of USX and being provided the basic strength of an energy company.'' The union is negotiating a new contract for 18,000 union members employed by USX in seven states. The two sides have set a Nov. 10 target date for a new pact. Earnings for the 1990 third quarter totaled $163 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with $175 million, or 62 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Earnings per share increased mainly because of a significant reduction in preferred stock outstanding, USX said. Quarterly revenues totaled $5.11 billion compared with $4.42 billion, up about 16 percent. In the company's energy division, operating income increased 47 percent to $278 million on sales of $3.7 billion, compared with $189 million on sales of $3 billion in the year-ago period. The steel segment reported operating income fell nearly 26 percent to $63 million on sales of $1.3 billion, from $85 million on sales of $1.3 billion in the third quarter of 1989. Corry said the latest results from operations actually outpaced the previous third quarter, which included $98 million in profits from asset sales and $179 million in favorable effects of special items. The 1990 third quarter included $5 million in pretax profits from asset sales.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Earnings Show Lack of Gouging, Industry Group Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The petroleum industry as a whole did not reap a third-quarter windfall from the Persian Gulf crisis, a leading trade group said in a defense of Big Oil against charges of profiteering. ``The third-quarter earnings statements released by several oil companies show that oil companies have not gouged the public,'' American Petroleum Institute President Charles J. DiBona said at a press briefing Tuesday. DiBona said total operating income was unchanged from the third quarter of 1989 and below the same period in 1988, based on reports from 18 top U.S. petroleum companies. Industry earnings were actually something of a mix, ranging from double- and triple-digit increases in profits at some companies to double-digit decreases at others. Amerada Hess Corp., for example, reported a 440.5 percent increase in earnings, based largely on profits from successful oil futures trading. ``It shows they were able to judge the future better than other people,'' DiBona said. In response to the API report, some industry foes still contended the companies were taking advantage of the Gulf crisis, which began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``It's wrong for them to say they're not doing quite well,'' said Edwin S. Rothschild, energy policy director for Citizen Action, a consumers group in Washington. ``They are making lots of money while people are hurting.'' While income from operations was unchanged, total net income for the 18 companies cited by DiBona showed an increase of 16.5 percent for the quarter, according to API's figures. Net income includes special one-time items, such as Amerada Hess's gains in the futures market. As analysts had predicted, the production branches of big oil companies - the so-called ``upstream'' end of the business - made plenty of extra money as oil prices shot up during the crisis. But the refining and marketing divisions - the ``downstream'' end - generally did not do as well. They had to shell out higher prices for the crude oil they imported. In addition, DiBona said, oil profits have been kept down as the companies refrained from passing along all of the higher crude costs in retail prices for gasoline and home heating oil. Christopher Dyson of the Ralph Nader consumer group, Buyers Up, said he believes oil companies were trying to conceal how well they're doing. ``There's a lot of little accounting tricks which oil companies can do with their profit figures,'' Dyson said. ``That tends to make them look less dramatic than they are.'' Dyson declined to offer specifics, but said, for example, that oil companies can try to hide their profits by putting large sums into funds that will be used for eventual environmental cleanups at drilling sites. Industry analysts have said oil companies do this, but they point out it is an accepted accounting technique that shows up in public statements from the corporations. Dyson also found fault with API's use of industrywide statistics. ``I would argue first of all that there were some companies that did very well,'' he said. ``It's nice the oil companies broke even, because a lot of other industries, such as the airline industry, are losing billions of dollars because of this crisis.'' Citizen Action acknowledged that oil companies showed restraint in pricing shortly after the invasion, so it has backed off on its allegations of price-gouging, at least for now. Among the big oil companies that showed higher net income in the third quarter were Amoco Corp., up 57.7 percent; Atlantic Richfield Co., up 21.9 percent; Occidental Petroleum Corp., up 0.9 percent; Phillips Petroleum Co., up 104.6 percent; Texaco Inc., up 24.9 percent; and Unocal Corp., up 53.2 percent. Among those showing lower net income were Chevron Corp., down 3.4 percent; Mobil Corp., down 28.8 percent; Shell Oil Co., down 33.2 percent; and Sun Co., down 70.6 percent. Exxon Corp. reported quarterly earnings that were unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Falls Into Line; UAW Has Contacts at All of Big Three
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp., which said it needed the United Auto Workers to give it relief from labor costs, has a new tentative agreement very similar to contracts at General Motors and Ford. The company and union reached a tentative agreement Tuesday afternoon after 27 straight hours of bargaining. There was no strike and the 63,000 UAW members covered by the agreement worked without a contract for about a half-day. UAW President Owen Bieber bragged at a news conference that the union had reached its goal of bargaining a pattern agreement used at each of the Big Three. ``It's a pattern settlement and a pattern settlement in all respects,'' Bieber said. ``It's a total pattern settlement.'' Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John, the company's main negotiator, agreed the contract was mostly patterned on UAW deals with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. ``The tentative agreement reached today with the UAW contains elements of the pattern, but also some provisions which addresses needs specific to Chrysler,'' he said. Bieber and St. John declined to talk about details of the contract pending a Monday union leaership meeting in Detroit. If it wins approval by the group of local presidents and bargaining council chairs, the contract will be sent out for rank-and-file ratification. It appeared that the union and company agreed to push for a new production schedule at Chrysler's profitable St. Louis II minivan plant, which has about 3,500 employees. Last November, members of UAW Local 110 in St. Louis overwhelmingly rejected a move endorsed by the company and the UAW's leadership to change from a normal two-shift production schedule to one involving three crews, two shifts and a 20-percent production increase. The company said the change would have swollen the plant's employment by 1,000 to 1,300 workers. But union members turned down the proposal saying it could cut out overtime. St. John said also the company and union agreed to continue the ``30-and-out'' retirement program that allows an employee to get retirement benefits after 30 years of service, regardless of age. The company had pressed for pension payments to be held until the worker is 60 years old. ``There are elements in this agreement that are particularly helpful to Chrysler's case,'' St. John said. Bieber and St. John declined to answer questions about health-care provisions, which were seen as a major sticking point in the talks. In the GM-Ford pattern agreement, there is no change in the method of coverage, but the union and the companies agreed to look for ways to cut costs. Chrysler said it spent $684 million on health-care last year. Chrysler has nearly one retiree for every active worker - a higher proportion than GM or Ford. A higher percentage of retirees increases a company's health-care bill. The UAW reached an agreement with GM on Sept. 17. After that contract was ratified, it took just six days for the union and Ford to reach a tentative agreement, which was ratified earlier this month. The union canceled an extension of its Chrysler contract at midnight Monday but told members to report to their jobs as usual Tuesday while bargaining continued. Late Tuesday morning, Bieber and Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca held a 1{-hour private meeting, which broke up about four hours before the tentative agreement was announced. The agreement came a day after Chrysler reported a third-quarter loss of $214 million, mostly from incentive costs and lost production due to the retooling of its minivan plants in St. Louis and Windsor, Ontario. Those are among the company's most profitable factories. Analysts said that despite the loss, Chrysler is in decent financial shape. ``They've got $3 billion in cash,'' said David Healy of investment bankers Barclays de Zoete Wedd in New York City. ``They're not in financial trouble at all, far from it. They will be profitable for the year.''

DOC.HEAD: Editor Of Conde Nast Traveler Named Head Of Adult Trade Imprint
DOC.TEXT: Harold Evans, founding editor in chief of Conde Nast Traveler and a former editor of The Times of London, has been named president and publisher of Random House Adult Trade Books. Random House Inc. said Tuesday that Evans, 61, will be replacing Joni Evans, 48, as publisher of the Adult Trade Books imprint, which publishes general fiction and non-fiction. Ms. Evans, no relation to Harold Evans, will start her own list of books for Random House, said Alberto Vitale, chairman of Random House. Evans also has been named executive vice president of Random House. Ms. Evans also holds that title. William T. Loverd, a Random House spokesman, said the change was a surprise but ``not an upheaval.'' He said 1990 has been one of the most successful years for the Adult Trade Books imprint. Random House publishes more than 100 titles a year including books by such well-known authors as William Styron, James Michener and Norman Mailer. Ms. Evans joined Random House in 1987 with the intention of starting her own imprint, Loverd said. Her new imprint, still to be named, will be housed in a brownstone in midtown Manhattan outside the Random House headquarters. As publisher and president of Random House Adult Trade Books, Harold Evans will have the overall responsibility for the publishing and editorial direction of the imprint, in addition to heading Villard Books and Times Books. Evans was editor of the Sunday Times of London for 14 years starting in 1967 and became editor of The Times of London, the daily, in February of 1981. He resigned that post in March 1982 in a dispute with the owner, Rupert Murdoch. In 1986, Evans joined Conde Nast Publications as founding editor-in-chief of Conde Nast Traveler, which has won praise from media critics for publishing features that were often critical of potential advertisers. Both Random House and Conde Nast are owned by the Newhouse familiy's Advance Publications Inc.

DOC.HEAD: First Brands Takes Itself Off Market
DOC.TEXT: First Brands Corp., citing sagging capital markets and a sluggish economy, has announced it is no longer for sale. The company, which manufacturers Glad bags, Prestone antifreeze and STP car care products, said Tuesday that its major shareholders, First Boston Corp. and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., had discontinued talks with potential buyers. First Brands announced that it was up for sale in June, after investors said they had received several inquiries about the company. Donald DeSantis, vice president and chief financial officer, said the slow economy, coupled with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a declining bond market, hurt acquisition possibilities. ``The combination of all those things just provided a climate that wasn't conducive for selling a business,'' he said. Alfred E. Dudley, First Brands chairman, president and chief executive officer, and 28 other managers launched First Brands in 1986 with an $840 million leveraged buyout from Union Carbide. In three years, First Brands reduced its work force, sold two divisions, boosted sales and cut debt. Between 1987 and 1989, the company went from a $6.98 million loss to a net income of $60.9 million. First Brands had sales of more than $1 billion and earnings of $50 million for the year ended in June. The company employs 3,350 people worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Weyerhaeuser Restructures Management Team
DOC.TEXT: Weyerhaeuser Co. laid the groundwork for the next generation of executive leadership by elevating president John W. ``Jack'' Creighton Jr. to the newly created office of chief executive. Creighton in turn named five men to his executive team to head Weyerhaeuser's various operations, and plans to name a sixth next year. Creighton, 58, is expected to succeed George H. Weyerhaeuser, 64, as chief executive when Weyerhaeuser retires in mid-1991. Weyerhaeuser will stay on as chairman of the board of the timber company. In the meantime, he will share the new office of chief executive with Creighton. The changes, announced Tuesday, will ``bring about an effective leadership transition at the top of Weyerhaeuser Co.,'' the company said. Weyerhaeuser said the new configuration was also set up in part to help bolster the company's financial performance. Creighton's executive team includes executive vice presidents Charles W. Bingham, 57, and John H. Waechter, 62; senior vice president and chief financial officer William C. Stivers, 52; and senior vice presidents Norman E. Johnson, 57, and Steven R. Hill, 43. Two other executives, chief financial officer Robert L. Schuyler, 54, and Frederick R. Fosmire, 64, senior vice president for human resources, technology and engineering, are retiring next year, the company said. Creighton and his executive team will oversee a continuing restructuring in which Weyerhaeuser sells some businesses and reduces the size of others. Last week the company announced it will trim its work force at its Longview pulp and paper operations over the next several years, although it didn't say how many jobs will be cut.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Government Awards Control Data $850 Million Contract
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian government has awarded Control Data Corp. a 10-year, $850 million contract to provide the Canadian armed forces with a global network communications system. Analysts on Tuesday said the contract - the largest in the company's history - is a positive sign for Control Data, which has undergone a major restructuring after record 1989 losses. ``This contract is positive testimony of their capabilities in this field,'' said Frederick Wise, an analyst for Bear Stearns & Co. in New York. Control Data's Canadian subsidiary, Computing Devices Co., competed against eight other companies for the contract. Linda Jadwin, a company spokeswoman, said equipment will not be delivered for two years. The contract will be a break-even deal for the company over the next 12 months, she said, after which it should start generating profits. Jadwin said she did not know how much the company expects to make from the contract. Control Data has eliminated several unprofitable businesses and improved operations in its remaining divisions over the past 15 months. Last week the company reported third-quarter earnings of $8.5 million on revenues of $434.1 million. For the nine months, Control Data earned $26.5 million, or 62 cents a share, on revenues of $1.26 billion. The communications system, called Iris, will replace 1950s-vintage communications equipment still in use by the Canadian forces. Specifics of the development and production contract, which must be signed by the Treasury Board of Canada, will be negotiated over the next 60 days. As part of the deal, Control Data, acting through Computing Devices, will build a factory in Calgary, Alberta. Its cost, which is being negotiated, will be paid by the government as part of the contract. Dick Holm, a spokesman for the government systems division, said the communications system will ``move us into an application area that is new to us and has great growth potential.'' He said Control Data hopes to sell the system to Canadian allies who will want a compatible communications system.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp Eliminating 2,000 Jobs In Corporate Business
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said today that by the end of next year about 2,000 jobs will be eliminated through an ongoing reorganization of its corporate business. The disclosure provides the first indication of the size of layoffs since the company's retrenchment in corporate financing activities began several months ago. Bank profits generally have been battered in recent months by writeoffs related to loans for commercial real estate and by a decline in lending activity for buyouts. Citicorp spokeswoman Anne Luzzatto said the layoffs are mostly middle management and professionals in lending and deal making. She said they were expected to be completed by the end of 1991. The corporate business division, which covers Japan, Europe and North America and Australia, had about 17,000 employees and plans to reduce expenses by more than $250 million annually, she said. The Wall Street Journal was the first to report on the actual number of layoffs today, quoting Michael Callen, the executive in charge of the division, as saying as many as 700 people in North America have left so far, with an additional 400 employees to be notified by year end. Luzzatto said about half of the remaining 900 intended cuts are employees in Asia and Europe. The rest of the 450 cuts will come from businesses targeted for sale by the end of 1991, she said. Some of the largest personnel cutbacks have come in the leveraged loan division, where business is off because of the decline in leveraged corporate buypouts and equipment finance and leasing, Luzzatto said. Other reorganization moves include the consolidation of Citicorp's 18 corporate finance offices in the United States into six primary locations and concentration of commercial real estate activity into nine offices rather than 21 locations, she said. No such personnel reductions are planned for the consumer banking operation, which employs 77,000 people, according to the Journal story. The Journal report also said Citicorp Chairman John Reed is considering strategic alliances with other large global banks. Reed reportedly told the Harvard Business Review in an interview that is to be published soon that strategic alliances under which Citicorp would swap portions of its business with other major banks could help build a stronger capital base.

DOC.NOTE: $adv05
For release Monday, Nov. 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Company Goes Nationwide With New Waste Disposal System
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A Connecticut company says it has just the answer for hospitals looking for a better, cheaper way to dispose of infectious medical waste: Cook the stuff in a giant microwave. Nothing is emitted into the air and the treated waste, which takes up just one-eighth of its original space, can be dumped into an ordinary landfill, says ABB Sanitec Inc. ``It's a brand new solution,'' said David C. Knesel, spokesman for Forsyth Memorial Hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C., which bought a Sanitec unit for $500,000 in February. ABB Sanitec has gained regulatory approval in two states and is seeking the go-ahead in six others for its system, which grinds up and decontaminates infectious medical waste. One of the main attractions of the system for hospitals is its relatively low cost, which is saving Forsyth more than $200,000 a year in waste disposal. So far, Forsyth is the only U.S. hospital using the system, which is subject to a state-by-state review. In addition to North Carolina, the system has been given thumbs up in California and is under consideration in New Jersey, Ohio, New York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Texas, according to ABB Sanitec President John L. Cusack. The ABB Sanitec system has been sold to 10 hospitals and waste disposal companies in France, Germany, Switzerland and Italy since 1986, Cusack said. The system is manufactured in West Germany and sells for $500,000 to $600,000, he said. The company makes the system in two sizes, and can set the unit on wheels so that two or more small hospitals could share it, Cusack said. ABB Sanitec is a unit of Asea Brown Boveri Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of ABB Ltd. of Zurich, Switzerland. The patented system comes in a self-contained, computerized, 20-by-8-foot metal box that looks like a large trash compactor. Waste is dumped into the box, sent through a shredder and zapped for a half-hour with microwaves, leaving nothing but a pile of small garbage pieces that's less harmful than normal kitchen garbage. ``It looks like potpourri when it dries out,'' Forsyth's Knesel said. ``It's colorful, actually. It's got all kinds of different colors and different pieces.'' Microwaving the waste exposes it to high temperatures that destroy microorganisms, said V. James McLarney, director of the division of health facilities management for the American Hospital Association. He said microwaving is an environmentally sound method, but that it is just one of many technologies being developed to dispose of medical waste, including treating the waste with chemicals or radiation and incineration. Since there are not yet national regulations regarding the disposal of medical waste, individual states approve disposal methods, McLarney said. ``To use a new technology requires that the state include that new technology on the list of accepted treatment alternatives,'' he said. The problem of medical waste disposal made headlines in 1988 when needles, syringes and other products washed up on shores in the Northeast. Hospitals facing stringent disposal laws pay up to 50 cents a pound to dispose of their medical waste, according to the AHA. The ABB Sanitec system costs between 7 and 10 cents a pound, Cusack said. Knesel said Forsyth had been spending $270,000 a year to have its infectious medical waste hauled in refrigerated trucks to a special medical waste incinerator. With ABB Sanitec, the cost has dropped to $60,000 a year, he said. ``We figure this unit will probably pay for itself by 1992,'' Knesel said. Some hospitals have considered building their own incinerators to dispose of their waste, but the high costs of adding pollution-control systems and strong public sentiment against incinerators make that option more difficult, he said. Knesel said that was exactly the case with Forsyth, a 926-bed hospital and one of the largest in North Carolina. ``We were planning to build our own incinerator ... and really were disturbed about having to do so,'' he said. ``It's politically impossible in this state to build a medical incinerator ... there are protests everywhere, and we really had better things to do than to deal with an irate public about an incinerator.'' In California, where one Sanitec unit was bought by a waste disposal company, the device was easily approved for statewide use, said Nancy Smith, a health program adviser for the state Department of Health. California officials evaluated the unit for its ability to disinfect medical waste and for harmful emissions, Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Dinar Rate, Political Woes Threaten Economic Reforms
Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: To some Western creditors, Premier Ante Markovic forged an economic miracle by slashing inflation from 2,500 percent to near zero in six months and saving Yugoslavia from bankruptcy. The 65-year-old pragmatist stopped the runaway price spiral, boosted hard currency reserves and pushed foreign debt below $16 billion for the first time in more than a decade. But the gains have proved temporary. Inflation is creeping upward again, and unemployment is rising. Many businessmen complain that Markovic's reforms have gone too far and are disrupting Yugoslavia's transition to capitalism from communism. Markovic's main anti-inflationary tool - the newly convertible dinar currency pegged at seven to one German mark - spells problems for many companies, even those considered closest to Western business practices. The exchange rate, introduced Jan. 1, restored confidence in the Yugoslav currency after it had plunged in value against Western currencies. But companies now say the exchange rate should be 11 or 12 dinars per mark to make their products more competitive. Unemployment, already 17 percent nationwide, could top a quarter of the work force as the reforms take hold. Inflation also has become a problem again. After plummeting from an annual 2,500 percent in 1989 to zero in the second quarter of this year, inflation took a 7 percent jump in September. The annual rate could far surpass the government's 17 percent forecast. Tight credit and a wage freeze helped throttle inflation, but one result is that Yugoslav products have become even more expensive at home than many imported items. ``If I go to the supermarket and cheese from Hungary and Austrian margarine are cheaper - why should I buy Yugoslav?'' asked Alenka Ogrin, a tourist guide from Ljubljana. Western investors have been scared away from Yugoslavia by simmering ethnic and political tensions. More than anything, Markovic now needs social stability to consolidate his reforms. Matija Skof, president of Sloveniales, one of Yugoslavia's largest trading companies, halved profit targets to $10 million this year after sales prospects dwindled at home and abroad. Founded in 1948 to export furniture, Sloveniales deals in everything from household goods to helicopters. But Skof still sees some reasons for optimism. ``We're still notching up a real growth rate of 5 percent on last year's sales of $1.35 billion,'' he said. ``We reorganized as a private company in July and we're running like one - on the profit motive.'' Under Yugoslavia's self-management system, companies are technically owned by their workers. Markovic's reforms are supposed to weed out unprofitable companies buoyed for decades by state subsidies, cheap bank credits and a weak dinar. The debts of many companies are virtually impossible to calculate. Markovic, premier since March 1989, is determined to revitalize the economy by ending wasteful subsidies, but some critics say his measures are too harsh. Political squabbling among Yugoslavia's six republics complicates the issue. Slovenia and Croatia, where center-right parties ousted Communist governments in free elections this year, are pushing for a new loose confederation of sovereign states in a common market. The southern, less-developed republics of Serbia, Bosnia-Hercegovina, Montenegro and Macedonia are still in Communist hands ahead of elections later this year. They tend toward a more centralized federation. Serbian authorities are vetoing reforms they say are against their interests. They have subsidized wheat prices and refused to shut giant loss-makers like Smederevo steel works that employs 16,000 workers. ``There was a dream that Markovic could save Yugoslavia but it's now clear that we need political reorganization before we can talk about economic programs,'' said Danilo Slivnik, domestic editor at Delo, Slovenia's leading daily newspaper. ``Socialism is still entrenched in over half of Yugoslavia - so how can free-market reforms work?'' he asked. Slovenia's Social Planning Institute estimates that 40 mostly large enterprises in Yugoslavia's richest republic will face bankruptcy this year, including showcase ski producer Elan. With only 8 percent of the country's population, Slovenia produces more than 25 percent of Yugoslav exports. In less-developed republics, many more enterprises could go bust. ``Markovic was right to stop inflation with harsh measures, but he should have let up in June and given the economy a breathing space,'' Skof asserted. The federal government says rising exports prove the economy is rebounding. Other observers disagree. ``It's just an illusion,'' asserted one analyst at a bank in Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia. ``Companies are exporting because they have no home market and it's easier to get paid from abroad, even if that means selling at a loss and eating into their capital.''

DOC.HEAD: GM Posts Nearly $2 Billion Loss for Third Quarter with Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 10 new grafs to UPDATE with GM earnings. Picks up 4th graf pvs, Among the ...
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. today reported a $2 billion loss for the third quarter including a one-time charge of $2.1 billion for closing four assembly plants and related expenses. The loss amounts to $3.54 per common share. GM had earned $516.9 million, or 72 cents a share, in the July-September quarter a year earlier. Without the charge, GM's earnings for the latest period stood at $109 million, down 78.9 percent from earnings a year earlier. GM's third-quarter revenue rose 6.9 percent to $30.8 billion from $28.8 billion last year. The $2.1 billion charge includes costs associated with the formal shutting down of four assembly plants the were idled during the past three years. Those car plants are near Kansas City, Mo.; Framingham, Mass.; Pontiac, Mich.; and Atlanta. The company said the charge also contemplates the closing or consolidating of other plants and warehouses during the next three years. The company previously had announced it planned to idle truck assembly plants in Scarborough, Ontario; Lordstown, Ohio; and Pontiac. ``The restructuring is a major element in GM's long-term strategic plan to improve the competitiveness and profitability of its North American operations,'' GM Chairman Robert Stempel said in a statement today. Including the charge, GM said it lost $368.7 million, or $1.20 a share, in the first nine months of the year compared with a profit of $3.52 billion, or $5.32 a share, in the first nine months of 1989. Revenues for the January-September period were $94.8 billion this year, down 0.8 percent from $95.6 billion a year ago. On Tuesday, GM's major subsidiaries reported their third-quarter results. Among the subsidiaries, General Motors Acceptance Corp. reported the largest jump, 24.7 percent. Electronic Data Systems Corp. said its profits rose 17 percent and GM-Hughes Electronics Corp. reported earnings up 7 percent. GMAC said it earned $293 million during the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $235 million for the third quarter of 1989. EDS said it had net income of $128.4 million, or 54 cents a share, for the period, up from $110.9 million, or 46 cents a share, for July-September 1989. Revenues for the quarter rose to $1.53 billion from $1.37 billion in the third quarter of 1989, the company said. GM Hughes Electronics said it had net income of $158.1 million, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter, up from $147.8 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $2.93 billion for the period from $2.58 billion in the third quarter of 1989, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Fine Gives Kodak Third Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co., ordered by a court to pay $909.5 million in damages to Polaroid Corp., said today it suffered a $206 million loss in the third quarter. Kodak said its earnings would have increased 19 percent without the judgment against it. The photographic company said the loss, which translated to 64 cents per share, compared with earnings of $510 million, or 93 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. The U.S. District Court in Boston earlier this month awarded $454.2 million in damages and $455.3 million in interest to Polaroid in a 14-year-old patent infringement suit against Kodak. Both Kodak and Polaroid have appealed the decision, but Kodak decided to take a $909.5 million charge against its third-quarter earnings to cover the costs of the award. ``While no money has yet changed hands, and the litigation has yet to be finally resolve, this charge to earnings is appropriate at this time,'' Kodak Chairman Kay R. Whitmore said in a statement. Without the charge, earnings would have been $358 million, up 19 percent from $300 million a year earlier, Kodak said. Sales increased 5 percent for the quarter to $4.77 billion, compared to $4.54 billion in the same quarter last year. Whitmore said Kodak's strong sales gains in international markets were partly offset by lagging U.S. shipments that reflected the weakening economy in this country. Earnings for the first three quarters of 1990 totaled $377 million, or $1.16 per share, down 36 percent from $589 million, or $1.82 per share, in 1989. Without the Polaroid charge, earnings would have been up 60 percent to $941 million. This third quarter was only the fourth time Kodak has ever taken a loss. The last time was in the fourth quarter of 1989 when Kodak took a charge of $273 million to pay for a restructuring program in which 7,500 jobs were cut and about 20 businesses were sold or consolidated. That restructuring was announced following depressed earnings in the first three quarters of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached After 15 Years in Poisoning Case
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese company has agreed to pay $3.5 million to 41 victims of arsenic poisoning blamed on mining operations in a case first taken to court 15 years ago, officials announced Wednesday. Sumitomo Metal Mining Co. and the plaintiffs accepted the compromise plan recommended by the Supreme Court, according to a court official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Eighteen of the victims are still alive. The rest were represented by family members. Tatsuro Kamata, a spokesman of Sumitomo Metal Mining, said in a statement that the company agreed to pay the amount not as compensation but as a token of sympathy. He said the agreement did not refer to the question of the company's responsibility for the poisoning. The plaintiffs had demanded a total of $16.6 million in compensation, Kamata said. An official of the Environment Agency, also speaking on condition of anonmity, said residents near a mine on the southernmost main island of Kyushu suffered arsenic poisoning from fumes. He said the mine had been burning ore containing arsenic since 1920 to manufacture arsenic acid for agricultural use. Arsenic poisoning damages the nerves, liver, skin and other human organs. Kamata said Sumitomo Metal Mining received mining rights for the Toroku Mine from Nakajima Mining Co. in 1967 as a payment for Nakajima's debts to Sumitomo. But Sumitomo gave up the rights in 1973 without ever engaging in mining or any other operations at the mine, he added. In 1975, 23 victims filed suit, demanding $6 million in compensation from Sumitomo for poisoning. A district court ruled in 1984 that as the owner, the company was responsible for compensation whether it operated the mine or not. It ordered Sumitomo to pay $4.3 million and a high court upheld that ruling in 1988. Another group of 18 filed suit in 1984 and the previous rulings were upheld again in March this year. Nine of those 18 have died.

DOC.HEAD: Say Gulf War Could Triple Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: The price of oil could easily ``explode'' to $100 per barrel if war broke out in the Persian Gulf, a panel of experts told a Senate committee Wednesday. ``There's no limit,'' said John Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. ``It depends on how much panic there is.'' With the Bush administration rattling sabres in Iraq's direction, Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., presiding over a hearing of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, echoed growing concern in Congress about what will happen at the pump if war breaks out. ``The day the war starts prices will explode,'' said Lichtblau, one of several experts on the oil industry to appear before the panel. Oil prices hovering in the $33 per barrel range could easily triple, said Professor Fariborz Ghadar of George Washington University's business school. ``I would not be surprised if oil prices reached $100 per barrel,'' Ghadar said. Translating a crude oil price increase into a higher price at the pump is an inexact science. But some industry experts use a ratio of 12 cents more per gallon for every $5 increase in the price of a barrel of crude. At $100 per barrel, under that formula, gasoline could rise to nearly $3 per gallon. The witnesses told Lieberman that with oil production already at or near capacity, oil consuming states could do little beyond releasing oil reserves onto the market. Tapping oil reserves would have to go beyond the use of the U.S. government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, said Professor M.A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It would have to occur globally. In addition to the strategic reserves there are the oil reserves held by private companies as well as substantial reserves held by Japan and western European nations, witnesses said. The reasons for the sharp price rise, the experts said, would be fear that war would disrupt supply lines combined with the likelihood that a Gulf war would curtail Saudi Arabia's oil-producing capabilities. Conversely, if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein suddenly ends the crisis by withdrawing forces from Kuwait, the price of oil could drop just as suddenly to levels below those that preceded the Aug. 2 invasion Iraqi, witnesses said. ``That range is likely to be reached approximately 48 hours after the crisis is over,'' Lichtblau said. If the stalemate continues it is likely that oil prices will remain about where they are. But they could jump quickly with any disruption of a supply system already straining to meet demand. ``This is a very tight market,'' Ghadar said. ``A pipe blowing up in Nigeria, a fire in Venezuela, some other disruption,'' could be enough to spread panic and push prices higher. In the second of three hearings on the oil industry, Lieberman continued to pursue the question of whether oil companies and oil producing nations are unfairly gouging consumers. ``In the past few months there has been an enormous transfer of wealth from the many oil consuming nations, including the United States, to the few oil producing nations,'' Lieberman said. Saudi Arabia alone would reap a $50 billion windfall if oil averaged $30 per barrel over the course of a year. The answers Lieberman received were not encouraging to consumers. The witnesses said there was little the United States could do to break up the OPEC cartel. In the meantime, the simple laws of supply and demand would govern the price of oil. Witnesses rejected as unworkable, for example, Lieberman's suggestion that Saudi Arabia unilaterally lower the price of its crude in exchange for U.S. military support. The market would quickly absorb the cheap Saudi oil and no other countries would be compelled to lower their prices, Lichtblau said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: he said.
DOC.TEXT: In addition, mortgage applications nationwide have fallen about 20 percent from the peak summer months. Although part of that is seasonal, Wynn blames sluggish economic conditions or prolonged worries about a recession. ``People who may have had an interest in buying a house are just walking away,'' he said. Many are opting to renovate the homes they already have. That has helped builders and carpenters like 50-year-old Gonzalez keep busy as the rate of new commercial and residential building declines. Still, Gonzalez has tightened his belt. ``I don't go out that much. I can't afford it. I can't buy the running shoes I want. I go to Kmart ... seven dollars,'' Gonzalez said. The Northeast is among the hardest hit. Big layoffs on Wall Street and in New England's high-tech corridor have contributed to a plunge in real estate values and sales. That translates into less demand for appliances, furniture and other home incidentals. Even in the Pacific Northwest, one of the economically strongest regions, the rate of home sales and home appreciation has slowed. Wes Lynch, spokesman for the Washington State Association of Realtors, said Seattle area homes that once sold within weeks now languish on the market for up to half a year. ``I suspect a lot of Washingtonians are waiting for the other shoe to drop,'' said Lynch, referring to uncertainties posed by the Persian Gulf ordeal and the new federal budget. Both those situations have helped drive up interest rates, although the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, has signaled its intention to ease credit. Higher rates curtail consumer spending because they make borrowing more expensive. Rates on 30-year conventional mortgages have risen to an average 10.12 percent in October from 9.81 percent four months ago. Some economists argue that part of the sluggishness around the country can be traced to the changing nature of the population. Edward Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said this change is particularly acute among members of the free-spending postwar generation now getting into a more financially conservative middle age. ``Most baby boomers have almost every material good known to mankind. (But) people in their late 30s and early 40s are no longer speculating in real estate and buying expensive foreign cars,'' he said. ``I think they're more selective in their purchases.'' That's true for Mrs. DeLessio, a 29-year-old insurance claims representative on maternity leave. ``We started cutting coupons, watching sales. We wanted to get a new dining room set but we've postponed it until after Christmas. We've been making an effort to save more,'' said Mrs. DeLessio, with annual family income of around $60,000. Ironically, if more consumers behaved like Mrs. Delessio, her husband, Philip, could be out work. He's a 33-year-old sales representative for a leather goods wholesaler who's largely dependent on the health of the nation's retailers. ``When the economy is bad they may not want to buy his products,'' Mrs. DeLessio said. Dillon, who sells medical equipment and earns $175,000 a year before taxes, has swum against the economic tide before. The Rocky Mountain region in which he does business never prospered like the Northeast or West Coast during the '80s. Although conditions have stabilized, he faces new challenges, like filling his car with gasoline without losing money. ``My travel costs have damn near doubled but my commissions haven't,'' the 49-year-old Dillon said, adding that he's doing more business by phone and has dropped marginally profitable clients. At the same time, Dillon said, he's tried to invest more in his company by upgrading the phone and computer systems. ``You've got to stand out among the crowd, especially in times of economic trouble.'' California financial planner and psychologist Felton-Collins agreed: ``This is an ideal time to look at where you stand financially, what your goals are and what steps you can take to improve yourself.'' There are other opportunities as well. ``If you're in a steady profession ... and you don't anticipate this type of a situation would hurt you, now might be the best time in the world to buy some of the things you've been thinking of buying,'' Badders of the National Foundation for Consumer Credit said. ``There are some good buys in homes, probably autos.'' Others see possibilities in the stock market, which also has taken a beating this year. Some of the stocks favored by investment counselors include drug companies and the ``blue chips,'' or big-name issues with the greatest long-term returns. ``Stocks will continue to grow. In the next five to 10 years the Dow (Jones industrial average) will probably hit 5,000,'' said Lenn Width, a retired lumberyard owner from Lynwood, Wash., who belongs to an investment club that has played the stock market for years. Even though Width estimates losing about a quarter of his $500,000 stock portfolio over the past several months, he maintains, ``There are thousands of bargains. If you got any money this is the time to be investing.''
