DOC.HEAD: Toys R Us Reports Sluggish Sales After Iraqi Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Toys R Us Inc. reported sluggish third-quarter sales Wednesday, an indication that toy stores suffered the same drop-off in business as other retailers because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Toys R Us said sales from stores open at least a year rose 1.6 percent in the quarter ended Oct. 28, while overall sales were up 14.8 percent. Retail industry analysts believe sales from stores open a year or more give a more accurate picture of a retailer's performance. The company said its results, which it attributed to the difficult retail environment, were down from the first half of the year. Retail sales - which were already shaky because of a weakening economy - slowed markedly after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Many economists say the Middle East crisis has undermined consumers' sense of security, and it has also left them with less money to spend on extras like toys because of rising energy prices. Retailers are expected to have a difficult Christmas season because consumers are certain to spend more cautiously this year than in previous holiday seasons. Toy retailers are likely to fare somewhat better than apparel or general retailers as parents may forgo gifts for adults in favor of spending more on children. However, the Toys R Us sales figures indicate that toy retailers may not be immune from the uncertainties expected to plague the overall industry this year. The Christmas season is crucial to all retailers, because they generally make half their annual sales and earnings at that time. Many retailers are keeping their inventories low and slashing their expenses in hopes of holding on to their profits.

DOC.HEAD: Pressure Easing on Oil Supplies, Agency Says
With AM-War-Oil Prices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The International Energy Agency reported Wednesday that threats of oil shortages due to the Persian Gulf crisis are easing as OPEC countries boost output and industrial nations cut demand. In a report made public as delegates from the organization met privately, the IEA predicted the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will produce 22.6 million barrels of oil per day in the last quarter of 1990. This would be a slight increase over 21.9 million barrels in the third quarter. IEA Chairman Ulrich Engelmann told reporters after the meeting that the situation is ``somewhat easier than anticipated.'' Nonetheless, he said, ``if something happens, there isn't any flexibility in the supply situation.'' Engelmann described the meeting as routine and said the delegates devoted most of their time to planning next year's budget. The report said total fourth-quarter world oil supplies among nations outside the former communist bloc should total 53.4 million barrels per day, up 400,000 barrels from the third quarter. Consumption in the 21 industrial countries making up the IEA, founded in 1973to plan strategy for energy crises, should fall by 800,000 barrels per day in the fourth quarter, it said. The latest estimates suggest a better balance in oil supply and demand than the IEA thought at its last meeting in September, according to the report. The reasons are falling demand, a moderate third-quarter buildup of OPEC stocks, and increased output by OPEC members to make up for the 4.5 million barrels per day lost to world markets by the U.N. embargo of Iraq and Kuwait. ``There isn't any shortage of supply in oil product markets,'' said IEA Executive Director Helga Steeg. Industrial countries will need to draw on a bit less than 1 million barrels of oil a day from commercial reserves after New Year's to keep the figures in balance, the report said. ``Short of any demand restraint and draw of government controlled stocks, the draw of commercial stocks is practically the only possible response left to cope with unforeseen demand surges or supply disruptions,'' it said. The IEA urged members to keep their strategic petroleum reserves as high as possible and warned that the oil market remains vulnerable to disruption. Saudi Arabia, the main staging point for the U.S.-led multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the Gulf, has boosted production to 8 million barrels per day to help make up the shortfall caused by the embargo. The IEA said Saudi Arabia could keep output at that level but probably not increase it much. A spell of cold weather in northern countries this winter could drive up prices.

The stock market was little changed today as traders kept a close watch on oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped .25 to 2,447.77 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers slightly outnumbered losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 756 up, 694 down and 473 unchanged. Analysts said stocks drew some tentative support from a drop in oil prices as the session began. By midafternoon, however, oil had recovered its early losses. In the economic news, the Commerce Department reported that new factory orders rose 0.1 percent in September. Excluding oil, however, the total showed a 1.1 percent decline. On Tuesday the government reported a stronger-than-expected gain in the gross national product, at a 1.8 percent annual rate after adjustment for inflation, in the third quarter of the year. But brokers said that failed to convince most market participants that the business outlook had improved to any significant extent. Among actively traded blue chips, Boeing rose ] to 44~; Philip Morris gained { to 47\; International Business Machines dropped } to 105|, and General Motors was up [ at 36}. GM took an aftertax charge of $2.1 billion in the third quarter for the cost of closing four idle assembly plants, resulting in a $1.98 billion net loss for the period. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .40 to 166.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .58 at 287.49. Volume on the Big Board came to 125.11 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Small Business Optimism Plunges
With AM-Fed Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The small business community's economic mood this year took the steepest drop since the recession year 1982, Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said in an annual survey released Wednesday. The survey of 5,000 small businesses found that 23 percent are pessimistic about their economic prospects over the next 12 to 18 months, rising sharply from 13 percent reporting pessimism in 1989. The survey's finding is significant because the mood index has closely matched shifts in economic growth these past 10 years, marching ``together in virtual lockstep,'' said Patricia W. Hamilton, editor of D&B Reports, Dun & Bradstreet's magazine for small business which conducted the survey. Roughly 68 percent of respondents said inflation would rise in the coming year, while only 3 percent thought it would decline and 17 percent said it would remain about the same. Survey respondents also expressed anxiety over interest rates, with 47 percent predicting that rates would rise in the coming year, and only 9 percent saying they would fall. Chief worries among small businesses were, in order of importance: cash-flow squeeze, controlling costs, finding skilled employees, cost of liability insurance and the prospect of recesssion. The survey showed recession was at the top of the list for small-company owners in troubled New England and worker-hiring problems were the foremost concern for the relatively strong West Coast economy. Despite worries, small business owners and presidents generally continue to be a relatively optimistic group compared with other key economic groups, with 59 percent of respondents calling themselves optimists about the economy, the survey found. That figure, however, was down from 67 percent a year ago. For the second year in a row, health-care costs continued to chill businesses, with four out of five respondents telling the magazine that their costs had increased more than 10 percent in the past year - with some reporting increases of more than 50 percent. The D&B Reports survey, completed Oct. 15, was mailed to presidents and owners of 5,000 randomly selected small businesses with sales under $12 million. Dun & Bradstreet, based in New York, is a leading world marketer of business information and services.

DOC.HEAD: `Chunnel' Breakthrough Will Inspire Investment, Deputy Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: Now that British and French diggers have linked up beneath the English Channel, a project executive said Wednesday he was more confident of raising the billions of dollars needed to finish the rail tunnels. ``People now believe that the tunnel can be done under the channel and the construction risk is perceived as hugely reduced,'' Alastair Morton, deputy chairman of the Anglo-French consortium Eurotunnel PLC, said by telephone. ``Everything is in place now for completion of the project'' in 1993, he said. Diggers working from the English side in one of the three tunnels punched a 2-inch hole through to the French side Tuesday night, three years after work began on the world's largest current civil engineering project. The breakthrough came on the service tunnel, the smallest of three bores, and it will be two months before that tunnel reaches its full 15.7-foot diameter. The first of the two 31-mile rail tunnels between Folkestone and the French port of Calais is expected to be linked up next year. Eurotunnel timed a new share offering, intended to raise $1.03 billion to coincide with the breakthrough, Morton said. The success of the share sale is a condition for the release of an additional $3.9 billion in loans from banks, which already have put up $9.8 billion. Investors already have bought $1.94 billion of Eurotunnel stock. The tunnel now is estimated to cost $14.9 billion, up 57 percent from the initial estimate of $9.4 billion in 1986. Eurotunnel is expected to open in June 1993 and carry passengers, cars and freight between London and Paris in three hours. It expects to carry 28 million passengers in the first year. Morton said he was confident the share sale would succeed even though it was taking place just before the government plans to sell $7.8 billion worth of stock in Britain's electricity industry. The giant stock sales are being launched in a stock market that has been jittery because of the slowing British economy and the Middle East crisis. Many investors have been sitting on the sidelines and trading volume has been low. Morton noted the Eurotunnel sale already has been underwritten by investment firms, and expressed confidence that investors have plenty of cash on hand. The project has no government support, and Eurotunnel has said it doesn't expect to pay dividends for years. However, the stock offering includes inducements such as travel discounts. Confidence in Eurotunnel has been shaken in the past by overruns, cost disputes with contractors and management shakeups. Eurotunnel shares were offered at $6.79 in 1987, and rose as high as $14.22 this year. They fell 6 cents to close at $9.51 on London's Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Bounce Off 3-Month Lows
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed slightly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade after bouncing off three-month lows in trading dominated by grain dealers. Corn and wheat futures retreated. The soybean market opened stronger, then fell as commercial players sold heavily following an unusually large number of delivery notices posted against the November contract. Wednesday was first notice day for the November soybean contract, the first day for traders to indicate their intentions to deliver soybeans to those holding obligations to take delivery. Analysts said speculators absorbed most of the commercial selling, then gladly sold many of those contracts back to the commercial players toward the end of the session to avoid getting stuck with physical deliveries. The commercial buying interest surfaced when the November contract dropped below $5.90 to $5.89 a bushel, its lowest price since Aug. 3. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.61} a bushel; corn was 1} cents lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.29{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent higher with December at $1.21\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2} cents higher with November at $5.92 a bushel.

The stock market turned in a mixed showing today as traders kept a close watch on oil prices. Analysts said stocks drew some tentative support from a drop in oil prices as the session began. By midafternoon, however, oil had recovered its early losses. In the economic news, the Commerce Department reported that new factory orders rose 0.1 percent in September. Excluding oil, however, the total showed a 1.1 percent decline. On Tuesday the government reported a stronger-than-expected gain in the gross national product, at a 1.8 percent annual rate after adjustment for inflation, in the third quarter of the year. But brokers said that failed to convince most market participants that the business outlook had improved to any significant extent.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Postpone Balanced Budget, Again
With AM-Budget Details Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congress and the White House have once again postponed the date by which the federal deficit must be eliminated. But in their latest change in the budget law, they have included something new that is drawing raves from some fiscal experts: tight spending controls. ``We never before have had effective expenditure controls,'' Carol Cox, president of the watchdog Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, said Wednesday. ``That is incredible progress.'' Under the original 1985 version of the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law, the federal shortfall was supposed to be eliminated this year. When the law was changed in 1987, the target date was pushed back to fiscal 1993. Neither goal is attainable. The deficit for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was $220.4 billion, the second highest total ever. This year's gap is projected to exceed $250 billion - a record - even with the giant deficit-reduction bill Congress passed last Saturday. But that same measure contained extensive changes in the budget process that de-emphasizes the law's focus on reaching specified deficit targets. Instead, it groups many kinds of federal spending into three separate categories - domestic, defense, and foreign affairs - and puts a spending cap on each of them. If the cap is exceeded, most programs in that category would be slashed by an amount equal to the excess spending - a powerful incentive to not go beyond the limit. The creation of the three separate categories is important for another reason: it prevents lawmakers from increasing domestic spending by cutting military programs. This satisfies the Bush administration, which has been eager to prevent the Democratic-controlled Congress from slashing the Pentagon's budget so it could beef up social programs. ``They know ... we're not going to cut money in one area and switch it to another,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. The three categories will be combined into one in 1994. Other controls have been put on the fastest-growing category of spending, benefit programs such as Medicare and Social Security. These programs will be allowed to grow with inflation and as the population increases, but any expansion in benefits would have to be balanced by an equal cut somewhere else. Some critics of the new law have argued that it shifts congressional budget power to the White House. That is because the executive branch will have the power to decide which programs are assigned to each spending category, and how deep required spending cuts will have to be. But others argue tat under the old law, the administration already had the final word on how deep spending slashes would have to be if deficits exceeded the ceilings the law set for them. Other changes in the budget law include: - Deficit targets in the old law were fixed. Under the new law, the targets will be adjusted to reflect changes in the economy. Since economic fluctuations have dramatic effects on government tax collections and spending, this makes the target much more attainable. - Some spending, such as Operation Desert Shield and the bailout of the savings and loan industry, will not be counted against the deficit target. Those items were included under the old law. For the first time, emergencies - such as funds to clean up after hurricanes - will also not be counted.

DOC.HEAD: Company Drops 8-Month-Old Runways Magazine
DOC.TEXT: The final issue of Knight-Ridder Inc.'s Runways magazine will be published Monday, ending an eight-month experiment due to a soft advertising market, the publisher said. The magazine was envisioned as a weekly aimed at businesses and workers around major airports. Runways Southern California, the original product, focused on airports from San Diego to Santa Barbara. With circulation of more than 33,000, the magazine drew readers but failed to attract advertising from the aerospace industry, which was cutting back due to military spending cuts. ``We just weren't making it,'' said publisher Larry Birger, a former Miami Herald business section editor. Runways converted to a twice-monthly publication and laid off five employees in July. It expanded its focus to the West Coast in September, forcing it to compete more directly with well-established trade publications. With the magazine's shutdown, 17 staff members will be laid off with eight weeks' severance pay.

DOC.HEAD: Record Auction Announced
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury plans to borrow a quarterly record $34.25 billion from the public next week in a series of debt auctions to replenish the government's coffers, officials said Wednesday. ``We are offering $34.25 billion of notes and bonds to refund $23.5 billion of privately held notes maturing on Nov. 15 and to raise approximately $10.73 billion of cash,'' Assistant Secretary Jay Powell told a news conference. The borrowing would surpass the previous record of $32.25 billion in notes and bonds sold last August. Powell said the auctions next week would include: - $12.5 billion in three-year notes in minimum denominations of $5,000 to be sold on Tuesday. - $11.0 billion in 10-year notes in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be auctioned on Wednesday. - $10.75 billion in 30-year bonds in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be offered on Thursday. In addition, the Treasury will auction on Thursday $12 billion in 161-day cash management bills in minimum denominations of $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Close Higher After Meandering in Confused Market
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rallied late Wednesday to move above $35 per barrel in a third straight erratic trading session that largely ignored news on the Persian Gulf standoff. Light sweet crude oil had been down about $1 per barrel in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but a surge in the afternoon pushed it up by about $2 from the morning lows. Crude settled at $35.23 per barrel, up 69 cents for the day, on contracts for delivery in December. All later contract months closed higher in a market that stayed about as sluggish as the two previous lackluster sessions. ``Compared to normal changes, it's a wimp today,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an oil analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``There hasn't been anything to signal that we're closer to war or peace. It just gets caught in the middle.'' There was no dominant news moving the market, although some of the move down was attributed to conciliatory remarks from Iraq and some of the move up was attributed to war rhetoric from the United States and Britain. Energy analyst Thomas Blakeslee of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., said the late rally came as floor traders who had agreed to sell oil early in the day found they had bet the wrong way as oil refused to drop. They then bought crude-oil contracts to avoid losing more money and the price went up. ``On the close, the market took off,'' Blakeslee said. ``You found locals caught on the wrong side. As it turned positive, locals realized this market had no oomph to the down side.'' Future contracts for refined petroleum products also seemed to fluctuate with little sense of direction. Home heating oil closed 1.63 cents lower at 89.54 cents a gallon on November contracts. January and December contracts fell, but more distant months moved higher for the day. Unleaded gasoline contracts were all higher at the close, with November delivery up 2.71 cents to 96.44 cents a gallon. Natural gas prices were also mixed. December delivery contracts fell 4.8 cents to $2.36 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Machinists Hold Rare Vote; Recommend Rejecting Boeing Drug Plan
DOC.TEXT: Union machinists at The Boeing Co. will cast an unusual mid-contract vote in November on whether to accept the company's new program for dealing with drug and alcohol abuse. Leaders of the Machinists union here recommend their 40,000 members at Boeing vote the proposal down, saying it fosters ``a police-state mentality.'' Machinists' leaders say the plan punishes people seeking treatment for substance abuse. Boeing officials say the union wants too much of a hand in what should be a company-run program. The Machinists struck Boeing last year for 48 days before a new three-year contract was approved Nov. 20. Union officials say there won't be a strike if the plan is rejected, but legal action is possible if Boeing tries to impose it unilaterally. Bob De Lappe, corporate director of personnel, said the vote was the first to be held by Machinists in mid-contract in the 38 years he has been with Boeing. Jack Daniels, spokesman for District Lodge 751 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, said members of the four Seattle-area locals at Boeing would vote at meetings on Thursday and Nov. 7, 8 and 14. Results won't be released until the 15th, he said. Boeing machinists elsewhere, including large contingents in Wichita, Kan., and Portland, Ore., also will vote on the proposal, Daniels said, at meetings scheduled by local lodges. De Lappe said the new policy, which would cover all of Boeing's approximately 150,000 U.S. employees, is ``a total shift from punitive action to rehabilitative action.'' In the past, he said, employees caught with or using drugs on company property were fired. The new plan would offer them a second chance if they agree to undergo treatment. Boeing negotiated with Machinists over the new drug policy in late August, September and early October, Daniels said. It continues to negotiate with the United Auto Workers, which represents production workers at the Boeing Helicopter plant in Philadelphia. The Seattle Professional Engineering Employees Association, which represents Boeing engineers and technicians, has approved the plan. Boeing's new policy comes as the U.S. Department of Transportation is requiring stiffer substance abuse policies, including random drug testing, for some aircraft workers. About 3,100 Boeing workers, including drivers, flight crews, ground-school instructors and employees working on certain aircraft will be subject to the random tests under the federal rules. Boeing also plans testing when there is reasonable suspicion of alcohol or drug possession or use, and after serious accidents or safety violations. Individuals who go through a treatment program also would be subject to tests. Workers who come to Boeing's Employee Assistance Program for help with a drinking or drug problem will be referred to an outside rehabilitation program, De Lappe said. If the testing finds they've been backsliding, they will be given one more chance. People found possessing or under the influence of drugs or alcohol can go through rehabilitation, but won't be given a second chance if they again test positive, De Lappe said. As in the past, anyone caught selling drugs on company property will be fired. Boeing has launched an extensive in-house education campaign about the new policy. It also is training supervisors how to recognize drug and alcohol problems. ``Socially, we think it's the right thing to do,'' De Lappe said. ``We have a major drug problem in the community and we think this may be one way to address it in a positive manner.'' The policy makes financial sense because ``it's cheaper to rehabilitate people than to hire new ones,'' he said. But in a letter to union members, District Lodge 751 President Tom Baker said there aren't enough safeguards in Boeing's plan against arbitrary decisions or harassment. ``The Boeing-proposed program is a company program - by, for, and to the benefit of the company,'' he says. ``It uses a police-state mentality and threats of termination - even against those who voluntarily seek help.''

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Fine Gives Kodak Third Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: A $909.5 million patent infringement judgment against Eastman Kodak Co. resulted in a $206 million third quarter loss for the photographic company. Kodak said Wednesday its earnings would have increased 19 percent for the quarter without the judgment. The loss, which translated to 64 cents per share, compared with earnings of $300 million, or 93 cents per share, in the third quarter of 1989. Without the charge, earnings for the third quarter of 1990 would have been $358 million, or $1.10 per share. Kodak was ordered by a U.S. District Court judge in Boston earlier this month to pay Polaroid $909.5 million in a 14-year-old patent infringement suit over Kodak's sales of instant cameras and film. ``While no money has yet changed hands, and the litigation has yet to be finally resolved, this charge to earnings is appropriate at this time,'' Kodak Chairman Kay Whitmore said in a statement. Sales increased 5 percent for the quarter to $4.77 billion, vs. $4.54 billion in the same quarter last year. ``The results were pretty much in line with expectations,'' said Peter Enderlin, an industry analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``Sales were a little disappointing but the margins were excellent.'' Kodak benefited from a favorable foreign exchange rate and improvements in productivity gains, Enderlin said. The company posted gains in its imaging, chemicals and health segments. The only disappointment was the information segment, which includes Kodak's copier and business operations, where sales dropped 2.9 percent for the quarter. ``I think top management is beginning to lose patience,'' Enderlin said. ``There may be some fairly drastic steps taken with some pieces of that segment if they don't show tangible gains by the middle of next year.'' Earnings for the first three quarters of 1990 were $377 million, or $1.16 per share, down 36 percent from $589 million, or $1.82 per share, in 1989. Without the Polaroid charge, earnings would have been up 60 percent to $941 million. Kodak last showed a loss in the fourth quarter of 1989, when the company took a charge of $273 million to pay for a restructuring program in which 7,500 jobs were cut and about 20 businesses were sold or consolidated. That restructuring was announced following depressed earnings in the first three quarters of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises in NY After Falling Overseas
DOC.TEXT: The dollar advanced against most major foreign currencies in domestic trading Wednesday after generally finishing lower abroad. Gold prices were mixed. Analysts said there was no one force driving the foreign exchange market, but a variety of factors affected the dollar's performance against specific currencies. Mike Faust, a currency analyst with Money Market Services in Chicago, said the dollar gained ground against the German mark on speculation that the Bundesbank, the German central bank, might lower interest rates. Lower interest rates reduce a currency's attractiveness because investments denominated in that currency earn less. The dollar rose to 1.5185 marks in New York from late Tuesday's 1.51485. In earlier European trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5150 marks, down from 1.5190 late Tuesday. The British pound was also shaken by talk of interest rate cuts. Sterling fell to $1.9430 in New York from late Tuesday's $1.9565. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9440, compared with $1.9485 late Tuesday. Faust said the market expected the British government to lower rates by as much as half a percentage point. The dollar had its best showing against the Japanese yen, which was hurt by pessimism over the Persian Gulf crisis. The Japanese economy is seen as particularly vulnerable should there be a disruption of energy supplies from the Middle East, as the country imports 99 percent of its crude oil. In New York, the dollar rose to 130.105 yen from 128.725 yen late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 129.35 yen, up 0.35 yen from Tuesday's finish, and in London, it was quoted at 129.90 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.2865 Swiss francs, up from 1.2825; 5.0855 French francs, up from 5.0695; 1,138.00 Italian lire, up from 1,134.25; and 1.16675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16775. Other European dollar rates, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.2850 Swiss francs, down from 1.2890; 5.0725 French francs, down from 5.0845; 1.7070 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7120; 1,135.50 Italian lire, down from 1,137.75; and 1.1669 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1668 Gold fell 30 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $379.40 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $379.30 a troy ounce, up 80 cents from Tuesday. Gold traded in London at $379.75 bid per troy ounce, up from $375.50 Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $379.25, up from $373.40 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $4.96 an ounce to close at $379.61. Silver fell in New York, dropping 6.4 cents to close at $4.153 on the Commodity Exchange. Earlier, silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.22 a troy ounce, up from Tuesday's $4.16.

DOC.HEAD: Houses Become More Affordable In September
DOC.TEXT: Rising incomes and declining home prices boosted the typical American family's ability to buy an existing house in September to its highest level in nearly two years, a real estate trade group said Wednesday. The National Association of Realtors said its housing affordability index rose to 110.9 in September from 107.5 in August. That meant a family with a median income of $35,239 had 110.9 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing to buy a median-priced home costing $94,300. The median income was $35,125 in August, while the median price of a home was $97,100, the Realtors said. The index was at its highest level since a 111.2 reading in December 1988. The median means half of the families earn more and half less, or that half of the houses sell for more and half for less. ``A decline in the median home price in September had the biggest positive impact on the index reading last month,'' Realtors President Norman D. Flynn said. ``However, the decline failed to bring more buyers into the market, as evidenced by an 8 percent drop in existing-home sales last month.'' The interest rate used to compute the affordability index is a composite of closing rates for both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages on existing homes as reported by the Federal Housing Finance Board. It rose from 9.98 percent in August to 10.00 percent in September. Changes in the median home price, median family income and average mortgage rate resulted in a $19 decrease in the monthly mortgage payment to $662 in September.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Bounce Off 3-Month Lows
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rebounded from three-month lows Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade in what amounted to a market maneuver by grain dealers to transfer some of their storage costs to speculators. On other commodity markets, corn and soybean futures retreated; oil futures were mixed; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures rose. Soybean futures settled { cent lower to 2\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in November at $5.92 a bushel. The November contract fell as low as $5.89 a bushel, its lowest level since Aug. 3, before bouncing back late in the session. Analysts said commercial players profited from the day's action, which began with an unusually large number of delivery notices posted against the November contract. Wednesday was first notice day, or the first day for players holding ``short'' positions in the November contract to indicate to the exchange their intention to settle those sale agreements through physical delivery of soybeans rather than by taking offsetting market positions. On the Board of Trade, traders post delivery notices by handing over to the exchange clearinghouse their receipts for soybeans stored in exchange-approved warehouses. As the receipts come in, the clearinghouse matches them with traders holding obligations to buy soybeans, beginning with the oldest ``long'' position. The holder of a receipt is considered the owner of the soybeans and is obliged to pay the storage costs. Analysts said virtually all of Wednesday's delivery notices were posted by commercial grain dealers and most of the receipts were transferred to speculators, most of whom have no interest in owning soybeans. The speculators overwhelmingly refused delivery by selling November futures contracts to offset their market positions. The buyers of those contracts, late in the session, were mainly the commercial players who posted the delivery notices, analysts said. Meanwhile, the warehouse receipts bounced from speculator to speculator and will eventually find their way back to the commercial participants. Thus, many commercials were able to temporarily avoid storage costs for soybeans. The most successful commercials also managed to effectively sell soybeans, then buy them back at a lower price. ``It was just like a gravy train,'' said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 2\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.62 a bushel; corn was 1} cents lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.29\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent higher with December at $1.21\ a bushel. Crude oil prices rallied above $35 a barrel late in the session on the New York Mercantile Exchange in a third straight day of erratic trading that largely ignored news on the Persian Gulf standoff. Light sweet crude oil settled 64 cents to 69 cents higher with December at $35.23 a barrel; heating oil was 1.63 cents lower to .03 cent higher with November at 89.54 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.2 cents to 2.71 cents higher with November at 96.44 cents a gallon. The gold and silver markets ignored the oil rally and closed lower on New York's Commodity Exchange. Platinum futures rose slightly on the New York Mercantile Exchange, extending Tuesday's powerful gains. Gold finished 40 cents lower across the board with December at $381.30 a troy ounce; silver was 6.3 cents to 6.5 cents lower with November at $4.153 a troy ounce; platinum settled $1.40 higher across the board with January at $438.40 a troy ounce. Higher cash cattle prices boosted cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork prices firmed amid expectations that cash markets will strengthen soon. Live cattle settled .10 cent to .45 cent higher with December at 77.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent to .68 cent higher with November at 87.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent lower to .40 cent higher with December at 51.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to .95 cent higher with February at 61.25 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Wendy's Profits Up 45 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Wendy's International Inc. profits increased by 45 percent for the third quarter, partly because of improved company operations, menu additions and advertising featuring founder David Thomas, the fast-food company said Wednesday. Earnings for the quarter ending Sept. 30 totaled $12.7 million, or 13 cents per share, vs. $8.7 million, or 9 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenues for the quarter totaled $257.5 million, compared with $269.2 million a year ago. The company said Wendy's had 74 fewer company-operated restaurants than last year. Most were sold to franchise owners. James W. Near, chief executive officer, president and chief operating officer, said the improved performance was partly the result of ``healthy new choices'' on the menu, such as a grilled chicken sandwich. He also noted that the restaurants converted to french fries cooked in all-vegetable oil instead of animal oil. He said nationwide television advertising featuring Thomas lifted awareness of Wendy's to the highest level in four years. There were 3,726 Wendy's Old Fashioned Hamburgers restaurants worldwide at the end of the quarter, including 1,069 operated by the company. For the nine months, Wendy's earned $31.52 million or 33 cents a share, vs. $24.67 million or 26 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues totaled $761.35 million vs. $808.59 million.

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims Milken Guilty of Additional Crimes
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK (AP)- In a final bid to persuade a judge to give Michael Milken a long prison term, prosecutors claimed Thursday the junk-bond financier committed ``serious'' crimes beyond those he has admitted. The government said in a closing statement that it ``conclusively'' proved at a special hearing that Milken broke the law during three transactions, despite scant hard evidence presented in testimony. On Wednesday, the defense said the government had failed to prove its case and that Milken should be sentenced only on the six felony counts to which he pleaded guilty in April. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood has not yet set a sentencing date, but it is expected to take place next week. Milken faces a maximum 28 years in prison. He already has agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. In its 40-page memorandum, prosecutors maintained that evidence presented at the eight-day hearing ``establishes that Michael Milken committed serious crimes in addition to his admitted crimes.'' It said the evidence also ``strongly refutes Milken's claims that his crimes were isolated, largely motiveless and committed reluctantly and at the behest of others.'' As in earlier court papers, the government claimed Milken directed a crime spree to consolidate his market power and for his personal gain. The judge will weigh the closing arguments along with the testimony and evidence presented at the hearing, which she called to gain insight into Milken's professional character. Despite the government's strong language, testimony appeared to fall short of clearly linking Milken to allegations of stock manipulation in Wickes Cos., bribery and misappropriation of Storer Communications Inc. securities and insider trading in Caesars World Inc. It did offer suggestions that Milken's criminal behavior may have extended beyond the narrow charges to which he pleaded guilty. Testimony also presented vivid descriptions of shady behavior by underlings at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield bond department. Milken had been the main target of the government's Wall Street probe from 1986, when he was named by inside trader Ivan Boesky. On Wickes, the government said ``the record is crystal clear'' that Milken ordered the company's stock manipulated upward in concert with Boesky. A former Milken subordinate testified that Milken shouted out a closing stock price, which he said amounted to a call to manipulate the shares. No witness, though, said Milken directly ordered the manipulation and the defense claimed the main witness lied. The government based its argument partly on an assertion that Milken alone had the authority to use the Boesky organization for illegal purposes. Several of the charges in Milken's guilty plea involved lawbreaking with Boesky. The government also said Milken illegally offered gratuities to favored clients and hoarded lucrative securities in a 1985 takeover of Storer. It also said Milken deceived a major client and violated Drexel policy in the deal. On insider trading, prosecutors said Milken knew Drexel's plans to advise Caesars about a debt restructuring when he ordered traders to buy the casino company's bonds in 1983. Testimony was contradictory and did not establish a firm Milken tie. The government said Milken personally made $553,000 from the insider trading, and that Drexel and a major client made additional illegal profits. Finally, the government memo said that suggestive testimony about possible obstruction of justice by Milken should be considered as evidence of ``the pervasiveness of Milken's criminal conduct.'' At the hearing, witnesses described secret bathroom meetings and hints to destroy evidence. The defense said Milken did not directly order any Drexel employee to destroy papers, give false testimony or obstruct investigators.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Organization Says It Doesn't Know If It Will Make Interest Payment
DOC.TEXT: Developer Donald Trump raised new doubts about his financial stability Wednesday by telling the American Stock Exchange it was unclear whether he would make a big interest payment on Taj Mahal casino bonds next month. Bob Shabazian, an exchange spokesman, said the Trump Organization made the statement in response to a question from the exchange, where the bonds are traded. Shabazian said Trump didn't say whether the payment would be made or not. The spokesman said the exchange routinely asks companies before their interest payments are due if they will meet their obligations. The Trump Organization is supposed to pay $47 million in interest on $675 million in Taj bonds Nov. 15. Stephen Bollenbach, the Trump Organization's chief financial officer, was not in his office when a reporter called for comment late Wednesday. The American Stock Exchange halted trading in the bonds Wednesday while it made the request of Trump. Shabazian said activity in the securities would resume Thursday, but he said they would be trading on a flat basis, meaning they would no longer accrue interest. The development signaled new investor skepticism about Trump, who has been juggling his massive debt problems for months and has been intensely negotiating with bondholders on a restructuring of debts on the Taj Mahal, the glitziest of his three Atlantic City casinos. Earlier this month, Trump unveiled a restructuring proposal, and warned bondholders that the Taj Mahal might be forced into bankruptcy court if the plan is turned down. The restructuring would give bondholders a nearly 20 percent equity stake in the billion-dollar Taj Mahal in return for changes in the terms of the junk bonds. The plan called for the interest rate on the bonds to be lowered to 9 percent from their current 14 percent. It also calls for the Nov. 15 payment to be met by issuing additional bonds. Some future interest payments would also be made with new bonds, and the maturities of some issues would be extended under the plan. Wilbur Ross, a bondholder representative, rejected the plan, saying the 19.9 equity stake was too low. Ross represents 10 institutions that hold about one-third of the Taj Mahal bonds. The Taj Mahal opened earlier this year but like other Atlantic City casinos has been struggling in an uncertain economy. Trump has been forced to negotiate with bondholders because his three casinos - which also include Trump Castle and Trump Plaza - have been unable to generate enough cash to pay all their bills. Earlier this year, the developer negotiated a $65 million bank bailout that was supposed to give him breathing room to repay his loans, which together are believed to total more than $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Largest-Ever Cotton Sale Already Affecting Market
DOC.TEXT: A cotton sale billed as the largest ever comes at a time when cotton supplies worldwide already are tight, industry observers said Wednesday. The sale of 500,000 bales to China was announced Tuesday by Dunavant Enterprises Inc. of Memphis. The U.S. cotton industry expects total sales of 15 million bales between Aug. 1, 1990, and July 1991. Of that total, sales abroad are projected at 6.8 million bales. The Dunavant sale is the largest single cotton deal on record, topping a 1984 sale when China bought 484,000 bales from Cargill Inc., according to the National Cotton Council. The Dunavant sale, expected to be worth $200 million, was negotiated over the past several weeks by representatives of Dunavant Enterprises and Chinatex Cotton Import & Export Corp. of Beijing. Even before the sale was finished, the U.S. cotton market was reacting to speculation of a major deal in the works, said Dean Ethridge, a vice president of Sparks Commodities Inc. of Memphis. ``This has been talked about for weeks. I think to the extent that anyone is surprised, it is to the size of the sale,'' he said. Cotton prices on spot and futures markets hovered around 75 cents a pound in the days just prior to the sale. Prices were under 72 a pound on Oct. 1. The Dunavant deal will add to market pressures expected to keep cotton prices strong for the next nine months, Ethridge said.

DOC.HEAD: On Eve of Senate Hearing, Price Goes Up For Oil Speculators
DOC.TEXT: The New York Mercantile Exchange announced steps Wednesday that likely will drive out some oil speculators, on the eve of a Senate inquiry into what critics have called reckless gambling on oil in the futures market. Thehange, one of the world's key markets for petroleum, said it would raise the amount of cash that must be put up by people who buy and sell contracts for future delivery of crude oil, heating oil and unleaded gasoline. Players in the market will have to put up two to three times as much money as they did before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices skyrocketing. ``Basically, what that does is it takes a certain percentage of speculators out of the market,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``The higher the margin, the more costly it is for a speculator to be involved.'' The move came just before a Senate Governmental Affairs Committee hearing Thursday that will explore oil trading on the Mercantile Exchange. The hearing was organized by Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman, D-Conn., who has called oil traders ``speculator sharks'' and urged that they be required to put up more money. Mercantile Exchange President R. Patrick Thompson said Wednesday evening that the exchange's move has nothing to do with Lieberman's inquiry and is not intended to drive away speculators. Thompson said there is little speculation taking place on the futures market, with minimal effect on oil prices. He cited an exchange study, also released Wednesday, that indicates more than 90 percent of trading on the exchange is done by participants in the oil industry, who conceivably have oil production or oil purchases that can be ``hedged'' against price fluctuations by futures trading. Thompson said the exchange was raising its margins in order to ensure participants will be able to pay cash to meet their obligations, and that the higher margins were needed because of increased volatility in recent days. ``In order to protect the financial integrity of the contracts, it's appropriate to raise margins,'' Thompson said in a telephone interview. Lieberman did not accept everything the exchange had to say. ``The timing is too coincidental for me not to feel some satisfaction that we've influenced them,'' the senator said from Washington. ``It does confirm the fears that I've expressed over the last month or more that there was an irresistible temptation to participate in a market which was rising as fast as the oil futures market has been, when you could become a player with so little money on the table.'' The exchange's higher margins will take place in two steps after the trading sessions on Friday and Tuesday. After the end of the trading day Tuesday, customers who buy a contract for 1,000 barrels of crude oil for next month delivery will have to put up $12,000, or $14,000 during the last six days in which that contract is traded. At current oil prices, that means a player would have to put up a little less than a third of the contact's value. ``It remains to be seen whether that's adequate,'' Lieberman said. The senator also questioned the Mercantile Exchange's method of determining how much oil speculation is taking place. The exchange's numbers consider a market participant to be a non-speculator if he or she is connected with the oil industry. The only oil deals that are taken into account are those that are left ``open'' overnight, which would exclude any trades made by people who get in and out of the market in the same day. ``A lot of those that I would consider speculators are closing their interest by the end of the day and are therefore not being counted,'' Lieberman said. ``My concern is that the numbers as they've given them to me underestimate the amount of speculation.'' Thompson was to appear at Lieberman's hearing to present the Mercantile Exchange's side. Another of Lieberman's witnesses, a former stockbroker who now works as a financial consultant, planned to paint a darker view of the oil trading industry. Oil futures prices can be manipulated by traders spreading rumors, and the eventual effects can be devastating to the economy, the witness, Rande Leonard of Phoenix, said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ``The implications are too great to have some jokers messing around, just jacking up this commodity,'' he said. ``If they want to do this to something, let them do it in pork bellies, orange juice, cocoa.''

DOC.HEAD: NJ Company Acquires 8.2 Percent Stake in Zenith
DOC.TEXT: NYCOR Inc., a Basking Ridge, N.J. company disclosed on Wednesday it has acquired an 8.2 percent stake in the stock of Zenith Electronics Corp. and may seek more. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, NYCOR said it spent $10.8 million to acquire 2.2 million Zenith shares between Aug. 30 and Tuesday as an investment. NYCOR, which used to manufacture rotary compressors and automotive components, sold those operations in 1989 and this past April and now is ``principally engaged in a search for businesses to acquire'' using the proceeds from the sale of the earlier businesses, according to the filing. NYCOR said it will review its investment in Zenith and might consider direct capital investment, seeking representation on the board or even acquiring control. NYCOR said it also might sell off all or some of its holding in the Glenview, Ill.-based manufacturer of televisions, video cassette recorders and other electronic products.

DOC.HEAD: US, Panama Negotiate Bank Account Disclosure Deal
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Panama opened negotiations Wednesday on a banking disclosure proposal that businessmen say would destroy the country's bank secrecy and hurt its overseas banking business. The proposed legal assistance agreement covers investigation, prosecution and prevention of crimes in general but its main target is the laundering of drug money in Panama's international banking center. Panama allows banks to disclose information on accounts only when a crime that is covered by Panamanian law is being prosecuted in this country. The United States is proposing disclosure of all information about transactions worth more than $10,000 when there is an investigation into a ``crime or violation of laws of the side requiring the information,'' according to a draft of the proposal obtained by The Associated Press. Private banking and business organizations immediately stated their opposition. The Banking Association, a private organization of nearly 100 banks, warned in that any such agreement must ``not place the country or the International Banking Center of Panama in a disadvantageous situation against countries with service economies and similar banking centers.'' The association said an agreement should be applied only when laws of both countries are violated and not apply to violations of tax or foreign exchange laws. Signing the agreement, ``far from solving our problems, worsens them,'' the Association of Panamanian Business Executives said. ``By pretending to give the Justice Department of the United States indiscriminate access to any bank account, without regard for the honorability of the account holder, would destroy the confidentiality and the possible exodus of a large amount of depositors would begin,'' the businessmen said. ``This would endanger many jobs. This cost would not be offset by the economic assistance that the United States has conditioned to the signing of this agreement.'' Part of the $420 million in U.S. aid approved for Panama after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that overthrew dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega was conditioned on the signing of a legal assistance agreement. Noriega is jailed in Florida, awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges.

DOC.HEAD: Savings & Loan Group Ditches Vegas for Disney
DOC.TEXT: Realizing they have a bit of an image problem, planners of a savings and loan industry conference discreetly moved it from the gaming mecca of Las Vegas to the wholesome home of Mickey Mouse. The meeting of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions will bring about 400 people to Orlando. Most will stay at a Walt Disney World hotel. ``I think the reason is obvious'' why Orlando became the new site, Jim Grohl, a spokesman for the association in Washington, said Wednesday. Officials decided Las Vegas was inappropriate for an industry embroiled in controversy stemming in part from some wild lending risks, he said. The league represents solvent S&Ls, but the entire industry has suffered a black eye from the abuses of some thrifts.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Earnings Down 78 Percent, National Steel Down 9.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp.'s profits dropped 78 percent in the third quarter and National Stee Corp. saw a 9.5 percent dip, the companies reported Wednesday. Bethlehem cited lower prices, fewer shipments and higher operating costs. National, based in Pittsburgh, said its drop was partly due to reduced demand for its more profitable products.

For the quarter, Bethlehem Steel reported net income of $10.1 million, or 5 cents a share, on sales of $1.21 billion. In the same period last year, the company had profit of $46.9 million, or 54 cents a share, on sales of $1.27 billion. The Bethlehem, Pa.-based company said orders have slowed, but that the amount of orders in the third quarter was relatively strong. The company said shipments should increase slightly in the fourth quarter and said price increases take effect in the first quarter of 1991. Bethlehem Steel's net income for the first nine months of 1990 was $53 million, or 46 cents per share, on sales of $3.7 billion. In the same period last year earnings were $196 million, or $2.35 cents per share, on sales of $4.1 billion.

For the three months ended Sept. 30, profits totaled $11.4 million, compared with $12.6 million in the corresponding period of 1989. Sales increased 4 percent to $633.8 million from $609.1 million. Kokichi Hagiwara, National Steel's chairman and chief executive, said unscheduled equipment outages and sales of a greater percentage of less profitable products were factors in his company's ``somewhat disappointing'' third-quarter performance. For the first nine months of the year, net income fell 62.9 percent to $20.3 million from $54.8 million in the same period last year. Sales were about even at $1.9 billion. Earnings in the nine-month period included credits of $2.7 million, compared with $15 million in the same period of 1989. NKK Corp., the Tokyo-based iron and steel giant, owns 70 percent of National, which is not traded publicly. National Intergroup owns the remaining 30 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Travelers Reports $499 Loss in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Travelers Corp. Wednesday reported a third-quarter net loss of $499 million, citing its move earlier this month to add $650 million to reserves to cover expected real estate losses. The loss, which amounts to $4.93 a share, came on premiums of $1.808 billion. That compares with net income of $94 million, or 89 cents a share, on premiums of $1.866 billion for the third quarter of 1989. Travelers forecast a $500 million third-quarter loss on Oct. 5, when it announced it would add to its reserves for expected losses in mortgage loans and real estate investments. The company said that excluding the impact of the reserve addition, third quarter net income was up 47 percent from a year earlier. Edward H. Budd, chairman and chief executive, said the sharp decline in the commercial real estate market prompted the company's decision to add to reserves. Budd said despite the third-quarter loss, Travelers is performing well in its core businesses, including managed care, employee benefits and property-casualty. Budd said since the beginning of the year, Travelers' managed care and employee benefits operations have posted a record $1.3 billion in new business. For the first nine months of 1990, the company reported a net loss of $306 million, or $3.08 a share, on premiums of $5.808 billion. In the first nine months of 1989, the company reoprted a net income of $306.1 million, $2.95 per share, on premiums of $5.898 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Fontana Herald-News to Close Because of Continued Losses
DOC.TEXT: The Fontana Herald-News will close after 67 years of publication because of declining circulation and continued financial losses, the owners announced Wednesday. The afternoon newspaper will publish its final edition Nov. 9, said Jon Hays, assistant general manager of The Press-Enterprise Co. of Riverside, which bought The Herald-News in June 1989. The newspaper, published Monday through Friday, has a paid circulation of about 2,100. It served the central San Bernardino Valley since 1923. ``When we bought it, it was a paper in distress, and we thought we could resurrect it,'' Hays said. ``The downturn in the economy has made us decide we have tried enough. We're not willing to sustain the losses any longer.'' Hays said the newspaper lost a ``considerable amount of money,'' but declined to provide exact figures. He said some of the newspaper's 24 employees would be hired by The Press-Enterprise, but most would be laid off.

DOC.HEAD: New Haven Register Names New CEO
DOC.TEXT: William J. Rush, publisher and editor-in-chief of The Morning Journal in Lorain, Ohio, was named chief executive of the New Haven Register Wednesday, the papers' parent company announced. Rush, 53, led The Morning Journal's move from an afternoon to a morning publication and coordinated a $6.5 million building expansion and press installation. The Morning Journal and the New Haven Register are both owned by Princeton, N.J.-based Journal Register Co., which is a holding company of the New York investment firm E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Co. The investment firm acquired publisher Ralph Ingersoll II's American newspapers in July. Rush replaces Thomas P. Geyer, who was dismissed Oct. 15 in a disagreement with the Register's new owners over the need for more layoffs. The Register laid off 19 employees at the beginning of this month and 30 more a day after Geyer's departure. Twenty of the positions were in the news department. Rush, who was introduced Wednesday to Register employees, said his first priority will be to ``make sure the paper fulfills its commitment to the community while being financially responsible.'' Rush spent 11 years in editorial and advertising management positions in New England and Ohio before joining Horvitz Newspapers in 1969 as assistant to Harry R. Horvitz, the chief executive officer. He subsequently served as chief executive at The News-Herald in Lake County, Ohio, the News Journal in Mansfield, Ohio, The Record in Troy, N.Y., and The Tribune Chronicle in Warren, Ohio. A native of Alliance, Ohio, Rush is a 1958 graduate of Ohio State University's School of Journalism.
